(b)  In the event of a national, state or local emergency requiring the immediate action(s) of the village manager or the village manager pro tem, and the village manager or the village manager pro tem is incapacitated or otherwise unable to take such necessary action(s), then the following persons shall, during a time of emergency, assume the duties and powers of the village manager as set forth in Section 2.21.060 of this chapter, pursuant to the following order of succession: 
(1)  The village manager shall retain his or her powers during a civil emergency, as that term is defined by Section 8.50.010 of this code, unless he or she is incapacitated or otherwise unavailable. 
(2)  If the village manager is incapacitated or otherwise unavailable to act then an acting village manager shall be appointed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(3)  If the village manager and/or board of trustees is unable to appoint an acting village manager pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, then the president, if capable and available, shall appoint a qualified person to act as acting village manager. 
    The residency requirement for the position of village manager, set forth in subsection (a) of this section, shall be suspended during times of emergency. If any person becomes capable or available after being incapacitated or unavailable, that person shall immediately assume or resume the duties and powers of the village manager and replace any persons acting as village manager that may have succeeded them pursuant to the order of succession set forth in this subsection. 
(Ord. 4071 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.21.030 - Tenure of office. 
    The village manager shall serve at the discretion of the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.21.040 - Bond and oath. 
    The village manager shall furnish a surety bond in such amount and form as is approved by the board, the bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. Before entering upon the duties of his office, the village manager shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by the statutes of the state of Illinois, and file an affidavit and disclosure statement as prescribed by the village ordinance. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.21.050 - Compensation. 
    The village manager shall receive compensation in the amount and manner as the board shall determine. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.21.060 - Powers and duties. 
    The village manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the village and shall be responsible for the management and operation of all the affairs and departments of the village. As such administrative officer he shall have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to the operation and maintenance of the properties of the village and of all the departments of the village. 
    Specifically, but not in limitation of the above, the village manager shall: 
(1)  Hire, suspend or remove employees, as set forth in the personnel policy manual; 
(2)  Cause to be purchased all materials, supplies, and equipment for which funds have been provided in the budget; 
(3)  Routinely attend all official meetings, of the board of trustees and such other meetings as the board may require and attend and participate in all committee meetings, meetings of task forces, workshops, and meetings of the boards and commissions. The village manager shall have the privilege of taking part in discussion of all matters coming before the board and shall make recommendation on all matters under his purview. He may be excused from a meeting of the board whenever the board deems it necessary; 
(4)  Investigate all complaints in regard to administration, operation and activities; 
(5)  Keep the village board currently informed on matters of policy and legislation that relates to board responsibility; 
(6)  Be responsible for the preparation of the annual budget; 
(7)  Consolidate, combine, or reorganize positions, divisions, or units of departments under his jurisdiction consistent with other ordinances of the village; 
(8)  Cause to be prepared and present to the corporate authorities financial statements which shall show, according to accepted accounting practices, the financial state of the village; 
(9)  Have power to issue on behalf of the board all licenses and permits not otherwise provided by ordinance or statute; 
(10)  Devote his entire working time to the discharge of official duties; 
(11)  Not participate in any local political activities; 
(12)  Perform other duties as may be required of him by the board consistent with the ordinances and statutes of the state of Illinois; 
(13)  Keep himself advised on all public improvements within the village; 
(14)  Be responsible for the preparation of all agendas for board meetings, with the advice of staff; 
(15)  Have the authority to bind the village to indemnification obligations required under contracts that require payment from the village of under twenty thousand dollars. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4755, § A, 2-4-2013) 
Chapter 2.22 - VILLAGE ATTORNEY-PROSECUTOR 

2.22.010 - Creation of positions. 
    There is created positions of village attorney and village prosecutor who shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.22.020 - Suits and actions. 
    The village attorney shall prosecute or defend all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village or its officers or employees in their official capacity may be a party, or in which the village may be interested, as directed by the village manager. The manager may direct the village attorney to defend former officers and employees in civil actions arising out of their performance or nonperformance of official duties. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.22.030 - Advice. 
    The village attorney shall be the legal advisor to the village and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting the village whenever requested to do so by the village manager. Upon requests by the village manager, he shall reduce any such opinion to writing. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.22.040 - Additional counsel. 
    Additional counsel may be hired by the corporate authorities or by the village manager with the advice and consent of the corporate authorities to assist the village attorney on special matters or on an as-needed basis. 
(Ord. 3558, § A, 2001: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.22.050 - Duties. 
    The duties of the village attorney and village prosecutor shall be set forth in a job description or agreement which shall be approved by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.22.060 - Authority to prosecute various driving related offenses. 
    The village attorney and village prosecutor are hereby granted the authority to prosecute offenses for misdemeanor driving without a license under the Illinois Vehicle Code at 625 ILCS 5/6-101 and 625 ILCS 5/6-303 in circuit court as petty offenses, at their discretion. 
(Ord. No. 5102, § A, 8-7-2017) 
Chapter 2.23 - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section B of Ord. No. 4592, adopted March 21, 2011, amended Ch. 2.23, Department of Finance and Administrative Services, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 2.23 derived from Ord. No. 1698, adopted in 1980; Ord. No. 2241, adopted in 1986; and Ord. No. 3657, adopted in 2002. 

2.23.010 - Establishment. 
    There is created the department of finance. This department shall consist of the director of finance and such other employees as may be provided for by the annual budget. 
(Ord. No. 4592, § B, 3-21-2011) 
2.23.020 - Director of finance-Personnel of the department. 
    There is established the position of director of finance who shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. The village manager shall appoint and remove all personnel of the department. The village manager shall serve ex officio as director of finance whenever that position is vacant. The director of finance shall act as village collector and treasurer and shall exercise and perform all duties and be subject to all the requirements and obligations pertaining to such offices. 
(Ord. No. 4592, § B, 3-21-2011) 
2.23.030 - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The director of finance shall be charged with preparing and maintaining all financial records of the village. He shall exercise and perform such further duties relating to village finance, accounting, office management, payroll, personnel, and purchasing as may be delegated to him by the village manager. 
(b)  The director of finance shall keep accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of the village, including the current and anticipated revenues and expenses of all municipal funds and accounts. 
(Ord. No. 4592, § B, 3-21-2011) 
2.23.040 - Municipal budget officer. 
(a)  The director of finance shall serve as budget officer at the pleasure of the village manager. His duties shall be to compile a budget, which budget shall contain estimates of revenues available to the municipality for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended expenditures for the municipality and all of the municipality's departments, commissions and boards. 
(b)  The budget officer shall give a bond, before entering upon the duties of office, in the sum required by the board of trustees, but such amount shall not be less than the required amount by statute. This bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of duties by the budget officer and shall be conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty by the budget officer. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. 
(Ord. No. 4592, § B, 3-21-2011) 
2.23.045 - Budget procedures. 
(a)  The budget shall be itemized in a manner consistent with a chart of accounts as may now or in the future be approved by the auditor of public accounts of the state of Illinois. 
(b)  The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the two years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. So far as is possible, the fiscal years shall be itemized in a form consistent with the chart of accounts approved by the auditor of public accounts for the state of Illinois. 
(c)  Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made. 
(d)  The annual budget shall contain money set aside for contingency purposes not to exceed ten percent of the total budget, which monies may be expended for contingencies upon a majority vote of the corporate authorities then holding office. 
(e)  Three percent of equalized assessed value of property subject to taxation by the municipality may be accumulated in a separate fund for the purpose or purposes of specific capital improvements, repairs, and/or replacements of specific types of municipal equipment or other tangible property to be designated as the "capital improvements, repair or replacement fund." 
(f)  Expenditures from the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which the capital improvement, repair or replacement will occur. 
(g)  Upon the completion or abandonment of any object for which the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund, or should any surplus monies remain after the completion or abandonment of any object for which the capital improvement, repair or replacement fund was inaugurated, then such funds no longer necessary for capital improvement, repair or replacement shall be transferred into the general corporate fund of the municipality on the first day of the fiscal year following such abandonment, completion, or discovery of surplus funds. 
(h)  The president and board of trustees shall make the annual budget conveniently available to public inspection for at least ten days prior to the passage of the annual budget, by publication in the journal of proceedings of the president and board of trustees or in such other form as they may prescribe. Not less than one week after the publication of the annual budget, and prior to final action on the budget, the president and board of trustees shall hold at least one public hearing on the annual budget. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the municipality at least one week prior to the time of hearing. 
(i)  The president and board of trustees hereby delegates authority to the village manager or his designee, to delete, add, change or create line item accounts and other subclasses within divisions or departments and divisions and departments themselves, and to transfer previously budgeted amounts between line item accounts, divisions and departments within the same fund. In no case shall the approved budget be increased or decreased without board approval. 
(j)  By a vote of two-thirds of the members of the corporate authorities, the annual budget may be revised by deleting, adding to, or changing line item accounts within divisions or departments and divisions and departments themselves. 
(k)  No revision of the budget shall be made increasing the budget in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the revision. 
(Ord. No. 4592, § B, 3-21-2011) 
2.23.050 - Expenditures. 
(a)  The director of finance shall prepare a warrant on the village treasury for the payment of all sums due from the village. No item can be included in such warrant unless it has been authorized and approved by the corporate authorities in the fiscal budget. 
(b)  Items and services under contract can be paid pursuant to the document; however, the corporate authorities will at all times be kept aware of such expenditures by an appropriate means. 
(c)  It is the intent of this chapter to provide for the proper conduct of the finances of the villages. Changes in procedure or in the presentation of financial information to the corporate authorities can be amended by the corporate authorities by appropriate resolution. 
(Ord. No. 4592, § B, 3-21-2011) 
2.23.060 - Revenues. 
(a)  The director of finance shall receive and collect all license fees, permit fees, charges for municipal utility services, charges for the use of village or special services rendered by the villages, sums due the village on any contract, and all other sums due. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the director of finance, through the village manager, to the keep the president and board of trustees informed as to all sums due on taxes, accumulations in the motor fuel account to the credit of the village, and all other revenues to which the village is entitled. 
(Ord. No. 4592, § B, 3-21-2011) 
Chapter 2.25 - PURCHASES, CONTRACTS AND BIDDING PROCEDURES* 

2.25.020 - Responsibilities. 
    All purchases and contracts for materials, supplies, equipment and services required by any department or organizational unit of the village shall be performed under the authority of the village manager or his authorized representative. Any deviations from this authorization shall be approved by the village manager. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.030 - Purchases of five thousand dollars and under. 
    The village manager is hereby authorized to make purchases or authorize purchases to be made whose total actual or estimated costs do not exceed five thousand dollars; provided that the funds are provided for within the annual budget, and provided, further, that such purchases are made in accordance with the rules and procedures provided for by this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.040 - Purchases in excess of five thousand dollars but under twenty-five thousand dollars. 
    The village manager is authorized to make purchases or to authorize purchases or contracts, including settlements of pending claims, to be made whose total or actual estimated costs will be greater than five thousand dollars but less than twenty-five thousand dollars; provided, that (a) where possible at least three written quotations are obtained prior to awarding the purchase to the best qualified vendor, (b) the funds are provided for within the annual budget. The provisions of this section shall not apply to purchases or contracts as set forth in Section 2.25.150 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 4048 § A (part), 2006: Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
(Ord. No. 4428, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 4962, § A, 11-23-2015; Ord. No. 5260, § C, 5-20-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5260, § C, adopted May 20, 2019, changed the title of § 2.25.040 from "Purchases in excess of five thousand dollars but under twenty thousand dollars" to read as herein set out. 
2.25.050 - Purchases in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars. 
(a)  All purchased or contracts covered by this Chapter whose estimated costs exceed twenty-five thousand dollars shall be submitted to the president and board of trustees for approval prior to purchase or contract. 
(b)  Except for the purchases or contracts set forth in Section 2.25.150 of this Chapter, all purchases or contracts whose estimated costs exceed twenty-five thousand dollars shall be based upon written specifications and awarded in the following manner: 
i.  By written contract let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising for sealed bids; or 
ii.  In any manner authorized by resolution of the president and board of trustees; or 
iii.  In any manner authorized by statute or ordinance. 
(Ord. 4048 § A (part), 2006: Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
(Ord. No. 5260, § C, 5-20-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5260, § C, adopted May 20, 2019, changed the title of § 2.25.050 from "Purchases in excess of twenty thousand dollars" to read as herein set out. 
2.25.060 - Local preference in purchasing. 
(a)  Any purchase or contract to be made with entirely village funds may be awarded to the lowest written quoted price or lowest evaluated bid price from a responsive and responsible local vendor provided that the local vendor's quote or bid is no higher than the lowest responsive and responsible non-local vendor by more than two percent or two thousand dollars, whichever is less. 
(b)  Local vendor means any person, firm, partnership, corporation (including franchises or branches) licensed to conduct business within the village, physically operating within the corporate boundaries of the village, and subject to village taxes. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.070 - Newspaper notice. 
(a)  When a bid is required by this Chapter, advertisements shall be published at least once in at least one newspaper of general circulation in the village at least ten days prior to the date announced for the receipt of bids. In computing the time for the required notice, the first day shall be the day of the publication of the notice, and the time shall run consecutively thereafter, including therein Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. The newspaper notice required by this section shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold or the work to be performed, the location where blank bid forms and specifications may be secured, the time by which bids must be submitted, the location where the bids must be submitted, and the time and place for opening bids. 
(b)  The village may solicit sealed bids from all responsible bidders whom the village manager or departmental representatives know from experience or research appear to be capable of providing the items to be purchased or performing the required service. Notice shall be by sending the prospective bidders a copy of such newspaper notice or such other notice as will acquaint them with the proposed purchase or sale. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.080 - Format for submission of bids. 
    Bids shall be submitted in a sealed opaque envelope to the village manager. Each bid shall be addressed to the village manager and shall bear on the face of the envelope the name of the bidder, a statement that it is a sealed bid to be opened on the date and hour mentioned in the public notice, and a statement of the contract for which the bid is made. Each bid shall be submitted on the printed form supplied by the village. Any bid not submitted as required herein may be rejected and not considered a proper bid. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.090 - Bid opening procedures. 
(a)  Bids shall be opened by the village manager, or his/her designee, in public at the time and place specified in the public notice, in the presence of a representative of the department recommending the purchase. 
(b)  A tabulation of all bids received shall be made available for public inspection in the office of the village manager within a reasonable period of time after opening of the bids. 
(c)  Any bid which is not submitted in the form as required by Section 2.25.080 and which is inadvertently opened prior to the official bid opening shall be rejected. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.100 - Award of contract. 
(a)  The village manager is empowered to award contracts on behalf of the village within the purview of this Chapter, which are under twenty thousand dollars. Except as otherwise provided herein, the president and board of trustees shall award all other contracts. 
(b)  Contracts subject to bidding requirements shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder as determined at the sole discretion of the corporate authorities. In determining the lowest possible bidder, the corporate authorities shall consider the following as well as other criteria: 
(i)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required; 
(ii)  The capacity of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference; 
(iii)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder including but not limited to past performance record; default under previous contracts, whether or not such contracts were with the village; competency; and failure to pay or satisfactorily settle all bills due for labor and material on former contracts; 
(iv)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(v)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service; 
(vi)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and financial ability of the bidder to perform the contract or service; 
(vii)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies, machinery, plant or other equipment or contractual services to the particular use required; 
(viii)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract, including guarantees; 
(ix)  Whether the bidder is entitled to local preference as set forth in this Chapter. 
(c)  When the award is not recommended to be given to the lowest bidder, a statement of the reasons for such award recommendation shall be prepared. 
(d)  Nothing set forth herein shall prohibit the village from negotiating a lower price than the lowest responsible bidder. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
(Ord. No. 4708, § A, 7-16-2012) 
2.25.110 - Rejection of bids. 
    The corporate authorities may reject any and all bids received, may waive any procedural informality in the bidding process if determined to be in the best interest of the village or, if no bids are received, may: 
(a)  Abandon the project; 
(b)  Readvertise for new bids; or 
(c)  Provide for the contract to be negotiated in the open market. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.120 - Advance disclosures. 
    Any disclosure of information contained in any submitted bid documents in advance of the opening of bids, made or permitted by a member of the corporate authorities or a village officer or employee or representative thereof, shall operate to void the bid in its entirety as to all bidders. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.130 - Documents required for purchase or contract. 
    The following requirements shall be met in the manners indicated below: 
(a)  Bid Security. 
(i)  Public works or construction contracts over twenty thousand dollars. When the estimate for any public works or construction contract is over twenty thousand dollars, all bidders shall submit a bid bond secured by a cashier's check or certified check or by an insurance company licensed to do business within the state, attached to the bid documents in an amount equal to at least five percent of the bid or such other reasonable amount as determined by the village manager. The security will be held to ensure good faith on the part of the bidder and to be applied as liquidated damages should the successful bidder fail to execute and submit all required contract documents within the time required by Section 2.25.140 or attempt to withdraw the bid prior to the beginning date of the contract. 
(ii)  Other Purchases or Contracts. For any purchase or contract other than as set forth in section (a) or if the bid award is computed from a bid not based on a fixed total contract sum, the village manager is empowered to fix a reasonable bid security amount to ensure good faith on the part of the bidder and to be applied as liquidated damages should the successful bidder fail to execute and submit all required contract documents within the time required by Section 2.25.140 or attempt to withdraw the bid prior to the beginning date of the contract. If the village manager determines that the requirement of a bid bond may result in a lack of competitive bids or quotes or is otherwise not warranted, the village manager may waive the requirement of a bid bond. 
(iii)  Return of Bid Security. All bid security, other than that submitted by the successful bidder, shall be returned to the respective bidders within a reasonable period of time after award of a contract or rejection of the bid. The bond of the successful bidder shall be held by the village manager until all required contract documents have been fully executed. 
(b)  Affidavits of Compliance. Each bidder shall submit, with other required contract bidding documents, the following affidavits: 
(i)  An affidavit that the bidder is familiar with and will comply with all applicable state, local and federal laws, including but not limited to, the Prevailing Wage Act, the Davis-Bacon Act, the Anti-Bid Rigging and Anti-Bid Rotating provisions of the Illinois Criminal Code, the tax delinquency provisions of Section 11-42.1-1, et seq. of the Illinois Municipal Code and the Village of Wheeling Ethics Code. 
(ii)  An affidavit indicating the following ownership status of the bidder: 
(A)  If a Corporation. The name of the state in which the corporation is chartered; the name, address and telephone number of the local registered agent and office; 
(B)  If a Partnership. The name of all partners and the address and telephone number of the business office; 
(C)  Sole Proprietorship. The name of the owner and the address and telephone number of the business office; 
(iii)  An affidavit that the bidder has not colluded with any person in the bid for the contract; 
(iv)  An affidavit that the bidder does not and will not engage in discriminatory practices and does not and will not engage in discrimination because of race, sex, religion, national origin, age or sensory, mental or physical handicap in hiring or firing, and is in fact an equal opportunity employer. 
(c)  Insurance, all construction and public works contracts. 
(i)  The successful bidder in all construction or public works contracts shall submit with other required contract documents a certificate of general liability insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business within the state, indicating the bidder as the insured and naming the village as an additional insured for the duration of the contract, in at least the following amounts: 
(A)  Commercial General Liability. One million dollars combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury, and property damage. The minimum general aggregate shall be no less than a project/contract specific aggregate of one million dollars; 
(B)  Business Automobile Liability. One million dollars, combined single limit per accident for bodily injury and property damage; 
(C)  Worker's compensation insurance, amount as required by state statute. 
(D)  Any self-insured retentions must be declared to and approved by the village. 
    This certificate shall be submitted with the other required documents. 
(ii)  The successful bidder shall require the same amounts and coverages as in subsection (a) of this section from all subcontractors. 
(d)  Labor and Performance Bonds. 
(i)  Labor and Performance Bond. Construction and public works contracts over twenty thousand dollars. The successful bidder in all construction and public works contracts whose estimated contract price exceeds twenty thousand dollars shall submit a labor and materials bond and a performance bond written for the duration of the contract issued by an insurance company licensed to do business within the state. The labor and materials bond shall be conditioned upon the full and complete payment for all materials and labor used to complete the contract, in the amount of one hundred percent of the contract price. The performance bond shall be conditioned on the full completion of the contract according to its terms, in the amount of one hundred percent on the contract price. Any person may submit in lieu of the performance bond required in this section, cash in escrow with an escrow agreement approved as to form by the village attorney. The amount deposited in escrow shall be in the amount of one hundred percent of the contract price. Notice of intent to make such an escrow deposit shall accompany the bid proposal. No withdrawal of the escrow deposit by the bidder shall be allowed until the completion of the project as approved by the village manager. The successful bidder shall execute the performance bond on a form provided by the village or its equivalent and submit the bond with other required contract documents. 
(ii)  The village manager may require a labor and materials bond or a performance bond for any other contract to be entered into by the village. 
(iii)  All bidders on any contract which is funded from the state motor fuel tax in whole or in part shall submit to the director of public works when required by the state, a current certificate of eligibility indicating prequalification in at least the amount of the bid and areas of expertise required and issued by the state at or prior to the time and date set for bid opening. 
(Ord. 4048 §§ A (part), B, 2006; Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.140 - Submittal of required documents. 
(a)  Within fifteen calendar days after award of the contract by the village and prior to commencing work, the successful bidder shall submit the following required contract documents fully executed and bound, to the village manager: 
(i)  All documents as required by Section 2.25.130; 
(ii)  Signed contract form provided by the village. Failure to tender the above documents as required shall, at the option of the village, terminate the contract award and all the village to draw upon the full amount of the bidder's bid bond as liquidated damages. 
(b)  The submission of a document required by this Chapter which is in whole or in part false or misleading in any material statement shall be considered a default under the contract. The village manager is hereby empowered to immediately inform the successful bidder of the default pursuant to the provisions set out in the contract documents. He or she shall immediately take steps to institute the village's remedies available under the contract and at law, which shall include, but not be limited to, entering into a contract with the next lowest responsible bidder or readvertising for bids. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.150 - Exceptions to bidding requirements for purchases or contracts of twenty-five thousand dollars or more. 
    The following purchases or contracts whose estimated cost is equal to or greater than twenty-five thousand dollars shall not require written specifications or competitive bidding. 
(a)  Purchases which may only be made from a single source; 
(b)  Purchases for additions to and repairs and maintenance of personal property owned by the village which may be more efficiently added to, repaired, or maintained by a specific person; 
(c)  Purchases of personal property which are compatible with the existing equipment or systems owned by the village including, but not limited to the purchase of computer software and hardware, phone or other electronic equipment; 
(d)  Purchases which can be made at a public auction, close-out sale, bankruptcy sale, or other similar sale at a cost below the market cost in the community; 
(e)  Purchases where an emergency immediately affects the public health, safety or welfare if authorized by the village manager. Upon cessation of the emergency, the village manager shall inform the corporate authorities by a full written account of the contracts entered into or purchases made pursuant to this subsection; 
(f)  Contracts for the services of individuals possessing a high degree of professional skill; 
(g)  Contracts for the printing of bonds, tax warrants and other evidences of indebtedness; 
(h)  Purchases, which because of the unique characteristics of the personal property, including but not limited to computer software and hardware, phone or other electronic equipment, or the needs of the village are not susceptible to competitive bidding; 
(i)  Contracts with options to renew for additional periods of time at a fixed price. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
(Ord. No. 4962, § B, 11-23-2015; Ord. No. 5260, § C, 5-20-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5260, § C, adopted May 20, 2019, changed the title of § 2.25.150 from "Exceptions to bidding requirements for purchases or contracts of twenty thousand dollars or more" to read as herein set out. 
2.25.160 - Change orders. 
    Change orders shall be executed in the following manner: 
(a)  The village manager is hereby empowered to execute the following change orders: 
(i)  Change orders that do not alter the scope, cost, or quality of the project; and 
(ii)  Change orders that cumulatively result in less than a ten thousand dollar reduction in cost and do not alter the time of completion of the project by a period of thirty days or more. 
(b)  The village manager is hereby empowered to execute the following change orders without prior approval by the corporate authorities, provided, however, he/she shall report such change orders to the corporate authorities: 
(i)  Change orders which result from emergency situations, in the discretion of the village manager, with emergency situations being defined as: 
(A)  Any clear and present danger or hazard to health, safety or welfare; or 
(B)  Condition which would require the cessation of work on the project, if not immediately executed. 
(ii)  Change orders which result in an additional project cost, if the accrued costs of all change orders to date are below ten thousand dollars and provided that the change order being considered does not necessitate an increase or decrease in the time to complete a project by a total of thirty days or more. 
(iii)  All change orders not included in subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be effective only after prior approval of the corporate authorities. If such approval is given, the village manager is hereby authorized to execute such change orders. 
(iv)  All change orders necessitating an increase or decrease in the cost of a contract by a total of ten thousand dollars or more or the time of completion by a total of thirty days or more shall be effective only after prior approval of the corporate authorities and a finding that: the circumstances said to necessitate the change in performance were not reasonably foreseeable at the time the contract was made; or, the change is germane to the original contract as signed; or the change is in the best interests of the village and authorized by law. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
(Ord. No. 4962, § C, 11-23-2015) 
2.25.170 - Exclusions from this chapter. 
    This Chapter shall not apply to: 
(a)  Any collective bargaining agreement or employment contracts to which the village is a party; 
(b)  Any purchase, sale or lease of real property to which the village is a party; 
(c)  Contracts with or purchases from another governmental entity. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
2.25.180 - Disposition of village-owned property. 
(a)  In the event any material or equipment is determined to be surplus by the corporate authorities, the village manager is authorized to dispose of the property by public auction as provided in the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(b)  In the event the village manager determines that disposal of material or equipment by public auction will not provide the village with the best price for such property, the village manager is authorized to dispose of such property by broker, trade-in, sealed bids or such other method determined to be in the best interests of the village. 
(Ord. 3432 § A, 1999) 
Chapter 2.26 - FIREMEN'S PENSION FUND 

2.26.010 - Created. 
    There is created and established a firemen's pension fund in and for the village of Wheeling, in accordance with 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq. 
(Ord. 4076 § A (part), 2006: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.26.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, "firefighter" and "fire pension board of trustees" are defined, respectively, as a full-time firefighter or full-time firefighter/paramedic entitled to participate in the benefits of the pension fund as provided by 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq. and the board of trustees of the pension fund are participating members as outlined in Section 2.26.060 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 4076 § A (part), 2006: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.26.030 - Moneys included. 
    There shall be set apart by the village of Wheeling, and the treasurer thereof, beginning as of January, 1970, the following moneys to constitute the fire pension fund: 
(1)  All moneys derived from the taxes levied for the purpose of the fund; 
(2)  All rewards in moneys, fees, gifts and emoluments that may be paid or given to the village of Wheeling fire department for or on account of extraordinary services by the fire department or any member thereof (except when allowed to be retained by competitive awards); 
(3)  All gifts, grants, devises or bequests of money, real estate, personal property or other valuable things received by the board of trustees of the pension fund, which the board of trustees shall be empowered to receive and dispose of pursuant to statute; 
(4)  The current rate as mandated by State Statute for fire pension funds will be dedicated from each full-time firefighter and placed by the village treasurer to the credit of the pension fund. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.26.040 - Levying of annual tax. 
    There shall be levied annually, commencing with the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Chapter, a tax upon all the taxable property of the village of Wheeling at the rate on the dollar which will produce an amount to meet the annual requirements of the fund as computed by the Department of Insurance of the state of Illinois. The actuarial reserve requirements shall be computed at a rate of not less than seventeen and one-half percent of the salaries and wages to be paid to the firefighters for the ensuing year, and shall provide for the amortization of the unfunded accrued liabilities, including liabilities on account of Pension Act. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.26.050 - Reserve fund. 
    A reserve fund to insure the payment of all obligations of the pension fund shall be established and maintained. The reserve shall be not less than one thousand dollars for each one thousand inhabitants of the village of Wheeling pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Pension Act. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.26.060 - Board of trustees created-Membership. 
    A board of trustees of the fire pension fund of the village of Wheeling is created for the administration of the funds. The board shall consist of five members. Two members of the board shall be appointed by the president of the board of trustees. Two members of the board shall be active participants of the pension fund who are elected from the active participants of the fund pursuant to 40 ILCS 5/4-121. One member of the board shall be a person who is retired under the Firemen's Pension Fund Act of 1919 or Article 4 of the Illinois Pension Code, 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq., who is elected from persons retired under the Firemen's Pension Fund Act of 1919 or Article 4 of the Illinois Pension Code, 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq., pursuant to 40 ILCS 5/4-121. Members of the board of trustees of the fire pension fund of the village of Wheeling shall not be considered officers of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 4076 § A (part), 2006: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.26.070 - Rights of board of trustees. 
    The rights, powers, duties and functions of the board and the members thereof, as such, and the rights and benefits of the various beneficiaries of the pension fund shall be and are declared to be in accordance with the applicable provisions of 40 ILCS 5/4-01 et seq. 
(Ord. 4076 § A (part), 2006: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.26.080 - Treasurer designated custodian of fund. 
    The village treasurer shall be treasurer and custodian of the pension fund. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.27 - POLICE PENSION FUND 

2.27.010 - Created. 
    There is created and established a police pension fund for the village of Wheeling in accordance with the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § O, 4-25-2011) 
2.27.020 - Moneys included. 
    There shall be set apart by the village of Wheeling, and the treasurer thereof, the following moneys to constitute this fund: 
(1)  All moneys derived from taxes levied for this purpose; 
(2)  All interest moneys earned on investments of the fund; 
(3)  Payroll deduction, as established by State Statute, of all members of the fund; 
(4)  Any reward, grant or gift that may be given the Wheeling police department. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.27.030 - Levying of annual tax. 
    There shall be levied annually, a tax upon all the taxable property of the village at a rate which produces an amount to meet the requirements by the Department of Insurance of the state of Illinois. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.27.040 - Treasurer designated custodian of fund. 
    The village treasurer shall be treasurer and custodian of the pension fund. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.28 - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT REVENUE BONDS* 

2.28.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter may be referred to as the "Village of Wheeling Economic Development Revenue Bond Enabling Ordinance." 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed below: 
(a)  "Bond ordinance" means the ordinance authorizing a specific issue of bonds adopted by the president and board of trustees of the village in accordance with the policies set forth in this chapter and such other supplementary ordinance(s), resolution(s), and other proceedings as they deem necessary describing the public purpose to be served. 
(b)  "Economic development project" means any capital project including any land, interest in land, building, structure, facility, system, fixture, improvement, addition, appurtenance, machinery or equipment or any combination thereof, and all real and personal property deemed necessary in connection therewith; provided, that the existence of such economic development project will: (1) create or retain employment opportunities in or near the village; or, (2) increase the tax base of the village; or, (3) provide for the health and welfare of the citizens of the village, and be a project of good standing which will benefit the village of Wheeling. 
(c)  "Person" means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation (including public utilities), association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, state agency or any other legal entity, or its legal representative, agent or assigns. 
(d)  "Project" means any economic development project located within the village or within ten miles of the corporate boundaries, but not within another municipality. 
(e)  "Project costs" means and includes the sum total of all reasonable or necessary costs incidental to the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, repair, alteration, improvement and extension of a project including without limitation the cost of studies and surveys, plans, specifications, architectural and engineering services, legal, marketing or other special services, financing, acquisition, demolition, construction, equipment and services, financing, acquisition, demolition, construction, equipment and site development of new and rehabilitated buildings, rehabilitation, reconstruction, repair or remodeling of existing buildings and all other necessary or incidental expenses whether directly or indirectly related to the project, including an initial bond and interest reserve, together with interest on bonds issued to finance a project to a date six months subsequent to the estimated date of completion, and any costs, or expenses which may be included under the provisions of Section 103(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended. 
    The term "project costs" shall also include all village costs, including but not limited to printing, publication, fiscal, financial, legal, review, public hearing and the costs of preparation of all ordinances, resolutions, agreements and other legal and financial documents that are necessary to authorize and deliver the economic development bonds. 
(f)  "Village" means the village of Wheeling, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois. 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.030 - Declaration of purpose. 
    It is hereby determined and declared that the purpose of this chapter is to provide a means of financing the costs of projects which will relieve conditions of unemployment, increase the tax base of the village, provide for the public safety, health, and welfare of the citizens of the village, and/or to encourage the increase of industry or commerce within or near the village. These are declared to be public purposes and functions pertaining to the government and offices of the village. 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.040 - Additional powers. 
    The village of Wheeling, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois, acting by and through its president and board of trustees shall have the power and authority under this chapter: 
(1)  To construct, acquire by gift, purchase or lease, reconstruct, improve, better or extend, or to finance the construction, acquisition, reconstruction, improvements, betterment, extension of any economic development project, within or partially without the village, but in no event further than ten miles from the territorial boundaries of the village, and, if deemed necessary, to acquire by gift, purchase, lease, lands or rights in land in connection with any economic development project; 
(2)  To issue revenue bonds to defray in whole or in part the project costs of any economic development project and to designate an appropriate name for such bonds, which bonds shall be issued pursuant to a bond ordinance authorizing the same; 
(3)  To enter into leases or other agreements, including without limitation, loan agreements with any person in order to secure the village's revenue bonds; provided, however, that any such lease or other agreement must provide that such person shall pay to, for or on behalf of the village an amount sufficient to pay principal, interest, redemption premiums and all other costs in connection with the village's revenue bonds so that such bonds will never constitute an indebtedness of the village or the loan of its credit within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provision; 
(4)  To pledge to the punctual payment of bonds authorized under this chapter, the interest thereon, and the redemption premiums, if any, the revenue and receipts to be received pursuant to such leases or other agreements; 
(5)  To mortgage such project in favor of the holder or holders of bonds issued therefor; 
(6)  To sell and convey such project including, without limitation, the sale and conveyance thereof subject to a mortgage, if any, as provided in this chapter, for such price and at such time (whether prior or subsequent to the payment in full of bonds authorized under this chapter) as the president and board of trustees of the village may determine. However, no sale or conveyance of such project shall ever be made in such manner as to impair the rights or interests of the holder or holders of any bond issued hereunder; 
(7)  To issue its bonds to refund, in whole or in part, bonds theretofore issued by the village under authority of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.050 - Exercise of powers-Bond ordinance. 
(a)  The exercise of all powers granted by this chapter and the issuance of economic development revenue bonds shall be authorized by an ordinance and such supplementary ordinance(s), resolution(s), and other proceedings as are deemed necessary (collectively designated the "bond ordinance") describing the public purpose to be served by the issuance of economic development revenue bonds. Findings as set forth in the ordinance relating to the public purpose of such financing, the validity thereof, or any other purpose shall be conclusive. 
(b)  The bond ordinance shall indicate the amount of money necessary to be borrowed, the amount of bonds to be issued in evidence thereof, and shall fix the necessary details of such bonds. The term of bonds shall not exceed forty years from the date of the bonds. The interest rate, sale price, redemption and registration privileges, conditions and covenants, manner of payment and all other details shall be as determined by the president and board of trustees. The bonds may be sold at public or private sale in such manner and upon such terms as may be deemed advisable by the president and board of trustees. A contract for the sale of such bonds may be entered into prior to the adoption of the bond ordinance or the bond ordinance may provide for the subsequent sale of the bonds. The bonds and interim receipts or certificates shall be deemed to be securities and negotiable instruments within the meaning and for all purposes of the Uniform Commercial Code. 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.060 - Title to the project. 
    It shall not be necessary for the village to own or acquire any project or part thereof financed hereunder. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.070 - Covenants in bonds. 
(a)  Any bond ordinance may contain such covenants as the village may desire, including but not limited to covenants as to: 
(1)  The use and disposition of the revenues and receipts from the lease or other agreements or the project for which the bonds are to be issued, including the creation and maintenance of reserves; 
(2)  The issuance of other or additional bonds relating to the project or any rehabilitation, improvements, renovations, enlargements or additions thereto; 
(3)  The maintenance and repair of such project; 
(4)  The insurance to be carried thereon and the use and disposition of insurance moneys; 
(5)  The appointment of any bond or trust company within or outside the state of Illinois having the necessary trust powers as trustee for the benefit of the bondholders, paying agent and bond registrar; 
(6)  The investment of any funds held on behalf of the village; and 
(7)  The terms and conditions upon which the holders of the bonds or any portion thereof or any trustees therefor are entitled to the appointment of a receiver. 
(b)  The bond ordinance may provide that the principal of and interest on the bonds shall be secured by a mortgage or indenture of trust upon such project for which the bonds are issued and may include any improvements or extensions thereafter made. Such mortgage or indenture of trust may contain any covenants and agreements to properly safeguard the bonds not inconsistent with this chapter or the bond ordinance and shall be executed in the manner as may be provided for in the bond ordinance. The provisions of this chapter and the bond ordinance and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall constitute a contract with the holder or holders of the bonds and continue in effect until the principal of, the interest on, and the redemption premiums, if any, on the bonds so issued have been fully paid, or until provision for payment shall have been made as provided in the bond ordinance, and the duties of the village and its corporate authorities and officers under this chapter and any bond ordinance and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall be enforceable by any bondholder by mandamus, foreclosure of any such mortgage or indenture of trust or other appropriate suit, action or proceedings in any court of competent jurisdiction, in the manner and subject to the terms of such bond ordinance, mortgage or indenture of trust. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.080 - Signature, seal, form and validity of bonds. 
    The bond ordinance shall authorize the execution of the bonds therein authorized on behalf of the village by the village president and village clerk and may, additionally, authorize execution by any such other person or persons (including a corporation) who or which may be designated in the bond ordinance. Any signature on the bonds may be by facsimile; provided, however, that at least one signature required or permitted to be placed thereon shall be manually subscribed. The form of bond shall be as prescribed in the bond ordinance. The validity of the bonds is not dependent on or affected by the validity or regularity of any proceedings relating to the acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping, betterment or extension of the project for which the bonds are issued. The bond ordinance may provide that the bonds shall contain recital that they are issued pursuant to this chapter, which recital shall be conclusive evidence of their validity and of the regularity of their issuance. 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.090 - Lien of bonds. 
    All bonds issued under this chapter shall have a lien upon the revenues and receipts derived from such lease or other agreement, and the president and board of trustees may provide in the bond ordinance for the issuance of additional bonds to be equally and ratably secured by a lien upon such revenues and receipts, or may provide that the lien upon such revenues and receipts is subordinate. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.100 - Liability for bonds unless expressly authorized to the contrary. 
    All bonds issued under and pursuant to this chapter shall be limited obligations of the village payable solely out of the revenues and receipts derived from such lease or other agreement. No holder of any bonds issued under this chapter shall have the right to compel any exercise of taxing power of the village to pay the bonds, the interest or premium, if any, thereon, and the bonds shall not constitute an indebtedness of the village or a loan of credit thereof within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
    It shall be plainly stated on the face of each bond that it has been issued under the provisions of this chapter and that it does not constitute an indebtedness of the village or a loan of credit thereof within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provisions. 
(Ord. 1491 § A (part), 1983: Ord. 1698 §A (part), 1980) 
2.28.110 - Exemption from construction and bidding requirements for public buildings. 
    The acquisition and construction of a project shall not be subject to any requirements relating to public buildings, structures, grounds, work or improvements imposed by the Illinois Compiled Statutes or any other similar requirements which may be lawfully waived by this section, and any requirement of competitive bidding or restriction imposed on the procedure for award of contracts for such purpose of the lease, sale or other disposition of property of the village is not applicable to any action taken under authority of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § S, 4-25-2011) 
2.28.120 - Powers conferred as additional and supplemental limitations imposed- Effect. 
    The powers conferred by this chapter are in addition and supplemental to, and the limitations imposed by this chapter shall not affect the powers conferred by any law or any other ordinance. Projects may be financed, acquired, purchased, constructed, reconstructed, improved, bettered, equipped and extended, and bonds may be issued under this chapter for such purposes, notwithstanding that any law or any other ordinance may provide for the financing, acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping, betterment and extension of a like project, or the issuance of bonds for like purposes, and without regard to the requirements, restrictions, limitations or other provisions contained in any law or any other ordinance. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.28.130 - Procedure for issuance- Application. 
A.  Application for industrial revenue bonds shall be made to the director of finance. The application shall be accompanied with a nonrefundable fee of five thousand dollars and such supporting financial documents and information as is necessary to make a complete and thorough analysis of the industry. Information requested includes: 
(1)  Name of the firm that will purchase the bonds (if available); 
(2)  A SEC 10-D report of the corporation if it is required to file; 
(3)  The last five annual reports of the corporation; 
(4)  The latest preliminary financial status report of the current fiscal year, if available. 
    The village manager, upon the advice of staff and consultants, may require additional information from the applicant. 
B.  All village fees, including printing, publication, legal, fiscal, review, hearings and cost of preparation of all ordinances, resolutions, agreements and other legal and financial documents that are necessary to authorize and deliver the industrial revenue bonds, shall be at the expense of the applicant. Services may be financed as part of the bonded project. 
C.  Applicant shall contract for the sale of the bonds at terms agreeable to the applicant and his bank or investment banker. 
D.  The final fee to the village for authorizing the issuance of industrial revenue bonds shall be negotiated between the village and the applicant. The village manager shall have the authority to negotiate such fee on behalf of the village. From this amount the initial fee of five thousand dollars shall be deducted. The final fee and all village expenses shall be paid on or before the date of closing of the bonds. 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § C, 3-21-2011) 
2.28.140 - Criteria for issuance. 
A.  Prior to the issuance of any economic development bonds the president and board of trustees will require the following statements: 
(1)  A statement from the village attorney that he reviewed or will review all documents pertinent to the application and bond issue. 
(2)  A statement from the village financial consultant that, based on the consultant's study of the information supplied and from other available sources, the applicant is financially sound and, further, that in the event that the applicant should be in financial trouble the village would be protected from any financial obligations. 
(3)  A statement from the director of community development that the industry is in compliance with the village's comprehensive plan and that the industry would be an asset to the village. 
(4)  A statement from the director of finance that suitable arrangements have been made for the payment of all fees. 
(5)  A statement from the village manager that he has reviewed all documents and recommends to the president and board of trustees that they authorize the issuance of the industrial revenue bonds. 
B.  The president and board of trustees reserve the right to have the applicant appear before them to explain the proposed development and to answer any questions. 
C.  Upon completion of all steps the president and the board of trustees shall consider approval of industrial revenue bond issue. 
    The following standards shall be used to evaluate the issuance of economic development bonds: 
(1)  That the project is in compliance with the intent and purpose of the Wheeling Municipal Code, as specified in Section 2.28.030; 
(2)  That the applicant is financially sound and further that in the event that the applicant should be in financial trouble the village would be protected from any financial obligations; 
(3)  That the project is in compliance with the village's comprehensive plan and would be an asset to the village; 
(4)  That the project is in compliance with all other applicable ordinances of the village; 
(5)  That bond counsel shall issue their opinion that the bond issue shall be exempt from federal income taxation; 
(6)  That the village attorney shall issue his opinion that the bond issue is in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1941 § A (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § C, 3-21-2011) 
Chapter 2.29 - INDEBTEDNESS FOR CORPORATE PURPOSES* 

2.29.010 - Authority to borrow money and issue bonds. 
    The village of Wheeling, Cook and Lake Counties, Illinois, acting by its president and board of trustees, may, from time to time, borrow money for proper public purposes and in evidence of such borrowing, issue its full faith and credit bonds (general obligation) payable from ad valorem taxes to be levied without limitation as to rate or amount against all taxable property situated within the village. Such bonds may be issued without the submission of the question of their issuance to the electors of the village for their approval and the procedures for the issuance of such bonds shall be substantially as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.29.020 - Bond ordinance-Statement of necessity and purpose. 
    The village shall adopt an ordinance and such necessary supplementary ordinance(s), resolution(s), and other proceedings as it deems necessary (hereinafter collectively designated the "bond ordinance") describing the public purpose or purposes to be served by such borrowing. Findings as set forth in said ordinance relating to the necessity of such borrowing, the validity thereof, or any other purpose, shall be conclusive. 
(Ord. 1915 § A (part), 1982: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.29.030 - Information required-Interest. 
    The bond ordinance shall indicate the amount of money necessary to be borrowed, the amount of bonds to be issued in evidence thereof, and shall fix the necessary details of such bonds. The term of bonds shall not exceed forty years from the date of said bonds. The interest rate, sale price, redemption and registration privileges, manner of payment and all other details of the bonds shall be as determined by the president and board of trustees. A contract for the sale of such bonds may be entered into prior to the adoption of the bond ordinance or the bond ordinance may provide for the subsequent sale of the bonds therein authorized. 
(Ord. 1915 § A (part), 1982: Ord. 1852 § A, 1982: Ord. 1744 § A, 1981: Ord. 1736 § A, 1981: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.29.040 - Signature, seal and form of bond. 
    The bond ordinance shall authorize the execution of the bonds therein authorized on behalf of the village by the village president and village clerk and may, additionally, authorize execution by any such other person or persons (including a corporation) who or which may be designated in the bond ordinance. Any signature on the bonds may be by facsimile; provided, however, that at least one signature required or permitted to be placed thereon shall be manually subscribed. The form of bond shall be as prescribed in the bond ordinance. 
(Ord. 1915 § A (part), 1982: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.29.050 - Tax levy. 
    The bond ordinance shall make provision for the payment of such bonds, both principal thereof and interest thereon, until maturity, by the levy of a direct annual tax upon all the taxable property within the village of Wheeling sufficient for such purpose. A copy of such bond ordinance, as adopted, certified by the village clerk, shall be filed in the offices of the county clerks of the counties within which any part of the village of Wheeling may be situated. Such bond ordinance, as so filed, shall constitute the authority for such county clerks, in and for each of the years for which taxes are levied in the bond ordinance, to extend such taxes for collection against all the taxable property situated within the village of Wheeling. The taxes so levied for the payment of principal of and interest on the bonds shall be extended annually by the several county clerks without limitation as to rate or amount, and such taxes shall be in addition to and in excess of all other taxes levied or authorized to be levied by the village of Wheeling. Except as provided herein, such taxes so levied shall not be subject to repeal or abatement in any manner whatsoever until such time as all the bonds authorized under the terms of the bond ordinance, and issued, shall have been paid in full or duly provided for, both principal thereof and interest thereon up to and including the date of maturity or applicable date of redemption; provided, however, that if the village of Wheeling has funds available, it may appropriate same and order their deposit in trust with the village treasurer, the paying agent for such bonds, or any other authorized person (including a corporation) for the purpose of the payment of any principal of bonds or interest thereon in which event the taxes so levied to pay such principal or interest may be abated by an appropriate amount, such abatement to be by ordinance of the village of Wheeling duly adopted and placed on file with the respective county clerks. 
(Ord. 1915 § A (part), 1982: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.29.060 - Appropriation-Publication. 
    The provisions of any bond ordinance shall constitute an appropriation of the amounts required as therein referred to and described. A bond ordinance shall become effective immediately upon its passage and approval as provided by law. It may be published, if so provided in the bond ordinance, either in a newspaper as designated therein or in pamphlet form by authority of the president and board of trustees, but such publication shall be for public information purposes only and failure to publish or any defect therein shall not affect either the effective date of the bond ordinance or its validity or the validity of the bonds. 
(Ord. 1915 § A (part), 1982: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.29.070 - Refunding bonds. 
    Any bonds authorized and issued pursuant to the provisions of any bond ordinance adopted pursuant to the provisions hereof, and also any bonds issued and outstanding, which by their terms are payable from taxes unlimited as to rate or amount and levied against all the taxable property within the village of Wheeling, may be refunded prior to their maturity or at their maturity, and including the refunding of matured interest coupons evidencing interest upon such unpaid bonds. Such refunding shall be by the issuance of refunding bonds to be authorized by a refunding bond ordinance which shall be adopted in the manner and subject to the terms, conditions and provisions as required in this chapter for the issuance of bonds for public purposes. 
(Ord. 1915 § A (part), 1982: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.29.080 - Controlling authority designated. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by Section 6 of Article VII of the Constitution of Illinois 1970, the procedures hereby established for the issuance of full faith and credit bonds (general obligation), as herein provided for, shall be controlling and shall be complied with by the village of Wheeling in the borrowing of money through the issuance of general obligation bonds of the village notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in the provisions of the "Illinois Municipal Code" and all acts amendatory thereof and supplementary thereto, and any other law or laws of the state of Illinois. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.30 - POLICE DEPARTMENT* 

2.30.010 - Department created. 
    There is established a department of the village which shall be known as the police department. The police department shall consist of a chief of police and such other employees as established in the village budget. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.30.020 - Appointment-Removal of employees. 
(a)  The positions of chief of police, deputy chiefs of police and commanders are designated as specifically exempt from the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 
(1)  The chief of police shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. 
(2)  Individuals shall be recommended by the chief of police to the village manager for appointment or removal as deputy chief and commander. The deputy chiefs of police and commanders shall be appointed or removed by the village manager. 
(3)  In the event any regular member of the police department is appointed as police chief, deputy police chief or commander, he shall be classified during his term in such position as on furlough from the police department at the rank to which he is entitled under the board of fire and police commissioners at the beginning of his term of office. At the end of his term of office, he shall be returned to active duty as a regular member at his rank and seniority and shall thereinafter be entitled to all the benefits and emoluments of such prior rank without regard to whether a vacancy exists in such rank. 
(4)  The provision set out in subdivision (3) of this subsection shall not apply where such individual has been discharged for cause, in which case he shall be disqualified as a member of the police department. 
(b)  Appointment-Removal of Police Personnel. The sworn members of the police department, other than exempt positions shall be appointed and removed by the fire and police commission under the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes and the Wheeling Municipal Code. Appointment of non-exempt supervisory officers from the regular members of the police department is the responsibility of the fire and police commission; provided, however, that no new positions, temporary or permanent, will be created or filled without prior approval by the corporate authorities through resolution and fiscal appropriation. 
(c)  Appointment-Removal of Nonsworn Personnel. The appointment and removal of nonsworn personnel of the police department shall be performed by the village manager as outlined in the personnel manual of the village. 
(Ord. 1975 § A, 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § Q, 4-25-2011) 
2.30.030 - Police department's duties generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to see to the enforcement of all ordinances of the village and all statutes effective in the village and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the laws and arrest violators thereof. Every sworn member of the police department is declared to be a conservator of the peace. All duties of positions, as outlined in approved job descriptions, as well as duties outlined in the departmental procedures, shall be adhered to. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.30.040 - Establishment of regulations. 
    The chief of police may establish regulations for the guidance of the members of the department. These shall be approved by the village manager. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.31 - FIRE DEPARTMENT* 

2.31.010 - Fire department created. 
    There is established a department within the village of Wheeling that shall be known as the fire department. The fire department shall consist of a fire chief and other employees as established by the village budget. 
(Ord. 3190 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.31.020 - Appointments and removal of employees. 
(a)  Appointment and Removal of Command Staff Personnel. The positions of fire chief, deputy fire chiefs and battalion chiefs are designated specifically exempt from the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, Chapter 65, Paragraph 5/10-2.1-1, et seq. 
(1)  The fire chief shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. The fire chief shall also be the fire marshal of the village of Wheeling. 
(2)  Individuals shall be recommended by the fire chief to the village manager for appointment as deputy fire chief and battalion chief. These positions shall be appointed by the village manager. 
(3)  In the event any member of the fire department is appointed as fire chief, deputy fire chief or battalion chief, the member shall be classified as on furlough from the fire department rank to which the member is entitled to under the board of fire and police commissioners. At the end of the term of office, the member shall be returned to active duty at the rank and seniority prior to such appointment, and shall thereafter be entitled to all the benefits and emoluments of such rank without regard as to whether a vacancy exists in such rank. 
    The provisions set out in subdivision (3) of this subsection shall not apply where such individual has been discharged for cause, in which case the individual shall be disqualified as a member of the fire department. 
(b)  Appointment and Removal by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. The positions of lieutenant and firefighter shall be positions within the fire department and shall be appointed and removed by the board of fire and police commissioners under provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes and the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 3190 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 1975 § B, 1983: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.31.030 - Fire department general duties. 
    It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and its personnel to: 
(a)  Respond to possible or reported fires and extinguish such fires; 
(b)  Provide emergency medical treatment, care and transportation to a hospital for those individuals who are sick or injured; 
(c)  Respond to possible or reported releases of hazardous materials and provide containment and mitigation, when possible; 
(d)  Provide specialized rescue services for entrapment, high angle rescue and underwater rescue/recovery; 
(e)  Support private entities in providing secondary rescue services for confined spaces and below-grade situations; 
(f)  Provide public education in the area of fire prevention, first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation; 
(g)  Perform inspectional services for the purpose of preplanning and fire prevention code compliance; and 
(h)  Perform other duties as directed by the fire chief, the corporate authorities and/or imposed by ordinance from time to time. 
(Ord. 3190 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.31.040 - Establishment of department regulations. 
    The fire chief is authorized to establish reasonable rules and regulations for the guidance of fire department personnel. All rules and regulations governing personnel shall be subject to approval by the village manager. 
(Ord. 3190 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.31.050 - Fire prevention bureau created. 
    There is established within the fire department a fire prevention bureau. The fire prevention bureau shall be operated under the supervision of the fire chief. The fire chief shall designate other members of the fire department as fire inspectors, as authorized by the village manager. The fire chief shall also recommend the employment of technical personnel, as shall from time to time be necessary. 
(Ord. 3190 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.31.060 - Fire prevention bureau general duties. 
    Fire department personnel assigned to the fire prevention bureau shall be responsible for enforcement of the fire prevention code as adopted by the Wheeling Municipal Code, Title 14, Fire, Chapter 14.01, Fire Prevention Code, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. 3190 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.31.070 - Service outside of the corporate limits. 
(a)  The fire department and its members are authorized to go outside of the corporate limits of the village for rendering aid to other fire departments and/or communities, as deemed necessary by the fire chief. All aid rendered outside of the corporate limits of the village shall be in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Wheeling fire department, the mutual aid box alarm system (MABAS), the terms and conditions of any legally binding contracts entered into by the corporate authorities, and/or conditions of any automatic aid agreements authorized by the corporate authorities of the village of Wheeling, as may be modified from time to time. 
(b)  The fire department and its members are authorized to participate in fire-department-related training exercises outside of the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling, as deemed necessary by the fire chief. 
(Ord. 3190 § 1 (part), 1997: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.32 - EMERGENCY AND DISASTER MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section A of Ord. No. 4384, approved on Dec. 22, 2008, replaced Ch. 2.32, Emergency Services and Disaster Agency, §§ 2.32.010-2.31.120, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 2.32 derived from Ord. 1698, passed 1980. 

2.32.10 - Definitions. 
(a)  "Disaster" defined. The term "disaster" shall mean an occurrence or threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or technological cause, including but not limited to fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, tornado, hazardous materials spill/release, or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, extended periods of severe and inclement weather, drought, infestation, riot, civil unrest, public health emergencies, or acts of domestic terrorism. 
(b)  "Emergency management coordinator (EMC)" defined. The term "emergency management coordinator" shall mean a specific member of the village of Wheeling's administrative staff assigned responsibility for coordinating the village of Wheeling's emergency management programs. During a disaster, the emergency management coordinator shall serve as the village of Wheeling's incident commander in accordance with the National Incident Management System (NIMS). The abbreviation "EMC" shall be used to refer to the "emergency management coordinator". 
(c)  "Emergency operations center (EOC)" defined.
