The term "emergency operations center" shall refer to a specific physical location at which the coordination of information and resources to support the management of large scale emergency situations or disasters that affect the village of Wheeling occurs. Within the emergency operations center key personnel from all the village's operating departments are represented, as well as members of the village board and outside public and private organizations who have a direct role in the emergency. The abbreviation "EOC" shall be used to refer to the "emergency operations center". 
(d)  "Emergency operations plan (EOP)" defined. The term "emergency operations plan" shall refer to a written plan describing the organization, mission, and functions within the village of Wheeling for responding to and recovering from disasters. The abbreviation "EOP" shall be used to refer to the "emergency operations plan". 
(e)  "Emergency services" defined. The term "emergency services" shall mean those resources managed, owned, deployed, and/or coordinated by the Village of Wheeling to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury and damage resulting from any disasters caused by natural or manmade causes. These functions shall include but are not limited to: fire suppression services, emergency medical services, health services, hazardous materials containment/mitigation services, law enforcement services, public work services, technical rescue services, utility restoration services, as well as other functions related to the protection of residents and the overall protection of life or property. 
(f)  "Illinois Emergency Management Agency (IEMA)" defined. The term "Illinois Emergency Management Agency" shall apply to the agency created by the executive branch of the State of Illinois responsible for the coordination of the overall emergency management program for the State of Illinois. The abbreviation "IEMA" shall be used to refer to the "Illinois Emergency Management Agency". 
(g)  "Incident commander (IC)" defined. The term "incident commander" shall refer to the individual responsible for all incident activities, including the development of strategies and tactics, as well as the ordering of and releasing of resources, during an emergency situation. The incident commander has the overall authority and responsibility for conducting incident operations. The abbreviation "IC" shall be used to refer to the "incident commander". 
(h)  "Incident action plan (IAP)" defined. The term "incident action plan" refers to an oral or written plan containing general objectives that reflect the overall strategy for managing an emergency incident. It may include the identification of operational resources and assignment of these resources to particular aspects of the emergency incident. The abbreviation "IAP" shall be used to refer to the "incident action plan". 
(i)  "National Incident Management System (NIMS)" defined. The term "National Incident Management System" shall refer to a system mandated by the federal government that provides a consistent nationwide approach for federal, state, local, and tribal governments; private sector; and nongovernmental organizations to work effectively and efficiently together to prepare for, respond to, and recover from domestic incidents, regardless of cause, size, or complexity. The "National Incident Management System" encompasses incident command, multiagency coordination, training, identification and management of resources, as well as the collection, tracking, and reporting of incident information. The abbreviation "NIMS" shall be used to refer to the "National Incident Management System". 
(j)  "Supervisory employee" defined. The term "supervisory employee" as used in this Chapter shall refer to those employees with direct managerial responsibilities during an emergency or disaster situation within the village of Wheeling. This shall be limited to: village manager, assistant village manager, fire chief, deputy fire chief, battalion fire chief, fire lieutenant, police chief, deputy police chief, police commander, police sergeant, public works director, assistant public works director, public works superintendent, public works supervisor, director of community development, deputy director of community development, deputy code official, finance director, and assistant finance director. These individuals are authorized to request the activation of the emergency operations center (EOC), as well as serving as incident commander (IC), when necessary. 
(k)  "Unified incident command (UIC)" defined. The term "unified incident command (UIC)" refers to the incident command system utilized where there is more than one village of Wheeling operating department or outside organization (private or governmental) with incident jurisdiction or when an incident crosses political jurisdictions. All entities work together through their designated members (department and/or organization) to establish a common set of objectives and strategies, as well as a single incident action plan. The abbreviation "UIC" shall be used to refer to the use of "unified incident command". 
(Ord. No. 4384, § A, 12-22-2008) 
2.32.20 - National Incident Management System (NIMS). 
    The National Incident Management System (NIMS) shall be implemented during all local emergency incidents, disasters, or emergency-related training exercises. During emergency incidents or disasters an "Incident Commander" shall be designated and shall have the authority to implement an incident action plan (IAP) that is formulated and directed towards the protection of life and property without prior consultation or approval by any village of Wheeling department head, the village manager, and/or any member of the village board. The incident commander (IC) will be selected based upon the type of emergency incident, complexity of the emergency incident, the overall incident management objectives, as well as but not limited to the training, educational background, and overall related experience of the individual. In the event of a large scale emergency incident or disaster which requires the involvement of two or more Village of Wheeling operating departments and/or the involvement of outside organizations (private or governmental), a unified incident command system shall be implemented. 
(Ord. No. 4384, § A, 12-22-2008) 
2.32.30 - Emergency management coordinator (EMC). 
(a)  An emergency management coordinator (EMC) will be appointed by the village manager and shall serve in this capacity until replaced. 
(b)  The emergency management coordinator (EMC) will have direct responsibility for administration, organization, training, and operation of all emergency services in relationship to disaster preparedness and response for the village of Wheeling. Said responsibility will be subject to direction and control by the village manager, as well as state statute which may be amended from time to time. During disaster operations, the emergency management coordinator (EMC) or his/her designee will be responsible for the development of an incident action plan (IAP) and coordination of a unified incident command (UIC). In the absence of the emergency management coordinator (EMC) during a disaster situation, the following line of succession will be implemented: 
a.  Fire chief. 
b.  Deputy fire chief. 
c.  Police chief. 
d.  Deputy police chief. 
e.  Public works director. 
f.  Deputy public works director. 
(c)  The emergency management coordinator (EMC) will coordinate the development of an emergency preparedness and disaster plan for the village of Wheeling. Said plan will be based upon the use of the National Incident Management System (NIMS), as well as input from all village operating departments and outside public and private organizations, as deemed necessary. 
(d)  The emergency management coordinator (EMC) will serve as the village of Wheeling's liaison to the Cook County Emergency Management Agency. 
(e)  The emergency management coordinator (EMC) will serve as the village of Wheeling's liaison to the Illinois Emergency Management Agency (IEMA). 
(f)  The emergency management coordinator (EMC) will serve as the village of Wheeling's liaison to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). This responsibility will include coordination of and recordkeeping of training completed by village employees for compliance with requirements of the National Incident Management System (NIMS). 
(g)  The emergency management coordinator (EMC) will be responsible for fostering and negotiating mutual aid agreements between the village of Wheeling and neighboring communities, community taxing bodies, fire protection districts, state and township entities, and private organizations as it relates to disaster preparedness, emergency response, and disaster recovery in accordance with 20 ILCS 3305/13. Said mutual aid agreements will be subject to the final approval by the village president and board of trustees. 
(h)  The emergency management coordinator (EMC) will be responsible for preparing an annual budget request for equipment and supplies necessary to maintain the village's emergency operations center (EOC) and the overall community's disaster preparedness. Said budget request shall be subject to review and approval in accordance with the budgetary policies of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. No. 4384, § A, 12-22-2008) 
2.32.40 - Emergency operations center (EOC). 
    In the event of a large scale incident or disaster situation that affects the village of Wheeling, the emergency operations center (EOC) will be placed into operation. The decision to open the emergency operations center (EOC) can be made by any supervisory employee of the village of Wheeling based upon the type and/or complexity of the emergency situation and/or the extent of the necessary resources to effectively handle the emergency situation. Once the decision has been made to activate the emergency operations center (EOC), the department head and assistant/deputy department head of each operating department within the village of Wheeling will be notified. A representative of each operating department will then report to the emergency operations center (EOC) and will assist in formulating a unified incident command (UIC), in order to handle the emergency situation. Oversight of the emergency operations center (EOC) during an emergency situation will be the responsibility of the emergency management coordinator (EMC) or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 4384, § A, 12-22-2008) 
2.32.50 - Declaration of state of emergency. 
    In the event of a disaster which affects the village of Wheeling, provisions contained within Chapter 8.50 of the Wheeling Municipal Code, as may be amended from time to time, will be implemented as deemed necessary by the village president or president pro tem. 
(Ord. No. 4384, § A, 12-22-2008) 
Chapter 2.35 - DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT 

2.35.010 - Establishment. 
    There is established the department of community development. This department shall consist of operational divisions, as determined by the village manager, empowered to assist in commercial, residential and industrial development within the village. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.35.020 - Director of community development-Personnel of the department. 
    There is established the position of director of community development who shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. All personnel of the department shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.35.030 - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The department of community development shall be charged with the overall coordination among the appropriate advisory commissions, board of trustees, staff, and citizens for the development of structures and land utilization within the corporate limits of the village. The director shall keep abreast of development trends and provide staff assistance to the village manager on all matters assigned. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the department of community development to enforce all laws and ordinances relating to the following: health and sanitation, animals, streets and sidewalks, trees and vegetation, waters and sewers, buildings and construction, plumbing, planning and subdivisions, zoning, environmental protection, signs and floodplain regulations. 
(Ord. 2819 § A, 1992: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.37 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section A of Ord. No. 4593, adopted March 21, 2011, amended Ch. 2.37, Department of Operations and Maintenance, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 2.37 derived from Ord. No. 1698, adopted in 1980. 

2.37.010 - Establishment. 
    There is established a department of public works. This department shall consist of operational divisions, as determined by the village manager, to expedite and control the physical operations of the village including, but not limited to, the water and sewer system, roads, bridges, sidewalks, village equipment and other items.

2.37.020 - Director of public works-Personnel of department. 
    There is established the position of director of public works who shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. All personnel of the department shall be appointed and removed by the village manager.

    The department of public works shall be charged with the efficient running and maintenance of all physical plants and operations of the village. Operations included are the water and sewer systems, municipal roads and sidewalks, village trees, village buildings, village equipment and other assignments by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 4593, § A, 3-21-2011) 
Chapter 2.51 - BOARD OF HEALTH* 

2.51.010 - Board of health-Created. 
    There is created the board of health of the village. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.51.020 - Board of health-Composition and term of office. 
    The board of health is to be composed of seven members, each of whom shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The village health officer will be an ex officio member of the board and shall attend board meetings. The members of the board shall annually elect a chairperson who shall serve for a term of two years or until his or her successor is elected and qualified. The election of each chairperson thereafter shall occur every two years prior to or at the board's first regularly scheduled meeting in July or as soon thereafter as is practicable. An individual may not be elected or appointed to the position of chairperson more than two consecutive terms. The terms of the board members shall be for a period of three years. Any member missing three meetings per year will be subject to removal by the Wheeling Village board upon written notification from the chairperson of the board of health. Any health or medically oriented person may be appointed to the board; however, if none is available, a competent and interested person of the community shall be appointed. 
(Ord. 4222 § 4, 2007: Ord. 3907 § 6 (part), 2004: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4764, § A, 4-1-2013) 
2.51.040 - Board of health-Organization and meetings. 
    The board shall select from its membership the vice-chairperson and secretary every two years. The persons so selected shall serve for a term of two years, and may not be reelected to the same position more than two consecutive terms. It shall be the duty of the chairperson, to conduct meetings and to transmit any recommendations for proposed rules, regulations and decisions of the board to the corporate authorities. It shall be the duty of the vice-chairperson, to act as the chairperson, in the absence of the selected chairperson. It shall be the duty of the secretary to sign the minutes. The minutes of the meetings and hearings of the board and of all ordinances proposed shall be public record and available within fourteen days following each stated or emergency meeting or hearing, and shall be available for public inspection in the office of the village clerk during regular business hours. The board shall meet regularly not less than once every two months except for special or emergency meetings or as deemed necessary by approval by the board of health. Such special or emergency meetings are to be called by the chairperson, or by the chairperson at the request of any two board members or at the request of any duly appointed or elected official of the village. In the case of meetings, however, a majority of the appointed members of the board shall constitute a quorum to conduct business. 
(Ord. 3907 § 6 (part), 2004: Ord. 3319 § A, 1998: Ord. 2811 § A, 1992: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4764, § A, 4-1-2013) 
2.51.050 - Board of health-Rules. 
    The board shall adopt rules for the conduct of its meetings and hearings, and such rules may include the creation of committees authorized to conduct the appropriate hearings at any time two or more members of the board of health are present. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.51.060 - Board of health-Powers and duties. 
    The board of health shall have general supervision of the interests of the people of the village. The board shall cooperate with the Department of Health of the state in enforcing the rules and regulations for control of communicable diseases promulgated by the department, and such other rules and regulations of the United States, state, county, and village as may be related to the sanitation and health of the village. The board of health of the village shall have authority to make recommendations to the president and board of trustees for the passage of ordinances, as they may from time to time deem necessary for the preservation and improvement of the public health and for the suppressing of disease. The board of health shall also give to the village authorities such professional advice and information as may be required or requested to preserve the public health. 
    The board of health may sponsor blood drives annually contracting with a professional blood donor organization to provide the services. The board of health shall be responsible for providing public health information and services to the residents of the village via health fairs and educational presentations sponsored by professionally recognized organizations. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4764, § A, 4-1-2013) 
2.51.080 - Orders and notices. 
    Any person violating or refusing to obey any order of the board of health or destroying or mutilating or concealing any notice posted by or under the authority of the board of health shall be in violation of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.51.090 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation, violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04 of this code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.54 - PLAN COMMISSION 

2.54.010 - Creation and purpose. 
    In order that adequate provisions are made for the preparation of a comprehensive village plan and for the guidance, direction and control of the growth, development and redevelopment of the village and contiguous territory not more than one and one-half miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any municipality, a plan commission is created. 
(Ord. 3544 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.54.020 - Membership. 
(a)  The plan commission shall consist of seven members, from residents of Wheeling who have illustrated an interest in serving on the commission, appointed by the village president, on the basis of their particular fitness for duty on the plan commission, and subject to the approval of the village board of trustees. 
(b)  From the seven appointed members, the village president shall annually appoint the chairperson of the plan commission, with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees. The chairperson shall serve for a period of one year or until his successor is appointed and qualified. The president's first appointment of a chairperson made pursuant to this code shall be made at the conclusion of the term of the chairperson as of the date of the adoption of the amendment. 
(Ord. 3907 § 1, 2004: Ord. 3544 § A (part), 2001) 
(Ord. No. 4920, § A, 1-12-2015) 
2.54.030 - Term of office. 
    Such members shall serve at the pleasure of the president and board of trustees. Terms of plan commission members shall be for a period of three years, which terms shall expire on the last day of June. In the event that any member of the plan commission fails to attend plan commission meetings for a period of three consecutive months, his office may be declared vacant by motion passed by a majority of the president and board of trustees of the village, and his unexpired term shall be filled by appointment as provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3544 § A (part), 2001) 
2.54.040 - Adoption of procedure. 
    The members of the plan commission shall meet and organize as they deem necessary, and adopt and later change or alter rules and regulations of organization and procedure consistent with village ordinances and state laws. The commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which shall be open at all times to public inspection. The membership shall elect a secretary on an annual basis, who shall not serve more than two consecutive years in that capacity. 
(Ord. 3907 § 2, 2004: Ord. 3544 § A (part), 2001) 
2.54.050 - Powers and duties. 
    The plan commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the president and board of trustees of the village of Wheeling a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the village and contiguous unincorporated territory not more than one and one-half miles beyond the corporate limits of the village and not included in any other municipality. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of Wheeling, Illinois. Such plan shall be advisory, except as to such part thereof as has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the president and board of trustees. All requirements for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption with the county recorder of deeds, and filing of the plan and ordinances with the municipal clerk shall be complied with as provided for by law; 
(2)  To review and recommend to the president and board of trustees the subdivision or resubdivision of land in accordance with the standards of design for subdivisions and for resubdivisions of land and of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements as herein provided and in accordance with the requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, street lights, parks, playgrounds, school sites, other public grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewer collection and treatment; 
(3)  To designate land suitable for annexation to the municipality and the recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation; 
(4)  To recommend to the village board of trustees, from time to time, such changes in the comprehensive plan or any part thereof as may be deemed necessary; 
(5)  To prepare and recommend to the village board of trustees, from time to time, plans and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan; 
(6)  To give aid to the officials of the village of Wheeling charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced with the official plan or parts thereof, to further the making of such improvements, and generally to promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan; 
(7)  To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions and other agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure harmonious and integrated planning for the area; 
(8)  To hold the appropriate public hearings on applications for special uses as set out in Chapter 19.92, and pursuant thereto to prepare and transmit to the corporate authorities its written findings and recommendations with respect to the proposed special use; 
(9)  To hold the appropriate public hearings on applications for amendments or proposals for amendments to the regulations imposed and districts created under the authority of Title 19, pursuant to the procedure set out in Chapter 19.94, and further to make findings and recommendations pursuant thereto and forward same to the corporate authorities; 
(10)  To review and recommend site plans for development or redevelopment of property; 
(11)  To act in the capacity of the zoning board appeals and to hold the appropriate public hearings on applications for variations to the regulations imposed by Title 19, pursuant to the procedure set forth in Chapter 19.88, and further to make findings and recommendations pursuant thereto and forward the same to the corporate authorities; 
(12)  To act in the capacity of the zoning board appeals and to hold the appropriate public hearings on applications for variations to the regulations imposed by Title 17, pursuant to the procedure set forth in Chapter 17.52, and further to make findings and recommendations pursuant thereto and forward the same to the corporate authorities; 
(13)  To act in the capacity of the zoning board of appeals and to hear appeals from the decisions of the zoning administrator in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 19.90; 
(14)  To review and make recommendations on new developments and redevelopments in the village, including the aesthetics of such developments or redevelopments as set forth in the Wheeling Municipal Code or in the rules and procedures of the plan commission; 
(15)  To promote and encourage aesthetic growth in the community and to work against the deterioration of the visual character, harmony and beauty of the village; 
(16)  To act in the capacity of the sign code board of appeals in accordance with the provisions of Title 21; 
(17)  To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by the corporate authorities pursuant to the authority of the Wheeling Municipal Code or the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 3544 § A (part), 2001) 
2.54.052 - Plan commission meetings and rules. 
    All hearings at which applications for special uses, applications for amendments to Title 19, variations to the provisions of Title 17 or 19, or proposals for amendments to Title 19 shall be open to the public and shall be governed by the provisions of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. At said hearings any person may appear and testify either in person or by duly authorized agent or attorney. All testimony shall be given under oath, and the chairman or, in his absence, the acting chairman shall administer oaths. The plan commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question or, if absent or failing to vote indicating such fact. The plan commission shall also keep records of its hearings and other official actions. Every amendment or repeal thereof or requirement, decision or determination made in connection therewith shall be filed immediately in the office of the director of community development and shall be a public record. 
(Ord. 3544, § A (part), 2001) 
2.54.060 - Official map provisions. 
(a)  At any time or times, before or after the formal adoption of the official comprehensive plan by the corporate authorities, an official map may be designated by ordinance, which map may consist of the whole area included within the official comprehensive plan or one or more separate geographical or functional parts, and may include all or any part of the contiguous unincorporated area within one and one-half miles from the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling. All requirements for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption with the county recorder of deeds, and filing of said plan and ordinances including the official map with the municipal clerk shall be complied with as provided by law. 
(b)  No map or plat of any subdivision or resubdivision presented for record, affecting land within the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling, or within contiguous territory which is not more than one and one-half miles beyond the corporate limits, shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless the subdivision shown thereon provides for standards of design, and standards governing streets, alleys, public ways, ways for public service facilities, street lights, public grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater and floodwater run-off channels and basins, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment, in conformity with the applicable requirements of the ordinances including the official map. 
(Ord. 3544, § A (part), 2001) 
2.54.070 - Reporting on improvement regulations. 
    The director of community development shall furnish the plan commission for its consideration a copy of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any nature. The plan commission may report in relation thereto if it deems a report necessary or advisable, for the consideration of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. 3544, § A (part), 2001) 
Chapter 2.55 - ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS 

2.55.020 - Membership of zoning board of appeals. 
(a)  The Wheeling plan commission shall be the ex officio zoning code board of appeals of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 3544 § B, 2001: Ord. 1761 § A (part), 1981) 
Chapter 2.56 - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS 

2.56.010 - Creation and terms of office. 
    There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners, which shall consist of five members appointed by the village president with the approval of the board of trustees. The term of office for such members shall be for three years and until his successor is appointed and shall qualify. The village president shall have the power to remove any of the commissioners for cause, after a public hearing before the board of trustees, and such removal shall be subject to confirmation by a majority of the members of the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. 1974 § A (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4441, § A, 6-29-2009) 
2.56.020 - Qualifications. 
(a)  The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be residents of the village. Upon appointment, they shall be considered officers of the village and shall file an oath with the village clerk. 
(b)  No person holding an office in the village shall be a member of the board of fire and police commissioners. The acceptance of any such office by a member of the board shall be deemed a resignation of his office as a commissioner. No person shall be appointed a commissioner who is related, either by blood or marriage, up to the degree of first cousins, to any member of the Corporate Authorities. 
(c)  No more than two commissioners shall belong to the same political party existing in the village at the time of such appointments and as defined in Section 10.2 of the Illinois Election Code. If only one or no political party exists in the village at the time of such appointments, the state or national political party affiliations shall be considered in making such appointments. Party affiliation shall be set forth in an affidavit of the person appointed as a commissioner. 
(Ord. 1974 § A (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4604, § A, 4-25-2011) 
2.56.030 - Duties of the board. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall have those duties with respect to the appointment and removal of sworn members of the police and fire departments provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq., as amended, except such duties as are modified by village ordinance. 
(Ord. 1974 § A (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § R, 4-25-2011) 
2.56.040 - Rules and regulations. 
    The authority to adopt rules and regulations as provided in Division 2.1 of Article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code is hereby amended and superseded and the board of fire and police commissioners is hereby granted the authority to make such rules and regulations as are deemed necessary and proper to implement the following: 
(a)  To establish and conduct competitive examination processes for original appointment and promotion; 
(b)  To determine the number and types of examinations to be utilized; 
(c)  To establish a grading process for such examinations and minimum passing grades for each examination; 
(d)  To establish physical requirements for original appointment; 
(e)  To provide for the utilization of application pools within the examination process and to determine the number of applicants within each pool; 
(f)  To establish a preference point system for military service, community service officer experience, job based college degrees and job based certifications; 
(g)  To extend the probationary time period for probationary officers to a period of twenty-four months; and the ability to extend such probation for an additional period not to exceed one year; 
(h)  To establish rules for the satisfactory completion of probation; 
(i)  To establish a minimum level of work experience for officers as a condition precedent for eligibility to take promotional examinations; 
(j)  To establish probationary time period for all officers promoted from a lower rank; 
(k)  To establish a demotion procedure whereby the board shall have the authority to demote to a lower rank those officers who in the determination of the board have not met the standards of the fire and police departments and whereby an officer may request demotion; 
(l)  To revise or eliminate the seniority point system for promotion; 
(m)  To charge a fee for the examination process; 
(n)  To make temporary appointments for as long as determined necessary by the personnel director; 
(o)  To suspend for a period of thirty calendar days per charge; 
(p)  To establish rules for the conduct of all hearings before the board. 
(q)  To establish rules governing lateral entry of firefighters and police officers. 
(Ord. 3308 § A, 1998; Ord. 2976 § A, 1994: Ord. 1974 § A (part), 1983) 
2.56.050 - Ranks exempt. 
(a)  The board of fire and police commissioners shall not have the power to appoint or remove the chief of police, deputy chiefs of police and commanders within the police department, and the fire chief, deputy fire chiefs and battalion chiefs within the fire department, those positions being specifically exempt from the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, Chapter 65, Section 5/10-2.1-1, et seq. 
(b)  The appointment and removal of individuals to such exempt positions shall be made in accordance with the provisions of the Wheeling Municipal Code, Title 2, Sections 2.30.020 and 2.31.020. 
(Ord. 3190 § 2, 1997: Ord. 1974 § A (part), 1983) 
2.56.060 - Reports of the board. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall annually, on or before March 15th of each year, submit to the president and board of trustees a report of its activities and the rules and regulations in force and the practical effect thereof and any recommendations which the commissioners believe would result in greater efficiency in the fire and police departments. 
(Ord. 1974 § A (part), 1983) 
2.56.070 - Chairperson-Secretary of board. 
(a)  The members of the commission shall annually elect a chairperson who shall serve for a term of one year or until his or her successor is elected and qualified. The term of the chairperson appointed prior to the adoption of this amendment shall expire upon the election or appointment of his or her successor. The election of the first chairperson pursuant to this section shall be made within thirty days from the date of the adoption of this amendment. The election of each chairperson thereafter shall occur each year prior to or at the commission's first regularly scheduled meeting in July or as soon thereafter as is practicable. If a chairperson is not elected and qualified within thirty days of the adoption of this amendment or by the end of July in each succeeding year, the village president may appoint a chairperson of the commission with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees at the first regularly scheduled meeting of the board of trustees in August or at any time thereafter. 
(b)  At the first regularly scheduled meeting of the board of fire and police commissioners after April 30th, or as soon thereafter as is practicable, the board shall annually elect a secretary who shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be the custodian of all papers relating to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations held, and shall perform such other duties as the board may from time to time prescribe. 
(Ord. 4222 § 1, 2007; Ord. 3907 § 3, 2004: Ord. 1974 § A (part), 1983) 
Chapter 2.57 - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX BOARD 

2.57.010 - Creation and terms of office. 
(a)  The village of Wheeling Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Board ("foreign fire board") is hereby created to consist of seven trustees, with the fire chief of the Wheeling fire department serving as a trustee, along with six trustees who shall be elected at large by the sworn members of the Wheeling fire department, from the members of the Wheeling fire department. If there is an insufficient number of candidates to fill all the trustee positions, the number of trustees comprising the foreign fire board may be reduced, but not to fewer than three trustees. The officers of the foreign fire board shall be identified and defined by the board in its bylaws and shall be elected annually by the trustees. 
(b)  The term "member of the Wheeling fire department" as used in this section, shall mean any full-time sworn firefighter or officer of the village of Wheeling fire department, including the fire chief and all sworn, promoted positions. 
(c)  The elections of the trustees and the officers of the foreign fire board shall be held in accordance with bylaws established by the foreign fire board as required by Section 11-10-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-2), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 4736, § 2, 11-12-2012) 
2.57.020 - Foreign fire insurance tax fund created. 
    A village of Wheeling Fire Department Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Fund ("fund") is hereby created and all revenue hereinafter received by the village of Wheeling from the foreign fire insurance tax required by Sections 11-10-1 and 2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 and 2) and Chapter 4.36 of the village of Wheeling Municipal Code shall be turned over to the foreign fire board within fourteen calendar days of the date on which the village receives such revenue. All such revenue shall be deposited in the fund by the foreign fire board. This revenue shall be expended by the foreign fire board according to the following procedures: 
(a)  The treasurer of the foreign fire board shall provide the village treasurer with a quarterly accounting of receipts and expenditures of the fund. 
(b)  The foreign fire board shall develop and maintain a list of those items that it determines are appropriate expenditures under Sections 11-10-1 and 2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 and 2). A copy of this list shall be forwarded to the village treasurer within fourteen calendar days of its approval by the foreign fire board. The foreign fire board shall amend this list on an as-needed basis and shall send all such amended lists to the village treasurer. 
(c)  Each year, the revenue received by the village pursuant to Sections 11-10-1 and 2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 and 2) and Chapter 4.36 of the village of Wheeling Municipal Code shall be set aside for expenditure by the foreign fire board and deposited into the fund within fourteen calendar days of the date on which the village receives such revenue. The foreign fire board shall open its own bank or credit union account. The village treasurer shall be provided with online, read-only access to said account where read-only access is permitted by said bank or credit union. 
(d)  All expenditures of the foreign fire board shall be for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department as required by Sections 11-10-1 and 2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 and 2). As such, expenditures shall not be permitted where they are intended solely to serve personal and non-professional interests and/or pursuits that do not have either a direct or indirect relationship to (1) the business or operation of the fire department or the foreign fire board, (2) the provision of any of the services identified in Section 2.31.030 of Chapter 2.31 of the village of Wheeling Municipal Code, or (3) any of the fire department's fire stations or the property contained or housed therein. 
(e)  The foreign fire board shall have the sole and exclusive power to approve the expenditure of monies from the fund for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department. All purchases shall be preapproved by a majority vote of the foreign fire board taken in accordance with the board's bylaws. 
(f)  The foreign fire board's purchases of any item or product shall be subject to the following purchasing requirements: 
(1)  The foreign fire board shall be authorized to make purchases that do not exceed five thousand dollars per item; 
(2)  Proposed purchases that cost between five thousand dollars and twenty thousand dollars per item shall, where possible, require a minimum of three quotations prior to awarding the purchase to the best qualified vendor; and 
(3)  Proposed purchases that cost more than twenty thousand dollars per item shall be advertised for sealed bids, shall be based upon written specifications, and shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder whose bid is most responsive to the specifications of the proposed purchase. In determining the lowest and most responsive bidder, the foreign fire board shall consider the criteria identified in Section 2.25.100 of Chapter 2.25 of the village of Wheeling Municipal Code, as well as other criteria. 
(g)  The foreign fire board shall provide written notice to the village treasurer prior to any purchase of physical property in order that a determination can be made as to its impact on the village's property and liability insurance provisions. 
(h)  Prior to purchasing any physical property that will be brought into any of the village's fire stations, the following procedure shall be followed: 
(1)  The board's officers will notify the fire chief or his/her designee in writing of its intention to make an expenditure of funds and the anticipated date of that intended expenditure prior to making said expenditure. 
(2)  The fire chief or his/her designee must approve of the intended expenditure unless he/she determines that (1) the item or product sought to be brought on village property through the board's intended expenditure of funds will pose a genuine safety risk, (2) the item or product sought to be brought on village property through the board's intended expenditure of funds will legitimately interfere with a genuine operational need of the village's fire department, or (3) the intended expenditure will not be made for the maintenance, use or benefit of the village's fire department. The fire chief and the village will not otherwise interfere with the expenditure of funds by the board or its officers, and, in all circumstances, will comply with the requirements of Sections 11-10-1 and 2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 and 2). 
(3)  If the fire chief or his/her designee determines that (1) the item or product sought to be brought on village property through the board's intended expenditure of funds will pose a genuine safety risk, (2) the item or product sought to be brought on village property through the board's intended expenditure of funds will legitimately interfere with a genuine operational need of the village's fire department, or (3) the intended expenditure will not be made for the maintenance, use or benefit of the village's fire department, the fire chief or his/her designee shall notify the board's chairperson or treasurer in writing that he/she does not approve of the intended expenditure of funds and the foreign fire board shall not make the expenditure. That notification must be delivered to the board's chairperson or secretary prior to the announced date of the intended expenditure (when possible) and no later than five business days (excluding weekends and recognized village holidays) from the day on which the fire chief received written notice of the foreign fire board's intent to make an expenditure of funds. The fire chief's or his/her designee's failure to respond in writing shall be taken as an approval of the intended expenditure. The fire chief's or his/her designee's written notification of disapproval shall contain a statement of the reasons for his/her determination that the intended expenditure (1) will pose a genuine safety risk, (2) will legitimately interfere with a genuine operational need of the village's fire department, or (3) will not be made for the maintenance, use or benefit of the village's fire department. The fire chief's or his/her designee's written notification of disapproval will not be valid in cases where he/she has not asserted any reason to support his/her determination(s) with respect to the intended expenditure and the foreign fire board shall make the proposed expenditure. 
(4)  Within seven calendar days from, but not including, the day on which the fire chief or his/her designee tendered his/her written notice of disapproval, one or more of the foreign fire board's officers shall meet with the fire chief or his/her designee in person for the purpose of discussing the fire chief's or his/her designee's disapproval of the intended expenditure of funds. During that meeting, the parties shall, in good faith, make their best attempt to resolve the dispute. 
(5)  In the absence of reaching a resolution concerning the intended expenditure of funds during the parties' in-person meeting, either party may request that the dispute be appealed to the village manager. The notification must be in writing. Within seven calendar days from, but not including, the day on which the appeal is provided to the village manager, one or more of the foreign fire board's officers shall meet with the village manager in person for the purpose of discussing the fire chief's disapproval of the intended expenditure of funds. During that meeting, the parties shall, in good faith, make their best attempt to resolve the dispute. Within five business days (excluding weekends and recognized village holidays) of this meeting, the village manager shall issue a written decision on the matter. If the board is not satisfied with the manager's decision, it may pursue legal action in the circuit court of Cook County. 
(i)  The foreign fire board treasurer shall provide a bond to the village president and board of trustees in an amount equal to three times the amount of the prior year's actual foreign fire insurance tax receipts to ensure the faithful performance of the board treasurer of his duties imposed by law and by the foreign fire board's bylaws. Fees for said bond shall be paid from the funds collected from the foreign fire insurance tax. 
(j)  As part of the village's annual audit, the fund shall be audited and said audit shall be provided to the village for its records. 
(k)  The foreign fire board shall be authorized to expend fund monies to pay for legal, financial or other professional services that are necessary for the board to execute its statutory duties and/or protect its statutory interests. 
(l)  Trustees and officers of the foreign fire board shall be released from duty without loss of pay to attend to board functions, meetings and responsibilities provided that attendance at such meetings does not result in additional expenses to the village, does not interfere with the daily operations of the fire department and does not adversely impact emergency operations. 
(m)  No trustee or officer of the foreign fire board shall be subject to any form of discipline on the basis of engaging in any legitimate activity on behalf of the foreign fire board. 
(Ord. No. 4736, § 2, 11-12-2012) 
2.57.030 - Meetings of board. 
    The board shall, in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, establish a regular time and place for its meetings. The foreign fire board shall adopt all needful rules and regulations concerning the operation and conduct of its meetings and shall forward said rules and regulations to the Wheeling Village Board. 
(Ord. No. 4736, § 2, 11-12-2012) 
2.57.040 - Rules and regulations. 
    The foreign fire board shall promulgate written rules and regulations governing board matters so long as such rules and regulations are not inconsistent with any applicable law, including, but not limited to, the Illinois Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.); the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.); the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act (5 ILCS 430/1-1 et seq.); and the Local Records Act (50 ILCS 205/1 et seq.). All rules and regulations promulgated by the board must be approved by a majority of the foreign fire board members. All rules and regulations shall be posted in each fire station, the Wheeling village hall, and a copy provided to the village clerk. Such rules and regulations shall be made available for public inspection. The board shall maintain a record of all board rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 4736, § 2, 11-12-2012) 
2.57.050 - No interference. 
    At no time shall the actions of the board or its officers violate the express rights of the fire chief under Illinois law, change the composition of the Wheeling fire department, violate the express rights of the Wheeling board of fire and police commissioners under Illinois law, or interfere with a genuine operational need of the village's fire department. 
(Ord. No. 4736, § 2, 11-12-2012) 
Chapter 2.91 - SENIOR CITIZENS COMMISSION 

2.91.010 - Creation-Purpose. 
    There is created a senior citizens commission, to be composed of members appointed and designated as provided in this Chapter, which shall be a regular and permanent commission of the village of Wheeling, and which shall perform the duties and exercise the powers provided in this Chapter. The purpose of the senior citizens commission shall be to serve as an advisory body to the president and board of trustees, to the village manager, and to such other governmental agencies as may have jurisdiction over or exercise any authority or provide or fund any services in the village of Wheeling, with respect to the general welfare of senior citizens in the village. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.91.020 - Appointment-Qualification-Terms. 
(a)  The senior citizens commission shall be composed of eleven members and one ex officio nonvoting member. The members of the commission shall annually elect a chairperson who shall serve for a term of one year or until his or her successor is elected and qualified. The term of the chairperson appointed prior to the adoption of this amendment shall expire upon the election or appointment of his or her successor. The election of the first chairperson pursuant to this section shall be made within thirty days from the date of the adoption of this amendment. The election of each chairperson thereafter shall occur each year prior to or at the commission's first regularly scheduled meeting in July or as soon thereafter as is practicable. If a chairperson is not elected and qualified within thirty days of the adoption of this amendment or by the end of July in each succeeding year, the village president may appoint a chairperson of the commission with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees at the first regularly scheduled meeting of the board of trustees in August or at any time thereafter. 
(b)  The voting members of the commission shall be appointed by the president subject to the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(c)  One employee of the village of Wheeling shall be designated to serve ex officio on the commission by the village manager. 
(d)  All members of the commission appointed by the president must be residents of the village at the time of their appointment and during their service on the commission. At least four of the members appointed by the president must be senior citizens who have attained the age of sixty. 
(e)  Terms of members of the commission shall be one year, and all members shall serve their appointed or designated terms and until their respective successors are appointed or designated. The terms of any members appointed to the commission after June 1, 2016, shall expire on June 30, 2017, at which time the village board will re-examine the effectiveness of an eleven-member commission. 
(f)  Vacancies shall be created by resignation, death, failure to attend any regular meetings of the commission, for three successive months, failure to meet any applicable qualification for the particular appointment or designation, or upon the occurrence of any event which disqualifies the appointee or designee from holding public office under the laws of Illinois or the general ordinances of the village of Wheeling. Vacancies may be declared by the commission or by the appointing or designating authority. 
(g)  Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the vacated term by the appropriate appointing or designating authority, the same as for a new appointment. Except as may otherwise be provided by law or by general ordinance, current or previous members of the commission may be appointed or designated to successive or subsequent terms, or to fill vacated terms, so long as qualified at the time of such appointment or designation. However, no member of the commission may simultaneously fill more than one membership on the commission. 
(Ord. 4222 § 3, 2007; Ord. 3907 § 5 (part), 2004; Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 5012, §§ 2, 3, 6-6-2016) 
2.91.030 - Organization-Procedures. 
(a)  The commission shall annually elect from its voting membership a vice-chairperson and a secretary, for one-year terms, and may elect such other officers as the commission shall from time to time provide. All officers of the commission, including the chairperson, shall serve until their respective successors are elected and have taken office. Vacancies shall arise as in the case of memberships on the commission and shall be filled by election by the commission for the remainder of the term. 
(b)  A quorum of the commission shall be six voting members. The ex officio member may participate in all meetings and deliberations of the commission, but may not vote or make motions, and shall not be counted towards the presence of a quorum. 
(c)  The commission shall meet at least quarterly, and may establish a regular meeting schedule more frequently than quarterly. The commission may create such committees as it may find necessary, and may appoint nonmembers to serve on such committees, but all committees shall be chaired by a commission member and shall have at least one other commission member appointed thereto. An affirmative vote of at least four members shall be required to create a committee, and no committee shall continue for longer than one year unless extended by the same vote. 
(d)  The commission may adopt such rules for the conduct of its business, not inconsistent with the provisions of this Chapter and the general ordinances of the village, as it may from time to time find necessary or desirable. 
(Ord. 3907 § 5 (part), 2004; Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
(Ord. No. 4926, § A, 2-17-2015; Ord. No. 5012, § 4, 6-6-2016) 
2.91.040 - Powers-Duties. 
    The senior citizens commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  To determine the needs and concerns of senior citizens residing within and near the village, including housing, employment, education, income, recreation, physical and mental health, nutrition, transportation, legal aid, retirement roles and activities, and to make findings and recommendations to the president and board of trustees in connection therewith; 
(b)  To receive, evaluate and analyze complaints of senior citizens residing within the village, and to make findings and recommendations to the village manager and the president and board of trustees in connection therewith; 
(c)  To review, evaluate and analyze programs, services and facilities of the village which are directed at or which significantly affect senior citizens residing within the village, and to make findings and recommendations to the village manager and the president and board of trustees in connection therewith; 
(d)  To make such studies and to develop such programs, recommendations, or findings as may from time to time be requested by the president and board of trustees; 
(e)  To review, evaluate and analyze programs, services and facilities which are operated, administered or funded by other governmental agencies, and which are intended to serve or benefit or which significantly affect senior citizens within the village, and to make findings and recommendations to the president and board of trustees and to such other governmental agency in connection therewith; 
(f)  To consult and cooperate with the departments, agencies and commissions of the village, as requested thereby or by the village manager, on matters of concern to senior citizens within the village; 
(g)  To consult and cooperate with and to advise other governmental agencies in connection with the planning and development or programs, services or facilities intended to serve or benefit or which will significantly affect senior citizens within the village, and to make findings and recommendations to such agency in connection therewith; 
(h)  To develop and recommend programs to serve and benefit senior citizens in the village, including publicity and education; 
(i)  To serve generally as a representative and advocate for the senior citizens residing within the village; and 
(j)  To conduct public hearings, engage in research and studies, and otherwise obtain information and develop knowledge in connection with the foregoing responsibilities. 
    The commission shall not issue any reports, recommendations or findings, or conduct any hearings, in the name of the village of Wheeling in connection with any official action required to be taken by the village under any state or federal law or administrative rule or regulation, or under any private agency's requirements for a grant or other benefit, without the prior authorization of the president and board of trustees. Such authorization shall be made by resolution of the president and board of trustees, and may be temporary or permanent. The commission may, however, submit requests for such authorization to the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.91.050 - Reports. 
    The senior citizens commission shall submit an annual report to the president and board of trustees during the month of June. The annual report shall summarize the activities of the commission for the preceding fiscal year of the village, and shall contain such recommendations and information as the commission finds appropriate, and such matters as have been requested by the president and board of trustees. The commission shall submit such other reports as are from time to time appropriate or required by the president and board of trustees. All reports shall be in writing, and shall be adopted by a majority of the members then serving. Any member of the commission may submit a concurring or dissenting report with respect to any finding or recommendation made in a commission report. All reports shall be public records and copies shall be retained in the official village records. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
2.91.060 - Expenses. 
(a)  Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. The commission shall have such staff assistance, and such compensated technical advisors and services as may be authorized by the village manager with the approval of the president and board of trustees. The commission shall not have the authority to expend funds or to obligate the village of Wheeling in any manner. Any funds appropriated or budgeted by the village for the use of the commission shall be expended only upon the approval of the village manager, the village treasurer, and the president. 
(b)  The commission may, with the approval of the president and board of trustees, apply for grants or other funding from governmental and private agencies for the commission's purposes and functions as specified in this chapter. Any such application shall be in the name of the village of Wheeling and shall be subject to the administration and fiscal controls of the village unless the terms of such grant or other funding require that it be in the name of the commission and made directly to the commission. In such event, if the president and board of trustees approve the application, and if funds are received pursuant thereto, the village treasurer shall hold such funds for the account of the commission, and shall make expenditures therefrom at the direction of the commission. 
(Ord. 1698 § A (part), 1980) 
Chapter 2.92 - DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Section A of Ord. No. 4596, adopted March 21, 2011, amended Ch. 2.92, Department of Senior Citizen Services, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 2.92 derived from Ord. No. 3398, adopted in 1999.

    There is established a department of the village which shall be known as the department of human services. The department shall consist of operational divisions as determined by the village manager and as established by the village budget. 
(Ord. No. 4596, § A, 3-21-2011) 
2.92.020 - Director of human services-Personnel of department. 
    There is established the position of director of human services, who shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. All department of human services personnel shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 4596, § A, 3-21-2011)
