    The department of human services shall be responsible for the operation of the senior citizen center. The department shall provide such services necessary to address the health, safety, and general well being of citizens as may be established in the village budget. 
(Ord. No. 4596, § A, 3-21-2011) 
Chapter 2.98 - CHICAGO EXECUTIVE AIRPORT BOARD OF DIRECTORS 

2.98.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Chapter shall be to provide for the membership and terms of those directors appointed to the Chicago Executive Airport board of directors by the village of Wheeling in accordance with the provisions of the intergovernmental agreement, dated July 1, 2005 between the village of Wheeling and the city of Prospect Heights for the organization, operation and maintenance of Chicago Executive Airport. 
(Ord. 4195 § A (part), 2007: Ord. 2641 § A (part), 1990) 
2.98.020 - Membership and terms. 
(a)  The president of the board of trustees with the advice and consent of the members of the board of trustees shall appoint three members to the Chicago Executive Airport Board of Directors in accordance with the Intergovernmental Agreement between the village of Wheeling and the city of Prospect Heights dated July 1, 2005, as amended. Appointments shall be made on the basis of particular fitness for service on the Chicago Executive Airport Board of Directors and may include a member of the board of trustees and/or the village manager. 
(b)  The term for members of the Chicago Executive Airport board of directors appointed by the village of Wheeling shall be as set forth in the intergovernmental agreement between the village of Wheeling and the city of Prospect Heights dated July 1, 2005. Members appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall be residents of the village. 
(c)  A chairman of the airport board shall be appointed by the joint decision of the Wheeling village president and the Prospect Heights mayor. The Wheeling village president's selection of the chairman of the airport board is subject to the advice and consent of the members of the Wheeling board of trustees. 
(d)  Membership on the Chicago Executive Airport board of directors shall be at the discretion of the president and board of trustees and members shall be subject to removal by adoption of a resolution of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. 4195 § A (part), 2007: Ord. 2641 § A (part), 1990) 
(Ord. No. 4470, § A, 10-19-2009; Ord. No. 4472, § A, 11-16-2009; Ord. No. 5105, § A, 8-7-2017) 
Chapter 2.99 - WHEELING/DES PLAINES JOINT EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD 

2.99.010 - Authority. 
    This chapter is enacted under the authority of the Emergency Telephone System Act, 50 ILCS 750/0.01 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 5083, § 2, 4-17-2017) 
2.99.020 - Purpose. 
    This chapter is enacted for the purpose of creating a joint emergency telephone system board. The intent of this system is to allow any telephone located within the village of Wheeling and connected to the public telephone network access to emergency services by dialing the numbers 9-1-1. 
(Ord. No. 5083, § 2, 4-17-2017) 
2.99.030 - Availability. 
    The features offered by the emergency telephone answering system shall be available twenty-four hours per day, seven days per week. 
(Ord. No. 5083, § 2, 4-17-2017) 
2.99.040 - Administration. 
    The village's emergency telephone answering system shall be administered by a joint emergency telephone system board ("JETSB") established pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement with the city of Des Plaines, approved by a duly adopted resolution of the village board on April 17, 2017. 
(Ord. No. 5083, § 2, 4-17-2017) 
2.99.050 - Funding. 
    If authorized by 50 ILCS 750/15.3, the village of Wheeling shall impose a surcharge on monthly billed subscribers of telecommunication carriers at a rate per network connection in order to implement and maintain a 9-1-1 emergency telephone system. 
    A surcharge is hereby imposed on monthly billed subscribers of telecommunications carriers residing within the corporate limits of the village at a rate of zero dollars per month, per network connection. Said surcharge shall be collected by the telecommunications carriers. For purposes of computing the surcharge imposed, the network connections to which the surcharge shall apply shall be those in-service network connections, other than those network connections assigned to the city, where the subscriber service address for each such network connection(s) is located within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Each telecommunication carrier is hereby authorized and instructed to deduct and retain three percent of the gross amount of the surcharge collected, prior to remittance, for reimbursement of the expense of accounting and collecting said surcharge. All monies collected from the 9-1-1 surcharge shall be deposited into an interest bearing bank account known as the emergency telephone system fund administered by the director of finance; however, said monies collected shall not include the above reimbursement. The account shall be administered in accordance with the bylaws of the joint emergency telephone system board. All such monies shall be used to fund enhanced 9-1-1 communication services in compliance with the Illinois emergency telephone system act, 50 ILCS 750/0.01 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 5083, § 2, 4-17-2017) 
2.99.060 - Severability. 
    If any section, provision or portion of this Chapter shall be adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this Chapter shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 5083, § 2, 4-17-2017) 
Title 4 - TAXES, BUSINESS REGULATIONS AND LICENSES* 
Chapter 4.00 - TAXPAYER'S RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES 

4.00.010 - Scope. 
    The provisions of this Chapter shall apply to the village's procedures in connection with all of the village's locally imposed and administered taxes. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.020 - Definitions. 
    Certain words or terms herein shall have the meaning ascribed to them as follows: 
    "Act" means the "Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act." 
    "Corporate authorities" means the president and board of trustees of the village of Wheeling. 
    "Locally imposed and administered tax" or "tax" means each tax imposed by the village that is collected or administered by the village, not an agency or department of the state. It does not include any taxes imposed upon real property under the property tax code or fees collected by the village other than infrastructure maintenance fees. 
    Local Tax Administrator. The director of finance is charged with the administration and collection of the locally imposed and administered taxes, including staff, employees or agents to the extent they are authorized by the local tax administrator to act in the local tax administrator's stead. The local tax administrator shall have the authority to implement the terms of this Chapter to give full effect to this Chapter. The exercise of such authority by the local tax administrator shall not be inconsistent with this Chapter and the Act. 
    "Village" means the village of Wheeling, Illinois. 
    "Notice" means each audit notice, collection notice or other similar notice or communication in connection with each of the village's locally imposed and administered taxes. 
    "Tax ordinance" means each ordinance adopted by the village that imposes any locally imposed and administered tax. 
    "Taxpayer" means any person required to pay any locally imposed and administered tax and generally includes the person upon whom the legal incidence of such tax is placed and with respect to consumer taxes includes the business or entity required to collect and pay the locally imposed and administered tax to the village. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.030 - Notices. 
    Unless otherwise provided, whenever notice is required to be given, the notice is to be in writing mailed not less than seven calendar days prior to the day fixed for any applicable hearing, audit or other scheduled act of the local tax administrator. The notice shall be sent by the local tax administrator as follows: 
(a)  First class or express mail, or overnight mail, addressed to the persons concerned at the persons' last known address; or 
(b)  Personal service or delivery. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.040 - Late payment. 
    Any notice, payment, remittance or other filing required to be made to the village pursuant to any tax ordinance shall be considered late unless it is (a) physically received by the village on or before the due date, or (b) received in an envelope or other container displaying a valid, readable U.S. postmark dated on or before the due date, properly addressed to the village, with adequate postage prepaid. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.050 - Payment. 
    Any payment or remittance received for a tax period shall be applied in the following order: (1) first to the tax due for the applicable period; (2) second to the interest due for the applicable period; and (3) third to the penalty for the applicable period. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.060 - Certain credits and refunds. 
(a)  The village shall not refund or credit any taxes voluntarily paid without written protest at the time of payment in the event that a locally imposed and administered tax is declared invalidly enacted or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction. However, a taxpayer shall not be deemed to have paid the tax voluntarily if the taxpayer lacked knowledge of the facts upon which to protest the taxes at the time of payment or if the taxpayer paid the taxes under duress. 
(b)  No claim for credit or refund shall be granted unless the claim has been filed with the village within four years after the end of the calendar year in which payment in error was made. The village shall not grant a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes, interest, or penalties to a person who has not paid the amounts directly to the village. 
(c)  The procedure for claiming a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes, interest or penalties paid in error shall be as follows: 
(1)  The taxpayer shall submit to the local tax administrator in writing a claim for credit or refund together with a statement specifying: 
(A)  The name of the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim; 
(B)  The tax period for the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim; 
(C)  The date of the tax payment subject to the claim and the cancelled check or receipt for the payment; 
(D)  The taxpayer's recalculation, accompanied by an amended or revised tax return, in connection with the claim; and 
(E)  A request for either a refund or a credit in connection with the claim to be applied to the amount of tax, interest and penalties overpaid, and, as applicable, related interest on the amount overpaid; provided, however, that there shall be no refund and only a credit given in the event the taxpayer owes any monies to the village. 
(2)  Within thirty days of the receipt by the local tax administrator of any claim for a refund or credit, the local tax administrator shall either: 
(A)  Grant the claim; or 
(B)  Deny the claim, in whole or in part, together with a statement as to the reason for the denial or the partial grant and denial. 
(3)  In the event the local tax administrator grants, in whole or in part, a claim for refund or credit, the amount of the grant for refund or credit shall bear interest at the rate of five percent per annum, based on a year of three hundred sixty-five days and the number of days elapsed, from the date of the overpayment to the date of mailing of a refund check or the grant of a credit. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.070 - Audit procedure. 
(a)  Any request for proposed audit pursuant to any local administered tax shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The tax; 
(2)  The time period of the audit; and 
(3)  A brief description of the books and records to be made available for the auditor. 
(b)  Any audit shall be conducted during normal business hours and if the date and time selected by the local tax administrator is not agreeable to the taxpayer, another date and time may be requested by the taxpayer within thirty days after the originally designated audit and during normal business hours. 
(c)  The taxpayer may request an extension of time to have an audit conducted. The audit shall be conducted not less than seven days nor more than thirty days from the date the notice is given, unless the taxpayer and the local tax administrator agreed to some other convenient time. In the event the taxpayer is unable to comply with the audit on the date in question, the taxpayer may request another date within the thirty days, approved in writing, that is convenient to the taxpayer and the local tax administrator. 
(d)  Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records of the taxpayer's business or activities, including original source documents and books of entry denoting the transactions which had given rise or may have given rise to any tax liability, exemption or deduction. All books shall be kept in the English language and shall be subject to and available for inspection by the village. 
(e)  It is the duty and responsibility of every taxpayer to make available its books and records for inspection by the village. If the taxpayer fails to provide the documents necessary for audit within the time provided, the local tax administrator may issue a tax determination and assessment based on the tax administrator's determination of the best estimate of the taxpayer's tax liability. 
(f)  If an audit determines there has been an overpayment of a locally imposed and administered tax as a result of the audit, written notice of the amount of overpayment shall be given to the taxpayer within thirty days of the village's determination of the amount of overpayment. 
(g)  In the event a tax payment was submitted to the incorrect local governmental entity, the local tax administrator shall notify the local governmental entity imposing such tax. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.080 - Appeal. 
(a)  The local tax administrator shall send written notice to a taxpayer upon the local tax administrator's issuance of a protestable notice of tax due, a bill, a claim denial, or a notice of claim reduction regarding any tax. The notice shall include the following information: 
(1)  The reason for the assessment; 
(2)  The amount of the tax liability proposed; 
(3)  The procedure for appealing the assessment; and 
(4)  The obligations of the village during the audit, appeal, refund and collection process. 
(b)  A taxpayer who receives written notice from the local tax administrator of a determination of tax due or assessment may file with the local tax administrator a written protest and petition for hearing, setting forth the basis of the taxpayer's request for a hearing. The written protest and petition for hearing must be filed with the local tax administrator within forty-five days of receipt of the written notice of the tax determination and assessment. 
(c)  If a timely written notice and petition for hearing is filed, the local tax administrator shall fix the time and place for hearing and shall give written notice to the taxpayer. The hearing shall be scheduled for a date within thirty days of receipt of the written protest and petition for hearing, unless the taxpayer requests a later date convenient to all parties. 
(d)  If a written protest and petition for hearing is not filed within the forty-five-day period, the tax determination, audit or assessment shall become a final bill due and owing without further notice. 
(e)  Upon the showing of reasonable cause by the taxpayer and the full payment of the contested tax liability along with interest accrued as of the due date of the tax, the local tax administrator may reopen or extend the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing. In no event shall the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing be reopened or extended for more than ninety days after the expiration of the forty-five-day period. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.090 - Hearing. 
(a)  Whenever a taxpayer or a tax collector has filed a timely written protest and petition for hearing as required in this Chapter, the local tax administrator shall conduct a hearing regarding any appeal. 
(b)  No continuances shall be granted except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the taxpayer. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance granted shall not exceed fourteen days. 
(c)  At the hearing the local tax administrator shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the tax determination, audit or assessment. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply. 
(d)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the local tax administrator shall make a written determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing. The taxpayer or tax collector shall be provided with a copy of the written decision. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.100 - Interest and penalties. 
    In the event a determination has been made that a tax is due and owing, through audit, assessment or other bill sent, the tax must be paid within the time frame otherwise indicated. 
(a)  Interest. The village hereby provides for the amount of interest to be assessed on a late payment, underpayment, or nonpayment of the tax, to be six percent per annum, based on a year of three hundred sixty-five days and the number of days elapsed. 
(b)  Late Filing and Payment Penalties. If a tax return is not filed within the time and manner provided by the controlling tax ordinance, a late filing penalty, of five percent of the amount of tax required to be shown as due on a return shall be imposed; and a late payment penalty of five percent of the tax due shall be imposed. If no return is filed within the time or manner provided by the controlling tax ordinance and prior to the village issuing a notice of tax delinquency or notice of tax liability, then a failure to file penalty shall be assessed equal to twenty-five percent of the total tax due for the applicable reporting period for which the return was required to be filed. A late filing or payment penalty shall not apply if a failure to file penalty is imposed by the controlling ordinance. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.110 - Abatement. 
    The local tax administrator shall have the authority to waive or abate any late filing penalty, late payment penalty or failure to file penalty if the local tax administrator shall determine reasonable cause exists for delay or failure to make a filing. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.120 - Installment contracts. 
    The village may enter into an installment contract with the taxpayer for the payment of taxes under the controlling tax ordinance. The local tax administrator may not cancel any installment contract so entered unless the taxpayer fails to pay any amount due and owing. Upon written notice by the local tax administrator that the payment is thirty days delinquent, the taxpayer shall have fourteen working days to cure any delinquency. If the taxpayer fails to cure the delinquency within the fourteen-day period or fails to demonstrate good faith in restructuring the installment contract with the local administrator, the installment contract shall be canceled without further notice to the taxpayer. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.130 - Statute of limitations. 
(a)  The village, through the local tax administrator, shall review all tax returns in a prompt and timely manner and inform taxpayers of any amounts due and owing. The taxpayer shall have forty-five days after receiving notice of the reviewed tax returns to make any request for refund or provide any tax still due and owing. 
(b)  No determination of tax due and owing may be issued more than four years after the end of the calendar year for which the return for the applicable period was filed or for the calendar year in which the return for the applicable period was due, whichever occurs later. 
(c)  If any tax return is not filed or if during any four-year period for which a notice of tax determination or assessment may be issued by the village, the tax paid was less than seventy-five percent of the tax due, the statute of limitations shall be six years maximum after the end of the calendar year in which return for the applicable period was due or end of the calendar year in which the return for the applicable period was filed. 
(d)  No statute of limitations shall apply if a fraudulent tax return was filed by the taxpayer. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.140 - Voluntary disclosure. 
    For any locally imposed and administered tax for which a taxpayer has not received a written notice of an audit, investigation, or assessment from the local tax administrator, a taxpayer is entitled to file an application with the local tax administrator for a voluntary disclosure of the tax due. A taxpayer filing a voluntary disclosure application must agree to pay the amount of tax due, along with interest of one percent per month, for all periods prior to the filing of the application but not more than four years before the date of filing the application. A taxpayer filing a valid voluntary disclosure application may not be liable for any additional tax, interest, or penalty for any period before the date the application was filed. However, if the taxpayer incorrectly determined and underpaid the amount of tax due, the taxpayer is liable for the underpaid tax along with applicable interest on the underpaid tax, unless the underpayment was the result of fraud on the part of the taxpayer, in which case the application shall be deemed invalid and void. The payment of tax and interest must be made by no later than ninety days after the filing of the voluntary disclosure application or the date agreed to by the local tax administrator. However, any additional amounts owed as a result of an underpayment of tax and interest previously paid under this section must be paid within ninety days after a final determination and the exhaustion of all appeals of the additional amount owed or the date agreed to by the local tax administrator, whichever is longer. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.150 - Publication of tax ordinances. 
    Any locally administered tax ordinance shall be published via normal or standard publishing requirements. The posting of a tax ordinance on the Internet shall satisfy the publication requirements. Copies of all tax ordinances shall be made available to the public upon request at the village clerk's office. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.160 - Tax liens. 
    The local tax administrator shall establish an internal review procedure regarding any liens filed against any taxpayers for unpaid taxes. Upon a determination by the local tax administrator that the lien is valid, the lien shall remain in full force and effect. If the lien is determined to be improper, the local tax administrator shall: 
(a)  Timely remove the lien at the village's expense; 
(b)  Correct the taxpayer's credit record; and 
(c)  Correct any public disclosure of the improperly imposed lien. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
4.00.170 - Application. 
    This Chapter shall be liberally construed and administered to supplement all of the village's tax ordinances. To the extent that any tax ordinance is in conflict with or inconsistent with this Chapter, this Chapter shall be controlling. 
(Ord. 3511 § B (part), 2000) 
Chapter 4.01 - SIMPLIFIED MUNICIPAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4508, adopted April 5, 2010, amended Ch. 4.01, Municipal Telecommunications Tax, §§ 4.01.010-4.01.110, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 4.01 derived from Ord. 3154 adopted in 1996. 

4.01.010 - Definitions. 
    The village of Wheeling adopts herein all relevant definitions of the Illinois Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax Act, codified at 35 ILCS 636/5-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 4508, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
4.01.020 - Simplified municipal telecommunications tax imposed. 
    A simplified municipal telecommunications tax is hereby imposed pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax Act, codified at 35 ILCS 636/5-1 et seq., as amended from time to time, at a rate of six percent. 
(Ord. No. 4508, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
4.01.030 - Collection from consumer and payment of tax by retailers. 
    The tax authorized by this Chapter shall be collected from consumers and paid according to the provisions of the Illinois Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax Act, codified at 35 ILCS 636/5-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 4508, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
4.01.040 - Collection and enforcement. 
    The tax imposed by this Chapter shall be collected and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue as provided by the Illinois Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax Act, codified at 35 ILCS 636/5-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. The Illinois Department of Revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4508, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
4.01.050 - Severability. 
    If any provision of this Chapter, or the application of any provision of this Chapter, is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such occurrence shall not affect other provisions of this Chapter, or their application, that can be given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or its application. Each unconstitutional or invalid provision, or application of such provision, is severable, unless otherwise provided by this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4508, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
4.01.060 - Effective date. 
    This Chapter does not impose any new tax, but rather is reflective of the automatic conversion of the telecommunications tax and telecommunications infrastructure maintenance fee, that existed in this Code as of July 1, 2002, to the simplified municipal telecommunications tax, effective January 1, 2003, pursuant to the Simplified Municipal Telecommunications Tax Act, codified at 35 ILCS 636/5-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 4508, § 1, 4-5-2010) 
Chapter 4.02 - HOME RULE RETAILERS' AND SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX* 

4.02.010 - Imposition of tax. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail in this municipality at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this Chapter is in effect. 
(b)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the village in the business of making sales of service, at the rate of one percent of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. 
(c)  The above taxes shall not be applicable on the sales of food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food which has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics. 
(d)  The imposition of these home rule taxes are in accordance with the provisions of Sections 5/8-11-1 and 5/8-11-5, respectively, of the Illinois Municipal Code (Ch. 65, sec. 5/8-11-1 and 5/8-11-5, of Illinois Compiled Statutes, as amended). 
(Ord. 3999 §§ 1, 2, 2005; Ord. 357 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 3119 § A (part), 1996: Ord. 2904 § A (part), 1993) 
4.02.020 - Collection by Illinois Department of Revenue. 
    The taxes hereby imposed in this Chapter, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the state of Illinois. The Department of Revenue shall have the full power to administer and enforce the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 357 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 3119 § A (part), 1996: Ord. 2904 § A (part), 1993) 
4.02.030 - Chapter copy to state. 
    The village clerk is hereby directed to file a certified copy of the ordinance codified in this Chapter with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before the first day of October, 1996. 
(Ord. 357 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 3119 § A (part), 1996: Ord. 2904 § A (part), 1993) 
Chapter 4.03 - MUNICIPAL USE TAX 

4.03.010 - Imposition of tax. 
    A tax is imposed upon the privilege of using within the village of Wheeling any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside of Illinois, at retail, from a retailer, and which is required to be either titled or registered with an agency of the state of Illinois, at the rate of one percent of the selling price of such tangible personal property, as "selling price" is defined in the Use Tax Act, 35 ILCS 105/2. Such tax shall be collected from those persons whose address for titling or registration purposes is within the corporate boundaries of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 2302 § A (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § D, 4-25-2011) 
4.03.020 - Payment. 
    At the time such tangible property is titled or registered with the appropriate state agency, there shall be paid to the State Department of Revenue, the amount of the tax imposed by this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2302 § A (part), 1986) 
4.03.030 - Copy to State Department of Revenue. 
    The village clerk is directed to transmit to the State Department of Revenue a certified copy of the ordinance codified in this Chapter not later than five days after the effective date of said ordinance. 
(Ord. 2302 § A (part), 1986) 
Chapter 4.04 - MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX* 

4.04.010 - Imposition of tax. 
    A tax is imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality in the business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent of the cost price of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-11-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 1029 § 1, 1969: Ord. 915 § 1, 1967: Ord. 686 § 1, 1961) 
4.04.020 - Filing report. 
    Every supplier of servicemen required to account for the municipal service occupation tax for the benefit of this municipality shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of Revenue required by Section 9 of the "Service Occupation Tax Act," approved July 10, 1961, as amended. 
(Ord. 1029 § 2, 1969: Ord. 915 § 2, 1967: Ord. 686 § 2, 1961) 
4.04.030 - Payment. 
    At the time the report is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department of Revenue the amount of tax imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1029 § 3, 1969: Ord. 915 § 3, 1967: Ord. 686 § 3, 1967) 
4.04.040 - Chapter copy to State Department of Revenue. 
    The village clerk is directed to transmit to the State Department of Revenue a certified copy of this Chapter not later than five days after October 1, 1969. 
(Ord. 1029 § 4, 1969: Ord. 915 § 4, 1967) 
Chapter 4.05 - AUTOMOBILE RENTING USE TAX 

4.05.010 - Tax imposed. 
    A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in the village of Wheeling an automobile which is rented from a renter outside Illinois and which is titled or registered with an agency of Illinois government in the village of Wheeling, at the rate of one percent of the monthly rental price of such automobile for each month that this Chapter is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-11-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code (Chapter 24, § 8-11-8, Ill. Rev. Stat.). 
(Ord. 1832 § A (part), 1982) 
4.05.020 - Reporting required. 
    Every lessee of an automobile which is rented from a renter outside Illinois and which is titled or registered with an agency of Illinois government in the village of Wheeling shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of Revenue required by Sections Two and Three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption," approved June 29, 1933, as amended. 
(Ord. 1832 § A (part), 1982) 
4.05.030 - Collection and payment. 
(a)  The tax provided for in this Chapter shall be collected from the person or entity whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being in the village of Wheeling. 
(b)  At the time each report required in Section 4.05.020 is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Ord. 1832 § A (part), 1982)

Rev. Stat.).

Chapter 4.08 - LICENSES AND PERMITS* 

4.08.010 - Applications. 
    Applications for all licenses and permits required by chapter shall be made in writing to the director of community development in the absence of provision to the contrary. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be paid. Each application shall also contain such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the village officials in the issuing of the permit or license. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.020 - License required. 
(a)  It is unlawful to operate, use or permit the use of any business or business operated from a vehicle in the village without first having obtained a license from the director of community development. 
(b)  Whenever in this code a license is required for the maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business of engaging in any activity or occupation, any person, firm or corporation shall be subject to the requirement, if, by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, he or it is engaged in operating the business or occupation; or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any part of such business or occupation in the village. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.025 - Zoning and occupancy certificate required. 
    The following businesses and all businesses permitted as home occupations per Title 19 of the Wheeling Municipal Code are exempt from the license provisions of this Chapter. Such businesses shall be required to apply for a zoning and occupancy certificate with community development department to confirm that the zoning for the subject location allows the proposed business type, and that the proposed building is designed for the occupancy class as defined in the building code. The fee for obtaining such certificate shall be as provided in Title 1, Chapter 26, schedule of fees. A zoning and occupancy certificate is required for the following business and all permitted home occupations: 
(a)  Architectural practice 
(b)  Attorney 
(c)  Barber (license needed to sell products) 
(d)  Beauty culturalist and cosmetologist (license needed to sell products) 
(e)  Business and vocational school 
(f)  Certified shorthand reporter 
(g)  Dental surgery and dentistry 
(h)  Detection of deception examiner 
(i)  Detective and detective agency 
(j)  Insurance broker 
(k)  Land surveyor 
(l)  Medical practice 
(m)  Nursing 
(n)  Nursing home administrator 
(o)  Optometric practice 
(p)  Pharmacy practice 
(q)  Podiatry practice 
(r)  Professional engineering 
(s)  Psychologist's registration 
(t)  Public accounting 
(u)  Real estate broker and salesman 
(v)  Security guard and watchman 
(w)  Social worker's registration 
(x)  Structural engineering 
(y)  Tree expert 
(z)  Veterinarian 
(aa)  Waterwell and pump installation contractor 
    Any business activity which is conducted on the premises of the above which is not exempt and is subject to this Chapter shall be licensed accordingly. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 5111, § 1, 9-5-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5111, § 1, adopted Sept. 5, 2017, changed the title of § 4.08.025 from "Exempt businesses" to read as herein set out. 
4.08.030 - Forms. 
    Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor, shall be prepared and kept on file by the director of community development. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.040 - Signatures. 
    Each license or permit issued shall bear the signatures of the village president and director of community development. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.050 - Investigations-License denial. 
(a)  Zoning Review and Property Inspections. Upon receipt of an application for a license or permit the director of community development shall refer such application to the proper individual(s) for making any required investigation or inspection determined by the director to be necessary in conjunction with the license or permit. The individual charged with the duty of making the inspection shall make a report, favorable or otherwise, after receiving the application or a copy thereof. Municipal code violations observed in the process of such investigations may be forwarded to the health and property maintenance division for code enforcement. 
1.  The zoning administrator shall determine whether the proposed business is permitted by the zoning regulations for the subject property. 
2.  The health officer shall make or cause to be made an inspection in regard to such licenses in connection with the preparation and handling of food and the preventing of nuisances and the spread of disease for the protection of health. 
3.  The building inspector(s) shall make or cause to be made any inspections relative to the construction of buildings or other structures. 
4.  The fire inspector shall make any inspections necessary to assure compliance with the local and state fire regulations. 
5.  The engineering inspector shall make any inspections relative to the condition of the parking lots, sidewalks, walkways, stairs, and ramps serving the subject location. 
(b)  Background Checks for Specified Business Types. For applications submitted for the following specified business types the chief of police or his designee will complete a background check, including fingerprinting of the applicant or new owner(s) (if the applicant is a partnership, limited liability company, or corporation, the police chief shall have the right to require fingerprints of any or all stockholders, directors, partners, members, managers or agents of the entity). Any change in ownership of a currently licensed business shall be reported to the director of community development in writing within five days of such change. Notice to the director of finance shall include the name(s) and address(es) of any individual who has not been previously reported as an owner and who has acquired any ownership interest in the entity. At the time of application or upon notice of a change in ownership, the applicant or licensee will pay a fee to the village in an amount determined by the village to cover the actual cost of the background check, including fingerprinting. The following categories of businesses shall be subject to a background check as described in this section: 
1.  Businesses requiring a liquor license. 
2.  Massage therapists. 
3.  Businesses providing childcare services or caring for children in the absence of a parent or guardian. 
4.  Businesses engaged in the acquisition and resale or disposal of personal property (salvage, pawn brokers, cash for gold, etc.). 
5.  Other businesses similar in nature to the above listed business types with respect to the potential for risk to the general public. 
(c)  When the investigation reveals the existence of any of the following circumstances, the director of community development may recommend that the village manager deny the license. The severity of the violation and the risk to the public shall be considered in making a recommendation for denial. The applicant shall be notified of the license denial. 
1.  The location of the business does not comply with the zoning ordinance or any other ordinance of the village of Wheeling. 
2.  The building or premises does not comply with the building code. 
3.  The applicant, building or premises does not comply with all local or state health, fire or safety codes. 
4.  The applicant has failed to comply with any applicable provisions of the Wheeling Municipal Code or has failed to pay any fine, penalty or debt owing to the village. 
5.  The applicant has failed to comply with any applicable state law or administrative regulation or has failed to receive a necessary license or permit from the state. 
6.  The applicant operated a business or activity within a previous year without a business license when such license was required. This requirement shall be waived if the applicant pays all past due license fees and penalties. 
7.  The applicant or if a partnership or corporation, any stockholder of a closely held corporation, director, member of the partnership, manager or agent: 
a.  Has been convicted of a felony or crime of moral turpitude within the last five years; 
b.  Has committed any fraud or material misrepresentation; 
c.  Has made a material false or misleading statement in the application for business license or any other required documentation; 
d.  Has violated any ordinances, laws or regulations relating to the license, the subject matter of the license or the premises to be occupied by the licensee; 
e.  Has refused to allow authorized village personnel to enter his business premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of making a pre-license investigation or has interfered with the inspection. 
f.  Has failed to pay any fine, penalty or debt owing the village. 
(Ord. 4280 § A, 2007: Ord. 3486 § A, 2000: Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 4592, § D, 3-21-2011; Ord. No. 5111, § 2, 9-5-2017) 
4.08.060 - Fees. 
    All fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is made to the director of community development. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 4965, § E, 11-23-2015) 
4.08.070 - Termination of license. 
    All annual licenses shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal year of the village where they are issued, where no provision to the contrary is made. The director of community development shall mail to all licensees of the village an application for license renewal, if an annual, three weeks prior to the date of such expiration. A failure to send out such notice, or the failure of the licensee to receive it shall not excuse the licensee from a failure to obtain a new license, or a renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in an action for operation without a license. In the event a licensee who has been licensed the previous year fails to obtain a license before May 1st of any year, the licensee shall pay to the director of community development, prior to the time the current license shall be issued, the sum of ten dollars as a late charge. In the event a licensee who has been licensed the previous year fails to obtain a license before June 1st of any year, the licensee shall pay to the director of community development, prior to the time the current license is issued, the sum of thirty dollars as a late charge, and thereafter litigation shall be instituted by the village for operating without the requisite business license. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.080 - Building and premises. 
    No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business and no permit shall be issued for any business activity, if the premises and building fail to comply with the requirements of Section 4.08.050, investigations -license denial. No such license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which would involve a use that is not permitted by the zoning ordinance of the village. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 5111, § 3, 9-5-2017) 
4.08.090 - Change of location. 
(a)  The location of any licensed business or occupation may be changed, provided, ten days' notice thereof is given to the director of community development; provided, that the building and zoning requirements of the ordinances have been complied with in their entirety. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.100 - Nuisances. 
    No business, or business activity, shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to a nuisance in fact. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.110 - Inspection. 
(a)  Whenever an inspection of the premises is required by ordinance, or is reasonably necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance or to detect any violation thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee, or the person in charge of the premises, to admit thereto any officer or employee of the village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(b)  Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure conformance with any ordinance or to detect any violation thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee or owner of the premises to grant access to any authorized officer or employee of the village requesting the same, to collect sufficient samples of such commodity or material for analysis. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the president may revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the village who wrongfully refuses to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make such inspection or take such sample to make the inspection, or take an adequate sample of the commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making such inspection provided, that no license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the premises, in the name of the village, stating that such inspection or sample is desired at the time it is sought to make the inspection or obtain the sample. Copies of reports noting violations shall be sent to the licensee by the reporting officer. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.120 - Suspension or revocation of business license. 
A.  Any business license may be suspended or revoked by the village president after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
1.  Any fraud or misrepresentation committed by the licensee; 
2.  Any false statement made in the application for the license; 
3.  Any violation by the licensee of any ordinances, laws or regulations relating to the license, the subject matter of the license, or to the premises occupied by the licensee; 
4.  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
5.  Failure of the licensee to pay any fine, penalty, or debt owing to the village; 
6.  Refusal of the licensee to permit an inspection or take a sample or interference with an authorized village officer or employee while in the performance of his duties in making inspections. 
B.  Any revocation shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other fines or penalties for the violation of village ordinances. 
C.  Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be personally served or sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing except in the case of an emergency. 
D.  For the purposes of this section, any act or omission committed by a director, officer, partner, agent or shareholder of more than twenty-five percent of stock in the licensee shall be deemed to have been committed by the licensee. 
(Ord. 4280 § B, 2007; Ord. 3000 § A, 1994: Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.125 - Emergency suspension of business license. 
    The village manager may temporarily suspend a business license if conditions are such that a continuation of the business would constitute a hazard to the health or safety of the public. Such suspension shall continue until the hazard is abated. 
(Ord. 3000 § B (part), 1994) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.128 - Appeal of suspension or revocation. 
    A licensee shall have the right to appeal a suspension or revocation of a business license to the corporate authorities. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the village clerk, within ten days after notice of a suspension or a revocation, a written statement, under oath, setting forth specifically the grounds for appeal. The corporate authorities shall thereupon set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the licensee. The decision of the corporate authorities on such appeal shall be final. 
(Ord. 3000 § B (part), 1994) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.130 - Posting license. 
    It shall be the duty of any person conducting a business in the village to post a current village license for such business in a prominent place of the premises used for such business at all times. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.140 - Fees by classification. 
    The business or vehicle and the annual license fee required are as set forth in this section. A business license fee is required for each classification of business operated upon or from each premises. The annual fee for the below-referenced classifications of licenses are provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code: 
(A)  Food: 
(1)  Not for consumption on premises; 
(2)  For consumption on premises. 
(B)  Amusements in operation more than two months of the fiscal year within the corporate limits. 
(C)  Businesses other than those in "A" and "B", catering to the general public: 
(1)  Wholesale and retail sales; 
(2)  Hotels, motels, and similar type of living units; 
(3)  Personal services; 
(4)  Professional services; 
(5)  Taxicabs, limousines, etc. - Flat charge/per vehicle charge; 
(6)  Scavenger services; 
(7)  Other services to the general public; 
(8)  Sales of items designed or marketed for use with cannabis or other illegal drugs. 
(D)  Businesses other than those services exhibiting, displaying or selling directly to the general public. 
(E)  Temporary business to be in operation less than two months of the fiscal year (excluding those covered by class "G"). 
(F)  Coin-operated vending, catering and amusement machines: 
(1)  Cigarette, cigar and other tobacco products; 
(2)  Jukeboxes, other amusement devices (See Section 4.14.030); 
(3)  Machines dispensing potentially hazardous foods as defined in Chapter 5.18; 
(4)  Other coin-op general. 
(G)  Itinerant merchants, hawkers, peddlers, solicitors, canvassers, etc. (other than those covered by Class "E"): 
(1)  Ice cream and similar-type food "wagons" primarily for sale of products to the general public, either from public rights-of-way or from private property; 
(2)  Other food product "wagons" primarily for delivery of products to homes of village residents; 
(3)  Nonfood products "wagons" for sale of products to the general public, either from a public right-of-way or from private property, or for delivery of products to homes of village residents (does not include so-called parcel delivery trucks); 
(4)  Other. 
    (Note: These fees are in addition to vehicle license fees, etc.) 
(H)  Retail cigarette sales, other than vending machine. 
(I)  Retail alcoholic liquor sales: 
Classes A, B, C $2,500, $2,500 initial license fee Classes A-1, B-1, N $1,750, $1,750 initial license fee Class D $7,500, $10,000 initial license fee Class D-1 $5,000, $7,500 initial license fee Class D-2 $5,000, $10,000 initial license fee Class D-3 $3,500, $7,000 initial license fee Class D-4 An amount equal to ten percent of the annual license fee required for the license holder's primary liquor license Class E $1,000 Class F $1,500 Class G $900 Class H $5,000 Class I $50 per day not to exceed $300 Classs J $900 Class K $50 (one day only) Class L $50 per day not to exceed $150 Classes M, M-1 $2,500, $2,500 initial license fee Classes A-V, B-V, C-V $2,500, $2,500 plus $500 per video gaming terminal initial license fee Classes A-1-V, B-1-V, N-V $1,750, $1,750 plus $500 per video gaming terminal initial license fee Class E-V $1,000, $500 per gaming terminal initial license fee Class O $1,750, $2,500 initial license fee  
  
    The corporate authorities will review the fees set forth in this subsection, at a minimum, every third year following the date of passage of the ordinance codified in this section, on March 13, 2006, for the purposes of assessing the adequacy of said fees and the need for future increases. 
(Ord. 4243 § C, 2007; Ord. 4131 § A, 2006; Ord. 4063 § 1, 2006; Ord. 3426 § A, 1999: Ord. 2704 § A, 1991; Ord. 2687 § A, 1991: Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 4459, § A, 9-14-2009; Ord. No. 4545, § C, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 4578, § F, 1-3-2011; Ord. No. 4605, § 1, 4-25-2011; Ord. No. 4788, § E, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 4841, § F, 3-3-2014; Ord. No. 4856, § E, 5-5-2014; Ord. No. 4859, § A, 5-5-2014; Ord. No. 4927, § F, 2-17-2015, eff. 5-1-2015; Ord. No. 4975, § E, 12-21-2015) 
4.08.150 - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  Taxing bodies of federal, state or local governmental agencies, located within the corporate limits of the village, shall be exempt from the applicable provisions of this section upon application. 
(b)  The village health inspector may inspect the preparation of all foods used in vending machines at the facilities where the food is prepared, as well as inspecting the delivery vehicles. 
(c)  Any not-for-profit organization which has been issued a charter by the state of Illinois and which is located within the corporate limits of the village may be issued a temporary business license to be effective for not more than a total of sixty days per year. The village manager shall approve all applications for such a temporary license, but only after a copy of the state of Illinois charter of any not-for-profit organization has been filed with the village. The fee for such a temporary license shall be as provided in the schedule of village fees and charges as set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. The above-mentioned provision for temporary business licenses shall not apply to amusements regulated by Chapters 4.12 or 4.14. 
(Ord. 4131 § B, 2006; Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.08.160 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine as set forth in Chapter 1.24, Administrative Citations, of this code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2681 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4418, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 4965, § F, 11-23-2015) 
Chapter 4.09 - HOTEL OPERATORS OCCUPATION TAX 
(a)  "Hotel" and "motel" shall mean every building or structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to place of lodging, or lodging and food or apartments, or suites, or other accommodations are offered for a consideration to guests, in which ten or more rooms, apartments, or suites, or other accommodations are used for the lodging, or lodging and food, for such guests. Accommodations within said buildings or structures which are leased to the same occupant for a period of more than thirty consecutive days shall be exempt from the tax provisions of this subchapter. 
(b)  "Room" or "rooms" shall mean any living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. 
(c)  "Rent" or "rental" means the consideration received for occupancy, valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature. 
(d)  "Finance department" means the finance department of the village of Wheeling, Illinois. 
(e)  "Person" means any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, public or private corporation, limited liability company, or a receiver, executor, trustee, guardian or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
(Ord. 3632 § A (part), 2002) 

4.09.020 - Imposition-Rate. 
    A tax is herby levied and imposed upon the use and privilege of renting, leasing or letting of rooms in a motel or hotel in the village at a rate of six percent of the gross rental receipts from such rental, leasing or letting. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of said tax shall be borne by the user, lessee or tenant of said room(s). The tax herein levied shall be in addition to any and all other taxes. 
(Ord. 3632 § A (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 4489, § A, 12-21-2009) 
4.09.030 - Duty to collect tax from user. 
    The owner and operator of each hotel and or motel and the person to whom the license to operate said hotel or motel shall have been issued by the village, shall bear jointly and severally, the duty to collect the tax from each user, lessee or tenant of rooms in such hotel or motel. Every person required to collect the tax levied by ordinance shall secure said tax from the user, lessee or tenant of a room or rooms at the same time he collects the price, change or rent to which it applies. 
(Ord. 3632 § A (part), 2002) 
4.09.040 - Report-Remittance. 
(a)  The finance director hereby is designated as the administration and enforcement officer of the tax hereby imposed on behalf of the village. It shall be the responsibility and duty of the finance director to collect all amounts due the village from the owners and operators of motels and hotels in the village. 
    This tax shall be remitted to the village finance department monthly, on or before the first day of the second month (e.g. December taxes are due and owing on or before February 1) after the taxes have been collected. Such taxes shall be remitted when a completed report on forms supplied by the village less a one percent fee for the administration of collecting this tax. 
(b)  The finance director or any person certified by him as his deputy or representative may enter the premises of any hotel or motel for the purposes of inspection and examination of its books and records for the proper administration of this subchapter, and for the enforcement of collection of the tax hereby imposed. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder or interfere with the finance director or his duly authorized deputy or representative in the discharge of his duties hereunder. 
(Ord. 3632 § A (part), 2002) 
4.09.050 - Fine on outstanding balance. 
    In the event these funds are not remitted by the deadlines listed in Section 4.09.040, a fine of one and a half percent per month on the outstanding balance shall be added for each month the payment is delayed. 
(Ord. 3632 § A (part), 2002) 
4.09.060 - Maintaining books and records. 
    Every taxpayer required by Section 4.09.020 to pay the tax imposed by Chapter 4.09 to the village finance department shall keep accurate books and records of its business activity, including original source documents and books of entry denoting the transactions that gave rise, to any tax liability under Chapter 4.09. All such books and records shall be kept in the English language and, at all times during business hours of the day, shall be subject to and available for inspection and auditing by the village's finance department, or its authorized agent. 
(Ord. 3632 § A (part), 2002) 
4.09.070 - Enforcement license revocation. 
(a)  Whenever any person shall fail to pay any taxes herein provided, or when any owner, operator or licensee of a hotel or motel in the village shall fail to collect the tax hereby imposed from any person who has the ultimate liability for payment of the same, the village attorney shall, upon request of the finance director, bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce the payment of said tax on behalf of the village in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  If the village manager, after a hearing held by or for him, shall find that any hotel or motel owner, operator or licensee has willfully evaded his responsibility to collect the tax imposed by this subchapter, he may suspend or revoke all village licenses held by such tax evader. Said person shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, to be held not less than five days after notice of the time and place thereof, addressed to him at his last known place of business. Any suspension or conviction resulting from such hearing shall not relieve or discharge any civil liability for nonpayment of the tax due. 
(Ord. 3632 § A (part), 2002) 
Chapter 4.10 - SALE OF ITEMS DESIGNED OR MARKETED FOR USE WITH ILLEGAL CANNABIS OR DRUGS 

4.10.010 - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons as principal, clerk, agent, or servant to sell any items, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs, as defined by Illinois Compiled Statues, without obtaining a license therefor. Such licenses shall be in addition to any or all other licenses held by applicant. 
(Ord. 2065 § (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § E, 4-25-2011) 
4.10.020 - Application. 
    Application to sell any item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs shall be accompanied by affidavits by applicant and each and every employee authorized to sell such items that such person has never been convicted of a drug-related offense. 
(Ord. 2065 § A (part), 1984) 
4.10.030 - Minors. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or give items as described in Section 4.10.010 in any form to any male or female child under eighteen years of age. 
(Ord. 2065 § A (part), 1984) 
4.10.040 - Records. 
    Every licensee must keep a record of every item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs which is sold and this record shall be open to the inspection of any police officer at any time during the hours of business. Such record shall contain the name and address of the purchaser, the name and quantity of the product, the date and time of the sale, and the licensee or agent of the licensee's signature. Such records shall be retained for not less than two years. 
(Ord. 2065 § A (part), 1984) 
4.10.050 - Regulations. 
    The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the police department. 
(Ord. 2065 § A (part), 1984) 
4.10.060 - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of the ordinance codified in this Chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than five hundred dollars for the first offense and succeeding offenses during the same calendar year, and each day that such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. 2065 § A (part), 1984) 
Chapter 4.11 - MUNICIPAL GAS USE TAX 

4.11.010 - Short title. 
    The tax imposed by this Chapter shall be known as the "Municipal Gas Use Tax" and is imposed in addition to all other taxes imposed by the village of Wheeling, the state of Illinois, or any other municipal corporation or political subdivision thereof. 
(Ord. 3651 § A (part), 2002) 
4.11.020 - Definitions. 
    "Finance department" means the finance department of the village of Wheeling, Illinois. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
    "Public utility" means a public utility as defined in Section 3-105 of the Public Utilities Act. 
    "Public Utilities Act" means the Public Utilities Act as amended, (220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq. (1996)). 
    "Retail purchaser" means any person who purchases gas in a sale at retail. 
    "Sale at retail" means any sale of gas by a retailer to a person for use or consumption, and not for resale. For this purpose, the term "retailer" paeans any person engaged in the business of distribution, supplying, furnishing or selling gas. 
(Ord. 3651 § A (part), 2002) 
4.11.030 - Tax. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by this Chapter, a tax is imposed on the privilege of using or consuming gas in the village that is purchased in a sale at retail at the rate of five cents per therm. 
(b)  The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is on the retail purchaser, and nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to impose a tax on the occupation of distributing, supplying, wishing, selling or transporting gas. 
(c)  The retail purchaser shall pay the tax, measured by therms of gas delivered to the retail purchaser's premises, to the public utility designated to collect the tax pursuant to Section 4.11.050 of this Chapter on or before the payment due date of the public utility's bill first reflecting the tax, or directly to the village finance department on or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which the gas is delivered to the retail purchaser if no public utility has been designated to collect the tax pursuant to Section 4.11.050 or if the gas is delivered by a person other than a public utility so designated. 
(d)  Nothing in this Chapter 4.11 shall be construed to impose a tax upon any person, business or activity which, under the constitutions of the United States or State of Illinois, may not be made the subject of taxation by the village. 
(e)  A purchaser who purchases gas for resale and therefore does not pay the tax imposed by this Chapter with respect to the use or consumption of the gas, but who later uses or consumes part or all of the gas, shall pay the tax directly to the village finance department on or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which the gas is used or consumed. 
(f)  The tax shall apply to gas for which the delivery to the retail purchaser is billed by a public utility on or after September 1, 2002. 
(g)  If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this Chapter 4.11, whether as a result of mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be (i) credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this Chapter 4.11 from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment or (ii) subject to a refund if no such tax is due or to become due; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefore shall be so credited or refunded. 
(h)  No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this Chapter 4.11 shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such amount. 
(Ord. 3735 § A, 2003; Ord. 3660 § A (part), 2002; Ord. 3651 § A (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 4760, §§ A-C, 3-4-2013) 
4.11.040 - Government entity exemptions. 
    The tax shall not apply to any school district or state of Illinois unit of local government lying either in whole or in part within the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 3651 § A (part), 2002) 
4.11.050 - Collection of tax. 
    The village president is authorized to enter into a contract for collection of the tax imposed by this Chapter with any public utility providing gas service in the village. The contract shall include and substantially conform with the following provisions: 
(1)  The public utility will collect the tax with respect to gas delivered by it to its customers as an independent contractor; 
(2)  The public utility will remit collected taxes to the village treasurer no more often than once each month; 
(3)  The public utility will be entitled to withhold from tax collections a service fee not to exceed three percent of the amounts collected and timely remitted to the village finance department; 
(4)  The public utility shall not be liable to the village for any tax not actually collected from a retail purchaser; and 
(5)  Such additional terms as the parties may agree upon. 
(Ord. 3660 § A (part), 2002; Ord. 3651 § A (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 4760, § D, 3-4-2013) 
4.11.060 - Books and records. 
    Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records, including original source documents and books of entry, denoting the activities or transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise to any tax liability or exemption under this Chapter. All such books and records shall, at all times during business hours, be subject to and available for inspection by the village. 
(Ord. 3651 § A (part), 2002) 
Chapter 4.12 - AMUSEMENTS GENERALLY* 

4.12.010 - Definition. 
    The term "amusement" as used in this Chapter means and includes carnivals, circuses, menageries, festivals, fairs, trade shows, trade amusement or exhibitions, or traveling shows. The term "amusement" also means public dances, concerts, and athletic exhibitions to which an admission fee is charged. 
(Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.12.020 - License required-Exemption. 
(a)  It is unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement within the village without first having obtained a license as herein provided. No license shall be granted to any person under the age of twenty-one. 
(b)  No license shall be required or imposed upon any public dance, concert or athletic exhibition operated or conducted by an educational institution the proceeds of which, after the payment of reasonable expenses, inure exclusively to the benefit of said educational institution. 
(Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.12.030 - License-Application-Contents. 
    Applications for a license required under this Chapter shall be made to the director of finance at least thirty days prior to the first day of operation of the proposed amusement. The application shall be on a form furnished by the village and shall set forth: 
(a)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation or association, the name and address of all officers and the registered agent, the corporate address and the state of the incorporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of all partners; 
(b)  The nature of the amusement activity for which the license is sought; 
(c)  The name(s) and address(es) of the person(s) in intermediate charge of the amusement during its operation; 
(d)  The name of any sponsoring organization and the names and addresses of the principal officers of such organization; 
(e)  The date or dates of the proposed amusement and the location at which the amusement will be conducted; 
(f)  The number of mechanical riding devices, sideshows, exhibitions, concessions, animals or exhibitors which will be present at the amusement activity; 
(g)  The estimated number of persons attending the amusement activity; 
(h)  The nature and extent to which any food will be served; 
(i)  A layout plan indicating where each individual activity of the amusement will be located; 
(j)  A security plan indicating the nature and extent of the security to be provided for the amusement including the name and address or any private security service proposed for the rendering or security at the amusement; 
(k)  A statement that the licensee will directly control and supervise each activity proposed to be authorized under the license sought, and will be responsible for the conduct, operation and management thereof; 
(l)  A statement that the licensee has a standard public liability insurance policy or policies with an insurance company or companies authorized to do business in the state of Illinois and satisfactory to the village with coverage amounts sufficient to cover the risk associated with the particular amusement. Unless any other such amounts of insurance coverage are approved by the director of finance, the licensee shall provide evidence of insurance coverage in an amount of not less than one million dollars of general liability coverage, including coverage for body injury and property damage. The village shall be named as an additional insured on any such insurance policy or policies, and evidence of same shall be furnished to the village prior to the issuance of the license; 
(m)  A statement certifying on penalty of perjury the correctness of the information given on the application and agreeing on behalf of the proposed licensee that there shall be full compliance of the licensee with all state and village laws in the conduct of the activities for which a license may be granted; 
(n)  A statement that the applicant, as a condition of receiving a license, agrees to indemnify and save harmless the village from any liabilities arising out of its issuance. 
(Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 4592, § E, 3-21-2011) 
4.12.040 - License fees. 
(a)  Each application for an amusement license shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges as set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. 
(b)  In the event food is to be served at the amusement, the applicant shall pay an additional fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges as set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. This fee shall be known as the health inspection fee. 
(c)  In the event the amusement shall contain mechanical riding devices, the applicant shall pay an additional fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges as set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. This fee shall be known as the mechanical inspection fee. 
(Ord. 4131 § C, 2006; Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.12.050 - Bond requirement. 
    The licensee shall, in addition to payment of the license fees established by the village, deposit with the village not later than ten days prior to the first day of conducting any amusement activity and shall maintain for a period of two days after the termination of activities under such licenses as may be issued by the village, a cash bond in the sum of one thousand dollars, or in lieu thereof, shall post and maintain in full force and effect during said period, a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars. Such bond shall be issued by a surety company, approved by the village attorney, and shall be in a form approved by the village attorney. Such bond shall, by its terms: 
(a)  Ensure payment to the village for any damage to village property occasioned by the entrance into or exit from the village of the licensee or of the equipment, facilities, or personnel of such amusement activity as shall be permitted by the license; 
(b)  Ensure the cleaning of the premises used for the amusement and of the immediate surrounding properties and streets of such litter and debris as may result from the operation thereof; 
(c)  Ensure payment of any fines levied against the licensee for violation of this or any other section or state law while conducting the amusement in the village; 
(d)  Such bonds may be waived or reduced in amount or sooner cancelled or returned by the president and board of trustees when, in its reasonable judgment, the conditions of or reason for requiring such bonds have been satisfactorily met. The licensee shall be promptly notified of any claims made or contemplated against such bond or surety, and shall have the right to appeal from any such claim, or the amount thereof, to the village board. The decision of the president and board of trustees shall be final; 
(e)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to mean that the licensee is absolved from liability for sums in excess of one thousand dollars. 
(Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.12.060 - Amusement security. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to provide adequate crowd control and overall security for the amusement. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of an amusement license, the applicant shall meet with the police chief or his designee who shall determine the extent of the security and crowd control required for the amusement. Such determination shall be based upon criteria established by the chief of police for providing security and shall include the nature, location, size and layout of the amusement and the projected number of patrons thereto. 
(c)  Any security organization chosen to protect and ensure the public safety at the amusement shall be approved by the chief of police. 
(d)  A licensee may contract with the village for security service for the amusement at an agreed upon rate. 
(Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.12.070 - License denial. 
(a)  No license shall be granted for any amusement violating any state, local, or federal law or to any amusement which would endanger public peace, health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  The denial of any amusement license may be appealed to the president and board of trustees, who shall review the denial of said license at their next regular meeting. The president and board of trustees may affirm the denial or overrule same and order the issuance of the license. 
(Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.12.080 - Hours of operation. 
    No amusement shall operate except during the following hours: 
(a)  On weekdays between the hours as follows: 
(1)  School days, four p.m. and midnight; 
(2)  Nonschool days, one p.m. and midnight; 
(b)  On Saturday between nine a.m. and midnight: 
(c)  On Sunday and holidays, between noon and midnight. 
(Ord. 2077 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4419, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.12.090 - Games of skill. 
(a)  No licensee shall operate, maintain or permit to be maintained on any premises being occupied for any amusement for which a license has been granted under this Chapter, any gambling or any game of chance prohibited by state law or local ordinance. No game of skill or science shall be controlled, fixed or operated so as to substantially deceive the public as to the possibility of succeeding at such game or of winning any prize offered in connection therewith. The use of, or employing of, or permitting of capper, shills or of persons posing as players in connection with any amusement is prohibited.
