plus single 
rollaway 5 Kitchenette 1 room 3 Kitchenette 2 rooms 5  
    Except for properly equipped kitchenettes, no cooking, including the use of hot plates or other heating elements, shall be permitted in hotel rooms, nor shall cooking be permitted in any other area of the hotel, either inside or outside, except in a properly equipped kitchen under the control and jurisdiction of the owner or operator of said hotel. Outdoor grilling areas may be installed after plans for the area are submitted, reviewed and approved; permit is issued; and area is inspected and approved by Fire and Community Development inspectors. 
    Notices of the maximum number of persons which may occupy a room or unit shall be posted in each room or unit, as well as notice of the regulations relative to the prohibitions against cooking, the use of hot plates, or other heating elements. In the event of any violation of these regulations, the business owner must correct the violation within the time period written on the notice of violation report issued by inspectors. 
(Ord. 954 § A, 1968: prior 1956 Code § 296) 
(Ord. No. 4425, § A, 4-27-2009; Ord. No. 5014, § B, 6-6-2016) 
4.68.030 - Inspection fee. 
    It shall be the duty of every person maintaining or operating a hotel, as defined herein, to pay to the director of community development services annually an inspection fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, for each sleeping unit so maintained or operated. 
(Ord. 4131 § H, 2006: Ord. 1481 § II, 1977: Ord. 799, 1965: prior 1956 Code § 297) 
(Ord. No. 4425, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.68.040 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 954 § C, 1968: Ord. 799 § A (part), 1965) 
(Ord. No. 4425, § A, 4-27-2009) 
Chapter 4.72 - TAXICABS AND LIVERY VEHICLES* 

4.72.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this Chapter have the meanings set forth herein: 
(a)  "Owner," "operator," "applicant" or "licensee" means every person, firm, corporation, or association having the use or control of one or more taxicabs or livery vehicles as herein defined, including an association of taxicab owners or livery owners, together with all partners, shareholders, officers and directors where a firm, corporation, or association is involved. 
(b)  "Person" includes an individual, a corporation or other legal entity, a partnership, and any unincorporated association. 
(c)  "Taxicab" or "livery vehicles" means a motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire, having a seating capacity of less than eight persons and not operated on a fixed route. 
(d)  "Taximeter" means a meter instrument or device attached to a taxicab which measures mechanically the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based. 
(e)  "Waiting time" means the time when a taxicab is not in motion from the time of acceptance of a passenger or passengers to the time of discharge, but does not include any time that the taxicab is not in motion if due to any cause other than the request, act or fault of a passenger or passengers. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.020 - Business license required. 
(a)  No person, firm, corporation or association shall operate a taxicab upon the streets of the village without first obtaining an annual license from the director of community development. 
(b)  No person, firm, corporation or association shall operate a livery vehicle upon the streets of the village without first obtaining a license from the village in the same manner as hereinafter provided for licensing of taxicabs; provided, however, that no license shall be required for any livery vehicle not operating out of a garage or office in the village of Wheeling and already bearing a valid business license lawfully issued by another municipality. 
(c)  The annual license required by this Chapter shall be issued as of the village's fiscal year and shall be effective for such period of time unless sooner suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.030 - License card or plate. 
    The license to be issued by the director of finance as provided in this Chapter shall be in the form of a card or plate which shall contain the official license number of the taxicab or livery vehicle together with the date of inspections. Such card shall be signed by the director of finance and shall be of a distinctly different color each year and in the case of taxicabs, the license number assigned thereto shall in each case be the same as that issued to the vehicle for that year. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.040 - License fees. 
(a)  The annual fee for the license required by this Chapter shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. Whenever the number of taxicabs or livery vehicles so operated shall be increased during the license year, the licensee shall notify the village of such change and shall pay the additional fee as required. 
(b)  It is expressly provided that the payment of any vehicle tax as required by other ordinances of the village does not entitle the owner of such vehicle to engage in the taxicab or livery business without first complying with the provisions of this Chapter and payment of the fees herein provided. 
(c)  The license issued hereunder shall not be sold, assigned, mortgaged, pledged or otherwise transferred. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.050 - Applications to be made to village. 
    Applications for licenses for taxicabs or livery vehicles shall be made to the village by the owner or operator upon blank forms to be furnished by the village. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.060 - Application information. 
(a)  An application for licenses for taxicabs or livery vehicles shall be made in writing, verified under oath, to the director of community development, upon forms provided by the village, accompanied by the required license fee. The application shall contain the following information (where the applicant is a partnership, corporation, or association, the applicable information shall be given as to all partners, shareholders, officers and directors): 
(1)  The full name and address of applicant; 
(2)  The financial status of applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments and claims against applicant and the nature of the transactions or acts giving rise to said judgments and claims; 
(3)  The previous business experience of applicant in the transportation of passengers, including a list of all municipalities in which the applicant is licensed; 
(4)  Any facts which applicant believes tend to prove that public convenience and necessity require the granting of the licenses applied for; 
(5)  The name of the company issuing public liability policy as required by state law; 
(6)  The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by applicant, the location of proposed depots and terminals, a complete description of each vehicle for which a license is desired, including kind and make of vehicle, the length of time vehicle has been in use, motor and serial number, seating capacity (excluding driver's seat or any part thereof), state license number, car number, color of vehicle and horsepower; 
(7)  The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or vehicles of applicant; 
(8)  Such further information as may be required; 
(9)  After said application has been filed, the village shall cause an investigation to be made into the applicant's qualifications, and no license shall be issued if the financial responsibility, experience, character or general fitness of the applicant is such as to warrant the belief that the business would not be operated lawfully and honestly or in a manner calculated to protect the health, safety, morals or general well-being of the public 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.070 - Character of applicant and drivers. 
(a)  No license required by this Chapter shall be issued to or held by any person who has been convicted of a felony, or a crime of moral turpitude, nor shall such license be issued to or held by any partnership, or association, corporation if any officer, director, partner, or shareholder thereof would be ineligible for a license under the foregoing conditions. 
(b)  No licensee shall allow any person who has been convicted of a felony or crime of moral turpitude to be a driver of a taxicab or livery vehicle. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.080 - Inspection of vehicles. 
(a)  Prior to the use and operation of any taxicab or livery vehicle under the provisions of this Chapter said taxicab or livery vehicle shall be subject to a safety inspection to be performed by the village. Valid inspections by other municipalities not more than ninety days old may be utilized in lieu of village inspections. 
(b)  No license shall be issued or maintained under this Chapter unless all taxicabs or livery vehicles to be used or operated under the provisions of this Chapter are determined to be in a safe and continued condition of fitness for public use. 
(c)  All taxicabs or livery vehicles used or operated under the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to safety inspection on a periodic basis or upon the complaint of any person. 
(d)  The village manager shall have the power to appoint such inspectors as he may deem necessary for the inspection as required herein. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.090 - Taximeter required. 
(a)  Each taxicab must have affixed thereto and in good working order a scaled taxi-meter. 
(b)  The chief of police, or any inspector appointed by him, shall examine any taximeter attached to any taxicab to see that the same is accurate before a license to operate such a taxicab is issued by the village. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.100 - Requirements generally. 
    The dial of every taximeter with which every taxicab shall be equipped shall show but one tariff, which shall be in compliance with this Chapter. Such taximeter shall also properly and accurately register, indicate and display the time consumed by the taxicab while in waiting, the distance traveled, and the amount of fare to be determined and charged therefor. Each taxicab shall be equipped with a flag at least three inches by two inches in size, either painted red or bearing thereon in letters at least one inch in height the word "vacant" or the words "for hire." The flagpost of such flag shall be kept up or towards a vertical position when the taxicab is for hire and when taxicab is engaged in the service of a passenger, such flagpost shall be kept down or in a horizontal position. 
    Each taxicab required to have a taximeter shall, during the period between sunset and sunrise, be equipped with a light which shall be so reflected upon the dial of the taximeter as to enable the passenger engaging and using such taxicab to read the figure indicated thereon. 
    Every taximeter hereafter placed on a taxicab shall be so arranged that the dial thereof is in plain view of the passenger while riding in such taxicab, or upon alighting from same. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.110 - Inspection-Generally. 
    Before any license shall be issued for a taxicab for which a taximeter is required, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to examine and inspect the taximeter attached thereto and report its condition to the director of community development. From time to time the inspector shall in like manner examine, inspect and seal all taximeters used in the village; however, in the event complaint is made to the chief of police that any taximeter registers improperly or inaccurately then it shall be the duty of the chief of police immediately to examine and inspect such taximeter complained of; and if such taximeter does not comply with the requirements of Section 4.72.100 of this code, then and in that event it shall be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of such taxicab to permit its use until such taxicab is equipped with a taximeter approved by the chief of police. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.120 - Manner of testing of taximeter. 
    Every taximeter shall be tested by running the taxicab to which it is attached over a course of a standard mile in length or by a mechanical test to prove the accuracy of the register thereof. Either of the foregoing tests may be made in the discretion of the chief of police. 
    In order to determine whether such taximeter correctly registers "waiting time," it shall be the duty of the chief of police to test such taximeter by comparing the time recorded as shown by the fare computed on the dial thereof with the standard time. 
    It shall be the duty of any person, owning, controlling or operating a taxicab to deliver either the taxicab together with the taximeter, to the village for the purpose of making the aforesaid test upon demand; provided, however, that such person may be present at the time such test is made, if desired. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.130 - Transferring meters from one vehicle to another. 
    No person shall detach any inspected taximeter from any taxicab and attach the same to any other taxicab. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.140 - Tampering with taximeter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or alter in any way a sealed taximeter without the consent of the village. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.150 - Record and information requirements. 
(a)  Licensee shall notify the village manager of the motor number and state license number of each taxicab or livery vehicle operated and the corresponding municipal vehicle license number issued for each taxicab or livery vehicle in operation. 
(b)  In connection with the provisions and requirement of this Chapter, the director of community development or his agents shall have the right to inspect and examine the plant, equipment, apparatus and other property and the inventories, books, papers, accounts and records of all property and operations of the licensee at all reasonable times. Every licensee whenever called upon by the director of community development shall file such other information as may be required by them. All statements required to be filed pursuant to this section shall be sworn to by the licensee or his duly authorized agent. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.160 - Identification of taxicab. 
(a)  Every taxicab while operated shall have on each side and rear, in letters not less than two inches in height, readable from a distance of thirty-five feet the name of the licensee operating it. If more than one cab is operated by a licensee each cab shall be designated by a different number and such number also shall appear on each side and rear of such cab. No two vehicles operated by the licensee shall bear the same number. 
(b)  No license shall be issued to any person having the same name or whose taxicabs are colored similar to that of any other taxicab already licensed to operate within the corporate limits of the village. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.170 - Insurance required. 
    No taxicab or livery vehicle shall be operated and no license for taxicab or livery operation shall be issued by the village unless and until the owner or operator thereof, or the applicant for such license, shall first have filed with the village: 
(a)  A certificate from the Illinois Secretary of State showing compliance by such owner, operator or applicant, for each taxicab or livery vehicle, with the provisions of Chapter 8 of the Illinois Vehicle Code now or hereafter in force relating to the bonding and insuring of motor vehicles used for the carriage of passengers for hire; and 
(b)  A duplicate policy or certificate of insurance for each of such taxicabs or livery vehicles issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state of Illinois and to be approved by the village. Said policy shall ensure that all final judgments recovered against such licensee, or such driver, for any injury to or death of any person resulting from the negligence of such licensee; his or its agents, or of such driver, in the operation of such taxicabs to the extent of two hundred fifty thousand dollars for bodily injury to, or death of, one person; 
(c)  A duplicate policy or certificate of insurance for each taxicab or livery vehicle issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state of Illinois and to be approved by the village, ensuring that all final judgments recovered against such licensee, or such driver, for any property damage resulting from the negligence of such licensee, his or its agents, or of such driver, in the operation of such taxicab to the extent of fifty thousand dollars for each accident will be paid. 
    Each such duplicate policy or certificate of insurance herein required shall provide for payment and satisfaction of any final judgment rendered as aforesaid and shall provide that suit may be brought in any court of competent jurisdiction upon such insurance policy by the owner of any such judgment, shall contain a description of each motor vehicle covered thereby, giving the manufacturer's description of each motor vehicle covered thereby, giving the manufacturer's name and number and state license number, and shall also provide that such insurance policy cannot be canceled by the company issuing the same without giving ten days' notice in writing of such cancellation to the village either personally or by registered mail. 
    The licensee shall at all times maintain the full insurance coverage hereinabove required, and whenever the obligation provided for in such bond or policy shall cease or be determined, then the license issued for the operator of such taxicab shall also cease to be in effect and force. 
    At any time in the judgment of the village such policies or certificates of insurance are not sufficient for any good cause, it may require replacement thereof with other good and sufficient policies or certificates of insurance in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.180 - Reasonably safe and adequate service required. 
    Each owner and licensee is required to furnish safe and adequate service at just and reasonable rates within the village as may be required to assure adequate accommodations to the public in accordance with the provisions provided for in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.190 - Rate schedule to be filed with village. 
(a)  Every person, firm or corporation which is licensed to operate a taxicab or taxicabs in the village shall establish a schedule of its fares and shall cause a true and correct copy thereof to be filed with the village within ten days after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Chapter. Any person, firm or corporation which shall hereafter apply for a public vehicle license shall file a schedule of its proposed fares with such application. In the event of any increase in such schedule of fares, or any part thereof, such person, firm or corporation shall file a notice thereof with the village at least thirty days prior to such effective date of the increase. 
(Ord. 2697 § A, 1991; Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.200 - Posting of rates. 
    The rates of fare charged by any taxicab licensed to operate in the village shall be prominently shown, exhibited and displayed on a card which shall be firmly affixed on the inside of such taxicab in such a manner that it may be readily seen and read by any passenger riding therein and such fares shall be printed in plain, legible words and figures. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.210 - Licensee to furnish daily service. 
    Every licensee, under the provisions of this Chapter, shall regularly and daily operate his licensed taxicabs during each day of the license year to the extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demand for such taxicab service and shall maintain a twenty-four-hour telephone service. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.220 - Passengers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the driver of any taxicab to accept as a passenger any person who seeks to so use the taxicab provided such person is not intoxicated and conducts himself in an orderly manner. No person shall be admitted to a taxicab already occupied by a passenger without the consent of the passenger. The driver shall take his passenger to his designation by the most direct available route from the place where the passenger enters the cab. 
(b)  Livery vehicles shall not indiscriminately accept passengers, but shall be limited in scope of operation to carrying passengers for hire on a contract basis at a price agreed upon prior to employment and by arrangement of the parties. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.230 - Receipts. 
    Any taxicab or livery passenger paying a fare shall on request be given a receipt indicating the amount paid. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.240 - Fare to be paid. 
    It shall be unlawful for a passenger to fail, or refuse to pay the lawful fare at the termination of the trip. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.250 - Conduct of drivers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver or person in charge of a taxicab or livery vehicle, while on duty, to be under the influence of any intoxicating liquor or drug or to use any profane, obscene language, to shout or call to prospective passengers, or to disturb the peace in any way. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.260 - Unlawful to drive without license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a taxicab or livery vehicle upon the public ways of the village without first having obtained an Illinois vehicle operator's license issued by the state of Illinois. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.270 - Unlawful to employ unlicensed driver. 
    No person owning, controlling or operating any taxicab or livery vehicle shall employ or permit any person other than a licensed driver to operate such vehicle upon the public ways of the village. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.280 - Use of vehicle for unlawful purpose. 
    It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any taxicab or livery vehicle to be used in the perpetration of a crime or misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
4.72.290 - Suspension and revocation of license. 
    A license issued under the provisions of this Chapter may be revoked or suspended by the village if the holder thereof has (a) violated any of the provisions of this Chapter, (b) discontinued operations for more than sixty days, (c) has violated any ordinances of the village of Wheeling, or the laws of the United States or the state of Illinois, the violations of which reflect unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to offer public transportation. 
    Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given written notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. 2066 § A (part), 1984) 
(Ord. No. 4426, § A, 4-27-2009) 
Chapter 4.74 - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5014, § C, adopted June 6, 2016, changed the title of Ch. 4.74 from "Massage Parlors and Massage Therapists" to read as herein set out. 

4.74.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section. 
(a)  Employee. Any person, over eighteen years of age, including a massage therapist, who renders any service in connection with the operation of a massage business and receives compensation from the operator of the business or patrons. 
(b)  Licensee. The operator of a massage establishment. 
(c)  Massage Establishment. Any establishment having a source of income or compensation derived from the practice of massage as defined in subsection (e), and which has a fixed place of business where any person, firm, association or corporation engages in or carries on the practice of massage as defined in subsection (e). 
(d)  Massage Therapist. An individual who is licensed by the state of Illinois and administers massage for compensation. 
(e)  Massage. Any method of pressure on or friction against or stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the external soft parts of the body with hands or with an aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance with or without such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powders, creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations commonly used in this practice; as performed by a licensed massage therapist. 
(f)  Patron. Any person who receives a massage under such circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he or she will pay money or give any other consideration therefor. 
(g)  Permittee. The person to whom a permit has been issued to act in the capacity of a massage therapist as defined in subsection (e). 
(h)  Person. Any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint stock company, corporation or combination of individuals of whatever form or character. 
(i)  Sexual or Genital Area. Genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or perineum of any person or the vulva or breasts of a female. 
(Ord. 3947 § 1, 2005; Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § D, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.020 - License required. 
(a)  A special use under Title 19, Zoning, is required for all massage establishments including hair and nail salons and athletic training facilities that provide massage in a private room. 
(b)  No person shall engage in or carry out the business of massage unless he has a valid massage business license issued by the village pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter. 
(c)  No person shall practice massage as a massage therapist or otherwise, unless he is a State licensed massage therapist. 
(Ord. 3571 § A, 2001; Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § E, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.030 - Inspection of massage establishments. 
    The village health officer or his designee, shall prior to granting a license and at least once during the license year, make an inspection of each massage establishment that has been granted a license under the provisions of this chapter for the purposes of determining that the provisions of this chapter are complied with. Such inspections shall be made at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to allow such inspection officer access to the premises or to hinder such officer in any manner. 
    All new and existing massage establishments must meet and conform to all requirements of Chapter 4.74. 
(Ord. No. 5014, § F, 6-6-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5014, § F, adopted June 6, 2016, repealed former § 4.74.030 and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former § 4.74.030 pertained to exemptions, and derived from Ord. 3204, § A, adopted in 1997; Ord. 3224, § A, adopted in 1997; and Ord. 3947, § 3, adopted in 2005. 
4.74.040 - Massage establishment license application. 
    Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate, or conduct a massage establishment shall file an application for a business license in accordance with Chapter 4.08. 
    Each application shall also contain the following information: 
(a)  One portrait photograph of the applicant at least two inches by two inches and a complete set of applicant's fingerprints which shall be taken by the police department. If the applicant is a corporation, one portrait photograph at least two inches by two inches of all officers and managing agents of said corporation and a complete set of the same officers' and agents' fingerprints which shall be taken by the police department. If the applicant is a partnership, one portrait photograph at least two inches by two inches in size of each partner, including a limited partner in said partnership, and a complete set of each partner or limited partner's fingerprints which shall be taken by the police department. 
(b)  The massage or similar business license history of the applicant, if an individual, or any if the officers and directors, of the applicant is a corporation or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business, whether such person has had a business license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. 
(c)  The name and address of all employees who is or will be employed in said establishment. 
(d)  Applicant must furnish a copy of the diploma or certificate of graduation for each certified massage therapist employed at the business. In addition, a certified copy of the academic transcript for each certified massage therapist shall be forwarded to the village clerk directly from the educational institution issuing the certified massage therapists diploma. 
(e)  The name and address of any massage business or other establishment owned or operated by any applicant wherein the business or profession of massage is carried on. 
    The licensee shall notify the village business license clerk of each change in any of the data required to be furnished by this section. 
(Ord. 4274 § A, 2007: Ord. 3947 § 4, 2005; Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § G, 3-21-2011; Ord. No. 5014, § G, 6-6-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5014, § G, adopted June 6, 2016, changed the title of § 4.74.040 from "Application for massage establishment license" to read as herein set out. 
4.74.070 - Denial of a massage establishment license. 
    The village may deny a license for any of the reasons set forth in Chapter 4.08 of the Code or for any of the following reasons: 
(a)  The correct license fee has not been tendered to the village or, in the case of a check or bank draft, payment has not been made upon presentation; 
(b)  The operation, as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the village's building, zoning, health or business regulations; 
(c)  The applicant, if an individual; or any of the stockholders holding more than ten percent of the stock of the corporation, any of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; or the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business, have been convicted of any of the following offenses or convicted of an offense outside of the state of Illinois that would have constituted any of the following offenses if committed within the state of Illinois: 
(1)  An offense involving the use of force and violence upon the person of another that amounts to a felony, 
(2)  An offense involving prostitution or other sexual misconduct, 
(3)  An offense involving narcotics, dangerous drugs or dangerous weapons that amounts to a felony, 
(4)  A crime of moral turpitude. 
    The village may issue a license to any person convicted of any of the crimes described in subsections (c)(1), (2), (3) or (4) of this section if it finds that such conviction occurred at least ten years prior to the date of the application and the applicant has had no subsequent misdemeanor convictions for any crime mentioned in this section. 
(d)  The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or fraudulent statement of fact in the license application or in any document required by the village in conjunction therewith; 
(e)  The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business, has had a massage establishment or other similar license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended by the village or another state or local agency within five years prior to the date of the application; 
(f)  The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business, is not over the age of eighteen years. 
(g)  The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation, has placed, published or distributed any advertising matter that depicts any portion of the human body that would reasonably suggest to prospective patrons that any services are available other than authorized massage services. 
(Ord. 3947 § 5, 2005: Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § H, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.080 - Posting of licenses. 
(a)  Every massage therapist shall post the license required by the state of Illinois in a prominent place in his/her work area. 
(b)  Every person, corporation, partnership or association licensed under this Chapter as a massage establishment shall display such license in a prominent place. 
(Ord. 3947 § 6, 2005: Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
4.74.090 - Register of employees. 
    The licensee shall maintain a register of all persons employed at any time as a massage therapist and their state license numbers. Such register shall be available for inspection at the massage establishment to representatives of the village during normal business hours. 
(Ord. 3947 § 7, 2005: Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
4.74.095. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5014, § I, adopted June 6, 2016, repealed former § 4.74.095, which pertained to record of transactions, and derived from Ord. 3204, § A, adopted in 1997; and Ord. 3224, § B, adopted in 1997. 
4.74.100 - Revocation or suspension of license. 
    Any license issued for a massage establishment may be revoked or suspended by the village after notice and hearing, for good cause, or in any case where any of the provisions of this Chapter are violated or where any employee of the licensee, including a massage therapist or other employee is engaged in any conduct which violates any of the state or local laws or ordinances at licensee's place of business and the licensee has actual or constructive knowledge by due diligence. Such license may also be revoked or suspended by the village after notice and hearing, if any reason stated in Section 4.74.050 (Denial of a massage establishment license) of this Chapter is determined to be valid. Such license may also be revoked or suspended by the village after notice and hearing, upon the recommendations of the health officer that such business is being managed, conducted or maintained without regard for proper sanitation and hygiene. 
(Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § J, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.120 - Facility requirements. 
    Massage establishments and accessory massage therapy shall be allowed in the zoning districts as illustrated Appendix A (Use Table) of Title 19, Zoning. Massage establishments must be located on the ground floor of a building. The public entrance to the massage establishments shall be clearly visible from the street or main public parking area. 
    No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an inspection by the village code enforcement inspectors reveals that the establishment complies with each of the following minimum requirements: 
(a)  Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths and showers shall be made waterproof with approved waterproofed materials and shall be installed in accordance with the village building code. Plumbing fixtures shall be installed in accordance with the village plumbing code. 
(1)  Steam rooms and shower compartments shall have waterproof floors, walls and ceilings approved by the village. 
(2)  Floors of wet and dry heat rooms shall be adequately pitched to one or more floor drains properly connected to the sewer. 
    (Exception: Dry heat rooms with wooden floors need not be provided with pitched floors and floor drains). 
(3)  A source of hot water must be available within the immediate vicinity of dry and wet heat rooms to facilitate cleaning. 
(4)  All massage tables, bathtubs, shower stalls, steam or bath areas and floor shall have surfaces which may be readily disinfected. 
(b)  The premises shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing nondisposable instruments and materials used in administering massages. Such nondisposable instruments and materials shall be disinfected after use on each patron. 
(c)  Closed cabinets shall be provided and used for the storage of clean linen, towels and other materials used in connection with administering massages. All soiled linens, towels and other materials shall be kept in properly covered containers or cabinets, which containers or cabinets shall be kept separate from the clean storage areas. 
(d)  Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When employees and patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the same time separate toilet facilities shall be provided for each sex. A single water closet per sex shall be provided for each twenty or more employees or patrons of that sex on the premises at any one time. Urinals may be substituted for water closets after one water closet has been provided. Toilets shall be designated as to the sex accommodated therein. 
(e)  Lavatories or washbasins provided with both hot and cold running water shall be installed in either the toilet room or a vestibule. Lavatories or washbasins shall be provided with soap and a dispenser and with sanitary towels, or electric hand dryers. 
(f)  All electrical equipment shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the village electrical code. 
(g)  Adequate bathing, dressing and locker facilities shall be provided for the patrons to be served at any given time. In the event male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously, a separate bathing, dressing, locker and massage room facilities shall be provided. 
(h)  The premises shall be equipped with a utility sink for custodial services. 
(i)  A stationary or portable professional massage table or chairs specifically designed for massage therapy shall be provided. All others shall be prohibited. 
(j)  A washer and dryer shall be provided on site for the laundering of sheets and towels used in the facility. A professional laundry delivery service may be used. A copy of the contract with the laundry service shall be given to the health division inspector. 
(Ord. 3224 § C, 1997: Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § K, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.130 - Operating requirements. 
(a)  Every portion of the massage establishment, including appliances and apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary condition. 
(b)  Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the reception area in a location available to all prospective customers. 
(c)  All employees, including massage therapists, shall be clean and wear clean, nontransparent outer garments, covering the sexual and genital areas. 
(d)  All massage establishments shall be provided with clean, laundered sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use thereof and stored in a sanitary manner. 
(e)  No massage establishment granted a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall place, publish, or cause to be placed, published or distributed any advertising matter that depicts any portion of the human body that would reasonably suggest to prospective patrons that any services are available other than authorized massage services. 
(f)  Eating in the massage work areas shall not be permitted. Animals except service animals shall not be permitted in the massage work areas. 
(g)  The sexual or genital areas of patrons shall be covered by sheets, cloths or undergarments at all times when in the presence of an employee or massage therapist. 
(h)  No massage therapist shall administer a massage on a patron's skin inflammation or skin eruption, unless a physician duly licensed in the state of Illinois certifies, in writing, that such patron may safely be massaged on that area. 
(i)  Each massage therapist shall wash his or her hands in hot running water, using a proper soap disinfectant before administering a massage to each patron. 
(j)  All walls, ceilings, floors, showers, bathtubs, steam rooms, pools and all other physical facilities shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms, shower compartments and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned and sanitized after each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs and showers shall be thoroughly cleaned and sanitized after each use. 
(k)  Oils, creams, lotions or other preparations used in administering massages shall be kept in clean, closed containers or cabinets and shall be dispensed in unit doses so that said bulk containers are not contaminated between clients. 
(l)  The doors to the establishment, corridors or individual massage rooms shall not be locked or obstructed during hours of operation. 
(Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § K, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.140 - Persons under age eighteen prohibited on premises. 
    No person shall permit any person under the age of eighteen years to come or remain on the premises of any massage business establishment, as employee, or patron. 
(Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § L, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.150 - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
    No person shall sell, give, dispense, provide or keep, or cause to be sold, given, dispensed, provided or kept, any alcoholic beverage on the premises of any massage business. 
(Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
4.74.160 - Hours of operation. 
    No massage business shall be kept open for any purpose between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
4.74.170 - Employment of massage therapist. 
    No person shall employ as a massage therapist any person unless said person is a certified massage therapist who has obtained and has in effect a valid state license. 
(Ord. 3947 § 8, 2005: Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
4.74.180 - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  With the exception of those massage therapists that have orders from a physician for medical massage for post-surgical or injury recovery, it shall be unlawful for any person, in a massage establishment, to place his or her hand or hands upon, to touch with any part of his or her body, to fondle in any manner, or to massage, a sexual or genital part of any other person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, in a massage establishment, to expose his or her sexual parts, or any portion thereof, to any other person. It shall also be unlawful for any person, in a massage establishment to expose the sexual or genital parts, or any portions thereof, of any other person. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while in the presence of any other person in a massage establishment, to fail to conceal with a fully opaque covering, the sexual or genital parts of his or her body. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, operating, or managing a massage establishment, knowingly to cause, allow or permit in or about such massage establishment any agent, employee, or any other person under his control or supervision to perform such acts prohibited in subsections (a), (b) or (c) of this section. 
(e)  No massage therapist, employee or operator shall perform, offer to perform, or agree to perform any act which would require a touching of a patron's genital area. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any massage service to be carried on within any cubicle, room, booth, or any area within a massage establishment which is fitted with a door capable of being locked. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish or provide or to record any false information within the record of transactions. 
(h)  Nothing contained herein shall be construed to eliminate other requirements of statute or ordinance concerning the maintenance of premises, nor to preclude authorized inspection thereof, whenever such inspection is deemed necessary by the police or health departments. 
(Ord. 3224 § D, 1997: Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
(Ord. No. 5014, § M, 6-6-2016) 
4.74.190 - Transfer of license prohibited. 
    No license for a massage establishment shall be transferable. 
(Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
4.74.200 - Name and place of business. 
    No person granted a license hereunder shall operate the massage establishment under a name not specified in the license, nor shall he conduct business under any designation or location not specified in his license. 
(Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
4.74.210 - Violation and penalty. 
    Every person, except those persons who are specifically exempted by this Chapter, whether acting as an individual owner, employee of the owner, operator or employee of the operator, or whether acting as a mere agent or independent contractor for the owner, employee or operator, or acting as a participant or worker in any way directly or indirectly who operates a massage establishment or provides of the services defined in this Chapter, without first obtaining a license for a massage establishment and paying a fee to do so from the village or who violates any provision of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction such person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 3947 § 9, 2005: Ord. 3204 § A (part), 1997) 
Chapter 4.80 - MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS 

4.80.010 - Definitions. 
(a)  "Individual meter" means a mechanical device used to measure utility service to one dwelling unit. 
(b)  "Master metered utilities" means that the utility service to more than one dwelling unit is measured by a single meter for the units. 
(c)  "Mobile home" means a structure equipped for use as a single-family dwelling unit suitable for year-round occupancy and containing water supply, waste disposal and electrical facilities. It is designed for transportation on its own wheels, or on a flatbed, or on other trailers, to arrive at a site to be occupied as a dwelling complete and ready for occupancy except for hooking up to local utility connections, but is not self-propelled. 
(d)  "Mobile home park" or "park" means a use of land in which four or more lots or spaces are offered for rent or lease for the placement of mobile homes and in which the primary use of the park or the mobile home section thereof is residential. 
(e)  "Park operator" means an owner or manager of a mobile home park, their officers, agents or employees. 
(f)  "Rental agreement" means any agreement between a park operator and a resident establishing the terms and conditions whereby a mobile home is placed upon a rented or leased lot in a mobile home park. A lease is a rental agreement. 
(g)  "Resident" is a person who has a tenancy in a mobile home park under a rental agreement. 
(h)  "Resident association" means any organization of residents representing a majority of the residents of the park, which is organized for the purpose of resolving matters relating to living conditions in the mobile home park. 
(i)  "Utility company" includes all suppliers of utility service, including the village of Wheeling. 
(j)  "Utility service" includes electric, gas, water or sanitary utility service rendered by a utility company. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.020 - Unfair business practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any park operator to: 
(a)  Require, as a condition to the rental of any site, the purchase of a mobile home from the park operator, or any dealer, manufacturer or agent named by the operator; 
(b)  Represent to any person that the purchase of a mobile home from the park operator or any dealer, manufacturer or agent named by the operator will give the purchaser an advantage over others in the rental or continued occupancy of a site; 
(c)  Discriminate or threaten to discriminate regarding the amount of rental charges or in any other respect against a resident for failure of the resident to purchase a mobile home from the operator or any dealer, manufacturer or agent named by the operator; 
(d)  Solicit or receive any payment or other thing of value from any person upon the representation or understanding that such consideration will give that person an advantage over others in the rental or continued occupancy of a site; 
(e)  Use a mobile home park site to display an unoccupied mobile home offered for sale, or rent a site to a mobile home dealer for purposes other than accommodation of a mobile home occupied as a residence, if the use or rental of the site results in their being no site in the mobile home park available to a prospective resident who does not purchase a mobile home from the operator or renting dealer. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.030 - Security deposits. 
(a)  The park operator may require as a condition of leasing a mobile home site a security deposit in an amount not exceeding one month's rent. 
(b)  A park operator of any park regularly containing twenty-five or more mobile homes shall pay interest to the tenant, on any deposit held by the park operator, computed from the date of the deposit at a rate equal to the interest paid by the largest commercial bank, as measured by total assets, having its main banking premises in this state, on minimum deposit passbook savings accounts as of December 31st of the preceding year on any such deposit held by the park operator for more than six months. However, in the event that any portion of the amount deposited is utilized during the period for which it is deposited in order to compensate the operator for nonpayment of rent or to make a good faith reimbursement to the operator for damage caused by the tenant, the principal on which the interest accrues may be recomputed to reflect the reduction for the period commencing on the first day of the calendar month following the reduction. 
    The park operator shall, within thirty days after the end of each twelve-month period, pay to the tenant any interest owed under this section in cash, provided, however, that the amount owed may be applied to rent due if the owner and tenant agree thereto. 
(c)  The security deposit with all unpaid interest shall be returned to the resident when the lease is terminated provided that the resident has paid in full all rent and other charges due, has caused no actual damage to the leased premises, and has left the lot reasonably clean and free of debris. 
(d)  Within fifteen days of the termination of the rental agreement, the park operator shall provide the resident with an itemized list of charges due and damages to the premises and the estimated cost of repair for each, and tender payment for the difference between the security deposit and the charges due and estimated cost of repair of damages to the premises. Failure to comply with the previous sentence shall constitute admission by the park operator that no damages are due, and it shall immediately remit to the resident the full amount of the security deposit. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.040 - Restrictions on fees and charges. 
(a)  No park operator shall charge residents any fees or charges other than the monthly rent charge, except for use-based charges that are set out in the rental agreement. Use-based charges are charges for services or facilities that are based on the amount of the resident's use of a particular service or facility. A charge is not use-based if a resident is charged even when he does not use the service or facility, or if different residents are assessed the same charge for using different levels of service or facilities. 
(b)  Charges for existing use-based services or facilities shall be set out in the rental agreement, and can only be increased as set out in the rental agreement. Any increase shall be reasonably related to the increases in the park operator's costs. 
(c)  The following fees are specifically prohibited and any rental agreement provision establishing such fees is void: 
(1)  Entrance and exit fees; 
(2)  Fees for a resident's resale of the home, assignment of the lease or sublet of the home; 
(3)  Fees for additional family members; 
(4)  Short-term guest fees; 
(5)  Pet fees, unless special facilities are provided for pets. 
(d)  No park operator shall charge a fee for a credit check to a prospective resident which exceeds the actual cost to the park operator of such credit check. 
(e)  A park operator may charge a penalty for late payment of rent or other fees after such payments are five days delinquent. Such late charge shall not exceed five percent of the amount owed and may be imposed only once for a particular late payment. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.050 - Utility charges. 
(a)  No park operator may demand payment for master metered public utility services pursuant to a rental agreement provision providing for resident payment of a proportionate share of public utility service without the park operator first providing the resident with a copy in writing either as part of the rental agreement or another written agreement of the formula used by the park operator for allocating the public utility payments among the residents. The total of payments under the formula for the park as a whole for a billing period may not exceed the sum billed by the public utility. The formula shall include all those that use that public utility service and may reflect variations in mobile home size or usage. The park operator shall also make available to the resident upon request a copy of the public utility bill for any billing period for which payment is demanded. Nothing herein shall preclude a park operator from leasing property to a resident, including the cost of utilities, for a rental which does not segregate or allocate the cost of the utilities. 
(b)  Any park operator who allocates public utility payments to residents by means of an individual meter, owned by the park operator, to the mobile home shall do so only in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  No park operator shall charge a resident a per-unit cost for such utility in excess of the per-unit charge of the utility service provider. 
(2)  No park operator shall include within the areas to be individually metered to a mobile home any common areas of the mobile home park. 
(3)  Utility charges allocated to residents shall be based upon the actual individual meter reading and, except as provided herein, no charge shall be based upon estimated meter readings. 
(4)  The park operator shall cause each individual meter to be tested by a reputable testing firm at least every five years. The park operator shall make available to the resident upon request a copy of the testing report for the individual meter to their mobile home. 
(5)  A resident may request that the individual meter servicing his mobile home be tested for accuracy. Such request shall be in writing and delivered personally or by certified mail to the park operator. Upon receipt of such request the park operator shall cause the meter to be tested by a reputable testing firm. In the event the meter is determined to be accurate the resident requesting the test shall be responsible for payment of the costs of removal, testing and reinstallation of the meter. 
(6)  Any individual meter determined to be inaccurate or inoperable shall be immediately replaced by the park operator at his sole cost and expense. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.060 - Restrictions on choice of vendors. 
    No park operator shall restrict the choice of vendors from whom a resident may purchase goods or services, or in any other way engage in conduct that discourages residents from selecting the vendor of their choice. This section does not apply to: 
(1)  Snow removal, lawn care, or similar site maintenance services performed by the operator, upon the failure of a resident to fulfill the resident's site obligations under the rental agreement. No charges may be imposed for site maintenance services performed by the operator under this subsection unless the resident, if available, is given prior notice and a reasonable opportunity to perform the resident's obligation under the rental agreement. Charges for site maintenance services shall be set forth in the rental agreement, and shall be reasonable and limited to the park operator's actual costs; 
(2)  A nondiscriminatory prohibition against sales solicitations within the mobile home park. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.070 - Park rules. 
(a)  The park operator may promulgate rules governing the rental occupancy of a mobile home lot and the use of common areas and facilities, but no such rule shall be unreasonable, unfair or unconscionable. 
(b)  Any rule which does not apply uniformly to all mobile home residents of a similar class shall create a rebuttable presumption that such rule or change in rule is unfair. 
(c)  No rule or regulation shall be enforceable against a resident unless a copy of all rules and regulations was delivered to the resident prior to signing the rental agreement. 
(d)  No change in a rule shall be effective until at least thirty days after the residents receive written notice of the change. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.075 - Park operator disclosure statement. 
(a)  A park operator shall provide to every person prior to the execution of a rental agreement a copy of the mobile home park disclosure statement. 
(b)  The mobile home park disclosure statement shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The rules of the park; 
(2)  The lot area for which the resident will be responsible; 
(3)  The park operator's maintenance responsibilities; 
(4)  The residents' maintenance responsibilities; 
(5)  A list of facilities and services which the park operator provides and the cost of such facilities and services, if any; 
(6)  Any late charges which may be imposed and the amount of such late charges; 
(7)  The amount of any security deposit; 
(8)  Any restrictions on the use of park facilities; 
(9)  The cost of any credit check for a new resident; 
(10)  The current monthly rental amount and the annual rental increases for the past five years; 
(11)  A list of those public utilities which the park operator provides as part of the rental agreement and a list of those utilities which are the resident's responsibility; 
(12)  A disclosure as to the following conditions of the park, which shall include: 
(A)  Whether the property is located within a flood hazard area, 
(B)  Whether the park operator has knowledge of defects in the plumbing system or sanitary system of the park, 
(C)  Whether the park operator has received notice of violation of state, local or federal laws or regulations relating to the park, which violations have not been corrected. 
(c)  The park operator shall certify that the park operator has prepared the disclosure statement and that the information provided is based upon the actual knowledge of the park operator. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.080 - Lease terms. 
(a)  All rental agreements and renewal agreements shall be in writing and signed by the park operator or manager and the resident. 
(b)  No rental agreement shall be offered for a term of less than twelve months. 
(c)  The park operator shall give the resident a copy of the rental agreement, with all park rules and attachments, and a copy of the park operator disclosure statement at the time the prospective resident initially contacts the park concerning a prospective vacancy and a completed agreement after the rental agreement has been signed. 
(d)  Any rental agreement or renewal agreement shall contain the following provisions: 
(1)  The monthly rental amount during the term of the lease; 
(2)  The rules of the park; 
(3)  Any late charges, fees or charges for services, including any increases during the term of the lease. If the amount of fees or charges change over the term of the lease, and the lease does not specify the dollar amount of the subsequent levels of fees or charges, the rental agreement must clearly set forth the formula or method for determining those changes, and must also give clear and realistic examples of how such formula or method would work in each year of the lease term; 
(4)  A description of the resident's mobile home site and its address or site number and the number and location of any accompanying automobile parking spaces; 
(5)  The park operator's name and address for the delivery of all official notices and also the name and telephone number of the individual who can be contacted for emergency maintenance; 
(6)  The amount of any security deposit imposed by the park operator; 
(7)  Any penalties the park operator may impose for the resident's early termination; 
(8)  The statutory grounds for eviction; 
(9)  The park operator shall keep all exterior property areas not in the possession of a resident, but part of the mobile home park property, free from the species of weeds and plant growth which are generally noxious or detrimental to the health of the tenants; 
(10)  The park operator shall maintain all electrical, plumbing, gas or other utilities which it furnishes in good working condition with the exception of emergencies after which repairs must be completed within a reasonable period of time; 
(11)  The park operator shall maintain all subsurface water and sewage lines and connections in good working order; 
(12)  The park operator shall respect the privacy of the residents and if only the lot is rented, agree not to enter the mobile home without the permission of the mobile home owner, and if the mobile home is the property of the park operator, to enter only after due notice to the resident, provided, the park operator or his representative may enter without notice in emergencies; 
(13)  The park operator shall maintain all roads within the mobile home park in good condition; 
(14)  A prominent disclosure that the resident can cancel the rental agreement with no obligation for the next three days after signing the agreement; 
(15)  The notice required by Section 17 of the Mobile Home Landlord and Tenant Rights Act, 765 ILCS 745/17. 
(e)  Any provision for rent increases or increases in fees over the term of the lease shall be initialed by the resident. 
(f)  The rental agreement shall be clearly written in understandable language. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.090 - Park operator's obligations. 
    It shall be the obligation of a park operator to: 
(1)  Comply with codes, statutes, ordinances and administrative rules applicable to the mobile home park; 
(2)  Maintain all common areas of the park in a clean and safe condition; 
(3)  Maintain in good working order all electrical, plumbing, sanitary, and appliances and recreational facilities which it furnishes; 
(4)  Maintain and protect all utilities provided to the mobile home and keep water and sewer lines in good working condition. Maintenance responsibility shall extend to that point where the normal mobile home utility hookups connect to those provided by the park operator or utility company; 
(5)  Maintain roads within the mobile home park in good and safe condition including snow removal, adequate drainage and water supply; 
(6)  Take reasonable steps to exterminate rodents, vermin, or other pests dangerous to the health and safety of the resident whenever infestation exists on the common premises. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.100 - Resident self-help for defects. 
    If the park operator fails to comply with any of the requirements of Section 4.80.090, the resident may notify the park operator in writing of the resident's intention to correct the condition at the park operator's expense. After being notified by the resident in writing, if the park operator fails to comply within fifteen days, or more promptly as conditions reasonably require in case of emergency, the resident may cause the work to be done by a licensed contractor with the proper permits being issued, and after submitting to the park operator an itemized statement deduct from the resident's rent the actual and reasonable cost of the work. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.110 - Retaliatory conduct. 
    It is unlawful for a park operator to increase a resident's rent or decrease services, change park rules, bring or threaten to bring an action for eviction or other civil action, or take any other action in retaliation because: 
(1)  The resident has expressed an intention to complain or has complained to a governmental agency about conditions in the park; 
(2)  The resident has made any complaint in good faith to the park operator; 
(3)  The resident has filed or expressed an intention to file a lawsuit or administrative action against the park operator; 
(4)  The resident has organized or is a member of a resident association; 
(5)  The resident has performed or expressed intent to perform any other act for the purpose of asserting, protecting or invoking the protection of any right secured to residents under any federal, state or local law. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.120 - Tenant association meetings. 
(a)  No park operator shall prohibit meetings by any resident association or residents relating to mobile home living or social or educational purposes, including forums for or speeches by public officials or candidates for public office, if such meetings are held at reasonable hours, in accordance with the reasonable rules and regulations of the park, and when facilities are available and not otherwise in use. 
(b)  No park operator shall harass or threaten any resident association, or engage in any unfair or deceptive conduct to inhibit or interfere with the creation or operation of a resident association by the residents. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.130 - Right of entry. 
    Except in the case of an emergency or when the resident has abandoned the mobile home, the park operator shall have no right of entry to a mobile home without the prior written consent of the resident. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.140 - Assignment of rental agreements, subleases. 
(a)  Except as specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, a resident shall have the right to assign the rental agreement to the purchaser of the resident's mobile home, or to sublease the mobile home site. 
(b)  The resident shall give the park operator notice of any assignment or sublease, and the park operator may only disapprove of the assignment or sublease if, within seven calendar days, it gives the resident written notice of the disapproval with the reasons for the disapproval stated therein, provided that such disapproval shall only be for reasons set out in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  The park operator may disapprove the assignment of a rental agreement or a sublease only if the assignee or sublessee does not have the financial ability to pay the rental amount or would pose an unreasonable hazard to the safety or peaceful enjoyment of the residents of the mobile home park. The age or condition of the mobile home is not grounds for disapproving an assignment or sublease unless the mobile home is significantly deteriorated and in substantial disrepair. The park operator may impose a fee for a credit check of the assignee or sublessee but no application or other fee may be imposed on the prospective assignee or sublessee. The park operator may not disapprove an assignment from the resident to the resident's bona fide creditor. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.150 - Sales of mobile homes. 
(a)  No park operator shall deny any resident the right to sell his mobile home to a purchaser of his choice, provided that the park operator shall be allowed to promulgate any general qualifications or lawful restrictions on park residents which limit or define the admission of entrants to the park. The purchaser, prior to closing, must obtain a written and signed lease. 
(b)  No park operator shall deny any resident the right to employ or secure the services of an independent salesperson in connection with the sale of such mobile home, providing that such salesperson collects and remits all governmental taxes. 
(c)  The park operator is prohibited from imposing any fee, charge or commission for the sale of a mobile home, except when a mobile home owner requests the park operator or his agent to assist in securing a purchaser for his mobile home. A commission may be accepted for such service subject only to the following conditions: 
(1)  That the exact amount of commission or fee shall be a percentage of the actual sales price of the mobile home; and 
(2)  That the maximum percentage figure for the services in the resale of the mobile home by park operator or his agent shall be set forth in writing prior to the sale. 
(d)  The park operator is prohibited from requiring, upon the sale by a resident of a mobile home to a qualified purchaser, the removal from the park of such mobile home unless the mobile home is less than twelve feet wide or is significantly deteriorated and in substantial disrepair, in which case the park operator shall bear the burden of demonstrating such fact and must, prior to sale, have given the resident written notice thereof, and that unless first corrected, removal will be required upon sale. 
(e)  No park operator shall place unreasonable, unfair or discriminatory restrictions on "For Sale" signs or on access to the park by prospective purchasers or realtors, or interfere with a resident's efforts to sell a mobile home. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.160 - Mobile homes sale disclosure report. 
(a)  Any mobile home owner who offers for sale a mobile home shall provide to any prospective buyer the mobile home sale disclosure report prior to the execution of an agreement for the sale of such mobile home. 
(b)  The mobile home sale disclosure report shall provide: 
MOBILE HOME SALE DISCLOSURE REPORT

4.80.170 - Waiver of provisions. 
    Any provision in a rental agreement or sales contract whereby any provision of this Chapter is waived shall be void. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
4.80.180 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars nor more than one thousand dollars, and each day a violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense for which a fine as herein provided shall be imposed. 
(Ord. 3181 § B (part), 1996) 
Chapter 4.84 - RENTAL RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY 

4.84.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Chapter is to provide for the licensing and inspection of rental residential property so as to protect the public health, safety, and welfare of the people of the village including: 
(a)  To protect the public health and safety by ensuring rental units comply with minimum housing standards of village ordinances. 
(b)  To protect the character and stability of residential areas. 
(c)  To correct and prevent housing conditions that adversely affect or are likely to adversely affect the life, safety, general welfare and health, including the physical, mental and social well being of persons occupying dwellings. 
(d)  To prevent the overcrowding of dwellings by requiring compliance with minimum space standards per occupant for each dwelling unit. 
(e)  To facilitate the enforcement of minimum standards for the maintenance of existing residential buildings and thus to prevent slums and blight. 
(f)  To preserve the value of land and buildings throughout the village. 
(Ord. 3530 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 3324 § A (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 4351, § A, 8-25-2008) 
4.84.020 - Provisions of inspection rights and penalties. 
    This Chapter shall not be construed as to restrict the right of this village to inspect any property nor to seek penalties for violations of other provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. 3530 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 3324 § A (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 4351, § A, 8-25-2008) 
4.84.030 - Definitions. 
(a)  "Code official" means the director of community development or his designee. 
(b)  "Conditional license" means a limited approval of the premises for a period of up to six months when a property cannot fully comply with all the applicable requirements of the village of Wheeling due to special circumstances (e.g., weather conditions, unavailability of require materials or services, or other circumstances approved by the code official). 
(c)  "Multiple-family rental residential property" means rental residential property with two or more dwelling units. 
(d)  "Owner's family" means the owner's parents, siblings or children whether natural or by adoption. 
(e)  "Premises" means a lot, plot or parcel of land including the interior and exterior of any structures thereon. 
(f)  "Property agent" means a person, operator, firm, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity designated in writing by the property owner to the code official to manage a rental residential property including the authority to receive notices or citations. 
(g)  "Rental residential property" means residential structures or dwelling units let or intended to be let for rent or lease including single-family detached structures. 
(h)  "Routine maintenance" means the scope of daily, weekly, monthly or annual maintenance required to keep a dwelling unit and/or building in a sanitary condition, free from damage or defects. Any remodeling, alteration or repair work involving structural, mechanical, electrical, plumbing, fire protection equipment requiring permits from the building division shall be considered to exceed the scope of routine maintenance. 
(i)  "Tenant" means an occupant of rental residential property. 
(j)  Words or phrases as used in this Chapter and not herein defined shall be defined as provided by the village of Wheeling's current property maintenance code, and current building code. 
(Ord. 3530 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 3324 § A (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 4351, § A, 8-25-2008) 
4.84.040 - License required. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity to operate, maintain, or offer to rent within the village of Wheeling a rental residential property whether vacant or not without first obtaining a license as provided in this Chapter. 
(b)  It is unlawful for a person to occupy a rental residential property, or for any owner or property agent to allow anyone to occupy a rental residential property which is not licensed. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity to offer for rent or to occupy any vacant dwelling unit or any dwelling unit that becomes vacant in a rental residential property for which a license is under suspension. 
(d)  This Chapter shall not apply to the following structures: 
(1)  Owner-occupied residential dwelling units. 
(2)  Residential dwelling units occupied by a member of the owner's family. 
(3)  Residential buildings or dwelling units which are vacant and which are not intended to be let for rent. 
(4)  Hotels, motels, and other structures which rent rooms to occupants which are primarily transient in nature. 
(5)  Dwellings, buildings, structures and uses licensed and inspected by the state or the federal government, including but not limited to, nursing homes, retirement centers, rest homes, etc. 
(6)  Dwellings, buildings, structures and uses owned by other governmental agencies and public housing authorities. 
(e)  A license for a rental residential property cannot be transferred to another rental residential property nor a succeeding owner. 
(f)  The issuance of a residential rental property license pursuant to this Chapter shall not relieve the applicant's obligation from complying with all applicable rules, regulations and by-laws imposed by the condominium and/or homeowners' association, including any rental restrictions and/or limitations, to which the rental residential property is subject. 
(Ord. 3530 § A (part), 2001: Ord. 3324 § A (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 4351, § A, 8-25-2008; Ord. No. 4407, § 1, 3-23-2009; Ord. No. 5246, § A, 2-19-2019) 
4.84.050 - License application and requirements. 
(a)  Each applicant for a license to maintain a residential property for the purpose of renting it to others shall file a written application with the code official stating: 
(1)  The full legal name, address, email, home and work telephone numbers of each and every owner. 
(2)  If the residential property is held in a trust, state the name, address, work phone number of the trustee and each beneficial interest holder. 
(3)  The address of the rental residential property. 
(4)  The number of dwelling units within the rental property. 
(5)  The name, address, email and phone number of any management company retained as property agent for the property and the name, address, and phone number of the person specifically assigned to the rental residential property. 
(6)  The name, address, email and twenty-four hour phone number or numbers of a responsible person who, in emergency situations, will be available on a twenty-four-hour basis and who has the authority to make repairs as needed. 
(7)  The square footage designated for living and sleeping purposes including room sizes as stipulated by the village's property maintenance code as amended. 
(b)  Whenever there is a change in the ownership of a rental residential property or the owner's property agent, the owners shall within thirty days of such changes, file an updated written notice with the code official indicating such changes. 
(c)  Each application for a new license or a renewal of an existing license shall be accompanied by a fee of one hundred dollars for each rental residential building. In addition thereto, a dwelling unit fee of fifty dollars will be added for each dwelling unit to be inspected in excess of one. All such fees shall be payable at the offices of the community development department.
