(1)  Revocation of the business license by the village president and the board of trustees; 
(2)  Repeated violations of this Chapter; 
(3)  Interference with the health officer or their designee in the performance of their duties; 
(4)  Repeated failure to correct violations of this Chapter ordered by the health officer, and identified in inspection reports. 
(b)  The health officer, or their designee shall enter a facility and remove the health permit from the premises after the health permit has been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 5223, § D, 12-3-2018) 
5.18.100 - Hearing. 
    The hearing provided for in this Chapter shall be conducted by the health officer or their designee and the director of community development. Based upon the hearing, the health officer shall sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. The health permit holder shall be notified in writing of the decision following the hearing. A record of the hearing shall be kept for a period of one year following the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 5223, § D, 12-3-2018) 
5.18.105 - Service of notices. 
    A notice is properly served when it is personally delivered to the health permit holder or designee, leaving a copy with a person over eighteen years of age at the address of the establishment provided on the business license application, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the health permit holder. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
5.18.110 - New and remodeled food service establishments or retail food stores. 
    All food service establishments or retail food stores which are hereafter constructed, reconstructed or remodeled shall conform in such construction to the requirements of this Chapter: 
(a)  New or replacement equipment, which includes new to the food service establishment or retail food store, shall meet or be equivalent to the standards of the National Sanitation Foundation as to construction, installation and performance. 
(b)  All food service establishments shall provide dry storage facilities which are separate and in addition to the food preparation area, service and utensil and equipment washing areas. The separate dry storage space shall have a minimum floor area equal to twenty-five percent of the total floor area of the facility excluding dining and restroom areas, office space, and walk-in refrigeration and walk-in freezer areas. This room shall be used for the storage of paper products, food supplies, food stock, food equipment and like items. Alcoholic liquors, maintenance and building equipment shall not be stored or located in this area. The dry storage facilities shall be used for no other purpose than storage, and shall be physically separated from the surrounding area. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
5.18.120 - Submission of plans. 
    Before the construction or remodeling of a food service establishment or retail food store, and whenever an existing structure is converted for use as a food service establishment or retail food store, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, major remodeling, or conversion shall be submitted to the village for review and approval of the health officer. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, arrangements, installation, mechanical plans, construction materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed equipment and facilities. The health officer and their designee shall treat such plans and specifications as confidential or trade secret information in accordance with the law and shall approve the plans and specifications if they meet the requirements of this Chapter. No food service establishment or retail food store shall be constructed, remodeled or converted except in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the health officer, or their designee. 
(a)  Remodeling of a food service establishment or retail food store cannot be conducted until a permit is issued or permission granted by the health officer or their designee. 
(b)  All areas in the food service establishment or retail food store where remodeling took place cannot be used until it is inspected and approved by the health officer or his designee. If electrical, structural or plumbing work was involved in the remodeling, the area must be inspected and approved by the necessary building inspectors. 
(c)  If upon inspection, it is observed that remodeled areas are being used without approval, the health officer or their designee can close down that area of the establishment until it is inspected and approved. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 5223, § D, 12-3-2018) 
5.18.140 - Food from other jurisdictions. 
    Food from food service establishments or retail food stores outside the jurisdiction of the village of Wheeling may be sold within the village if such food service establishments or retail food stores conform to provisions of this Chapter or to substantially equivalent provisions. To determine the extent of compliance with such provisions, the health officer may accept reports from the responsible authority in other jurisdictions where such food service establishments or retail food stores are located. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
5.18.150 - Examination and condemnation of food. 
(a)  Samples of food and other substances may be examined or sampled by the health officer or their designee as often as may be necessary to determine freedom from adulteration and misbranding and determine bacteriological contact. The health officer or their designee may request the condemnation of or request the removal, destruction or denaturing of any food which is unwholesome, adulterated or misbranded. The health officer or their designee shall upon written notice to the owner or person in charge, place a tag or hold order on any food they determine, or has probable cause to believe to be unwholesome. The health officer or their designee shall permit storage of food under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in which case immediate destruction shall be ordered and accomplished. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or alter a hold order, notice or tag placed on food by the health officer or their designee, and neither such food nor the containers thereof shall be relabeled or repacked, reprocessed, altered, disposed of or destroyed without permission of the health officer or their designee, except on order by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  The health officer or their designee may vacate the hold order, or may, by written order direct the owner or person in charge of the food, which was placed under the hold order, to denature or destroy such food or to bring it into compliance with provisions of this Chapter; provided, that such order shall be stayed if a hearing is requested within forty-eight hours. If food is denatured or destroyed, such action shall be taken under the supervision of the health officer or their designee. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 5223, § D, 12-3-2018) 
5.18.160 - Disease. 
(a)  When the public health officer or their designee has reasonable cause to suspect possibility of disease transmission from any food establishment or employee, the public health officer shall make such investigation, including the morbidity history of suspected employees, and take appropriate action. 
(b)  The public health officer or designee may require any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  The immediate closure of the food establishment until, in the opinion of the public health officer, no further danger of disease outbreak exists. Upon such closure, the establishment may reopen only upon authorization from the public health officer. 
(2)  The immediate exclusion of the employee from all food establishments. 
(3)  Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting disease. 
(4)  Adequate medical and laboratory examinations of the employee and, if deemed necessary, other employees. 
(Ord. No. 5223, § D, 12-3-2018) 
5.18.170 - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars nor more than five hundred dollars for each occurrence. A separate occurrence shall be deemed existing on each day on which a violation continues or occurs. In addition thereto, such persons may be enjoined from continuing such violations. 
(Ord. No. 4546, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
5.18.180 - Food service and food processing establishment grease trap/interceptor requirements. 
    The purpose of this section is to establish rules and regulations for the management of fats, oils and greases (FOG) discharged to the village sanitary sewers by food service and food processing establishments. 
(a)  Definitions. The definitions contained in this Chapter shall be observed and applied: 
(1)  "FOG" means fats, oils, greases, starches, proteins and certain other materials from animal or vegetable origins. FOG may originate from discharges from scullery sinks, pot and pan sinks, food processing equipment and floor drains located in a food processing area of a food manufacturer, retail food store or food service establishment. 
(2)  "Food processing establishment" means a commercial facility in which food is manufactured or packaged for human or domestic animal consumption. The term does not include a food service establishment or retail food store. 
(3)  "Grease trap/interceptor" shall mean a constructed device, whether installed internally or externally, and its surfaces and working parts, with the function of removing FOG from wastewaters before such waters are discharged to village sanitary sewer system. 
(4)  "Hauler" means a waste disposal business, that hauls and disposes of pumped materials and waste from a grease trap/interceptor. 
(5)  "High volume establishment" means a food establishment, retail food store or bakery that has deep fat fryers, woks, griddles and those establishments that bake, cook, prepare or wash grease-laden foods, grease-laden equipment or utensils. 
(6)  "Low volume establishment" means a food establishment or retail food store which does not have fryers or woks and those establishments that do not cook, prepare or wash large amounts of grease-laden foods or grease-laden equipment. 
(7)  "Manifest" means a log or document record of the hauler's name and address; and the volume, date of removal and disposal destination of pumped materials or waste from a grease trap/interceptor. (415 ILCS 22.30(d), (e)) 
(8)  "Village" means the village of Wheeling or its representatives from public works and community development departments as well as the public health and engineering divisions. 
(9)  "Twenty-five percent rule (25% rule)" means all grease traps/interceptors shall be cleaned based on the 25% rule. FOR EXAMPLE: If the total depth (TD) of a grease trap/interceptor is forty inches, the maximum allowable depth (d) of floatable and settled FOG equals forty inches multiplied by 0.25 or d = TD x 0.25 = 10 inches. Therefore, the maximum allowable depth of floatable and settled FOG in the grease trap/interceptor should not exceed ten inches. 
(b)  Required Installation and Use of Grease Trap/Interceptors. 
(1)  Each person or operating facility within the village, other than a private residence, which is or will be used for the manufacture, processing or preparation of food or food products must install and use, at its own expense, an appropriately sized grease trap/interceptor. 
(2)  External grease interceptors are required for high volume establishments. A permit is required through the community development department and the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. 
(3)  All new or altered restaurants that require an external grease trap/interceptor shall install a minimum of a one thousand gallon unit as per the village's engineering grease basin standard. 
(4)  Mechanical dishwashers will not be allowed to connect to any grease trap/ interceptor. 
(5)  Interior grease traps are required for low volume establishments. These restaurants do not have deep fat fryers, woks or griddles and limit their menu to nonfried foods, sandwiches, soups and other fresh foods. Grease traps are required for retail food stores that have meat cutting rooms, fish and deli areas. Interior grease traps must be cleaned and maintained on a weekly basis to prevent backups and odors. 
(c)  Required Cleaning, Maintenance and Inspection of Grease Trap/Interceptors. 
(1)  Operation of Plumbing Equipment, Section 890.200 of the Illinois State Plumbing Code states all plumbing equipment required by this Part shall be operated in the manner intended by the manufacturer and as required by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago operating permit. No alteration or modifications to plumbing fixtures, equipment and appurtenances which negate specified safety features shall be allowed. All plumbing systems shall be maintained in a functional, safe and sanitary condition. The owner of the facility shall be responsible for maintenance of the sanitary plumbing system. 
(2)  Each person who owns or operates a grease trap/interceptor shall have it maintained by having the accumulated FOG removed by a licensed hauler. The collected material shall be delivered to a facility authorized to use, treat or dispose of such material. 
(3)  High volume establishments shall have the grease trap/interceptor cleaned of accumulated FOG completed on a biannual basis unless the village determines that less or more frequent maintenance schedule is required to minimize the discharge of FOG into the village sanitary sewer system. 
(4)  Low volume establishments shall have the grease trap/interceptor cleaned of accumulated FOG completed on a biannual basis unless the village determines that less or more frequent maintenance schedule is required to minimize the discharge of FOG into the village sanitary sewer system. 
(5)  The structural integrity of the grease trap/interceptor shall be maintained. Any decaying structure, as determined by the village must either be replaced or be repaired. Repairs or replacement shall be the sole responsibility of the owner. 
(d)  Prohibition of Discharge of FOG. 
(1)  No person shall discharge a concentration of FOG into the village sanitary sewers from a facility required to install, use and maintain a grease trap/interceptor. 
(2)  No person shall reintroduce or deposit into the sanitary sewer system FOG which have been removed from the sewer system by grease traps/interceptors. 
(e)  Prohibitions on Introduction of Enzymes and Emulsifiers. 
(1)  No person shall introduce, nor allow the introduction of physical, chemical or biological agents into grease trap/interceptors for the purpose of suspending, dissolving, emulsifying or rendering soluble any FOG removed from wastewater by such grease trap/interceptors and reintroducing them into the village sanitary sewer system. 
(f)  Record Keeping Requirements for Grease Trap/Interceptors. 
(1)  The owner or operator of the grease trap/interceptor shall receive a manifest form from the licensed hauler after the grease trap/interceptor is cleaned. This manifest shall be retained for a minimum of two years by the owner or operator and the copies be stored on site. 
(2)  A copy of the most recent manifest must be sent to the village health division biannually on/or before July 31st and December 31st. 
(g)  Inspections. Any of the following three methods listed below may be used to determine if any grease trap/interceptor is functioning properly: 
(1)  The village may make, without notice to the owner of the facility, periodic inspections of the grease trap/interceptor to verify current operating conditions. The inspectors may use the 25% rule to check the condition of the grease trap/interceptor. 
(2)  Visual inspection of the grease trap/interceptor will be conducted to verify structural integrity and functionality. 
(3)  Inspections of manholes downstream of grease trap/interceptors will be conducted by village inspectors to check for accumulations of greases from upstream grease trap/interceptors. 
(h)  Failure to Maintain Grease Trap/Interceptors. 
(1)  If the operating condition of the grease trap/interceptor is found to be in noncompliance, the owner shall be required to take immediate action to correct such deficiencies with the grease trap/interceptor upon receipt of the inspection report/notice of violation. 
(2)  If the owner does not correct the deficiencies noted on the notice of violation, in the time frame established, the village may cause the grease trap/interceptor and private sewer lines to be properly cleaned and maintained, either through private parties hired by the village or by village staff. 
(3)  The owner of the grease trap/interceptor will be held liable for all costs incurred by the lack of maintenance, including labor, materials, administrative costs whether by outside contractors or by village staff. 
(4)  The business license or annual business-related license may be suspended, revoked, or not renewed if the owner fails to reimburse the village for incurred expenses. 
(5)  Administrative citations will be issued to those establishments that fail to maintain their grease trap/interceptors. 
(Ord. No. 4547, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
Chapter 5.20 - MISCELLANEOUS HEALTH REGULATIONS[4] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note- Municipal authorities may act or regulate for the promotion of health or suppression of disease-See S.H.A. Ch. 24, § 11-20-5. 

5.20.010 - Polluting water sources. 
    It is unlawful and a nuisance for any person, firm or corporation to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply for the village. 
(1956 Code § 359) 
5.20.020 - Pools. 
    Any stagnant pool of water in the village is declared to be a nuisance. It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his or its control. 
(1956 Code § 360) 
5.20.030 - Uncovered refuse. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to deposit anywhere in the village any uncovered piles of refuse, garbage, offal or carcasses of dead animals. Such refuse must be buried at least two feet below the surface of the ground or burned in properly constructed incinerators, or otherwise properly disposed of. Any uncovered pile of refuse is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(1956 Code § 361) 
5.20.040 - Cemeteries. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to establish a cemetery or bury any person within the village limits, or within a mile thereof except in an established cemetery. 
(b)  It is unlawful to add to or increase the area of any cemetery or burial ground in the village. 
(1956 Code § 362) 
5.20.050 - Maintenance of premises. 
    It is unlawful to permit any building, structure or place, to remain in such condition as to be dangerous to the public health in any way. Any such structure, building or place is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(1956 Code § 363) 
5.20.060 - Endangering health generally. 
    It is unlawful to commit or do any act which endangers the health of the public or results in annoyance or disturbance to the public. 
(1956 Code § 364) 
5.20.065 - Intoxicating compounds. 
    No person shall breathe, inhale or drink any compound, liquid or chemical containing toluol, hexane, trichloroethylene, acetone, toluene, ethyl acetate, methyl ethyl ketone, trichloroethane, isopropanol, methyl isobutyl ketone, methyl cellosolve acetate, cyclohexanone, or any other substance for the purpose of inducing a condition of intoxication, stupefaction, depression, giddiness, paralysis or irrational behavior, or in any manner damaging, distorting or disturbing the auditory, visual or mental processes. For the purposes of this Act, any such condition so induced shall be deemed to be an intoxicated condition. No person shall knowingly sell or offer for sale, deliver or give to any person under seventeen years of age, unless upon written consent of such person's parents or guardian, any compound, liquid or chemical containing toluol, hexane, trichloroethylene, acetone, toluene, ethyl acetate, methyl, ethyl ketone, trichlorathane, isopropanol, methyl isobutyl ketone, methyl cello-solve acetate, cyclohexanone, or any other substance which will induce an intoxicated condition, as defined herein, when the seller, offeror or deliverer knows or has reason to know that such compound is intended for use to induce such condition. 
(Ord. 963 § C; July 22, 1968) 
5.20.070 - Drinking cups. 
    It is unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup, or cups, dipper or other similar utensil, for the use of more than one person in any public hall, theater, store or other public place frequented by the public. 
(1956 Code § 365) 
5.20.080 - Authority to abate nuisances. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit or maintain the existence of any nuisance on any property under her, or its control. The chief of police and the health officer are each hereby authorized to abate any such nuisance existing in the village, whether such nuisance is specifically recognized by ordinance or not. 
(1956 Code § 367) 
5.20.090 - Dense smoke. 
    It is unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner, fire pit or any other agency of the village so as to cause annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof. 
    For the purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke, the Ringlemann smoke chart as published and used by the United States Geological Survey, shall be and is hereby adopted as a standard for such grading, and smoke shall be, and is hereby, defined as and declared to be "dense" when it is of a degree of density of number three of said chart, or greater, for more than six minutes in any one hour whether such period of time is consecutive or not. 
(1956 Code § 369) 
(Ord. No. 5223, §§ E, F, 12-3-2018) 
Editor's note- Section E of Ord. No. 5223, adopted Dec. 3, 2018, repealed former § 5.20.090 which pertained to spitting and derived from the 1956 Code, § 368. Said ordinance renumbered former §§ 5.20.100-5.20.110 as 5.20.090-5.20.105. 
5.20.100 - Well sealing. 
(a)  The owner of a property on which a private water well, boring or monitoring well exists shall assure that such well is sealed within thirty days after it is no longer used for the purpose for which it was intended. The village may grant an extension of time for sealing the well or boring provided the owner makes such request in writing. The request must include a date by which the well will be sealed or reused. 
(b)  All water wells, borings and monitoring wells must be sealed in accordance with all the requirements of the Illinois Department of Public Health. 
(Ord. 3434 § A, 1999) 
(Ord. No. 5223, § E, 12-3-2018) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 5.20.090. 
5.20.105. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04 of this code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 799 § A (part); March 1, 1965) 
(Ord. No. 5223, § E, 12-3-2018) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 5.20.090. 
Chapter 5.24 - CONTAGIOUS DISEASE[5] 
Sections: 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 5223, § G, adopted Dec. 3, 2018, amended Ch. 5.24 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 5.24, §§ 5.24.010-5.24.070 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the 1956 Code, §§ 336-340; and Ord. No. 799 X, § A, adopted March 1, 1965. 

5.24.010 - Authority to regulate quarantine and vaccination. 
    The village of Wheeling is hereby authorized to enforce and make such reasonable rules as may be necessary regarding quarantine and vaccination, for the prevention of the spread of contagious diseases, and to quarantine premises where such diseases occur for such time as may be necessary to protect public health, and to further the rules and objectives set by the Illinois Department of Health. 
(Ord. No. 5223, § G, 12-3-2018)

    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04 of this code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 5223, § G, 12-3-2018) 
Chapter 5.26 - MEDICAL WASTE 
Sections: 

5.26.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Chapter is to protect the environment and the public from infection and injury from improperly stored and disposed of infectious medical waste. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.020 - Definitions. 
    The terms shall have the following meanings when used in this Chapter: 
(1)  "Biologicals" means preparations made from living organisms and their products including vaccines, cultures, etc., intended for use in diagnosing, immunizing or treating humans or animals, or in research pertaining thereto. 
(2)  "Blood products" means any product derived from human blood including, but not limited to, blood plasma, platelets, red or white blood corpuscles and other derived products, such as interferon, etc. 
(3)  "Body fluids" means liquid emanating or derived from humans or animals, limited to blood, cerebrospinal, synovial, pleural, peritoneal, and pericardial fluids, and semen and vaginal secretions. 
(4)  "Communicable disease" means an infectious agent or its toxic products which can be transmitted directly or indirectly to a well person from an infected person, animal, or arthropod, or through the agency of an intermediate host, vector, or the inanimate environment. 
(5)  "Contaminated" means the presence of blood, blood products, body fluids, excretia, secretions, biologicals or infectious agents on solid waste. The term includes solid waste that is soaked with such matter and solid waste onto which such matter is dried and caked. 
(6)  "Cultures" means cultures and stocks of infectious agents and associated biologicals, including cultures from medical and pathological laboratories, research and industrial laboratories, waste from the production of biologicals, discarded live and attenuated vaccines, and cultures dishes and devices used to transfer, inoculate and mix cultures. 
(7)  "Facility, or generator's facility" means all contiguous land and structures, and other appurtenances and improvements at the location where a generator conducts or performs those acts and process procedures which produce infectious medical waste. 
(8)  "Generator" means a person, firm or corporation whose act or process procedures produces infectious medical waste. In the case where more than one generator is located in one building operating independently, each individual is a separate generator. In the case where several generators work for a single institution, e.g., a hospital, the institution is the generator. Examples of generators include, but are not limited to: 
(a)  Hospitals and clinics; 
(b)  Physicians, dentists, podiatrists, chiropractors, and any professional licensed under the Illinois Medical Licensing Act, or other professionals who diagnose and treat human beings; 
(c)  Medical diagnostic laboratories; 
(d)  Blood banks and plasma centers; 
(e)  Ambulatory surgical facilities; 
(f)  Long-term health care facilities; 
(g)  Research or analytical laboratories; 
(h)  Pharmaceutical facilities; 
(i)  Veterinaries and veterinary hospitals and clinics; 
(j)  Mortuaries; and 
(k)  Animal quarantine facilities. 
(9)  "Infectious agent" means any organism that is capable of being communicated by invasion of and multiplication in body tissues and capable of causing disease or adverse health impacts in humans or animals. 
(10)  "Infectious medical waste" means waste that is generated in the diagnosis, treatment, or immunization of human beings and animals, or in the research pertaining thereto, or in the production and testing of biologicals, or the collection and distribution of blood supplies, which may be capable of transmitting a communicable disease. Infectious medical waste includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(a)  Pathological waste; 
(b)  Cultures; 
(c)  Sharps; 
(d)  Biologicals; 
(e)  Blood and blood products; 
(f)  Human body parts and contaminated disposable bedding, bandages and dressings; 
(g)  Contaminated laboratory wastes; 
(h)  Wastes from surgery and autopsy; 
(i)  Animal carcasses, animal body parts and body fluids, and contaminated bedding; and 
(j)  Isolation wastes. 
(11)  "Isolation waste" means biological wastes and discarded materials contaminated with blood, excretia, exudates, or secretions from humans who are isolated to protect others from certain highly communicable diseases, or isolated animals known to be infected with highly communicable diseases. 
(12)  "Laboratory" means any research, analytical, or clinical facility that performs health care related analysis or service. This includes medical, pathological, pharmaceutical, and other research, commercial, or industrial laboratories. 
(13)  "Liquid infectious medical waste" means liquid waste that is included with solid infectious medical waste for treatment and disposal. It does not include urine, wash water, and other liquids more properly disposed of via the sanitary sewer. 
(14)  "Pathological waste" means body tissues, organs, and body parts and body fluids removed during medical procedures, and specimens of body fluids and their containers. 
(15)  "Regulatory authority" means village of Wheeling acting through the village sanitarian, or his designee. 
(16)  "Secure area" means an area within the generator's facility which is accessible only to the generator and employees trained to handle infectious medical wastes. If indoors, the area must not be accessible to the general public. If outdoors, the area must be covered and locked. 
(17)  "Sharps" means hypodermic needles, suture needles, syringes (with or without the attached needle), pasteur pipettes, scalpel blades, blood vials, needles with attached tubing, and culture dishes (regardless of presence of infectious agents) that have been used in animal or human patient care or treatment or in medical, research, or industrial laboratories. Also included are other types of broken or unbroken glassware that were in contact with infectious agents, such as used slides and cover slips. 
(18)  "Transportation" means the shipment or conveyance of infectious medical waste by air, rail, highway, or water. 
(19)  "Transporter" means a person engaged in the off-site transportation of infectious medical waste. 
(20)  "Treatment or effective treatment of infectious medical waste" means any method, technique or process designed to change the biological character or composition of any infectious medical waste so as to reduce the pathogenic qualities or eliminate its potential for causing disease. To be effective, the treatment must be designed for the waste the question. The treatment may include, but is not limited to, the following: 
(a)  incineration; 
(b)  steam sterilization (autoclaving); 
(c)  chemical disinfection; 
(d)  thermal inactivation; 
(e)  irradiation. 
(21)  "Universal biohazard symbol" means the symbol design that conforms to the design shown in 29 CFR 1910.145(f)(8)(ii). 
(22)  "Waste" means materials which are being discarded. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.030 - Duty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to package, store, transport, treat, or dispose of infectious medical waste in violation of the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.040 - Protocol required. 
    Generators of infectious medical waste shall establish a written protocol complying with the provisions of this Chapter and specifying the procedures to be followed in the generator's facility for the handling, packaging, storage, transportation, treatment and final disposal of infectious medical waste generated in the generator's facility. The protocol shall include procedures for: 
(1)  Storage of infectious medical waste before it is treated or removed from the generator's facility; 
(2)  Methods of treatment, if effective treatment is provided at the generator's facility, and quality control procedures as specified by the treatment equipment's manufacturer; 
(3)  Method of removal of the infectious medical waste from the generator's facility, including documentation of removal, and if removed by a person other than the generator or generator's employee, evidence that the person so removing the infectious medical waste in licensed to do so; 
(4)  Final disposal method; and 
(5)  Retention of records as required in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.050 - Records required. 
(a)  The generator shall maintain at the facility and make available to the regulatory authority upon request the following records: 
(1)  The written protocol; 
(2)  A generator's log showing dates that generator removed and transported infectious medical waste to a treatment or disposal facility; 
(3)  Receipts from the licensed waste haulers who have removed the waste for transportation to a treatment or disposal facility, or from the treatment or disposal facility to which the infectious medical waste was delivered; and 
(4)  The name, address, telephone number and, if applicable, the license number of the hauler removing the infectious medical waste, or, the treatment or disposal facility to which the infectious medical waste was delivered. 
(b)  The generator shall maintain, at the facility, the required records for a minimum of thirty-six months. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.060 - Receipts required. 
    The generator shall obtain a receipt from the hauler which removes the infectious medical waste from the generator's facility, or the treatment or disposal facility to which the generator delivers the infectious medical waste. Such receipts shall be maintained for thirty-six months. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.070 - Storage. 
(a)  Infectious medical waste which is being stored prior to being effectively treated at the generator's facility, or being stored prior to removal by a licensed waste hauler or the generator, shall be packaged according to the provisions of this Chapter and stored in a secure area. 
(b)  Each container of infectious waste shall be individually marked with the universal biohazard symbol. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.080 - Storage duration. 
    Infectious medical waste which can putrefy and generate noxious odors shall be stored for no longer than seven days at temperatures above fifteen degrees Fahrenheit or no longer than thirty days at temperatures of fifteen degrees Fahrenheit or below. All other infectious medical waste shall be stored for the shortest possible time but in no case shall it be stored longer than thirty days. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.090 - Packaging. 
    Infectious medical waste shall be packaged in the following manner: 
(1)  Liquid shall be placed in a leak-proof container before being bagged, boxed, or placed in a drum; 
(2)  Sharps shall be placed in a puncture-resistant container which is nonopenable except by use of tools, before being bagged, boxed, or placed in a drum; 
(3)  All waste shall be placed in sealed, tear-resistant plastic bags, identified by the universal biohazard symbol. The bags shall be thick enough to contain any liquid infectious waste which may spill or leak into it; and 
(4)  All waste shall be placed in a second bag, box, or drum identified with the universal biohazard symbol if the treatment process destroyed the biohazard symbol or reduced the structural integrity of the original container. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.100 - Treatment. 
    The generator may provide effective treatment at the generator's facility. If so, the generator shall conduct quality assurance checks, as specified by the treatment equipment manufacturer, on the waste and equipment and retain the records of the checks for thirty-six months. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.110 - Transportation. 
    Infectious medical waste shall be transported from the generator's facility to the treatment or final disposal facility by an Illinois Environmental Protection Agency Licensed Special Waste Hauler, except that the generator or an employee of the generator may transport the infectious medical waste to the treatment or final disposal facility. If the infectious medical waste is transported to the treatment or final disposal facility by an employee of the generator, the generator shall be jointly liable for violations of this Chapter committed by the employee. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.120 - Final disposal. 
    Final disposal of infectious medical waste, both treated and untreated, shall be in a sanitary landfill or an incinerator approved by the United States Environmental Protection Agency to accept infectious or medical wastes. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.130 - Exemptions. 
    Waste generated by an individual's self treatment shall be exempt from the provisions of this Chapter, except that sharps so generated shall be securely packaged in a sealed, leak-proof, rigid, puncture proof container prior to disposal. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
5.26.140 - Penalties. 
    Each violation of a provision of this Chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars. Each day a violation of any provision of this Chapter exists shall be deemed to be a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2729 § A (part), 1991) 
Chapter 5.28 - VITAL STATISTICS 
Sections: 

5.28.010 - Registrar of vital statistics. 
    The village clerk shall be and is hereby made registrar of vital statistics for the village. 
(1956 Code § 332) 
5.28.020 - Reports required. 
    A report of all births, stillbirths and deaths shall be made to the local registrar of vital statistics, which report shall contain all information required by law. 
(1956 Code § 333) 
5.28.030 - Record of vital statistics. 
    The registrar shall keep a record showing all births, stillbirths and deaths occurring within the village which record shall include the information required to be kept by statute. 
(1956 Code § 334) 
5.28.040 - Statutory rule.* 
    The provisions of the statutes relative to vital statistics shall be fully complied with by the village clerk in connection with vital statistic reports. 
    The village clerk shall make or cause to be made sufficient copies of all such records so that one complete set thereof may be retained and kept by the village. 
(1956 Code § 335) 
* Registration of vital statistics provided for by statute-See S.H.A. Ch. 111 1/2 §§ 36, et seq. 
5.28.050 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 799 X § A (part), 1965) 
Chapter 5.30 - MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE SYSTEM 
Sections: 

5.30.010 - Definitions. 
    The terms defined in this section shall have the meanings prescribed herein: 
    "Agency" means the solid waste agency of Northern Cook County. 
    "Municipal solid waste system" means the waste collection, transportation and disposal system of the municipality, pursuant to this Chapter, including all physical assets of the municipality and licensee used for the collection, transportation and disposal of system waste, all amounts on deposit in the municipal solid waste system fund and all amounts collected on account of rates and charges imposed under this Chapter. 
    "Person" means any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, or corporation, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
    "Project use agreement" means the 1992 project use agreement by and between the municipality and the agency, as amended from time to time. 
    "System waste" means garbage and general household waste from a residential dwelling discarded by persons within the corporate limits of the municipality. System waste does not include (1) institutional waste, (2) commercial and office waste, (3) industrial lunchroom waste, (4) construction and demolition waste, or (5) garbage and household waste from a mixed-use premises. 
    "Village" means the village of Wheeling, Illinois. 
(Ord. 2777 § B (part), 1992) 
5.30.020 - Required use of municipal waste system. 
(a)  All persons owning or occupying residential real estate within the corporate limits of the village shall dispose of system waste though the municipal solid waste system. All system waste shall be collected by or on behalf of the village pursuant to the terms of this Chapter and shall be delivered to a transfer station as directed by the agency and the village or as otherwise agreed to by the agency and the village under the project use agreement. 
(b)  No person shall dispose of system waste through the municipal solid waste system unless the system waste complies with all rules and regulations applicable thereto and established from time to time by either the village or the agency. 
(c)  Any person disposing of the system waste through the municipal solid waste system shall pay the rates and charges established by the village. 
(Ord. 2777 § B (part), 1992) 
5.30.030 - Private collectors and haulers. 
(a)  No person shall collect, transport or dispose of system waste without a license issued pursuant to the Chapter 5.32 of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(b)  Any person holding a license to collect, transport or dispose of system waste shall comply with the following obligations as a condition of that license in addition to those obligations set forth in Chapter 5.32: 
(1)  Comply with all the laws, ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to the collection, transportation and disposal of system waste as may be enacted from time to time by any lawful authority, including the state of Illinois, the village and the agency; 
(2)  Deliver all system waste to the transfer station designated by the agency and the village and at the direction of the village; 
(3)  Maintain all equipment used to collect, transport and dispose of system waste in good repair and working order and operate it efficiently and effectively; 
(4)  Collect as agent for and promptly pay to the village all rates and charges imposed by the village or agency on persons using the municipal solid waste system; 
(5)  Maintain accurate books and records and make them available to the village upon demand; 
(6)  Identify, pursuant to agency rules, vehicles used to transport system waste; 
(7)  To operate in a safe manner assuring to the greatest extent possible safety to the lives and property of all municipal residents. 
(c)  At time of application for any license issued under Chapter 5.32 of the Wheeling Municipal Code, the applicant shall provide to the village a listing of all residential customers to be served ("customer list") and projected annualized waste volume for said customers. If any residential customer is added to or deleted from said customer list, the licensee shall so notify the village in writing within ten days of said change. 
(Ord. 2777 § B (part), 1992) 
5.30.040 - The municipal waste system fund-Imposition of rates and charges. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established an enterprise fund of the village known as the municipal solid waste system fund, which shall be separate and apart from all other fund and accounts of the village as provided in subsection (g) of this section. 
(b)  As part of the regular budget process, the village manager shall recommend and the president and board of trustees shall adopt a budget for the municipal solid waste system. The budget shall estimate the revenue required to (1) pay all operating and maintenance expenses of the municipal solid waste system, including all obligations to the agency under the project use agreement; (2) pay as they become due interest on and principal of any revenue bonds or other obligations payable from the revenues of the municipal solid waste system; (3) provide for all unpaid claims; and (4) maintain appropriate depreciation and reserve funds, including reserves for uncollected charges. The budget shall estimate the amounts available to pay those obligations from (1) taxes levied and anticipated to be collected pursuant to law; (2) other amounts deposited in the municipal solid waste system fund; and (3) rates and charges to be imposed on persons disposing of system waste through the municipal solid waste system. 
(c)  The rates and charges imposed for use of the municipal solid waste system shall be sufficient, after taking into account monies then on hand in the municipal solid waste system fund and the proceeds of taxes levied and to be collected which have been assigned and pledged to the municipal solid waste system fund, (1) to pay all operation and maintenance expenses of the municipal solid waste system, including all obligations to the agency under the terms of the project use agreement; (2) to pay as they become due interest on and principal of any revenue bonds or other obligations payable from revenues of the municipal solid waste system; (3) to provide for all unpaid claims; and (4) to provide adequate depreciation and reserve funds for the municipal solid waste system, including reserves for uncollected charges. 
(d)  The village shall prepare and deliver a monthly bill setting forth the estimated or actual amount of charges for use of the municipal solid waste system. The bill for each month shall be paid no later than twenty days from the date of said bill. A late charge of three percent shall be paid on all amounts due and unpaid on the due date. In the event all amounts due, including any late charges, are not paid by the end of the month in which they are due, interest shall be charged on all such unpaid amounts at the rate of one percent per month or portion of a month, which interest shall accrue beginning with the first day of the calendar month after the due date. 
(e)  In addition to the right to receive a late charge and interest, the village reserves all other rights and remedies it may have at law or in equity, including but not by the way of limitation, revocation of license. Election of any remedy shall not be waiver of any other remedy. 
(f)  The owners and occupants of residential real estate within the village served by the municipal solid waste system shall be jointly and severally liable to pay all rates and charges imposed by the village pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter. 
(g)  All amounts collected from rates and charges imposed under this section shall be deposited in the municipal solid waste system fund, and together with all other amounts deposited in the municipal solid waste system fund, shall be separate and apart from all other monies of the municipality, except amounts deposited in the municipal waste system fund may be invested together with other funds of the village. 
(Ord. 2777 § B (part), 1992) 
Chapter 5.32 - GARBAGE AND REFUSE DISPOSAL* 
Sections: 

5.32.005 - Definitions. 
    The terms defined in this section, when used in this Chapter, shall have the meanings prescribed herein, unless the context clearly requires another meaning: 
(1)  "Approved receptacle" means a refuse or landscape receptacle as specified in Sections 5.32.020 and 5.32.025 of this code. 
(2)  "Bulk items" means items which by their size or nature are rendered unsuitable for deposit into an approved receptacle (including but not limited to pianos, beds, box springs, mattresses, sofas, furniture, furnishings and fixtures) and shall be called for and removed by a licensed scavenger service within seven days of being discarded. 
(3)  "Commercial handbill" means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copy of any matter of literature: 
(a)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, service or thing; 
(b)  Which directs attention to any business, mercantile or commercial establishment or other activity, for the purpose of directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; 
(c)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; or 
(d)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
(4)  "Landscape waste" means all accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs three inches or less in diameter, tree trimmings, brush, and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, bushes, shrubbery, vines, and trees. 
(5)  "Litter" means garbage, refuse and rubbish as defined in this section and all other waste material. 
(6)  "Newspaper" means newspaper of general circulation or any newspaper duly entered with the postal service of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulations and, in addition, means and includes any periodical or magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year, and sold to the public. 
(7)  "Noncommercial handbill" means any printed or written matter, any sample, or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copy of any matter of literature not included in the definitions of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
(8)  "Non-system waste" means commercial refuse and multi-family residential refuse (excluding townhome refuse), and certain commercial and multi-family recyclable materials (excluding townhome recyclables). 
(9)  "Parkway" means that portion of the dedicated right-of-way between the property line and the edge of the pavement. 
(10)  "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association, trust or land trust, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(11)  "Political literature" means any circular, handbill, pamphlet or similar printed material which promotes or opposes the nomination or election of any person to public or to political party office, or the adoption or defeat of any proposition to be submitted to referendum, or the promotion or opposition of any political party or its candidates; provided, that such nomination, election or referendum to which the literature relates is to be voted upon by citizens of the village of Wheeling, in part or entirely. 
(12)  "Private premises" means any dwelling, house, building, or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and includes any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
(13)  "Public place" means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public squares, spaces, grounds, public parks, tot lots and public buildings. 
(14)  "Recyclable materials" means: 
(a)  Fiber products, including, but not limited to, newspaper and inserts, computer paper, white ledger paper (bond, typing, copier and index cards), colored paper (bond, typing, copier and index cards), envelopes (with and without windows), plain paper facsimile paper, mixed paper (including magazines, catalogs, telephone books, junk mail, paper bags, and chipboard), manila and bleached file folders, junk mail, NCR forms, telephone and MLS books, old corrugated items, cardboard, overseas cardboard, post-in notes and chipboard; 
(b)  Containers, including, but not limited to, glass bottles and jars (clear, green and brown, excluding ceramics, window glass and Pyrex), food and drink cans (aluminum, steel and bi-metal), juice and milk boxes and cartons, aerosol cans, aluminum foil and formed aluminum (pie pans and pastry trays), plastics (coded plastics numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7, including #1 PETE and #2 HDPE plastic, and plastic rings from soda and beer packs); 
(c)  Aseptic beverage containers; and 
(d)  Any other items mutually agreed upon by the municipality and the contractor. 
(15)  "Refuse" means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
(16)  "Residential dwelling unit" means any single-family home, townhome or multi-family residential dwelling containing four or fewer units. 
(17)  "Reusable household goods" means articles of personal property including, but not limited to, clothing, toys, books, linens, tools, cooking utensils, glassware, dishware, electrical items or appliances placed within a labeled recycling container for pick up in the recycling program. 
(18)  "Rubbish" means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, metal cans, processed wood materials, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
(19)  "System waste" means garbage and general household waste, including Christmas trees, from a residential dwelling discarded by persons within the corporate limits of the village. System waste does not include: 
(a)  Institutional waste, 
(b)  Commercial and office waste, 
(c)  Industrial lunchroom waste, 
(d)  Construction and demolition waste, or 
(e)  Garbage and household waste from a mixed use premises. 
(20)  "Vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(21)  "White goods" means items including, but not limited to, stoves, ovens (including microwave ovens), washing machines, dryers, air conditioners, refrigerators, freezers, dehumidifiers, water softeners, water heaters, trash compactors and dishwashers. 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 2621 § A, 1990: Ord. 2587 § A (part), 1989) 
5.32.010 - Disposal requirement. 
(a)  The occupancy or use of any premises shall be prima facie evidence that refuse is being produced and accumulated on such premises, and pick ups must be made. All refuse shall be called for and disposed of by a scavenger service duly licensed by the village except that building or other construction contractors may remove construction, remodeling and demolition debris, tree trunks, bush and shrubs. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every person in possession of any premises to cause all refuse produced on the premises to be securely wrapped or bound and placed in approved refuse receptacles, as specified in Sections 5.32.020 and 5.32.025, in such manner as may be necessary to prevent the same from being scattered, spilled or blown away. All refuse of a size or nature which renders it unsuitable for deposit in approved refuse receptacles shall be placed on the ground adjacent to the receptacles in neat and orderly bundles or stacks not to exceed seventy pounds in weight and four feet in length, except as otherwise provided in this Chapter. Any refuse, which is by its size or nature rendered unsuitable for deposit into an approved receptacle, shall be called for and removed by a licensed scavenger service within seven days of being discarded. 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 2931 § A, 1993; Ord. 2621 § B, 1990: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.020 - Specifications for refuse receptacles. 
(a)  Residential with Curbside Pick Up. Each residential dwelling unit in the village shall be provided with either a standardized ninety gallon, sixty-five gallon or a thirty gallon covered waste container and either a sixty-five gallon or thirty gallon cart for recycling and replacement containers, free of charge to the resident. Residents shall have the option to request one replacement container of smaller size for both the waste and recyclables free of charge. Any resident request for a change-out based on size after the first change will be charged to the resident. Said containers shall be the property of the village. Each residential unit shall be responsible for properly utilizing these village-approved covered waste containers. Any waiver of this receptacle requirement shall be determined by the village manager or his designee. 
(b)  Commercial, industrial, institutional, and multi-family residential other than residential dwelling units as defined in Section 5.32.005(16) shall conform to the following specifications: 
(1)  Metal containers with covers commonly called "leach" type, with a capacity from one yard to three yards, or equivalent; 
(2)  Metal containers commonly called "trip-savers" with a capacity from three yards to ten yards, not equipped with wheels; 
(3)  Metal-enclosed container designed for use with a stationary compaction system; 
(4)  When scrap or waste for recycling in commercial, industrial, or institutional areas is allowed under Title 19, Zoning, of the Wheeling Municipal Code, the owner shall store the scrap or waste for recycling in receptacles similar in design and construction to those required in this subsection (b) for garbage, refuse and/or waste. Such recycling receptacle shall be leakproof to prevent oils or other liquids which may be on the solid waste from leaking into the environment and scrap or waste stored therein shall be stored so as to prevent the contents from being disseminated by the elements. The owner, operator, occupant or person in control of the property, or a part thereof, shall store the receptacle inside a completely enclosed building or shall provide a rainproof, weatherproof and waterproof cover on or over the receptacle, and shall not install holes in the receptacle to drain the water out. The owner, operator, occupant or person in control of the property, or a part thereof, shall maintain such recycling receptacles in good condition and free of leaks. The owner, operator, occupant or person in control of the property, or a part thereof, shall have the recycling receptacle emptied and its contents removed on a schedule or frequency similar to the schedule or frequency on which the contents of the refuse receptacle(s) is (are) removed, but not less frequently than once each month. 
(c)  The number and size of receptacles required in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be sufficient to completely contain all refuse generated at the premises between scavenger service pick ups. The number and size of receptacles required in subsection (b)(4) of this section shall be sufficient to completely contain all recyclable materials generated at the premises between recycling service pick ups. The owner, occupant or agent in control of the premises shall increase the number or size of the receptacles when the existing receptacle(s) is (are) inadequate to completely contain all recyclable materials generated at the premises between recycling service pick ups. The owner, occupant or agent in control of the premises shall increase the number or size of the receptacles when the existing receptacle(s) is (are) inadequate to completely contain all refuse or recyclable materials generated between pick ups. When additional receptacles or larger receptacles are added or installed, the receptacle enclosure, if any, shall be enlarged to accommodate and screen the new additional or larger receptacle. 
(d)  Scrap or waste for recycling in residential areas with curbside pick up shall be stored in receptacles approved by the village for such use. 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 2621 § C, 1990: Ord. 2518 § A, 1989: Ord. 1847 § B, 1982; Ord. 1280 § A, 1974; Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.025 - Specifications for landscape waste receptacles. 
    Residential Dwelling Units. "Receptacle" for curbside pick up of landscape waste shall be either a suitable container or a paper landscape waste bag constructed of two ply Kraft paper with a wet strength of at least fifty pounds, with a flat bottom and a capacity of not less than twenty gallons and not more than thirty gallons. Residents will be required to mark garbage containers not exceeding thirty gallons, containing, landscape waste with a large red "X" for ease of identification. No plastic bags or boxes of any kind shall be allowed. Tree trimmings and brush must be tied in bundles that do not exceed a weight of seventy pounds per bundle, are not more than four feet long, are not more than two feet in diameter, do not contain limbs greater than three inches in diameter and are tied with a biodegradable material. Landscape waste shall not be placed in the receptacles provided pursuant to Section 5.32.020(a). 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 2621 § D, 1990) 
5.32.030 - Burning of paper, garbage, leaves or other litter. 
    Open burning of paper, garbage, leaves, litter, refuse or any other materials is prohibited and declared unlawful. However, gas incinerators or similar equipment fueled independently from the refuse or other material to be incinerated, which is properly installed so as not to constitute a health hazard and subject to the inspection and approval by the building or health inspector, may be used for the burning of paper, garbage, leaves, refuse or other litter, provided that such incinerator or its use does not violate any rule or regulation of the Illinois or United States Environmental Protection Agencies. 
(Ord. 1701 § A (part), 1980: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.040 - Deposit of garbage or refuse. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to burn or bury garbage in any manner, or to permit garbage to accumulate in any manner so as to create a nuisance and to attract flies, vermin, rats, or to permit any garbage to accumulate more than seven days. 
(b)  No garbage or refuse of any kind shall be deposited in any street, alley or public way except in approved receptacles for collection by a licensed scavenger service. 
(c)  No garbage or refuse shall be deposited before 5:00 p.m. of the day before the scheduled pick up. Empty receptacles shall be removed by or before 8:00 a.m. the day after collection. 
(d)  No garbage or refuse of any kind shall be deposited in any exposed place, public or private, unless it is in a proper receptacle as provided in this Chapter. All receptacles shall be covered with a lid or cover. 
(e)  In residential districts, on days other than collection days as described above, all waste and recycling containers, along with bulk items, shall be kept in the garage or adjacent to a principal structure within the side or rear yard of any lot. No waste or recycling containers can be stored in front of a principal structure or within the front yard area of any single-family lot. 
(f)  Properly installed kitchen garbage disposal units may be used for the disposal of garbage into sewer lines, subject to the ordinance and regulations of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. 
(g)  Any person, firm or corporation depositing or permitting the deposit of garbage or refuse in violating of this Chapter is guilty of violating the provisions hereof and shall be subject to the penalties provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 2587 § B, 1989: Ord. 1701 § A (part), 1980: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
(Ord. No. 4349, § A, 8-25-2008; Ord. No. 4413, § A, 4-20-2009) 
5.32.043 - Unlawful collection of recyclables. 
    It is unlawful for any person to collect, obtain, possess or remove any recyclable material or reusable household good placed for collection at any residence unless authorized by the village to do so. 
(Ord. 2587 § A (part), 1989) 
5.32.045 - Receptacle enclosure maintenance. 
    The owner, operator, occupant or person in control of the property, or part thereof, where an enclosure is provided for the refuse or recycling receptacle, shall: 
(a)  Maintain the receptacle inside the enclosure at all times; 
(b)  Maintain all litter, garbage or other debris, refuse or waste inside the refuse receptacle at all times and shall maintain the floor of the enclosure clean and free of all litter, garbage or other debris, refuse or waste; 
(c)  Where an enclosure is on property occupied by a food handling establishment, the receptacle for the waste fats and oils, shall also be located inside the enclosure if the receptacle for said fats and oils is not stored inside the building; 
(d)  Maintain the enclosure in good repair at all times; 
(e)  Maintain the gates of the enclosure, if so equipped, closed at all times; 
(f)  Maintain the gates of the enclosure, if so equipped, in good repair, and operational at all times; 
(g)  Maintain the enclosure, and surrounding area, free of snow and ice to enable the scavenger service to access and remove the receptacle, in order to collect the refuse, and replace the receptacle in the enclosure after the refuse has been collected. 
(Ord. 2518 § B, 1989) 
5.32.050 - License required for scavenger service-Applications. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of collection, transportation or disposing of solid waste within the village without first having secured an exclusive franchise or a license for performing such work. 
(b)  All residential dwelling units, commercial properties, and multi-family buildings shall be serviced by the exclusive solid waste franchise scavenger selected by the village. No person occupying a residential dwelling unit, commercial property, or multi-family building shall enter into or extend a current contract for solid waste collection after June 1, 2004. All contracts that are not exempted under subsection (d) of this section shall be deemed invalid after June 1, 2004. 
(c)  Collection. Private scavengers operating under a license or exclusive franchise shall provide collection services as often as may be required to prevent a nuisance or a threat to public health, welfare and safety but in no event shall service be less than once each week. The site and containers, for storage of waste materials shall meet the requirements of health, sanitation and safety set by the village manager or his designee by the village board. 
(d)  Use of Licensed Scavenger. Any residential dwelling unit, commercial property, or multi-family building user that has been granted an exemption from the exclusive franchise or has a valid contract for solid waste services shall utilize only a scavenger that is licensed by the village. 
(e)  Obligations of Franchisee and Licensee. Each licensee or franchisee shall maintain its equipment used in the designated services in good repair and working order, shall perform its operations efficiently and faithfully, and shall punctually perform all obligations imposed on it pursuant to this section. All collection equipment used by the licensee or franchisee must have the name of the firm clearly displayed on both sides of vehicles and on the front of refuse containers. 
(f)  Availability of Books. Each licensee or franchisee shall make and keep proper books and accounts in which complete entries shall be made of all transactions relating to the licensed or franchised services (separate and apart from all other records and accounts of the licensee or franchisee), which books and accounts shall be made available to inspection by the village. 
(g)  Standards and Specifications. All licensees or franchisees shall meet any other standards and specifications, with respect to service, fees and collection thereof, and manner of performance, as may from time to time be required by agreement of the village and such licensee or franchisee. 
(h)  Indemnification. All licensees and franchisees shall indemnify, save and keep harmless, the village from any and all loss, cost damage, expense or liability of any kind whatsoever, which the village may suffer or which may be recovered against the village from or on account of the issuance of the license or franchise agreement or on account of any activity advocated or permitted by the village. Licensees and franchisees shall furnish the village a certificate of insurance for the insurance amounts indicated in a solid waste agreement, as established by the village manager or designee, and shall obtain additional insured coverage protecting the village for the required amounts of insurance, which additional insured status shall be reflected in the certificate of insurance. 
(i)  Revocation. The village manager has the authority to temporarily revoke the license or franchise of any scavenger whose practices present an immediate threat to the health, safety and well being of the community or any persons therein. The village manager has the right of permanent revocation for violation of any of the provisions herein upon notice and after a hearing. 
(j)  The village will provide, through its exclusive franchised contractor, solid waste and disposal services to all residential dwelling units, commercial properties, and multi-family buildings not having an existing collection and disposal contract, as of June 1, 2004. All fees for solid waste and disposal services, in accordance with the exclusive franchise contract, shall be the responsibility of the users. For commercial and multi-family buildings of five or more units having an existing solid waste collection and disposal contract as of June 1, 2004, such users will be incorporated into the franchised service no later than June 1, 2005. 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 1485 § B, 1977: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.060 - Qualifications for scavenger service. 
    No such license shall be issued except after the approval of the application by the board of health of the village. No such license shall be issued to or held by any person who does not comply with this Chapter. No such license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a person of good character or who has been convicted of a felony; nor shall such license be issued to or held by any corporation if any officer thereof would be ineligible for a license under the foregoing conditions. 
(Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.070 - Franchise fees for scavengers. 
    The annual franchise fee payable in advance shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. The payment of the franchise fee and the purchase of vehicle license fees for each vehicle operated, leased or owned shall be paid prior to the issuance of a license permitting the business of operating a scavenger service in the village. 
(Ord. 4131 § J, 2006: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.080 - Notification of scavenger vehicle identification. 
    The licensee shall notify the director of finance of the motor number and state license number of each scavenger truck operated and of the corresponding municipal tag or sticker number. 
(Ord. 1485 § C, 1977: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § I, 3-21-2011) 
5.32.090 - Insurance requirement. 
(a)  Every licensee is required to carry a full line of general and public liability insurance in amounts deemed prudent to properly carry out the provisions of this Chapter. In no case will the amounts, by line of coverage, be less than the statutory requirements for worker's compensation; five hundred thousand dollars per individual and one million dollars per accident bodily injury for automotive, with a one hundred fifty thousand dollar per accident coverage for property damage; and a general liability policy with limits of at least five hundred thousand dollars each person and one million dollars each accident bodily injury liability with one hundred fifty thousand dollars each accident for property damage. 
(b)  A certificate of insurance shall be kept on file with the village and will be updated at least annually with submittal of an application for a scavenger service license. Insurance certificates shall name the village as an additional insured. Said insurance policies shall not be cancelable without thirty days prior written notice to the village. 
(Ord. 2621 § E, 1990: Ord. 1485 § D, 1977: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.100 - Standards and schedules of scavenger service. 
(a)  Residential Dwelling Units. The scavenger service shall provide and furnish a regular weekly curbside scheduled collection service, (provided, that where a regularly scheduled service falls on a holiday, service shall be made the following working day) in the following manner: 
(i)  System waste, bulk items, white goods, and recyclable materials will be picked up on the same pick up day each week. 
(ii)  From April 1st through November 30th of any calendar year, or portion thereof, landscape waste will be picked up on the same pick up day each week as system waste, bulk items, white goods, and recyclable materials. 
(iii)  In addition to the regular service as provided in subsection (a)(i) herein, residents shall be provided on a voluntary subscription basis, a second weekly pick up day for system waste. 
(iv)  The scavenger service will not remove scrap materials from construction, remodeling and repair of buildings, nor concrete, bricks, tile, earth and earth materials, roots or tree trunks. Material not included in the regular pick up will be removed by the scavenger service on special order by the customer. 
(b)  Commercial Properties and Multi-Family Buildings. The scavenger service shall provide and furnish a regular minimum weekly scheduled collection service, (provided, that where a regularly scheduled service falls on a holiday, service shall be made the following working day) in the following manner: 
(i)  Non-system waste will be picked up on the same pick up day each week. 
(ii)  In addition to the regular commercial service, persons shall be provided on a voluntary subscription basis, additional weekly pick ups, up to seven per week. 
(iii)  The scavenger service will not remove scrap materials from construction, remodeling and repair of buildings, nor concrete, bricks, tile, earth and earth materials, roots or tree trunks. Material not included in the regular pick up will be removed by the scavenger service on special order by the customer. 
(c)  Private Service. In addition to the commercial services provided by the scavenger service, it shall also make available to the commercial entities and multi-unit buildings in the village private service for all types of waste not otherwise covered in this section including, but not limited to, earth, sod, rocks, concrete, rubble and waste from remodeling, construction and demolition of buildings, excavations and other materials; provided, however, that the scavenger service shall not provide for the collection and disposal of poisonous or toxic materials and large quantities of liquid requiring tank truck disposal equipment. 
(d)  Where an enclosure is provided around a receptacle served by a scavenger service, the scavenger service shall replace the receptacle (after collection of refuse from the receptacle) in the enclosure and position the receptacle therein so that the gates, if the enclosure is so equipped, can be closed completely. 
(e)  The scavenger service shall maintain all receptacles provided by the scavenger service free of leaks and in good repair and fully equipped with covers or lids in good repair and capable of excluding insects and rodents. 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 2621 § F, 1990: Ord. 2518 § C, 1989: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.110 - Scavenger service charges. 
    All charges for scavenger service must be in accordance with a schedule of charges filed with the director of finance and approved by the village board as being fair and reasonable. The license of any licensee who charges more than the amount set forth in the schedule filed and approved shall be revoked. 
(Ord. 1485 § E, 1977: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § I, 3-21-2011) 
5.32.120 - Refuse disposal-Truck requirements. 
(a)  The scavenger service shall dispose of all refuse outside the village limits. 
(b)  All scavenger trucks operated in the village of Wheeling (except in the case of roll-off or compactor type service) shall be enclosed and leakproof with load packer type of equipment and shall be maintained clean and in good repair and shall comply with the rules and regulations of the board of health. 
(c)  Where roll-off type service is provided, the receptacle shall not be transported on village streets unless the receptacle is completely covered, in a manner that prevents the release of the waste from the receptacle during transportation. 
(d)  Where compactor type service is provided, the opening in the compactor receptacle shall be securely covered in a manner that prevents the release of any waste from the receptacle opening during transportation. 
(Ord. 2518 § D, 1989: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.130 - License a privilege. 
    The village board reserves the right to deny any applicant a license if any reasonable doubt exists as to the applicant's ability to comply with the provisions of this Chapter or any other ordinance provision of the village. The number of scavenger licenses shall not exceed nine and shall not exceed one year in duration, unless sooner revoked. The license shall be considered a personal privilege and shall not constitute property, nor be alienable or transferable. The license of any person, firm or corporation who fails to comply with the provisions of this Chapter or with the rules and regulations of the board of health with reference to scavenger service shall be revoked after notice and hearing upon the question by the board of health. 
(Ord. 2106 § A, 1984: Ord. 2087 § A, 1984: Ord. 1401 § A, 1976: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969) 
5.32.140 - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Except as stated in subsection (b) of this section, any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than fifty dollars, nor more than five hundred dollars. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person, firm, or entity that violates the provisions of Section 5.32.050 of this Chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars, nor more than five hundred dollars for the first offenses in a calendar year. Any violations of Section 5.32.050 in excess of five violations in a given calendar year shall be fined at a minimum of five hundred dollars per offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 3867 § A (part), 2004: Ord. 2587 § C, 1989: Ord. 1021 § D (part), 1969)
