Chapter 5.34 - LITTER 
Sections: 

5.34.001 - Short title. 
    This Chapter 5.34 shall be known and may be cited as the "litter ordinance" of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.005 - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this Chapter shall have the meanings prescribed in Chapter 5.32, Section 5.32.005, unless the context clearly requires another meaning. 
(Ord. 2587 § D, 1989: Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.010 - Littering prohibited. 
    No person shall throw, discard, or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or in or upon any private property within the village except in approved receptacles. Litter must be deposited in approved receptacles in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place. 
(Ord. 1707 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.020 - Sweeping into public places-Duty to keep sidewalk clean. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street, or other public place within the village any accumulation of litter from any building or lot from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk and parkways in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.030 - Merchants to keep sidewalks, public places free of litter. 
(a)  No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place any accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk, driveway, or parking lot. Persons owning or occupying places of business shall keep the sidewalk and parkway in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(b)  Persons owning or occupying places of business within the village shall keep the premises under their control free of litter, except in approved receptacles. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.040 - Littering bodies of water. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter or any other material which could cause an obstruction to waterflow in any channel, storm sewer, creek, stream, waterway, detention or retention pond, or any other body of water within the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 2659 § A, 1990: Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.050 - Littering construction sites. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall throw, deposit or discard litter or permit it to be thrown, deposited or discarded on any construction site, except in approved receptacles. Litter must be deposited in approved receptacles in a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements on any public place or on private property. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.060 - General contractors' responsibility to maintain premises free of litter. 
    No person, generally responsible for construction at a construction site, shall allow litter to accumulate on a construction site, except in approved litter receptacles. Such persons shall provide approved receptacles on the construction premises to contain all litter generated between collections by a scavenger service licensed by the village. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.070 - Duty to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall, at all times, maintain the premises free of litter. However, this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in approved receptacles for collection. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.080 - Throwing, distributing commercial handbills in public places. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or discard any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street, or other public place. No person shall hand out or distribute or sell any commercial handbill in any public place. However, it is lawful on any sidewalk, street, or other public place for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill to any person willing to accept it. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.090 - Placing handbills on or in vehicles. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle; provided, however, that it is lawful in any public place for a person to hand out or distribute without charge to the receiver thereof, a noncommercial handbill to any occupant of a vehicle who is willing to accept it. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.100 - Depositing handbills on uninhabited premises. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or discard any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.110 - Distributing handbills. 
(a)  Where Prohibited. No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill upon any private premises, if requested by the owner, owner's authorized agent or lawful occupant not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement," or any similar notice, indicating that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any handbills left upon the premises. This subsection does not prohibit the distribution of political literature on residential premises, or the distribution of noncommercial handbills in common areas open to the general public within shopping centers or malls, provided such distribution complies with subsection (b). 
(b)  Manner of Distribution. No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill in or upon private premises except by handing or transmitting such handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or other person present in or upon such premises. However, in the case of inhabited private residential premises which are not posted as provided in subsection (a), such person, unless requested by the owner or his authorized agent or the occupant of the particular unit not to do so, may lawfully place or deposit such handbill in or upon inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent it from being blown or drifted about such premises or on or about sidewalks, streets, or other public places. It shall not be a violation of this section to distribute political literature, as defined in this Chapter, on residential premises in a manner provided by this subsection, notwithstanding posting or a request not to do so. Mailboxes may not be used for any distribution prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(c)  Mail, Newspapers and Subscriptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States postal service, to newspapers as defined in this Chapter, or to goods and material which the owner or occupant has subscribed to or ordered. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.120 - Duty of persons distributing handbills. 
    The person responsible for distributing commercial or noncommercial handbills shall collect those handbills which have not been delivered in accordance with this Chapter and shall either deposit the same in approved receptacles, or retain them in any manner not violative of this Chapter. The person responsible for distributing commercial or noncommercial handbills shall collect those handbills which have been distributed or discarded by others in violation of this Chapter and shall deposit those handbills in approved receptacles, or retain them in a manner not violative of this Chapter. Handbills shall be deposited in approved receptacles in such a manner as to prevent them from being carried by the elements into any public place or private property. 
(Ord. 1707 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.130 - Throwing litter from vehicles. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or discard any litter from a moving vehicle or permit such activity in or from any vehicle under his immediate control. No person shall throw, deposit or discard any litter from a vehicle except: 
(1)  Into an approved receptacle or other container intended by the owner or tenant of the property to be used for the deposit of litter by the general public or by his customers, as the case may be; or 
(2)  Onto property designated by the state of Illinois or by the village of Wheeling as a litter or waste disposal site, and the litter is disposed of in accord with the applicable rules and regulations governing disposal on that site; or 
(3)  When the person is acting under the direction of authorized state or village officials during special cleanup days or projects authorized by the village or by the appropriate state agency; or 
(4)  The person is acting or reacting lawfully to an emergency situation where health or safety is threatened, and removes and properly disposes of such litter when the emergency situation no longer exists. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.140 - Vehicles emitting litter. 
(a)  No person shall drive, tow, or cause to be driven or towed, any truck, van, trailer or other vehicle containing loose loads of material on the public streets, highways, roads, alleys or other public ways, unless such load is fully enclosed and covered or otherwise secured to prevent such material from being dropped, blown, or otherwise deposited on any such public way or on any public place. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be driven or towed on the public streets, highways, roads, alleys or other public ways from which loose materials or liquids (other than water) are released, dropped, blown or otherwise deposited on a public way or public place, except with the prior approval of the proper village or state officials for public purposes. 
(c)  It shall be an affirmative defense to a charge of violating subsections (a) and (b) of this section that all reasonable efforts were made to secure the load and to prevent material from being deposited on public ways and places; and that any materials which were released, dropped, blown or otherwise deposited were de minimus in quantity, nontoxic and nonreactive in quality, and that their presence on the public ways or places did not create any hazard or nuisance, or injury to persons or property. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
5.34.150 - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for the first such offense. Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for the second such violation and a fine of not less than fifty dollars nor more than two hundred dollars for the third and subsequent violations within a one-year period. Each act of littering, by unlawfully depositing, throwing, or discarding a distinct item shall be a separate offense. Each day in which a person violates a duty imposed by this Chapter, or continues to maintain property or equipment, or to utilize equipment or receptacles in a condition or manner in violation of this Chapter, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1701 § B (part), 1980) 
Chapter 5.36 - TRAILERS* 
Sections: 

5.36.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter certain words and phrases are defined as follow: 
    The term "house-car trailer" is defined to be any structure for, or used for, living or sleeping purposes mounted upon wheels and capable of being transported from place to place, either by its own power or by some vehicle attached to it; provided, however, that this definition shall not apply to any vehicle operated over fixed rails. 
    The term "trailer camp" is defined to be a vacant or improved plot of ground where two or more house-car trailers used as living or sleeping quarters may be located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodation. 
    The term "person" is defined to be any person, firm, or corporation. 
(1956 Code § 289) 
5.36.020 - Trailer camps prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to maintain or operate any plot of ground as a trailer camp for human habitation within the village of Wheeling. 
(1956 Code § 290) 
5.36.030 - House-car trailers prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to maintain any house-car trailer within the village of Wheeling, whether used for living or sleeping purposes, or whether such house-car trailer is vacant and not used for living or sleeping purposes and is being merely stored. 
(1956 Code § 291) 
5.36.040 - Wheels of house-car trailer not to be removed. 
    It is unlawful for any person to remove the wheels or other transporting device from any house-car trailer or to otherwise fix said house-car trailer to the ground so as to prevent ready removal of said trailer. 
(1956 Code § 292) 
5.36.050 - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in chapter 1.04. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 799 § A (part), 1965) 
Chapter 5.38 - BARBER, COSMETOLOGY, MANICURE AND PEDICURE ESTABLISHMENTS 
Sections: 

5.38.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, the terms used herein are defined as follows: 
(a)  "Barber, cosmetology, esthetics, manicure and pedicure establishments" means any establishment in which one or more persons are engaged in the practice of shaving or trimming the beard or cutting the hair; any practice for the purpose of styling, dressing, curling, waving, straightening, cleaning, singeing, depilating, shampooing, marcelling, chemically restructuring, bleach-ing, tinting, coloring, shaping the hair; any practice for the purpose of cleaning, massaging or toning the skin of the scalp, face or neck; any practice or professional treatment of hands and feet and fingernails and toenails for removing cuticles, trimming and shaping nails; any practice for the purpose of applying cosmetic make-up to the face or neck of any person. 
(b)  "Person in charge" means the individual present in the facility who is the apparent supervisor of the facility at the time of the inspection. If no individual is the apparent supervisor, then any employee present is the person in charge. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.020 - Structural requirements. 
    Barber, cosmetology, esthetics, manicure and pedicure establishments shall comply with the following require-ments: 
(a)  Floors, floor coverings and walls in areas where hair is cut or washed, and toilet rooms shall be constructed of smooth, easily cleanable and non-absorbent material. 
(b)  Permanently fixed artificial light sources shall provide a minimum of thirty foot candles of light in customer service areas. Permanently fixed light sources shall provide a minimum of fifteen foot candles of light in all other areas of the facility. 
(c)  The ventilation shall be designed and operated in a manner to remove the presence of any detectable fumes or noxious odors. 
(d)  The plumbing shall be sized, installed and maintained in accordance with the latest plumbing code as adopted by ordinance by the village of Wheeling. Hot and cold running water shall be provided under pressure to all fixtures at all times. 
(e)  Toilet fixtures shall be of a sanitary design and readily cleanable. Toilet facilities including rooms and fixtures shall be kept in clean condition and in good repair. Toilet tissue shall be provided at all times. Easily cleanable receptacles shall be provided for waste material and such receptacles in toilet rooms for woman shall be covered. 
(f)  Lavatories shall be at least the minimum required by law. A lavatory shall also be located within the hair cutting area and nail treatment areas. Lavatories shall be located to permit convenient use by all employees before serving a patron. Each lavatory shall be provided with a supply of liquid or powder hand-cleaning soap and a supply of sanitary towels or hand-drying device and a refuse container. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.030 - Sanitary requirements. 
    Barber, cosmetology, esthetics, manicure and pedicure establishments shall comply with the following requirements: 
(a)  Employee outer clothing shall be clean and sanitary. 
(b)  Employees shall thoroughly was their hands immediately before serving a patron and immediately after using the toilet. Patrons shall wash their hands before receiving any nail treatments. 
(c)  Soiled linens shall be stored in covered non-absorbent containers or washable laundry bags. All soiled towels and linens shall be laundered at a commercial laundry facility or on the premises. 
(d)  All powders, lotions, creams and other cosmetics shall be kept in clean, covered containers that are properly labeled and shall be dispensed in a sanitary manner using single use applicators only. Alum or other astringents used to stop the flow of blood shall be applied in powdered or liquid form only. The stick form shall not be used. 
(e)  Clean towels shall be stored in a sanitary manner. Employees shall use separate and clean towels for each patron. Unless a separate and clean apron or cape is used for each patron, a separate and clean towel or fresh paper shall be placed around the neck to prevent the apron or cape from touching the skin. Headrests shall be covered with a clean towel or fresh paper for each patron or they may be thoroughly sanitized after each patron. 
(f)  All implements, instruments, equipment and furniture including combs, brushes, scissors, tweezers, razors, headrest, neck dusters, shears, head coverings, hairpins, bobby pins, curlers, etc., used in barber, cosmetology, manicure and pedicure establishments shall be thoroughly cleaned and sanitized after having been used on or in contact with a patron and shall be stored in a sanitary manner thereafter. All sanitizing, barbicidal or germicidal solutions shall be used in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Nail brushes are prohibited unless they are disposable. 
(g)  Barber, cosmetology, manicure and pedicure establishments shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. Floors, walls, furniture, equipment and other fixtures shall be kept clean and in good repair. Hair droppings shall be stored in a covered waste container, and disposed of as often as necessary to prevent the creation of any nuisance. 
(h)  No animals or pets shall be kept in or allowed to enter a barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment, except dogs used to assist the handicapped. 
(i)  Effective measures shall be used to preclude the presence of insects and rodents. 
(j)  All persons engaged in barber, cosmetology, pedicure and/or manicure activities must display State of Illinois License in a conspicuous place, preferably at the station where such person is employed. Upon request, the operator or person in charge shall make available to the health officer, or his designee, any records requested to determine current personnel engaged in barber, cosmetology, manicure and/or pedicure activities at that facility. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.040 - Health and disease control of personnel. 
(a)  No person while afflicted with boils, infected wounds, sores or an acute respiratory infection shall work in any areas of the barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment in any capacity in which there is a likelihood of contaminating anything with pathogenic organisms, or transmitting disease to other individuals; nor shall any service be performed on any person known to have such disease or condition. 
(b)  The health officer, or his designee may require any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  The immediate exclusion of that person from any barber, cosmetology, manicure and pedicure activities. 
(2)  The adequate medical and bacteriological examination of the person, of his associates, and his and their body discharges. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.050 - Access. 
    The health officer, or his designee, after presenting proper identification, shall be permitted to enter any barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment at any time when the operator or employee is present for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.060 - Inspection. 
    Prior to the start of operations for any new or remodeled facility, the health officer, or his designee, shall inspect the barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment to determine compliance with the approved plans, specifications and with the requirements of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.070 - Inspection frequency. 
    Inspections of barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishments will be performed as often as necessary for enforcement of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.080 - Inspection reports. 
    Whenever an inspection of a barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment is made, the findings shall be recorded on an inspection report form. The inspection form shall summarize the requirements of this Chapter. A copy of the inspection report shall be furnished to the person in charge at the conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report form is a public document that shall be made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according to law. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.090 - Correction of violations. 
    The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of violations found. Correction of any violation(s) shall be accomplished within the period specified. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.100 - Submission of plans. 
(a)  Whenever a barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment is constructed, altered, or remodeled, and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for construction, altering, remodeling or conversion shall be submitted to the health officer for review and approval before construction, altering, remodeling, or conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout arrangement, construction materials of work areas, mechanical plans and equipment specifications. 
(b)  All newly constructed, converted or major remodeling, including structural alterations of a barber, cosmetology, manicure or pedicure establishment shall conform in its construction to the requirements of this Chapter. 
(c)  Establishments that are approved prior to the effective date of this Chapter, but do not meet the design and construction standards set forth in this Chapter, shall be deemed in compliance with this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.110 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the terms or provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars nor more than one thousand dollars. Each day that a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
5.38.120 - Alternative penalty. 
    Any person accused of violating any section of the barber, cosmetology, manicure and pedicure ordinance may be issued an administrative citation in accordance with the procedures as established in Chapter 1.24 of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 3618 § A (part), 2002) 
Chapter 5.40 - RAT EXTERMINATION 
Sections: 

5.40.010 - Rats. 
    The presence of any rats of any kind on any tract of land, whether improved or vacant, is a nuisance, and it is unlawful for any owner of or person interested in private property to permit the ingress of rats to their property or to fail to exterminate rats thereon. 
(Ord. 850 § A (part), 1966) 
5.40.020 - Notice. 
    It shall be the duty of the village health officer to serve, or cause to be served, a notice to the owner, occupant or interested person of any premises on which rats are present to demand abatement of the nuisance within ten days. 
(Ord. 2963 § A (part), 1994: Ord. 850 § A (part), 1966) 
5.40.030 - Abatement. 
    If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within ten days, the village health officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the expenses of the cost of the abatement. 
(Ord. 2963 § A (part), 1994: Ord. 850 § A (part), 1966) 
5.40.040 - Statement. 
    The director of finance shall mail a statement of the expenses incurred in exterminating the rats to the owners or occupants of the private property. Whenever the statement remains for a period of thirty days after it has been mailed, the director of finance shall prepare and record a lien for the expenses incurred. 
(Ord. 1485 § F, 1977: Ord. 850 § A (part), 1966) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § J, 3-21-2011) 
5.40.050 - Lien. 
    Within sixty days after the expense of exterminating the rats has been incurred, either the director of finance or the person, firm or corporation performing the service by authority of the municipality shall file or cause to be filed in his or its own name, a notice of lien in the office of the Cook County recorder of deeds, or in the office of the registrar of titles, if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens System. This notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and 
(3)  The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the municipality or person, firm or corporation performing the service. 
(Ord. 850 § A (part), 1966) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § J, 3-21-2011) 
5.40.060 - Foreclosure of lien. 
    Property subject to a lien for rat extermination charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case of mortgages or mechanics' liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within one year after the date of the filing of the notice of lien. 
    The attorney for the village is authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the village in any court having jurisdiction over such matter against any real property for which notice of lien has been recorded. 
(Ord. 850 § A (part), 1966) 
5.40.070 - Release. 
    Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the municipality or person in whose name the lien has been filed and release shall be filed on record in the same manner as filing notice of the lien. 
(Ord. 850 § A, 1966) 
5.40.080 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not less than five dollars not more than five hundred dollars for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a nuisance continues unabated after ten days from receipt of notice. 
(Ord. 850 § C, 1966) 
Chapter 5.46 - PUBLIC NUISANCES 
Sections: 

5.46.010 - Public nuisance defined. 
(a)  As used in this Chapter, a public nuisance shall mean any act, thing, occupation, condition or use property which shall continue for such length of time as to: 
(1)  Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose or safety of the public; 
(2)  In any way render the public nuisance in life or in the use of property; 
(3)  Greatly offend the public morals or decency; 
(4)  Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway, navigable body of water or other public way. 
(b)  Public nuisances shall include but not be limited to the following acts, conduct, omissions, conditions or things: 
(1)  All decayed, harmfully adulterated or unwholesome food or drink sold or offered for sale to the public; 
(2)  Carcasses of household pets or other animals not buried or otherwise disposed of in a sanitary manner within twenty-four hours after death; 
(3)  Accumulations of garbage in a manner in which flies, mosquitoes, disease-carrying insects, rodents, or other vermin may breed or may reasonably be expected to breed. (For purposes of this section, "garbage" means animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of food); 
(4)  Accumulations of refuse in which disease-carrying insects, rodents, or other vermin may breed or may reasonably be expected to breed. (For purposes of this section, "refuse" means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, including garbage, rubbish, debris, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned or inoperable automobiles, abandoned or inoperable household appliances, moveable furniture not designed for or modified to withstand the elements and outdoor use, solid market and industrial wastes); 
(5)  All stagnant water in which mosquitoes, flies or other insects can multiply; 
(6)  Containers with garbage or refuse which are not covered by solid, tight-fitting lids or which have any uncovered holes or for which at least weekly removal of garbage and refuse is not provided; 
(7)  Vegetation which: 
(A)  Harbors or aids in harboring rats, snakes or vermin; 
(B)  Which harbors or hosts disease or insects which may reasonably be expected to injure other forms of life; 
(C)  Which are prohibited by law or ordinance, including but not limited to noxious weeds; 
(D)  Which by reason of its location or condition constitutes an imminent danger to any person or property; 
(E)  Which covers or hinders the removal of accumulations of junk, garbage and debris; 
(F)  Which is unmanaged and in excess of eight inches, provided cultivated flowers, ornamentals, or food plants shall be presumed to be managed vegetation; provided further that vegetation in excess of eight inches shall be presumed unmanaged unless predominantly composed of cultivated flowers, ornamentals, or food plants, including vegetation which interferes with or obstructs the passage on any street, alley or other public way; 
(8)  The escape of smoke, soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes gases, fly ash or industrial dust within the Village limits or within one mile therefrom in such quantities as to endanger the health of persons of ordinary sensibilities or to threaten or cause substantial injury to property but excluding smoke emanating from residential fireplaces; 
(9)  The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water by sewage, creamery or industrial wastes or other substances; 
(10)  Any use of property, substances or things within the Village or within one mile thereof, emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious or disagreeable odors, effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or inconvenience the health of any appreciable number of persons within the Village; 
(11)  Any structure or building that is in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decayed, is of faulty construction, is open to intrusion, abandoned, damaged by fire to the extent as not to provide shelter, is extremely unsound, in danger of collapse or failure, and endangers the health and safety of the public; 
(12)  Any inoperable vehicle, or vehicle which lacks current, legal registration parked on private property for more than seven days; provided that such vehicles may be parked upon private property: 
(A)  If the vehicle is parked upon the premises lawfully zoned for the business of repairing, wrecking or junking vehicles upon such premises; or 
(B)  If the vehicle is stored within a building and completely out of view of the public; 
(13)  The accumulation of vehicle parts or tires in outdoor areas of any property; 
(14)  Any vehicle parked on private property except on a weed-free surface made of gravel, crushed stone, asphalt or Portland cement concrete; 
(15)  Dumpsters, trash containers, or trash container stands, located on a public way, provided that trash containers may be placed on the public way only on the day the owner has the trash in the container scheduled for removal by a trash hauler; 
(16)  The following acts, conduct, conditions or omissions upon the outdoor areas of any property: 
(A)  Accumulation of clothing and any other items not designed for outdoor storage; 
(B)  Accumulation of any personal property which is inoperable or in a state of disrepair or will no longer properly or safely function for its intended use; 
(C)  Any firewood that is not stacked and useable. "Useable" firewood has more wood than rot and is cut to lengths that will fit an approved fireplace or wood stove on the property; 
(D)  Any construction materials or equipment except those that are temporarily on the property and stored in a manner to protect their utility and prevent deterioration and are reasonably expected to be used at the site for work approved by Village building permits; 
(E)  Accumulation of appliances or appliance parts not specifically designed and manufactured for outdoor use; and 
(F)  All furniture not specifically designed and manufactured for outdoor use; 
(17)  Such other actions, conduct, omissions, conditions or things defined or specified in the Village Code as nuisances or as public nuisances; 
(18)  Conditions that are defined as a nuisance in this section of the Municipal Code located within a carport if the conditions are visible to the public from any public right-of-way; 
(19)  Conditions that are defined as a nuisance in this section of the Municipal Code and are located in an open garage if the conditions are visible to the public from any public right-of-way; 
(20)  Conditions that are defined as a nuisance in this section of the Municipal Code and are located on a front porch, back porch or balcony if the condition is visible to the public from any public right-of-way; 
(21)  Storage of motorized vehicles with over 400cc motor on front porches, back porches and balconies if the motorized vehicle is visible to the public from any public right-of-way. 
(Ord. 3666 § A (part), 2002) 
5.46.020 - Public nuisance prohibited, summary abatement authorized. 
    All conditions in violation of Section 5.46.010 of this Chapter shall constitute a nuisance. It is also unlawful for any person to erect, contrive, cause, maintain or permit to exist any public nuisance upon property under said person's ownership or control. In cases when the village manager determines that it is necessary to take immediate action due to an eminent danger to the health and safety of the residents of the village, summary abatement of such nuisance is authorized. The costs incurred by the village in abating any nuisance, where necessary to ensure the health and safety of the residents of the village, shall be recoverable from the owner or owners of the real estate on which such nuisance was erected, contrived, caused, maintained or permitted and is a lien thereon. 
(Ord. 4202 § A, 2007: Ord. 3666 § A (part), 2002) 
5.46.030 - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars not more than one thousand dollars. 
(b)  Each day during which a violation shall exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 3666 § A (part), 2002) 
Chapter 5.47 - SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES PROHIBITION* 
Sections: 

5.47.010 - Findings. 
    The village hereby adopts the findings of the Illinois General Assembly as set forth in 410 ILCS 82/5. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, the following items shall have the following meanings: 
(a)  "Bar" means an establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption by guests on the premises and that derives no more than ten percent of its gross revenue from the sale of food consumed on the premises. "Bar" includes, but is not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges, adult entertainment facilities, and cabarets. 
(b)  "Employer" means a person, business, partnership, association, or corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust, or nonprofit entity, that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
(c)  "Employee" means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profits or a person who volunteers his or her services for a nonprofit entity. 
(d)  "Enclosed area" means all space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or partially enclosed with: (i) solid walls or windows, exclusive of doorways, or (ii) solid walls with partitions and no windows, exclusive of doorways, that extend from the floor to the ceiling, including, without limitation, lobbies and corridors. 
(e)  "Enclosed or partially enclosed sports arena" means any sports pavilion, stadium, gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink, bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or other events. 
(f)  "Healthcare facility" means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. "Healthcare facility" includes all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare facilities. 
(g)  "Place of employment" means any area under the control of a public or private employer that employees are required to enter, leave, or pass through during the course of employment, including, but not limited to entrances and exits to places of employment, including a minimum distance, as set forth in Section 5.47.110 of this Chapter, of fifteen feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited; offices and work areas; restrooms; conference and classrooms; break rooms and cafeterias; and other common areas. A private residence or home-based business, unless used to provide licensed childcare, foster care, adult care, or other similar social service care on the premises, is not a "place of employment." 
(h)  "Private club" means a not-for-profit association that: (1) has been in active and continuous existence for at least three years prior to January 1, 2008, whether incorporated or not, (2) is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, (3) is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain, and (4) only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. For purposes of this definition, "private club" means an organization that is managed by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting, has established bylaws, a constitution, or both to govern its activities, and has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. 501. 
(i)  "Private residence" means the part of a structure used as a dwelling, including, without limitation: a private home, townhouse, condominium, apartment, mobile home, vacation home, cabin, or cottage. For the purposes of this definition, a hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and breakfast or other similar public accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or assisted living facility shall not be considered a private residence. 
(j)  "Public place" means that portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to the public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or in part by private persons or entities, the state of Illinois, or any other public entity and regardless of whether a fee is charged for admission, including a minimum distance, as set forth in Section 5.47.110 of this Chapter, of fifteen feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. A "public place" does not include a private residence unless the private residence is used to provide licensed child care, foster care, or other similar social service care on the premises. A "public place" includes, but is not limited to, hospitals, restaurants, retail stores, offices, commercial establishments, elevators, indoor theaters, libraries, museums, concert halls, public conveyances, educational facilities, nursing homes, auditoriums, enclosed or partially enclosed sports arenas, meeting rooms, schools, exhibition halls, convention facilities, polling places, private clubs, gaming facilities, all village-owned vehicles and facilities, including buildings and vehicles owned, leased, or operated by the state or state subcontract, healthcare facilities or clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service establishments, financial institutions, educational facilities, ticket areas, public hearing facilities, public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars, taverns, bowling alleys, skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than seventy-five percent of the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel, resort, inn, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public accommodation that are rented to guests, but excludes private residences. 
(k)  "Restaurant" means: (i) an eating establishment, including, but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, that gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, and (ii) a kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. "Restaurant" includes a bar area within the restaurant. 
(l)  "Retail tobacco store" means a retail establishment that derives more than eighty percent of its gross revenue from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes and other smoking devices for burning tobacco and related smoking accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental. "Retail tobacco store" does not include a tobacco department or section of a larger commercial establishment or any establishment with any type of liquor, food, or restaurant license. 
(m)  "Smoke" or "smoking" means the carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling, or exhaling of any kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, weed, herbs, or any other lighted smoking equipment. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.030 - Prohibition in public places, places of employment and governmental vehicles. 
    No person shall smoke in a public place or in any place of employment or within fifteen feet of any entrance to a public place or place of employment. No person may smoke in any vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the village. Smoking is prohibited in indoor public places and workplaces unless specifically exempted by Section 5.47.070 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.040 - Posting of signs-Removal of ashtrays. 
(a)  "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol, consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it, shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this Chapter by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of that place. 
(b)  Each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this Chapter shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this Chapter by the owner, operator, manager, or other person having control of the area. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.050 - Smoking prohibited in dormitories. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter, smoking is prohibited in any portion of the living quarters, including, but not limited to, sleeping rooms, dining areas, restrooms, laundry areas, lobbies, and hallways, of a building used in whole or in part as a student dormitory that is owned and operated or otherwise utilized by a public or private institution of higher education. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.060 - Designation of other nonsmoking areas. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, any employer, owner, occupant, lessee, operator, manager, or other person in control of any public place or place of employment may designate a nonenclosed area of a public place or place of employment, including outdoor areas, as an area where smoking is also prohibited provided that such employer, owner, lessee or occupant shall conspicuously post signs prohibiting smoking in the manner described in subsections (a) and (b) of Section 5.47.040 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.070 - Exemptions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter, smoking is allowed in the following areas: 
(a)  Private residences or dwelling places, except when used as a childcare, adult day care, or healthcare facility or any other home-based business open to the public. 
(b)  Retail tobacco stores as defined in Section 5.47.020 of this Chapter prior to the January 1, 2008. The retail tobacco store shall annually file with the Wheeling village clerk, by January 31st of each year, including 2008, an affidavit stating the percentage of its gross income derived from the sale of loose tobacco, plants or herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes and other smoking devices for burning tobacco and related smoking accessories. Any retail tobacco store that begins operation after the effective date of this amendatory Act may only qualify for an exemption if located in a freestanding structure occupied solely by the business and smoke from the business does not migrate into an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  Private and semi-private rooms in nursing homes and long-term care facilities that are occupied by one or more persons, all of whom are smokers and have requested in writing to be placed or to remain in a room where smoking is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the nursing home. 
(d)  Hotel and motel sleeping rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms, provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into nonsmoking rooms or other areas where smoking is prohibited. Not more than twenty-five percent of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may be designated as rooms where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to permanently add additional nonsmoking rooms. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.080 - Violations. 
    A person, corporation, partnership, association or other entity who violates Section 5.47.030 of this Chapter shall be fined pursuant to this section. Each day that a violation occurs is a separate violation. 
    A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under Section 5.47.030 of this Chapter shall be fined in an amount that is not less than one hundred dollars and not more than two hundred fifty dollars. A person who owns, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment that violates Section 5.47.030 of this Chapter shall be fined: (i) not less than two hundred fifty dollars for the first violation, (ii) not less than five hundred dollars for the second violation within one year after the first violation, and (iii) not less than two thousand five hundred dollars for each additional violation within one year after the first violation. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.090 - Injunctions. 
    The village may institute, in a circuit court, an action to enjoin violations of this Chapter which take place within the village's corporate boundaries. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.100 - Severability. 
    If any provision, clause or paragraph of this Chapter shall be held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such validity shall not affect the other provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
5.47.110 - Entrances, exits, windows and ventilation intakes. 
    Smoking is prohibited within a minimum distance of fifteen feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited under this Chapter so as to ensure that tobacco smoke does not enter the area through entrances, exits, open windows, or other means. 
(Ord. 4297 § A (part), 2008) 
Title 6 - HUMAN RIGHTS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 6.02 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

6.02.010 - Short title. 
    This title shall be known and may be cited as the "Wheeling Human Rights Ordinance." 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.02.020 - Statement of purpose. 
    The purpose of this title is to assure that all individuals within the jurisdiction of the village of Wheeling shall be fully protected in the enjoyment of their civil rights and that mutual understanding and respect be promoted among all groups who live and work within the village. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.02.030 - Liberal construction. 
(a)  The provisions of this title shall be liberally construed in order to accomplish its full purpose. 
(b)  The provisions of this title shall not limit the ability of any individual to seek an appropriate remedy for an act of unlawful discrimination through federal, state or county agencies. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Chapter 6.04 - DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

6.04.010 - Definitions. 
    Whenever used in this title, the following words shall have the meanings set forth herein. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.020 - Age. 
    "Age" means chronological age of not less than forty years. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.030 - Credit transaction. 
    "Credit transaction" means the grant, denial, extension or termination of credit to an individual. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.040 - Disability. 
    "Disability" means: (1) a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of the major life activities of an individual; (2) a record of such an impairment; or (3) being regarded as having such an impairment. Excluded for this definition is an impairment relating to the illegal use, possession or distribution of "controlled substances" as defined in schedules I through V of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 812). 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.050 - Employee. 
    "Employee" means: (1) any individual whether paid or unpaid, engaged in employment for an employer; or (2) an applicant for employment. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.060 - Employer. 
    "Employer" means any person employing one or more employees, or seeking to employ one or more employees: (a) if the person has his principal place of business within the village of Wheeling; or (b) does business within the village of Wheeling. 
    Employer does not include: (a) any agency or department of the federal government; (b) any Indian tribe or corporation wholly owned by an Indian tribe; (c) any agency, department or political subdivision of the state of Illinois; or (d) any Illinois municipality or unit of local government. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.070 - Employment. 
    "Employment" means the performance of services for an employer: (1) for remuneration; or (2) as a participant in a training or apprenticeship program. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.080 - Employment agency. 
    "Employment agency" means a person that undertakes to procure employees or opportunities to work for potential employees, through interviews, referrals or advertising, or any combination thereof. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.085 - Housing status. 
    "Housing status" means the type of housing in which an individual resides; an individual's ownership status with respect to the individual's residence; or the status of having or not having a fixed residence. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.090 - Labor organization. 
    "Labor organization" includes any organization, labor union or craft union, or any voluntary incorporated association designed to further the cause of the rights of union labor, which is constituted for the purpose, in whole or in part, of collective bargaining or of dealing with an employer concerning grievances, terms or conditions of employment, or apprenticeships or applications for apprenticeships, or of other mutual aid or protection in connection with employment, including apprenticeships or applications for apprenticeships. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.100 - Marital status. 
    "Marital status" means the status of being single, married, divorced, separated or widowed. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.110 - Military discharge status. 
    "Military discharge status" means the fact of having been discharged from the Armed Forces of the United States, their reserve components or any National Guard or Naval Militia other than by a "dishonorable discharge." 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.120 - National origin. 
    "National origin" means the place in which an individual or one of his or her ancestors was born. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.125 - Parental status. 
    "Parental status" means the status of living with one or more dependent minors or disabled children. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.130 - Person. 
(a)  "Person" means one or more individuals; partnerships, associations or organizations, labor unions, joint apprenticeship committees or union labor associations; corporations; legal representatives, trusts, trustees in bankruptcy, or receivers. 
(b)  For purposes of this Chapter "person" shall also means an owner, lessor, sub lessor, assignor, managing agent or other individual, firm or corporation having the right to sell, rent, lease or sublease any housing unit within the village of Wheeling or any agent, broker or other individual working on behalf of any such individual, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.140 - Public accommodation. 
    "Public accommodation" means a person, place, business establishment or agency that sells, leases, provides or offers any product, facility or service to the general public in the village of Wheeling, regardless of ownership or operation: (1) for or without regard to profit; or (2) for a fee or not for a fee. "Public accommodations" also means any products, facilities or services of a nonpublic accommodation that are made available in the village of Wheeling to the general public or to the customers or patrons of another establishment that is a public accommodation. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.150 - Real estate transaction. 
    "Real estate transaction" means the sale, exchange, rental, occupancy, lease, sublease or lease renewal of real property in the village of Wheeling or the provision of services or utilities in connection with such sale, exchange, rental, occupancy, lease, sublease or lease renewal. With respect to activity conducted or property located in the village of Wheeling, "real estate transaction" also means the brokering or appraising of real property in the village of Wheeling and the making, purchasing or guaranteeing of loans or mortgages or providing any other financial assistance secured by real property. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.160 - Religion. 
    "Religion" means all aspects of religious observance and practice, as well as belief, of the actual identification with or perceived identification with a religion. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.170 - Sexual harassment. 
    "Sexual harassment" means any unwelcome sexual advance, request for sexual favors, or conduct of a sexual nature when: (1) submission to such conduct is an explicit or implicit term or condition of an individual's employment; or (2) submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for any employment decision affecting the individual; or (3) such conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.180 - Sexual orientation. 
    "Sexual orientation" means the status or expression, whether actual or perceived, of heterosexuality, homosexuality or bisexuality. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.190 - Source of income. 
    "Source of income" means the lawful manner by which an individual supports himself or herself and his or her dependents. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.04.200 - Unlawful discrimination. 
    "Unlawful discrimination" means discrimination against a person because of the actual or perceived status, practice or expression of that person's race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, source of income, housing status, or military discharge status. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Chapter 6.08 - EMPLOYMENT 
Sections: 

6.08.010 - Coverage. 
    The prohibitions against unlawful discrimination in employment apply as follows: (1) to employment that is or would be in whole or in part in the village of Wheeling; or (2) when the act of unlawful discrimination takes place in the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.08.020 - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No employer shall directly or indirectly discriminate against any individual in recruitment, hiring, classification, grading, discharge, discipline, compensation or other term or condition of employment because of the individual's race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status, housing status or source of income. 
(b)  No employment agency shall directly or indirectly discriminate against any individual in classification, grading, processing, referral or recommendation for employment because of the individual's race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status, housing status or source of income. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.08.030 - Labor organizations. 
    No labor organization shall limit, segregate or classify its membership, or limit employment opportunities, selection and training for apprenticeship in any trade or craft, or otherwise take, or fail to take, any action which affects adversely any individual's status as an employee, or as an apprentice, or as an applicant for apprenticeships, or wages, tenure, hours of employment, or apprenticeship conditions, on the basis of unlawful discrimination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.08.040 - Exceptions. 
    The prohibitions contained in this chapter shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  BFOQ. Hiring or selecting between individuals for bona fide occupational qualifications. 
(2)  Military Discharge Status. Use of an individual's unfavorable discharge from military service as a valid employment criterion where; (a) authorized by federal law or regulation; or (b) where the affected position of employment involves the exercise of fiduciary responsibilities and the reasons for the unfavorable discharge relate to his or her fiduciary capacity; or (c) where the reasons for the unfavorable discharge specifically relate to criteria which constitute a bona fide occupational qualification for a particular job. 
(3)  Veterans. Giving preferential treatment to veterans and their relatives as required by federal or state law or regulations. 
(4)  Religion. Giving preference in employment by religious corporation, association, educational institution, or society to individuals of a particular religion to help carry out the religious activities of such corporation, association, educational institution or society. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.08.050 - Religious accommodation. 
(a)  No employer shall refuse to make reasonable efforts to accommodate the religious beliefs, observances and practices of employees or prospective employees unless the employer demonstrates that he or she is unable to reasonably accommodate an employee's or prospective employee's religious observance or practice without undue hardship on the conduct of an employer's business. 
(b)  Prima facie evidence of a reasonable effort to accommodate, include, but are not limited to, allowing an employee: (1) to take a day of paid leave or vacation, if applicable under the employee's employment agreement; or (2) to be excused from work without pay and without discipline or other penalty; or (3) to elect to take the day off with pay in order to practice the employee's religious beliefs, and to make up the lost work time at a time and date consistent with the operational needs of the employer's business. Any employee who elects such deferred work shall be compensated at his or her regular rate of pay, regardless of the time and date at which the work is made up. The employer may require that any employee who plans to exercise option (3) of this paragraph provide the employer with notice of the employee's intention to do so, no less than five days prior to the date of absence. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.08.060 - Sexual harassment. 
    No employer, shall engage in sexual harassment. An employer shall be liable for sexual harassment by nonemployees or nonmanagerial and nonsupervisory employees only if the employer becomes aware of the conduct and fails to take reasonable corrective measures. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Chapter 6.10 - PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS 
Sections: 

6.10.020 - Prohibitions. 
    No person that owns, leases, rents, operates, manages or in any manner controls a public accommodation within the village of Wheeling, shall withhold, deny, curtail, limit or discriminate concerning the full use of such public accommodation by any individual because of unlawful discrimination. The prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to: private clubs, private facilities, single sex residences, single sex educational institutions and distinctly private facilities as defined and exempted by federal or state laws and statutes. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Chapter 6.12 - CREDIT TRANSACTIONS 
Sections: 

6.12.020 - Prohibition. 
    No person shall discriminate in the village of Wheeling against any individual in any aspect of a credit transaction or in any term or condition of bonding on the basis of unlawful discrimination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.12.030 - Sexual harassment. 
    No person shall engage in sexual harassment in the village of Wheeling in any aspect of a credit transaction or in any term or condition of bonding. "Sexual harassment" means any unwelcome sexual advance, request for sexual favors, or conduct of a sexual nature when: (1) submission to such conduct is an explicit or implicit term or condition of an individual's credit transaction or of bonding; or (2) submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for any credit or bonding decision affecting the individual; or (3) such conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual's access to credit or bonding creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive environment in any aspect of a credit transaction. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Chapter 6.14 - REAL ESTATE AND FAIR HOUSING 
Sections: 

6.14.020 - Terms and conditions. 
    No person shall make any distinction, discrimination or restriction in the price, terms, conditions or privileges of any real estate transaction, including the decision to engage in or renew any real estate transaction, on the basis of unlawful discrimination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.030 - Discriminatory communications. 
    No person shall publish, circulate, issue or display, or cause to be published, circulated, issued or displayed, any communication, notice, advertisement, sign or other writing of any kind relating to a real estate transaction which will indicate or express any unlawful limitation or discrimination on the basis of unlawful discrimination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.040 - Steering. 
    No person shall influence or attempt to influence by words or acts the choice or location of housing of a prospective purchaser, occupant or tenant, in connection with viewing, buying, leasing or occupying real estate based on unlawful discrimination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.050 - Listings. 
    No person shall deliberately and knowingly refuse examination of any listing or real property within the village of Wheeling to any individual because of unlawful discrimination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.060 - Representations. 
    No person shall deliberately and knowingly represent to an individual that residential real property is not available for inspection, sale, rental or lease in the village of Wheeling when in fact it is available, or fail to bring a residential real estate listing in the village of Wheeling to an individual's attention, or refuse to permit a person to inspect residential real property in the village of Wheeling because of unlawful discrimination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.070 - Blockbusting. 
    No person shall solicit for sale, lease or listing for sale or lease, residential real property within the village of Wheeling on the grounds of loss of value due to the present or prospective entry into any neighborhood of any individual or individuals of any particular race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income, or housing status. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.080 - Encouragement of blockbusting. 
    No person shall distribute or cause to be distributed written material or statements designed to induce any owner of residential real property in the village of Wheeling to sell or lease his, her or its property because of any prospective change in the race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income, or housing status. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.090 - Creating alarm. 
    No person shall intentionally create alarm among residents of any community within the village of Wheeling by transmitting communication in any manner, including a telephone call whether or not conversation thereby ensues, with a design to induce any person within the village of Wheeling to sell or lease his or her residential real property within the village of Wheeling because of the present or prospective entry into the vicinity of the property of any individual or individuals of any particular race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income, or housing status. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.14.100 - Exceptions. 
    The prohibitions in this chapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Age. Restricting rental or sale of a housing accommodation to an individual of a certain age group: (a) when such housing accommodation is authorized, approved, financed or subsidized in whole or in part for the benefit of that age group by a unit of state, local or federal government; or (b) when the duly recorded initial declaration of a condominium or community association limits such housing accommodations to individuals fifty-five years of age or older; provided, that an individual or members of the household of an individual owning or renting a unit in such housing accommodation prior to the recording of the initial declaration shall not be deemed to be in violation of the age restriction as long as the individual or household member continues to own or reside in the housing accommodation. 
(2)  Religion. Limitation by a religious organization, association or society, or any not-for-profit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society, of the sale, rental or occupancy of a dwelling which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to individuals of the same religion, or from giving preference to such individuals. 
(3)  Single Sex. Restricting the rental of rooms in a housing accommodation to individuals of one sex. 
(4)  Private Rooms. Rental of a room or rooms in a private home by an owner if he or she or a member of his or her family resides therein or, while absent for a period of not more than twelve months, if he or she or a member of his or her family intends to return to reside therein. 
(5)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this title, nothing contained in this chapter shall require any person who does not participate in the federal Section 8 Housing Assistance Program (42 U.S.C. 1437f) to accept any subsidy, payment assistance, voucher or contribution under or in connection with such program or to lease or rent to any tenant or prospective tenant who is relying on such a subsidy, payment assistance, contribution or voucher for payment of part of the rent for such housing accommodation. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Chapter 6.16 - CONTRACTS 
Sections: 

6.16.010 - Prohibition. 
    No person who is a party to a contract with the village of Wheeling shall engage in unlawful discrimination or sexual harassment against any individual in the terms or conditions of employment, credit, public accommodations, housing or provision of village facilities, services or programs. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.16.020 - Contract provisions. 
    The purchasing agent for the village, and all other department heads, as authorized, shall include a provision in all village contracts that sets forth the village's policies with respect to unlawful discrimination and sexual harassment, as embodied in this title, and that requires every contractor to certify its compliance with these policies and its agreement to abide by such policies as a part of the contractor's contractual obligations. 
    All village contracts shall further provide that if any party to a contract with the village is found to have violated any provision of this title, or furnished false or misleading information in any investigation, hearing or inquiry held pursuant to this title, that contract may be subject to a declaration of default and termination. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.16.030 - Application. 
    This chapter applies only to contracts executed after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Chapter 6.18 - ADDITIONAL VIOLATIONS 
Sections: 

6.18.020 - Retaliation. 
    No person shall retaliate against any person because that person in good faith has opposed that which he or she reasonably believed to be unlawful discrimination, sexual harassment or other violation of this title or has made a complaint, testified, assisted or participated in an investigation, proceeding or hearing under this title. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.18.030 - Aiding and abetting. 
    No person shall aid, abet, compel or coerce a person to commit a violation under this title. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
6.18.040 - Interference. 
    No person shall willfully interfere with the performance of a duty or the exercise of a power by the commission or one of its members or staff. 
(Ord. 3051 § A (part), 1995) 
Title 7 - ANIMALS* 
Chapters: 
Chapter 7.04 - ANIMALS-GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

7.04.010 - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this title to protect animals from abuse, neglect or rabies; provide for security of persons from annoyance, intimidation, injury, or rabies by animals; encourage responsible pet ownership and animal population control; and establish a method of response to situations involving animals. 
(Ord. 2686 § A (part), 1991) 
7.04.020 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings set forth herein: 
(1)  "Animal" means any living vertebrate creature, either domesticated or wild, excluding humans. 
(2)  "Bite" means seizing with the teeth or jaws or scratching by the teeth which wounds or pierces the skin. 
(3)  "Cat" means all members of the family Felidae. 
(4)  "Dangerous animal" means: 
(a)  Any individual animal when unmuzzled, unleashed, or unattended by its owner or custodian that behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would believe poses a serious and unjustified imminent threat of serious physical injury or death to a person or a companion animal on either public or private property; or 
(b)  Any animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury to, or otherwise threaten the safety of human beings or domestic animals; or 
(c)  Any animal which because of its size, physical nature, or vicious propensity is capable of inflicting serious physical harm or death to humans; or 
(d)  Any animal which, without provocation, attacks or bites, or has attacked or bitten, a human being or domestic animal; or 
(e)  Any animal owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting, or any animal trained for fighting. 
(5)  "Diseased animal" shall refer to any animal infected with a contagious or infectious disease, including those diseases contagious or infectious only to animals. 
(6)  "Dwelling unit" means a structure or portion thereof designed and built as a complete, self-sufficient living facility for one family, including permanent provisions for sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. Units in a hotel or motel are not to be counted as dwelling units. 
(7)  "Family" means: 
(a)  An individual or two or more persons related by blood, marriage or adoption, and including not more than two boarders or lodgers, living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit; or 
(b)  A group of not more than four persons who need not be related by blood, marriage, or adoption, living together as a single housekeeping unit; plus, in either case; or 
(c)  A group of not more than eight persons with developmental disabilities who need not be related by blood, marriage, or adoption, living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit; plus, in all cases, usual domestic servants or attendant support staff. 
(8)  "Guide dog" or "companion animal" means any dog trained by a recognized organization to lead the legally blind or deaf; or any animal trained by a recognized organization to assist in the daily activities of a physically handicapped person. 
(9)  "Impounded" means taken into the custody of the public animal control facility in the city, town, or county where the animal is found. 
(10)  "Keep" or "harbor" means to maintain, possess, control and use. 
(11)  "Kennel" means any establishment where more than four dogs or four cats or any combination thereof over four months of age are maintained for boarding, training, or similar purposes for a fee or compensation; or offered for sale, exchange or adoption with or without charge those dogs or cats which are produced and raised by the operation of such kennel. Kennel shall not include veterinary hospitals, pet shops, or shelters. 
(12)  "Leash" means a strong cord, thong or chain not more than six feet in length for the purpose of keeping an animal under control. 
(13)  "Multiple-family dwelling" means a building containing two or more dwelling units whose residents live independently of one another. 
(14)  "Owner" means any person having the right of property in an animal, who keeps or harbors an animal, who has an animal in its care, acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits any animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him, excluding native wildlife remaining on or about the premises. 
(15)  "Person" means any natural person, partnership, trust, corporation, association, or other legal entity. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the term "person," as applied to partnerships or associations, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as applied to trusts or corporations, shall mean the trustees or officers thereof. 
(16)  "Pet shops" means any facility which sells, offers for sale, exchange or adoption, with or without charge or donation any dog, cat or other animal. 
(17)  "Physical injury" means the impairment of physical condition. 
(18)  "Proper control" means secured by a leash or lead or within the premises of its owner or confined within a crate, cage or fenced area or confined within a vehicle or within the premises of another person with the consent of such person. 
(19)  "Pound" or "animal control facility" may be used interchangeably and mean any facility operated by or under contract for the state, county, or municipal corporation or political subdivision of the state of Illinois, or approved by the county administrator for the purpose of impounding or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned, or unwanted dogs, cats, or other animals. 
(20)  "Running at large" means off the premises of the owner of the animal and not under the proper control of the owner. 
(21)  "Serious physical injury" means a physical injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious or protracted disfigurement, protracted impairment of health, impairment of the function of any bodily organ, or plastic surgery. 
(22)  "Single-family dwelling" means a building containing one dwelling unit only. 
(23)  "Shelter" means a facility operated, owned, or maintained by a duly incorporated humane society, animal welfare society, or other nonprofit organization for the purpose of providing for and promoting welfare, protection, and humane treatment of animals. 
(24)  "Vaccination against rabies" means the injection of a rabies vaccine approved by the Illinois Department of Agriculture and administered by a licensed veterinarian. 
(25)  "Vicious animal" means an animal that, without justification, attacks a person and causes serious physical injury or death or any individual animal that has been found to be a "dangerous animal" upon three separate occasions. 
(26)  "Village" means the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 3801 § A (part), 2003: Ord. 2686 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4435, § 1, 5-18-2009; Ord. No. 4585, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
Chapter 7.06 - IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMALS 
Sections: 

7.06.010 - Authority-Cause. 
    The police department is authorized to enforce the provisions of this title and may impound any animal found to be in violation thereof. 
(Ord. 2686 § A (part), 1991) 
7.06.020 - Record of impounded animals.
