(Ord. No. 4731, § 2, 11-12-2012) 
Chapter 8.56 - PENALTIES* 

8.56.010 - Penalties. 
a)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this Title shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars. 
(b)  Each day during which a violation shall continue to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2301 § N (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 5106, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.56.020 - Restitution. 
    In addition to any fine levied, the court may require restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed the actual loss or damage to property or pecuniary loss. Nothing in this section shall preclude such additional civil remedies available to a complaining party for any sum not recovered. 
(Ord. 2301 § N (part), 1986) 
Chapter 8.60 - POSSESSION OR PURCHASE OF TOBACCO, TOBACCO ACCESSORIES, OR SMOKING HERBS BY MINORS* 

8.60.010 - Definitions. 
(a)  "Tobacco accessories" means cigarette papers, holders of smoking materials of all types, cigarette rolling machines and other items, designed primarily for the smoking or ingestion of tobacco products or of illegal substances or of substances whose sale, gift, barter or exchange is made unlawful pursuant to law. 
(b)  "Smoking herbs" means all substances of plant origin and their derivatives, including but not limited to broom, calea, California poppy, daminia, hops, ginseng, lobelia, jimson weed and other materials of the Datura genus, passion flower and wild lettuce which are processed or sold primarily for use as smoking materials. 
(Ord. 3086 § A (part), 1996) 
8.60.020 - Possession and/or purchase of tobacco by minors prohibited. 
    No minor under twenty-one years of age shall purchase, attempt to purchase, or possess any cigar, cigarette or tobacco in any of its forms. 
(Ord. 3086 § A (part), 1996) 
(Ord. No. 5266, § 2, 5-20-2019) 
8.60.030 - Sale of tobacco to minor prohibited. 
    No person shall sell, purchase for, or furnish any cigar, cigarette or tobacco in any of its forms, to any minor under twenty-one years of age. 
(Ord. 3086 § A (part), 1996) 
(Ord. No. 5266, § 2, 5-20-2019) 
8.60.035 - Illegal purchase-Posting warning. 
    Every place in the village where tobacco products are sold, including every vending machine which offers tobacco products for sale, shall display at all times in a prominent place a printed card which shall be issued by the village clerk and which shall read substantially as follows: 
"Warning to Minors" 
Persons under the age of twenty-one are subject to a fine up to five hundred dollars under this Chapter, of the Village of Wheeling for purchasing any tobacco product, or for misrepresenting their age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining any tobacco product. 
(Ord. 3086 § A (part), 1996) 
(Ord. No. 5266, § 2, 5-20-2019) 
8.60.040 - Sale of tobacco accessories or smoking herbs to minors. 
    No person shall sell, purchase for or furnish any minor under twenty-one years of age any tobacco accessories or smoking herbs. 
(Ord. 3086 § A (part), 1996) 
(Ord. No. 5266, § 2, 5-20-2019) 
8.60.045 - Suspension or revocation of tobacco retailers license. 
    Any person licensed to sell tobacco products within the village shall be subject to suspension or revocation of said license in accordance with the provisions of Sections 4.08.120 and 4.08.125 of the Wheeling Municipal Code for any violation of the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3086 § A (part), 1996) 
8.60.050 - Purchase or possession of tobacco accessories or smoking herbs by minors prohibited. 
(a)  No minor under twenty-one years of age shall possess or purchase any tobacco accessories or smoking herbs. 
(b)  No person in the furtherance of facilitation of obtaining tobacco accessories or smoking herbs shall display or use a false or forged identification card or transfer, alter or deface an identification card. 
(Ord. 3086 § A (part), 1996) 
(Ord. No. 5266, § 2, 5-20-2019) 
Chapter 8.70 - ALARM SYSTEMS 

8.70.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein: 
(1)  "Alarm business" means the business by any individual, partnership, corporation or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved or installed any alarm system in or on any building, structure, or facility. 
(2)  "Alarm system" means an alarm system is any device installed for the purpose of alerting others to an unauthorized entry on the premises, the commission of an unlawful act or a fire emergency. The term "alarm system" shall include the terms "automatic hold-up alarm system," "burglar alarm system," and "hold-up alarm system." The term "alarm system" also includes a "receiving station alarm," having a direct burglar or fire alarm connection from any building, place or premises within the village at the police department or the fire department or a central station alarm system which relays the signal to a private person or company, either within or without the corporate boundaries of the village providing watchmen or security service, or providing a service to contact the police department or fire department or other emergency personnel of the village of Wheeling. 
(3)  "Alarm user" means any person, family, household, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind in control of premises where an alarm system is maintained. 
(4)  "Alarm user permit" means a license issued by the village of Wheeling for the privilege and ability to operate an alarm system on or in any building, structure or facility located within the limits of the village of Wheeling. 
(5)  "Automatic telephone alarm" means any telephone device or telephone attachment which automatically relays a prerecorded message to report a robbery, burglary, fire or other emergency situation by means of a telephone line which terminates upon a central switchboard. 
(6)  "False alarm" means any alarm signal eliciting a response by the police and/or fire departments wherein an emergency situation does not, in fact, exist, but does not include an alarm activated by violent conditions of nature (severe weather), power outages or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the alarm business operator or alarm user. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.020 - Alarm user permit-Requirements-Application-Fee. 
(a)  User Permit Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to lease, use, own an alarm system(s) or be in control of premises where an alarm system is operated or maintained without first having obtained a user permit from the director of finance. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for an alarm user permit shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, per each type of alarm system (fire or police). For initial permit applications received after October 31st, the fee shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, for the remainder of the permit year. All fees for alarm user permits shall be paid at the time application is made to the director of finance. Alarm system permits are nontransferable and government agencies shall be exempt from the alarm user permit fee. 
(c)  Application for User Permit. The application for an alarm user permit shall be filed with the director of finance and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  Name and address of the premises where the alarm system(s) is/are located. 
(3)  A statement listing the names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least three persons responsible for the premises where the alarm system(s) is/are located and who may be contacted to deactivate the alarm system(s). 
(4)  The name, address and telephone number of the person, firm or corporation which installed the alarm system(s) and of the person, firm, or corporation responsible for the ongoing maintenance and repair of the alarm system(s). 
(5)  Any additional information which the chief of police, the fire chief or the director of finance shall reasonably determine is necessary to properly investigate an application for an alarm user permit to verify that the alarm system(s) will be installed and operated in compliance with the provisions of this Chapter. 
(d)  Issuance of Alarm User Permit. The director of finance of the village of Wheeling shall issue a permit for alarm users within thirty days after a completed application is filed. Each permit shall bear the signature of the village president and the director of finance. Prior to the issuance of such permit, the chief of police and/or the fire chief may cause such inspection of the applicant's premises and individual alarm system(s) as is deemed necessary. 
(e)  Termination of Alarm User Permit. All alarm user permits shall terminate on April 30th of each year. The director of finance shall mail to all alarm users of the village a renewal application at least three weeks prior to the date of such expiration; provided, that a failure to send out such notice or the failure of the alarm user to receive it shall not excuse the alarm user from a failure to obtain a new permit, or a renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in an action for operation without a permit. In the event an alarm user who has had a permit the previous year fails to obtain a permit before May 1st of any year, the alarm user shall pay to the director of finance, prior to the time the current permit shall be issued, the sum of ten dollars as a late charge. In the event an alarm user who had a permit the previous year fails to obtain a permit before June 1st of any year, the alarm user shall pay to the director of finance, prior to the time the current license is issued, the sum of twenty dollars as a late charge, and thereafter collection procedures shall be instituted. 
(f)  Updating Alarm System Application. It shall be unlawful for any alarm system permit holder to fail or refuse to amend its alarm system permit application within ten days after any of the information required and contained therein becomes outdated and inaccurate. 
(g)  Alarm System Posting Requirements. No alarm system(s) shall be installed or maintained unless the permit holder of such alarm system(s) shall post or cause to be posted at or near the location where such alarm system(s) can be deactivated, a notice containing the name, address and telephone number of the person, firm or corporation responsible for the maintenance and repairs of such alarm system(s). 
(h)  General User Permit Requirements. No alarm system or alarm user permit shall be issued for any alarm system which does not meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Every burglar alarm system shall be equipped with an alarm delay mechanism that allows for at least a fifteen second delay before activation of the alarm. 
(2)  No alarm system shall be cross connected with both burglar alarms and fire alarms on the same line; provided, however, that alarm systems so installed as of May 1, 1991, shall be allowed to remain on a single line until such time as the alarm system is replaced or substantially altered, at which time it must be brought in to compliance with this requirement. 
(3)  All fire alarm systems shall be installed in accordance with the most current edition of National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) #72E and #72C. 
(Ord. 4131 § L, 2006; Ord. 3234 §§ A, B, 1997; Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § L, 3-21-2011) 
8.70.030 - False alarms-Additional charges. 
(a)  Any alarm system which has five or more false alarms within a permit year shall subject the alarm permit holder to additional charges as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. 
(b)  The above charges shall be paid to the village within thirty days from the invoice date. 
(c)  After the second false alarm, the chief of police and/or the fire chief, or their designated agent, shall notify the alarm user in writing of each instance wherein the village has recorded a chargeable false alarm which occurs within the alarm permit year. Each permit holder shall have the opportunity within twenty days after the receipt of such notice/bill to submit a report to or meet with the fire chief or police chief or their designated agent for the purpose of showing cause as to whether circumstances exist so as to warrant a voiding of the false alarm recordation. The decision of the fire or police chief, or their designated agent, as to whether a chargeable false alarm occurred shall be final. 
(d)  Officer in Charge-Responsibilities to Document False Alarm. When an alarm system is activated, the responding officer shall call in the appropriate alarm code to the communication center and that code, in turn, will be recorded along with other incident information. A chargeable false alarm will be any alarm activation due to negligence, employee/employer error, uncorrected or repeated line trouble alarm or unknown cause. The alarm user is responsible for ensuring the alarm is in proper working order. The alarm codes are as follows: 
1 Valid Alarm 5 Power Failure 2 Negligence/Empl. Error 6 Officer activation 3 Line Trouble 7 Unknown Cause 4 Weather Related 8 Repair or IBT Activation  
(e)  Grace Period for False Alarms. Whenever a new alarm system is installed or a new user (new resident or business) takes control of an existing alarm system, the permit holder shall be given sixty days from the date of the installation or occupancy within which no alarm from the premises shall be deemed to be a false alarm. 
(Ord. 4131 § M, 2006; Ord. 3234 § C, 1997; Ord. 2746 § A, 1991: Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.040 - Direct alarm connection to police/fire department. 
(a)  Direct burglar/fire alarm connections with the police/fire department shall be authorized provided the alarm use has a valid alarm user permit. 
(b)  Direct connections to the police/fire department shall be made with a private security alarm monitoring service. Any individual person or firm within the village of Wheeling may contract with this private security alarm monitoring service for direct connection to the police/fire department alarm board. The subscriber agrees to pay an agreed upon initial connection fee per connection plus a monthly monitoring, rental and maintenance fee. 
(c)  Liability Established. All applicants of direct burglar or fire alarm connections with the village must agree to indemnify the village for all claims, demands, judgments, liabilities, costs and expenses that may arise in any way as a result of the alarm connection and service. All applicants for direct connection alarms must certify that alarm system maintenance will be provided twenty-four hours per day, seven days per week on an as needed basis. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.050 - Central station alarms. 
    Every central station alarm company maintaining an alarm board or alarms or which has alarm users located within the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling shall furnish to the village a complete list of all its subscribers and shall report to the village any new subscribers at the time of requesting alarm user permits for such subscribers. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.060 - Automatic telephone alarm prohibited. 
    The use of any automatic telephone alarm system is prohibited. No person shall use or permit to be used or engage in the business of providing any telephone devise or telephone attachment that automatically selects a public trunk line of the police or fire department of the village and then reproduces any prerecorded message to report any robbery, burglary, fire or other emergency. Any automatic telephone alarm system shall be subject to abatement as a nuisance. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.070 - Outside ringers regulated. 
    Local alarms are those alarms that sound audibly on the premises of the subscriber and are not connected to any central station. Local alarms shall not make a sound similar to that of sirens on emergency vehicles or of civil defense warning systems. All outside ringers shall be clearly labeled as to the specific function of the alarm (burglar, fire, etc.) as well as which agency is to be notified in the event of activation. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.080 - Burglar alarm system deactivation requirements. 
    All owners of burglar alarm systems will be responsible for making arrangements to ensure that the burglar alarm system can be accessed for maintenance and turned off in case of malfunction or false alarm which would result in prolonged operation, thereby creating a disturbance for neighboring property owners. Regardless of arrangements made, it shall be unlawful for any permit holder to cause or permit a burglar alarm system for which a permit has been issued pursuant to this Chapter to sound in excess of one hour. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.090 - Fire alarm system access requirements. 
    All owners of fire alarm systems (excluding detached single-family dwellings) shall be responsible to provide a high security, supervised key box. Each key box shall be of a type approved by the fire department and shall contain all of the keys necessary to gain access to the building, common areas, utility rooms, as well as for servicing fire alarms/fire suppression equipment. In multi-family dwellings, no keys shall be provided for access to the individual dwelling units. The specific location where the key box shall be installed on the exterior of the building must be approved by the Fire Department prior to installation. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.100 - Inspection of alarm systems and business. 
    For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this Chapter, the chief of police, the fire chief, or their designated agent shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon reasonable notice, to enter any premises in the village in or upon which the alarm system(s) subject to this Chapter are located to inspect the operation of such alarm system(s). 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
8.70.110 - Penalties. 
    In addition to any fees, fines or other penalties established in this Chapter, any person, firm or corporation convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined an amount not less than fifty dollars but not to exceed five hundred dollars for each offense and each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2685 § A (part), 1991) 
Chapter 8.72 - MEDICAL CANNABIS DISPENSING ORGANIZATIONS 

8.72.010 - Public safety impacts. 
    The village hereby recognizes and declares that the operation of medical cannabis dispensing organizations within the village will require the village to perform additional police protection services to prevent and respond to potential impacts on the public health, safety, and welfare, including, without limitation, determining whether such organizations are being lawfully operated and whether qualifying patients and registered caregivers are complying with applicable laws, which prohibit, among other offenses (a) unlawful consumption of medical cannabis; (b) operation of certain vehicles under the influence of medical cannabis; (c) disorderly conduct; and (d) violations of state law and municipal ordinances. These additional police protection services will cause the village to incur increased costs in the approximate amount of twenty thousand dollars per year per medical cannabis dispensing organization located within the village, which amount is specifically and uniquely attributable to each medical cannabis dispensing organization. 
(Ord. No. 4907, § 2, 12-15-2014) 
8.72.020 - Impact fee imposed. 
    The village hereby imposes an annual medical cannabis dispensing organization impact fee in the amount of twenty thousand dollars on each medical cannabis dispensing organization located within the village. This medical cannabis dispensing organization impact fee shall be paid each year by each medical cannabis dispensing organization located within the village prior to the issuance by the village of a business license for the medical cannabis dispensing organization pursuant to Chapter 4.08 of Title 4 of the village code. No business license for any medical cannabis dispensing organization will be issued by the village prior to payment of the applicable medical cannabis organization impact fee. 
(Ord. No. 4907, § 2, 12-15-2014) 
8.72.030 - Use of impact fee. 
    All medical cannabis dispensing organization impact fees collected by the village will be deposited into the police department fund and will be used for the purpose of defraying the cost of providing and performing police protection service attributable to the operation of medical cannabis dispensing organizations within the village. 
(Ord. No. 4907, § 2, 12-15-2014) 
8.72.040 - Review of impact fee. 
    Every few years after December 15, 2014, being the effective date of this Chapter 8.72, the village manager and the chief of police will review the cost of the police protection services provided and performed by the village that are attributable to the operation of medical cannabis dispensing organizations within the village to ensure the impact fees are consistent with the cost of services and may recommend any adjustment to the amount of the medical cannabis dispensing organization impact fee imposed by Chapter 8.72 of the village code if, in their discretion, they determine it is necessary. 
(Ord. No. 4907, § 2, 12-15-2014) 
Title 9 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC* 
Chapter 9.01 - TITLE AND DEFINITIONS 

9.01.100 - Adoption of Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(a)  There is adopted, by reference, to the Wheeling Municipal code, Title 9, Vehicles and Traffic, the following provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., as may be amended from time to time: 
(1)  Chapter 1, thereof, in its entirety; 
(2)  Chapter 3, Article IV, thereof, in its entirety; 
(3)  Chapter 3, Article VII, thereof, in its entirety; 
(4)  Chapter 6, Article I, Sections 6-100, 6-101, 6-102, 6-104, 6-105, 6-106, 6-106.11, 6-112, 6-113, 6-115, 6-116; 
(5)  Chapter 6, Article III, Sections 6-303, 6-304, 6-304.1, 6-305; 
(6)  Chapter 6, Article VII, thereof, in its entirety; 
(7)  Chapter 6, Article VIII, thereof, in its entirety; 
(8)  Chapter 7, Article VI, Sections 7-601, 7-602; 
(9)  Chapter 11, thereof, in its entirety; 
(10)  Chapter 12, thereof, in its entirety; 
(11)  Chapter 13, thereof, in its entirety; 
(12)  Chapter 15, thereof, in its entirety; 
(13)  625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq.; 
(14)  625 ILCS 25/1 et seq. 
(b)  This Title shall be known as the Wheeling Vehicle Code. Citation to this Title may be made in the following manner: The Wheeling Vehicle Code, Section _____. 
(Ord. 2730 § B, 1991: Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § I, 4-25-2011) 
9.01.102 - Abandoned vehicles. 
    "Abandoned vehicles" means all motor vehicles or other vehicles in a state of such that rendering the vehicle is incapable of being driven in its condition; or any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved for seven consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.105 - All terrain vehicles. 
    All terrain vehicle means any off-highway device, powered by a motor, fueled by stored electricity or petroleum fuel, and fifty inches or less in width, having manufacturer's dry weight of six hundred pounds or less, traveling on three or more low pressure tires, designed with a seat or saddle for the operator use, and handlebars or steering wheel or steering control. 
(Ord. 3555, § A (part), 2001) 
9.01.109 - Boat. 
    "Boat" means any device used or capable of being used for navigation on water. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.118 - Department. 
    "Department" means the Wheeling police department acting through its authorized officers, agents, or employees. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.120 - Driveway. 
    "Driveway" means an established and surfaced portion of real property designed solely for the purpose of ingress and egress to a carport, garage, parking area of loading and unloading area. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.123 - Falsify. 
    "Falsify" means to change, alter, or forge. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.127 - Freeway. 
    "Freeway" means a highway or street especially designed for through traffic, and to, from or over which owners of or persons having an interest in abutting land or other persons have no right or easement or only a limited right or easement of access, crossing, light, air, or view by reason of the fact that such property abuts upon such highway or street or for any other reason. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.128 - Front lot line. 
    "Front lot line" means the boundary of a real property along an existing or dedicated public street, or where no public street exists along a public way. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.130 - Go-kart. 
    Go-kart means any device fifty inches or less in width, powered by a motor, fueled by stored electricity or petroleum fuel, and having a manufacturer's dry weight of six hundred pounds or less, traveling on four low pressure tires, designed with a seat for operator use and a steering wheel for steering control. 
(Ord. 3555, § A ( part), 2001) 
9.01.137 - Loading zone. 
    "Loading zone" means the space on a highway adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles for the purpose of loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.142 - Minibike. 
    Minibike means any device, powered by a motor of eight horsepower or less, fueled by stored electricity or petroleum fuel, traveling on two low pressure tires, designed with a seat or saddle for the operator use and handlebars for steering control. 
(Ord. 3555, § A (part), 2001) 
9.01.143 - Motorized skateboard or scooter. 
    Motorized skateboard or motorized scooter means any platform, board or horizontal surface, equipped with two or more wheels, which is powered by a motor, fueled by stored electricity or any petroleum based fuel and is operated by a single person in either a sitting or standing position. 
(Ord. 3555, § A (part), 2001) 
9.01.144 - Off-road motorcycle. 
    Off-road motorcycle means any motorized device designed to travel primarily off highway on two wheels, having a seat or saddle for the use of the operator and handle bars for steering control. 
(Ord. 3555, § A (part), 2001) 
9.01.147 - Regulating size and weight of vehicles. 
A.  Definition of Words and Phrases. The following words and phrases (when used in this Code) shall, for the purpose of this Code, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this Chapter, except when the context otherwise requires and except where another definition set forth in another Chapter of this Code and applicable to that Chapter or a designated part thereof is applicable. 
    Annual Permit. A permit issued to a single truck, truck-tractor power unit, or piece of special mobile equipment which is valid for unlimited moves for a period not to exceed three hundred sixty-five days from the date of issuance. 
    Axle Load. The total load transmitted to the road by all wheels whose centers may be included between two parallel transverse vertical planes forty inches apart extending across the full width of the vehicle. 
    Commercial Vehicle. Any vehicle operated for the transportation of persons or property in the furtherance of any commercial or industrial enterprise, for-hire or not-for-hire, but not including a commuter van, a vehicle used in a ridesharing arrangement when being used for that purpose, or a recreational vehicle not being used commercially. 
    Construction Vehicle. Any vehicle over ten thousand pounds actual weight, registered gross weight or G.V.W.R. that is required to comply with 625 ILCS 5/12-712 and 12-713 on identification required to be displayed. 
    Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR). The value specified by the manufacturer or manufacturers as the maximum loaded weight of a single vehicle. The GVWR of a combination of vehicles (commonly referred to as the "gross combination weight rating" or GCWR) is the GVWR of the power unit plus the GVWR of the towed unit or units. In the absence of a value specified by the manufacturer, GCWR is determined by adding the GVWR of the power unit and the total weight of the towed unit and any load on the unit. 
    Gross Weight. The weight of a vehicle (whether operated singly or in a combination) without load, plus the weight of the load thereon. 
    Highway. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Implement of Husbandry. Every vehicle designed and adapted exclusively for agricultural, horticultural or livestock raising operations, including farm wagons, wagon trailers or like vehicles used in connection therewith, or for lifting or carrying an implement of husbandry. 
    Motor Vehicle. Every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, except for vehicles moved solely by human power and motorized wheelchairs. For this Act, motor vehicles are divided into two divisions: 
    First Division: Those motor vehicles which are designed for the carrying of not more than ten persons. 
    Second Division: Those motor vehicles which are designed for carrying more than ten persons, those motor vehicles designed or used for living quarters, those motor vehicles which are designed for pulling or carrying freight, cargo or implements of husbandry, and those motor vehicles of the First Division remodeled for use and used as motor vehicles of the Second Division. 
    Nondivisible. A vehicle and load will be considered nondivisible when further separating or dismantling the vehicle or load: 
(1)  Would require more than eight work hours to dismantle using appropriate equipment. The applicant has the burden of proof as to the number of work hours required to dismantle the load. 
(2)  Will compromise or destroy the intended use of the load only. A load can be either permanently mounted or temporarily secured equipment. Any parts, fluids, or material necessary to the operation of only the power unit portion of the vehicle shall be deemed nondivisible. 
(3)  Would prohibit the vehicle from hauling one attachment that is necessary to the operation of the load. To be considered nondivisible, the attachment must be securely mounted to the load in the manner it is to be used and not carried as a separate object on the hauling vehicle. It is the duty of the applicant to declare such an attachment in the permit application. 
    One-way or Single Trip Permit. One move from the point of origin to the point of destination. Any additional stops between the point of origin and the point of destination are expressly prohibited. Single trip permits are valid for five consecutive days from the date of issuance unless otherwise directed by the Police Department. 
    Permit Route. The route authorized by the issuing authority with proper jurisdiction over the roadway(s) for which permission has been granted to move a vehicle or combination of vehicles that is in itself indivisible or carrying an indivisible load that exceeds normal dimensions or weight or a combination thereof. 
    Quarterly Permit. A permit issued to a single truck, truck-tractor power unit, or piece of special mobile equipment which is valid for unlimited moves for a period not to exceed ninety days from the date of issuance. 
    Round-trip Movement. Two trips over the same route in opposite directions. Round-trip permits are valid for ten consecutive days from the date of issuance. 
    Semitrailer. Every vehicle without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
    Tandem Axles. Any two or more single axles whose centers are more than forty inches and not more than ninety-six inches apart, measured to the nearest inch between extreme axles in the series, except as provided in Section 15-111 (625 ILCS 5/15-111) for special hauling vehicles. 
    Trailer. Every vehicle without motive power in operation, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle. 
    Truck Tractor. Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
    Village is the village of Wheeling. 
B.  Overweight and/or Overdimension Vehicles. 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person to be in control of, to drive, to park, or move on, upon or across or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be parked, driven or moved upon or across, any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the village, any vehicle or combination of vehicles exceeding the size and weight limitations stated in 625 ILCS 5/15-102 (width), 15-103 (height), 15-107 (length), and 15-111 (weight). 
2.  Size and weight limitations while operating on Village streets shall not apply to fire apparatus or equipment for snow or ice removal operations owned or operated by or for any governmental body or to implements of husbandry temporarily operated or towed in a combination in the furtherance of a farm or agricultural endeavor and to any vehicle or combination of vehicles operating under the terms of a valid oversize and/or dimension permit issued by the State of Illinois or Counties of Lake and Cook. 
3.  Where lower size and weight limits or other restrictions are imposed by ordinance under authority of 625 ILCS 5/15-111, 15-316 and 15-317, and signs indicating such limitations or restrictions are posted, it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle or combination of vehicles in excess of such size or weight limitations or in violation of such restrictions. 
4.  Whenever any vehicle or combination of vehicles is operated in violation of this section, the owner and/or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation and either or both the owner and driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation in an administrative adjudication hearing, as provided for in the Village Code, or otherwise. 
C.  Permits for Overweight and/or Overdimension Vehicles. 
1.  A permit shall be required for the movement of any vehicle or combinations of vehicles, that is nondivisible or is carrying a load that is nondivisible, while operating on roadways and bridges within the jurisdiction of the Village which exceed the maximum size and weight limits described in 625 ILCS 5.0/15-102 (width), 15-103 (height), 15-107 (length) and 15-111 (weight) of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
    Exempt from permits are the following: 
(a)  Fire department vehicles; 
(b)  Those vehicles operating under an emergency declaration; 
(c)  Village owned vehicles engaged in emergency utility repair; 
(d)  Equipment used for snow and ice removal, owned or operated by any governmental body. 
2.  Permits shall be issued only in the name of the person, firm, business or corporation that owns and operates the transporting vehicle or that operates the vehicle under a bonafide lease agreement. 
3.  Permits for vehicles both overweight and/or oversize are valid only a half hour before sunrise until a half hour after sunset, on any day which a permit issued by the Illinois Department of Transportation is valid. 
4.  Permits are nontransferrable and apply only to the permittee and vehicle to which it was issued. 
5.  The Village, in its discretion, may issue revisions to permits for a fee of twenty dollars (or fifty percent of the original permit fee if the original permit fee was thirty dollars or less): 
(a)  To correct an error attributed to the Village (no revision fee); 
(b)  To correct an error attributed to the applicant, discovered before the move; 
(c)  To adjust weights, dimension or routes as issued on the permit, before the move is made. 
6.  The permit, when issued constitutes an agreement between the permittee and the Village that the move described in the application will take place only as described. The permittee has the responsibility to report to the Police Department any inaccuracies or errors on the part of either the Village or the permittee before starting any move. Undertaking the move is prima facie evidence of acceptance of the permit as issued and its terms. 
7.  The routing prescribed in the permit constitutes the sole extent of the authority granted by the permit for the use of roads within the jurisdiction of the Village, and any vehicle and/or load found to be off route will be considered off route and without a permit. Permits shall be in the driver's possession in either written or electronic form at all times unless otherwise directed by the Police Department and presented upon demand to any and all police officers for the purpose of inspection. 
8.  Any vehicle(s) and/or load found to be divisible will render the permit null and void. The entire gross weight and axles weights of the vehicle(s) with the load are subject to legal size and weights. It is the duty of the applicant to verify the nondivisibility of the vehicle(s) before making application for the permit. The permit application itself is prima facie evidence that the applicant confirmed the vehicle(s) and/or load were non-divisible. 
9.  If required, arrangement shall be made by the permittee to have the proper utilities notified, property moved, bridge or highway analysis performed and completed in advance of any permit movement. 
10.  All movements under the permit shall be made in accordance with all applicable federal, State and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
11.  Permits are null and void if altered for the purpose of deception. The permits issued under this section constitute the grant of a privilege by the Village and may be denied or suspended for such reasons as the Village may deem rationally related to its governmental interests including, but not limited to: 
(a)  A permittee knowingly providing incorrect information in an application for a permit; 
(b)  A permittee, its agents, or employees operating on a permit which has been altered for purposes of deception; 
(c)  Noncompliance by permittee, its agents or employees with federal, State, or local ordinances pertaining to the transport of goods or operation of a vehicle engaged in the transport of goods; 
(d)  Moving on Village streets without a valid permit as required under this section. 
12.  All single-trip or round-trip permits are limited to movements on assigned routes only. 
13.  All quarterly or annual overweight permits are restricted to the following maximum limitations and routing: 
(a)  Twelve feet in width. 
(b)  Thirteen feet, six inches in height. 
(c)  One hundred fifteen feet in length. 
(d)  May not move across bridges or structures that are posted or listed as such on the Village truck route map. 
(e)  May not move on a "no-truck" route that is posted or listed as such on the Village truck route map, without written permission from a member of the Police Department. 
(f)  May not use any Village street as a cut-thru to avoid using a State, County, or Township highway. 
    These permits are subject to all standards of application set forth in [subsection] 15. below, except that the load may be interchanged provided none of the above listed maximum weight and size dimensions are exceeded. Quarterly and annual permits shall list the registration number and state (if applicable) for the power unit, and vehicle identification number (VIN). The serial number of the power unit, and/or owner applied number shall also be listed, if applicable. 
    Any violation of these terms will render the certificate null and void, and subject the driver, firm, business, or corporation that owns the vehicle to legal weight and dimension laws. The arresting police officer will immediately confiscate the permit. 
14.  All applications for permits shall be given full consideration. Permits for proposed moves may be issued: 
(a)  When the Village roadways and bridges will not be unduly damaged; and 
(b)  When the safety of the traveling public will be adequately protected. 
15.  Applications for a permit to move an oversized and/or overweight vehicle, and/or load, must be made to the Police Department. The following information shall be included on the permit application in addition to any other information deemed necessary by the Police Department: 
(a)  Company name. 
(b)  Company address, city, state and zip code. 
(c)  Company email, fax and telephone numbers. 
(d)  Make of hauling vehicle or power unit. 
(e)  Description of load to be moved. 
(f)  Maximum dimensions, gross weight, and axle weights of vehicle including load. 
(g)  Roads under jurisdiction of the Village to be traveled. 
16.  Police or civilian escorts are required at the discretion of the Police Department. The total number of police officers necessary to provide for a safe move shall be determined by the Police Department. Fees for police escorts shall be in addition to the permit fees set forth herein and included in the billing, invoicing and collection of permit fees. Police escort fees shall provide for a minimum of two hours of service calculated by the most current overtime rate established by the Police Department. 
17.  The permittee shall assume total liability for any and all damages to streets, bridges, Village owned appurtenances and private or public property while engaged in a permit move. The measure of liability is the cost for all repairs or replacement of property damaged by the permittee. 
18.  The permittee shall indemnify and hold harmless the Village or members of the Police Department from any costs, judgments or settlements, including attorneys' fees, arising from physical injuries, including loss of life, or damage to or loss of property related to acts or omissions by permittee, its officers, agents, or employees pursuant to the permit. 
19.  Upon application for a permit each applicant shall provide evidence of a valid comprehensive general liability insurance policy, with an insurance company approved by the Village, for protection against personal injury or property damage in the amount of one million dollars per occurrence. The Village and the Police Department shall be listed as an additional insured certificate holder on the policy. 
20.  Suspension of a current permit shall be for the time determined appropriate by the Police Department; however, reinstatement may be made upon conditions determined by the Village and payment of all outstanding settlements or judgments. 
21.  The Chief of Police or their designee shall administer and enforce this section and shall have the authority to grant, deny, suspend, or reinstate Permits. Any applicant or permittee denied a permit or who has had a permit suspended, upon request, shall be given a hearing before the Chief of Police first, then the Village Manager if the permittee is still unsatisfied. 
22.  No permits shall be issued to an applicant or company who has outstanding fees or payments due to the Village. 
23.  The Village with respect to highways under its jurisdiction shall collect a fee as shown herein from applicants for the issuance of a permit to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicle(s), and/or loads, which fit the categories shown. Any axle or gross weight greater than the maximum weights set forth in this section are subject to special assessment and investigation to determine appropriate fees. 
24.  The Village Finance Department is responsible for the billing, invoicing, and collection of permit fees. The Finance Department, in their discretion, may make rules and regulations as to acceptable methods of payment and due dates. Any unpaid permit fees will be turned over to a collection agency under contract of the Village. 
25.  The Police Department shall maintain a list of reasonable provisions to accompany every permit. The Police Chief or their designee may amend this document from time to time at their discretion. The provisions shall not be more restrictive than those listed in the OPER 993 form issued by the Illinois Department of Transportation, or the most current phase of interstate harmonization policies issued by the American Association of State and Highway Transportation Officials, except in extreme cases. Permit provisions shall accompany every permit issued.
