D.  Vehicles Prohibited on Certain Streets. 
1.  As provided under the authority of 625 ILCS 5/15-111 and 15-316, it shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle upon any street where the operation of that vehicle is prohibited by ordinance and where signs of such prohibition are posted. Vehicles operating under the authority of 625 ILCS 5/15-111 or 15-316 while utilizing village streets under "reasonable access" rules will be considered in violation of this section if they are not utilizing the most direct route to points of loading and unloading. 
2.  It shall be unlawful to operate any "construction vehicle" as defined herein on any street in the village when signs are posted on the street prohibiting "construction vehicles". Where the chief of police, with the approval of the board of trustees, establishes a truck route, construction vehicles will utilize only those established routes to service those areas of the village under construction. 
E.  Penalty. 
1.  Any person who violates, disobeys, neglects, fails to comply with or resists enforcement of the provisions of this chapter (except for subsection B., herein) shall be fined not less than fifty dollars, nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars, for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each separate incident that a violation occurs. 
2.  The driver of any vehicle in violation of section B., or any other section of the Illinois Vehicle Code relating to overweight or overdimension vehicles, shall be subject to any and all applicable fines and penalties under the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.) as follows: 
Up to and including 
2,000 pounds overweight = $50 From 2001 through 
2,500 pounds overweight = the fine is $135 From 2501 through 
3,000 pounds overweight = the fine is $165 From 3501 through 
4,000 pounds overweight = the fine is $300 From 4001 through 
4,500 pounds overweight = the fine is $425 From 4501 through 
5,000 pounds overweight = the fine is $475 From 5001 or more 
pounds overweight = the fine shall be computed by assessing $750 for the first 5,000 pounds over-weight and $75 for each additional increment of 500 pounds overweight or fraction thereof  
3.  In addition to seeking applicable fines (as herein provided), the village attorney may institute any proper action in the name of the village of Wheeling to enjoin the violation of any provision of this Chapter. 
F.  Authority of Administrative Adjudication Hearing Officer. Any violation of the Illinois Vehicle Code relating to overweight and/or overdimension vehicles, including violations of Section 15 or 5/3-401(d), or other violations set forth in this Chapter may be prosecuted in an administrative adjudication hearing as a municipal ordinance violation as set forth in Chapter 1.28 of the Wheeling Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 4416, § 1, 4-20-2009; Ord. No. 5018, §§ A, B, 6-20-2016, eff. 9-20-2016) 
9.01.151 - Part. 
    "Part" means any shell, essential portion, integral element, component or chassis of a vehicle. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.162 - Property line. 
    "Property line" means the line marking the boundary between any street and lots of property abutting thereon. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.163 - Public building. 
    "Public building" means any building used by a municipality, county, park district, school district, the state of Illinois or the United Sates Government. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.168 - Rear lot line. 
    "Rear lot line" means the boundary of real property which is the farthest distance from, and is, or is most nearly, parallel to the front lot line and which delineates the ownership of such real property. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.169 - Rear yard. 
    "Rear yard" means that portion of real property extending along the full length of the rear lot line and lying between the rear lot line and the closest edge of a residential, commercial or industrial building. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.170 - Recreational vehicle. 
    "Recreational vehicle" means every boat, boat trailer, camping trailer, motor home, mini-motor home, travel trailer, travel camper, or van camper which may be used primarily for recreational purposes. The term "recreational vehicle" shall not include a pickup coach unless altered for uses as temporary living quarters. 
(Ord. 3502 § A, 2000) 
9.01.172 - Remove. 
    "Remove" means to take away, deface, cover or destroy. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.174 - Residence district. 
    "Residence district" means the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business district when the property on such highway for a distance of three hundred feet or more is in the main improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
    For purposes of establishing maximum speed limits, a residence district shall be at least a quarter of a mile long with residences or residences and buildings in use for businesses spaced no more than three hundred feet apart. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.175 - Resident. 
    "Resident" means: 
(a)  Every natural person who resides in the village of Wheeling shall be deemed a resident of the village of Wheeling. 
(b)  In the case of a firm, partnership, association, or corporation if the principal place of business is located within the village of Wheeling, then such firm, partnership, association, corporation shall be deemed a resident of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.182 - Side lot line. 
    "Side lot line" means the boundary of real property delineating the ownership of such real property and extending between the front lot line and the rear lot line. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.183 - Side yard. 
    "Side yard" means the portion of real property extending along the full length of a side lot line and lying between the side lot line and the closest edge of a residential, commercial or industrial building. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.01.207 - Village. 
    "Village" means the village of Wheeling, counties of Cook and Lake, state of Illinois. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
Chapter 9.02 - OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC LAWS 

9.02.104 - Firemen authorized to enforce-Scene of fire. 
    The fire department officer in command or any fireman designated by him, may exercise the powers and authority of a policeman in directing traffic at the scene of any fire or where the fire department has responded to any emergency call for so long as fire department equipment is on the scene, in the absence of or in assisting the police. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.02.105 - Animals and bicycles. 
    Every person riding a bicycle or animal, or driving any animal-drawn vehicle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this Title, except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
Chapter 9.04 - SPEED RESTRICTIONS 

9.04.102 - Alteration of speed limits. 
    The board of trustees may establish, by ordinance, other maximum speed limits as provided in Illinois Compiled Statutes, 625 ILCS 5/11-604. Such limits as are established by ordinance under this section shall govern the rate of speed on the streets or highway as indicated. Appropriate signs shall be posted showing such speed limits. 
(a)  Vera Lane, maximum speed limit: twenty-five miles per hour. 
(b)  Astor Lane and Prestwick Lane, maximum speed limit: twenty-five miles per hour. 
(c)  River Hill Parkway and River Walk Drive, maximum speed limit: twenty-five miles per hour. 
(d)  Horizon Trail, maximum speed limit: twenty-five miles per hour. 
(e)  Potomac Court, maximum speed limit: twenty-five miles per hour. 
(Ord. 4191 § B, 2007; Ord. 4030 § B, 2005; Ord. 4029 § C, 2005; Ord. 3372 § B, 1999; Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § J, 4-25-2011; Ord. No. 4656, § B, 12-19-2011) 
Chapter 9.06 - TURNING, STARTING AND SIGNALS 

9.06.107 - Right, left turns prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to turn left or right at any place where such turns are prohibited by ordinance. Such prohibition shall be indicated by appropriate signs. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.06.110 - Right turn on red prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to turn right when facing a steady circular red traffic control signal at any intersection designated as a No Right Turn on Red intersection. Such prohibition shall be indicated by appropriate signs. 
(b)  The following intersection shall be designated as No Right Turn on Red (Stop): 
(1)  Northgate Parkway southbound shall not turn right on a red traffic control signal onto westbound Dundee Road during the hours of 4:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(Ord. 3509 § A, 2000) 
Chapter 9.10 - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 

9.10.101 - Limited parking zones-Signs required. 
    Appropriate signs shall be posted in all areas where parking is limited or prohibited, indicating such limitations or prohibitions. When signs are erected giving notice of such limitations or prohibitions, it is unlawful to park any vehicle otherwise than as directed. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.102 - All overnight parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on any street within the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. without first obtaining permission from the Wheeling police department. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the south side of Lakeview Drive between Buffalo Grove Road and Lakeview Drive. 
(Ord. 3247 § A, 1997: Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.103 - Parking during or after snow conditions. 
(a)  It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any street within the village at any time within eight hours after a snow fall of two inches or more. 
(b)  For each succeeding snowfall of two inches or more, the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall apply. 
(c)  Any motor vehicle parked in violation of subsection (a) of this section, may be towed away pursuant to Section 9.16.107 so that the streets can be plowed to protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of this village. 
(d)  Fees charged for the towing service shall be paid by the owner of the vehicle before the vehicle is released. 
(e)  In the case of a major snow storm where vehicles may be blocking the streets thereby limiting emergency vehicle operations and safe travel, the chief of police may authorize relocation tows to designated areas within the village. Fees for relocation tows ordered pursuant to this section shall be paid by the owner of the vehicle before the vehicle is released. 
(f)  Signs stating "Parking Prohibited when there is two inches or more of snow on the street. Vehicles parking in violation will be towed" shall be posted clearly on every street or highway entering the village. Such signs need be posted only at each point of entrance to the village. 
(Ord. 3512 § A, 2000: Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.104 - Parking in alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the alley for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.105 - Handicapped parking areas. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to stop, stand, or park any motor vehicle in an area including private or public off-street parking where an official traffic-control device specifically reserves such area for the stopping, standing or parking by handicapped persons only. 
(b)  This section shall not be applicable to those vehicles: 
(1)  Bearing registration plates issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1; 
(2)  Bearing registration plates issued to a disabled veteran pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes 625 ILCS 5/3-609; 
(3)  Bearing a "handicapped person" sticker approved and issued by the village of Wheeling or other governmental agency. 
(c)  Any person convicted of violating subsection (a) of this section shall be fined in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars for each offense. 
(Ord. 4187 § A, 2007: Ord. 3247 § B, 1997; Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.106 - Handicapped parking stickers- Application. 
    Any handicapped person as defined in Section 9.01.155 of this Title, residing in the village of Wheeling, may receive a handicapped parking sticker by filing an application with the director of finance. Information required on said application shall include the name and address of the applicant, a description of the vehicle for which the sticker is desired, including the year, make and model and vehicle identification number. All applicants shall submit a physician's statement describing with specificity the circumstances which qualify the applicant for issuance of a handicapped parking sticker. In lieu of a physician's statement proof that the vehicle for which the sticker is desired has been issued physically handicapped person or disabled veteran state registration plates may be substituted. 
(Ord. 1982 § (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § M, 3-21-2011) 
9.10.107 - Stopping, standing, or parking prohibited-No signs required. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the law or direction of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a parkway; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway or in a manner blocking use of the driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  Within fifteen feet of a lateral line from a fire hydrant to the curb; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within twenty feet of a crosswalk or an intersection; 
(7)  Within thirty feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, yield right-of-way sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of roadway; 
(8)  Between the curb or edge of the pavement and the public sidewalk or property line; 
(9)  Within fifty feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(10)  Within twenty feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five feet of said entrance when properly sign-posted; 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On a roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel. The prohibition of this subsection (13) shall not apply to parking upon the approaches to the Jeffery Avenue bridge located on Jeffery Avenue; 
(14)  At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet; 
(15)  On any controlled access highway; 
(16)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet of a point of the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone; 
(17)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping, standing, or parking; 
(18)  On a sidewalk, except between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. when vehicles may be parked in residence districts on that portion of the sidewalk which connects the driveway and the driveway apron. 
    No sign shall be required to be posted indicating parking is prohibited in those locations specified in subdivisions (1) through (18) of this subsection. 
(b)  No person other than a police officer shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any area enumerated in subsection (a) of this section or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful, or to start or cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change or move the levers, brake, starting device, gears or other mechanism of a parked motor vehicle to a position other than in which it was left by the owner or driver thereof, or attempt to do so. 
(Ord. 2127 § A, 1984: Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.108 - Manner of parking. 
    No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to the curb, except on one-way streets, and it is unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in a street other than parallel with the curb and with the two wheels of the vehicle within twelve inches of the regularly established curbline, except that upon those streets that have been marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb within the space indicated by such marks. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.109 - Loading zones. 
    During the times specified in this section, it is unlawful for a driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight-carrying, nonpassenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload, and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty minutes, in any of the following places: 
(a)  In any public alley, during any hour of the day or night; 
(b)  At any place not to exceed seventy-five feet along the curb before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time; 
(c)  At any place not to exceed seventy-five feet along the curbline before the entrance to a public building between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., except on a Sunday; 
(d)  Directly in front of the entrance to any theater at any time that the theater is open. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.110 - Use of cab and bus stands. 
    No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as a cabstand; and no vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.111 - Parking vehicles on private property without owner's consent. 
    It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property without the consent of the owner of the property. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.112 - Parking of vehicles on major streets prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle, except when necessary to avoid a conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law, or under the direction of a police officer or traffic-control device, upon any of the following streets within the village: 
(1)  Dundee Road, Illinois 68; 
(2)  Milwaukee Avenue, Illinois Route 21; 
(3)  McHenry Road, Illinois Route 83; 
(4)  Elmhurst Road, Illinois Route 83; 
(5)  Lake-Cook Road; 
(6)  Hintz Road; 
(7)  Wolf Road; 
(8)  Camp MacDonald Road; 
(9)  Wheeling Road; 
(10)  Schoenbeck Road; 
(11)  Strong Avenue. 
(b)  The prohibition set forth herein shall include the full right-of-way along the entire length of said streets including the shoulders and berms. 
(Ord. 3606 § A, 2002: Ord. 3179 § A, 1996) 
9.10.113 - Parking vehicles on unpaved surface prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle upon a surface which is not paved in accordance with the provisions of the ordinances of the village of Wheeling. It is also unlawful for any person to allow a motor vehicle to be parked on any property owned or under the control of such person when such vehicle is parked upon a surface which is not paved in accordance with the provisions of the ordinances of the village of Wheeling. It shall not be a violation of this provision where a vehicle is parked contrary to the provisions of this section upon a site at which actual construction is taking place and suitable paved surfaces are not then available. Nor shall it be a violation of the provisions of this section where a vehicle is temporarily parked upon a nonpaved surface in accordance with the provisions of any other section of the Code of the Village. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.114 - Parking of commercial vehicles in residence districts. 
(a)  No commercial vehicle bearing a class designation other than A or B under the provisions of Section 3-815 of the Illinois Vehicle Code shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified as a residence district, except when making a delivery or rendering a service at such premises. 
(b)  No commercial vehicle having a height from the underside of the tire to the top of the vehicle, inclusive of load, exceeding nine feet or having a length exceeding twenty feet extreme overall dimension shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified as a residence district, except when making a delivery or rendering a service at such premises. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983). 
9.10.115 - Parking of commercial vehicles in designated areas. 
(a)  Where by the approved site plan of a shopping or commercial area spaces have been designated for parking commercial vehicles, it is unlawful to park a commercial vehicle in other than the designated parking spaces except as provided by Section 9.10.109. 
(b)  Such designated parking space shall be clearly identified as commercial parking spaces and each owner or occupant of the shopping or commercial area shall be notified by certified mail of the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.116 - Parking on property of another. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to enter upon the land or any part thereof of another with a motor vehicle after receiving, immediately prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden, or is to remain upon the land of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart. 
(b)  A person has received notice from the owner or occupant within the meaning of this section if he has been notified personally either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land or the forbidden part thereof. 
(c)  The police department is authorized to have said motor vehicle towed and removed to a place of safety, upon complaint of the owner or occupant in charge of the land that said motor vehicle has unlawfully entered said land. 
(d)  Before the release of said vehicle to the owner, the owner shall cause to be paid to the village all charges incurred in the removal of said vehicle in accordance with Section 9.16.103. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.117 - Street cleaning parking prohibition. 
    It is unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street or portion thereof in the village at any time when such street is being cleaned. Signs indicating that a street or portion thereof is being cleaned shall be posted immediately before the cleaning of the street, and shall be removed after the cleaning of the street is finished. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.118 - Vehicles for sale-Vehicle merchandising. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle upon any street or private property for the purpose of displaying the vehicle for sale. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to licensed automobile dealers. 
(c)  It is unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of peddling merchandise from said vehicle. 
(Ord. 2730 § C, 1991: Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.119 - Storing unlicensed vehicle. 
    It is unlawful to leave or possess on any lot, driveway, or in a parking area any trailer, semitrailer, truck, automobile, or major parts thereof not licensed by the state of Illinois and the village of Wheeling for the current year. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.120 - Recreational vehicles-Parking and storage. 
    It is unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or store any recreational vehicle on any real property within the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling except as provided as follows: 
(a)  All recreational vehicles may be parked or stored in commercial zoning districts in conformance with the provisions of Title 19, Zoning, of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(b)  All recreational vehicles may be parked or stored in industrial zoning districts in conformance with the provisions of Title 19, Zoning, of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(c)  Recreational vehicles exceeding an overall width of eight feet, or an overall length of twenty-two feet including hitch, or an overall height of ten feet shall be parked or stored on single-family residential property only inside an enclosed garage or accessory building. 
(d)  Recreational vehicles not exceeding an overall width of eight feet or an overall length of twenty-two feet including hitch, or not exceeding an overall height of ten feet excluding air conditioner shall be parked or stored on single-family residential property inside an enclosed garage or accessory building or in the rear of side yard not closer than three feet from any rear of side lot line. 
(e)  Recreational vehicles not exceeding an overall width of eight feet or an overall length of twenty-two feet or an overall height of eight feet may be parked or stored on multifamily residential property inside an enclosed garage or accessory building or in those areas specifically designated by the homeowners' association or management firm as parking for recreational vehicles. 
(f)  Recreational vehicles may be parked on a driveway for a period not to exceed seven days (only upon the granting of written permission by the Wheeling police department). Such vehicles shall not obstruct the sidewalk or impact visibility on adjacent streets or driveways. No person shall receive written permission to park a recreational vehicle in a driveway under this section in excess of four times per calendar year. 
(Ord. 2105 § A (part), 1984; Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 5178, § 1, 5-7-2018) 
9.10.121 - Recreation vehicles-Unsafe conditions. 
    It is unlawful to park or store a recreational vehicle in such a manner as to create a dangerous or unsafe condition. The parking or storage of a recreational vehicle, not locked and choked, whether loaded or not, shall be considered a dangerous and unsafe condition. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.10.122 - Parking restrictions on Center Avenue. 
(a)  Parking on the south side of Center Avenue, east of Wheeling Avenue, excepting the easterly two hundred feet of roadway, is permitted for no more than two hours, Monday through Sunday, between the hours of six o'clock a.m. and two o'clock a.m. 
(b)  Parking on the south side of Center Avenue, inclusive only of the easterly two hundred feet of roadway, is prohibited between the hours of three o'clock p.m. and six o'clock a.m., Monday through Sunday. 
(c)  The director of public works is directed to post the appropriate signage along Center Avenue reflecting the restrictions contained in this section. 
(d)  The parking restrictions on Center Avenue contained in this section shall not apply to vehicles driven by the property owners or guests of the following residences, provided that the vehicles parked on Center Avenue display a parking pass issued by the village in the front windshield: 
100 Wille Avenue, Wheeling, Illinois 60090 
223 Center Avenue, Wheeling, Illinois 60090 
216 Center Avenue, Wheeling, Illinois 60090 
246 Center Avenue, Wheeling, Illinois 60090 
(e)  No more than two, twelve-month parking passes shall be issued per household of the residences stated in Section (d) above. 
(Ord. No. 4756, § A, 2-4-2013; Ord. No. 4773, § A, 6-3-2013) 
9.10.123 - Parking restrictions on Wille Avenue. 
(a)  Parking on the east side of Wille Avenue, between Center and Highland Avenues, is prohibited between the hours of seven o'clock a.m. and three thirty p.m. on school days. 
(b)  The director of public works is directed to post the appropriate signage along Wille Avenue reflecting the restrictions contained in this section. 
(Ord. No. 4756, § B, 2-4-2013) 
Chapter 9.13 - AMBULANCES AND OTHER EMERGENCY VEHICLES 

9.13.102 - Movement and parking exception- Stop signs. 
    The provisions of this Title regulating the movement or parking of vehicles shall not apply to the operation of an authorized emergency vehicle under the conditions of Section 9.13.106 and the driver of such ambulance may proceed cautiously past a red stop sign or signal but shall slow down as necessary for the safety of others. At other times, drivers of authorized emergency vehicles shall stop in obedience to a stop sign or signal. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.13.103 - Special privileges precluded except for emergency. 
    No driver of any authorized emergency vehicle shall assume any special privileges except when such vehicle is operated in response to an emergency call or in the immediate pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.13.104 - Exception for street improvement and repair. 
    The provisions of this Title regulating the movement and parking of vehicles shall not apply to persons, equipment or vehicles while actually engaged in installing, repairing, or otherwise improving streets or street pavements. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.13.105 - Fire department vehicles. 
(a)  Compliance With Emergency Vehicle Provisions. Upon the approach of a fire department vehicle, drivers of vehicles shall comply with the provisions of this Chapter relating to the approach of authorized emergency vehicles. 
(b)  Following. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle, other than one on official business, to follow any fire apparatus responding to a fire alarm, closer than 500 feet or to park any vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has stopped to answer a fire alarm. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.13.106 - Operation of emergency vehicle. 
    The driver of an authorized vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions stated as follows: 
(A)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this Chapter; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be required and necessary for safe operation; 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property; 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(B)  The exceptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle, other than a police vehicle, shall apply only when the vehicle is making use of either an audible signal when in motion or visual signals meeting the requirements of this section. 
(C)  The foregoing provisions do not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty of driving with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor do such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
Chapter 9.14 - FUNERALS AND OTHER PROCESSIONS 

9.14.102 - Regulations for drivers in processions. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand side of the roadway as close as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.14.103 - Identification of funeral procession. 
    A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other identifying insignia and by having the lights of each vehicle lighted. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.14.104 - Space between vehicle in motorcade or caravan-Funeral processions. 
    Motor vehicles being driven upon any street outside of a business or residence district in a caravan or motorcade, whether or not towing other vehicles, shall be so operated as to allow sufficient space between each such vehicle or combination of vehicles so as to enable any other vehicle to enter and occupy such space without danger. This provision shall not apply to funeral processions. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.14.105 - Driving through funeral or other procession. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated when required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
Chapter 9.16 - ABANDONED, LOST, STOLEN, UNCLAIMED VEHICLES 

9.16.101 - Storing, parking or leaving abandoned, dismantled or other such motor vehicle prohibited- Declared nuisance-Exceptions. 
    No person shall park, store, leave, or permit the parking, storing, or leaving of any motor vehicle of any kind which is in an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, rusted, junked, or partially dismantled condition whether attended or not, upon any public or private property within the village for a period of time in excess of seventy-two hours. The presence of an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, rusted, junked or partially dismantled vehicle or parts thereof, on private or public property is declared a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter. This section shall not apply to any vehicle enclosed within a building on private property or to any vehicle held in connection with a business enterprise, lawfully licensed by the village and properly operated in the appropriate business zone, pursuant to the zoning laws of the village. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.102 - Notice to remove. 
(a)  Whenever it comes to the attention of the village that any nuisance as defined in Section 9.16.101 exist within the village, a notice in writing shall be served upon the owner of the vehicle, or when the nuisance exists upon private property upon the owner or occupant of the land, notifying them of the existence of the nuisance and requesting its removal in the time specified in this Chapter. 
(b)  Written notice required under this section shall be given at least seven days prior to the time of compliance. It shall constitute sufficient notice, when a copy of same is posted in a conspicuous place upon the private property on which the vehicle is located or copy is sent by registered mail to the owner or occupant of the vehicle. 
(c)  The notice shall contain the request for removal within the time specified in this ordinance, and the notice shall advise that upon failure to comply with the notice to remove, the village or its designee shall undertake such removal with the cost of removal to be levied against the owner of the vehicle or the owner or occupant of the property. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.103 - Responsibility for removal. 
    Upon proper notice and opportunity to be heard, the owner of the abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, or inoperative vehicle or the owner of occupant of the private property in which the same is located, either or all of them, shall be responsible for its removal within seven days of posting of the notice of date or mailing. In the event of removal and disposition by the village, the owner of said vehicle or the owner or occupant of the private property where same is located, shall be liable for the expenses incurred. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.104 - Request for hearing. 
    The persons to whom the notice are directed, or their duly authorized agents may file a written request for hearing before the chief of police within the seven-day period of compliance prescribed in Section 9.16.103 for the purpose of defending the charges by the village. Failure to file a request within the specified time shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.105 - Procedure for hearing. 
    The hearing shall be held as soon as practicable after the filing of the request and the persons to whom the notices are directed shall be advised of the time and place of said hearing at least two days in advance thereof. At any such hearing, the persons to whom the notices have been directed may introduce witnesses and evidence. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.106 - Removal of motor vehicle from property. 
    If the violation described in the notice has not been remedied within the seven-day period of compliance, or in the event that a notice requesting a hearing is timely filed, a hearing is had, and the existence of the violation is affirmed, the police department shall have the right to take possession of the motor vehicle and remove it from the premises. It is unlawful for any person to interfere with, hinder, or refuse to allow such person or persons to enter upon private property for the purpose of removing a vehicle under the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.107 - Towing away cars/other emergencies. 
    The police department is authorized to remove and tow away or have removed and towed away by commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in any place where such parked vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant, or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle, or snow removal equipment or other equipment performing emergency service. Cars so towed away shall be stored on any village property or in a public garage or parking lot and shall be returned to the owner or operator thereof after payment for applicable expenses incurred by the village in removing and storing such vehicles. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.108 - Notice of removal. 
    Within forty-eight hours of the removal of a vehicle, under the provisions of this Chapter, the chief of police shall give notice to the registered owner of the vehicle if known, and also to the owner or occupant of the private property from which the vehicle was removed, that said vehicle or vehicles have been impounded and stored for violation of this Chapter. The notice shall give the location of where the vehicle or vehicles are stored and the costs incurred by the village for removal. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.114 - Reclaiming towed vehicles. 
    Any time before a vehicle at public sale is disposed of as provided for in this Chapter, the owner, lienholder, or other person legally entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the chief of police proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No vehicle shall be released under this section until all towing and storage charges have been paid. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.115 - Emergency tow hearing. 
(a)  Any person whose vehicle has been towed as abandoned pursuant to Section 9.16.107 shall have the right to request a hearing to contest disposition of the vehicle or any towing charges or fees incurred. 
(b)  Request for a hearing under this section shall be made in writing to the chief of police within seven days of the towing of the vehicle or within seven days after receipt of a notice of towing. Failure to file a request within the time specified shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. 
(c)  All hearings held pursuant to this section shall be held on a date convenient to both parties but in no event shall any hearing be scheduled later than thirty days after the date the request for hearing was filed. 
(d)  All notices sent pursuant to Section 9.16.108 to owners of vehicles towed pursuant to Section 9.16.107 shall advise of the availability of the hearing process. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.16.116 - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of the ordinance codified in this Title shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars. Each day a violation of any of the provisions of this Title exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
Chapter 9.17 - SPECIAL TRAFFIC RESTRICTIONS 

9.17.101 - Truck routes. 
(a)  All highways under the jurisdiction of the state of Illinois, Department of Transportation, and designated as truck routes shall be truck routes within the village and shall have such weight classification as designated by the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
(b)  The following streets and highways within and under the jurisdiction of the village of Wheeling are designated as truck routes:

9.17.102 - Traffic prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful to drive any vehicle having a gross weight exceeding sixteen thousand pounds upon any street or highway within the Village not designated by Section 9.17.101 as a truck route. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to those vehicles engaged in the delivery or picking up of a load where access by a truck route is not available, in which case such vehicle may be driven on a street not designated as a truck route for not more than the minimum distance necessary for such delivery or pick up. 
(c)  It is unlawful to drive upon a truck route any vehicle having a weight class designation greater than that allowed by Section 9.17.101. 
(Ord. 2730 § F, 1991: Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.17.105 - Special truck restrictions. 
(a)  It is unlawful to drive any truck, semitrailer or combination thereof having three or more axles on Wolf Road between Hintz Road and Dundee Road within the Village. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to recreational vehicles or to those vehicles engaged in the delivery of goods or services where access by a route other than Wolf Road is not available, in which case the vehicle may be driven on Wolf Road for not more than the minimum distance necessary for the delivery of said goods and services. 
(Ord. 3563 § A, 2001) 
9.17.115 - Permits for excess weight or size. 
    The provisions of this Chapter governing size, weight and/or load shall not apply where a special permit has been issued by the State of Illinois, pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, Section 15-301, authorizing the operation of a vehicle or vehicles of size, or weight, or of a vehicle or a load exceeding the maximum of this Chapter or where a permit has been issued by the Village in accordance with [Section] 9.01.147.C. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 5018, § C, 6-20-2016, eff. 9-20-2016) 
9.17.116 - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this Chapter governing size, weight, and load do not apply to fire apparatus or equipment for snow and ice removal operations owned or operated by any governmental body, or to implements of husbandry temporarily operated or towed in a combination upon a highway provided such combination does not consist or more than three vehicles, or, in the case of hauling fresh, perishable fruits or vegetables from farm to the point of first processing, not more than three wagons being towed by an implement of husbandry, or to a vehicle operated under the terms of a special permit issued under this Chapter. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
Chapter 9.18 - MISCELLANEOUS LAWS 

9.18.102 - (11-1102) Limitations on backing. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can be made with safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same upon any controlled-access highway. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.103 - (11-1403) Riding on motorcycles. 
    The operator of a motorcycle shall ride only astride the permanent and regular seat or saddle attached thereto, and the operator shall not permit more than one other person to ride thereon nor shall such other person ride on the motorcycle unless it is designed to carry two people, in which event the passenger shall also ride astride the permanent and regular seat or saddle, if it is designed for two persons, or astride another seat or saddle firmly attached behind the operator; however any seat or saddle designed for a passenger must be equipped with permanent handgrips, and, in addition, the motorcycle must be equipped with footrests adjusted to fit such passenger. A sidecar may be attached to a motorcycle in which additional persons may ride. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.104 - (11-1404) Special equipment for persons riding motorcycles. 
    The operator of a motorcycle and every passenger thereon shall be protected by glasses, goggles or a transparent shield. The Illinois Department of Transportation shall, pursuant to law, determine the standards for this equipment. These standards shall establish requirements based upon those set forth in Vehicle Equipment Safety Commission Regulation VESC-8, "Minimum Requirements for Motorcyclists' Eye Protection." 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.105 - (11-1405) Required equipment on motorcycles. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motorcycle with handlebars more than fifteen inches in height above that portion of the seat or saddle occupied by the operator. 
(b)  Any motorcycle carrying a passenger, other than in a sidecar or enclosed cab, shall be equipped with permanent handgrips on the seat or saddle carrying such passenger, and with footrests adjusted to fit such passenger. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.106 - (11-1406) Obstruction of driver's view or driving mechanism. 
(a)  No person may drive a vehicle when it is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat such number of persons, as to obstruct the view of the driver to the front or sides of the vehicle or as to interfere with the driver's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(b)  No passenger in a vehicle may ride in such position as to interfere with the driver's view ahead or to the sides, or to interfere with his control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(c)  No passenger on a school bus may ride or stand in a position as to interfere with the driver's view ahead or to the side or to the rear, or to interfere with his control of the driving mechanism of the bus. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.107 - (11-1407) Opening vehicle doors. 
    No person shall open the door of a vehicle on the side available to moving traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe to do so, and can be done without interfering with the movement of other traffic, nor shall any person leave a door open on the side of a vehicle available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.108 - (11-1408) Riding in house trailers. 
    No person shall occupy a house trailer while it is being moved upon a public highway. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.110 - (11-1410) Coasting prohibited. 
(a)  The driver of any motor vehicle traveling upon a down grade shall not coast with the gears or transmission of such vehicle in neutral. 
(b)  The driver of a motor vehicle of the second division, when traveling upon a down grade, shall not coast with the clutch disengaged. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.111 - (11-1411) Following fire apparatus prohibited. 
    The driver of any vehicle, other than one on official business, shall not follow any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm closer than five hundred feet or drive into or park such vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.115 - (12-603.1) Use of safety belts in motor vehicles. 
(a)  Each driver and front seat passenger of a motor vehicle operated on a roadway in this village shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened seat belt; except that a child less than six years of age shall be protected as required pursuant to the Illinois Child Passenger Protection Act (625 ILCS 25/1 et seq.) Each driver of a motor vehicle transporting a child six years of age or more, but less than sixteen years of age, in the front seat of a motor vehicle shall secure the child in a properly adjusted and fastened safety belt. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any of the following: 
1.  A driver or passenger frequently stopping and leaving the vehicle for roadway maintenance or roadway construction, if the speed of the vehicle between stops does not exceed fifteen miles per hour. 
2.  A driver or passenger possessing a written statement from a physician that such person is unable, for medical or physical reasons, to wear a safety belt. 
3.  A driver or passenger possessing an official certificate or license endorsement issued by the appropriate agency in another state or county indicating that the driver or passenger is unable for medical, physical, or other valid reasons to wear a safety belt. 
4.  A driver operating a motor vehicle in reverse. 
5.  A motor vehicle with a model year prior to 1965. 
6.  A motorcycle. 
7.  A motor vehicle which is not required to be equipped with safety belts under federal law. 
(c)  Violation of any provision of this section is declared to be a petty offense, and any operator or passenger of a passenger motor vehicle convicted of a violation hereunder shall be fined up to one hundred dollars. 
(d)  Failure to wear a seat belt in violation of this section shall not be considered evidence of negligence, shall not limit the liability of an insurer, and shall not diminish any recovery for damages arising out of the ownership, maintenance, or operation of a motor vehicle. 
(e)  Any village police officer may stop any motor vehicle, or driver or passenger of such vehicle solely on the basis of a violation or suspected violation of this section while such motor vehicle is being operated on any roadway within this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 3290 § A, 1998) 
9.18.120 - Removal of wheels-Recreational vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to remove the wheels from any recreational vehicle so as to fix said vehicle to the ground and prevent the ready removal of the vehicle. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.121 - Service connection-Recreational vehicle. 
    No recreational vehicle shall be connected to gas, electric, water or sanitary sewer service. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.122 - Habitation. 
    No vehicle shall be used for living, sleeping, or housekeeping or otherwise occupied within the corporate limits of the village. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.123 - Prima facie evidence. 
    The fact that a motor vehicle which is illegally operated or parked is registered in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that such person was in control of the motor vehicle at the time of such violation. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.124 - Posting signs. 
    Appropriate signs shall be posted to show all stop and yield right-of-way streets, all one-way streets and alleys and all stop intersections. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.18.126 - Operation of motor vehicles upon private property by persons under the age of sixteen years. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for persons under the age of sixteen years to operate any motor vehicle, including but not limited to automobiles, trucks, go-carts, snowmobiles, motorcycles, dirt bikes or any other motorized vehicle able or unable to be licensed in the state of Illinois, upon any private property within the village of Wheeling without the prior written consent of the owner of said property. 
(b)  Any person under the age of sixteen years operating any motor vehicle on private property shall have the required written consent in his immediate possession and, for the purpose of indicating compliance with this section, shall display such written consent upon demand made by any law enforcement officer. 
(Ord. 2088 § A, 1984) 
9.18.130 - Restrictions on the operation of all terrain vehicles, go-karts, minibikes, motorized skateboards or scooters or off-road motorcycles. 
(a)  No person shall use, operate, or be in control of an all terrain vehicle, go-kart, minibike, motorized skateboard or scooter, or off-road motorcycle: 
(1)  On any public street, parking lot, sidewalk, bike path, or other public property; 
(2)  On any property under the jurisdiction of a park board, school board or forest preserve district; 
(3)  On any private road or sidewalk; 
(4)  On the tracks or right-of-way of any operating railroad; 
(5)  On any property owned by a public utility company; 
(6)  On any private property without the express consent of the owner. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any of the above referenced devices when operated by a law enforcement officer in the performance of official duties. 
(Ord. 3555, § B (part), 2001) 
9.18.132 - Restrictions on the operation of motorcycles. 
(a)  No person shall use, operate, or be in control of a motorcycle: 
(1)  On any sidewalk, bike path, or other public property except roadways and parking areas; 
(2)  On any property under the jurisdiction of a park board, school board or forest preserve district except roadways and parking areas; 
(3)  On any private sidewalk; 
(4)  On the tracks or right-of-way of any operating railroad; 
(5)  On any property owned by a public utility company; 
(6)  On any private property except driveways, roadways or parking areas, without the express consent of the owner. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any of the above referenced devices when operated by a law enforcement officer in the performance of official duties. 
(Ord. 3555, § B (part), 2001) 
9.18.133 - Wille Avenue traffic direction. 
    Wille Avenue shall be a two-way street along its entirety, including Wille Avenue extending north of Center Avenue to Dundee Road. 
(Ord. No. 4624, § 1, 8-15-2011) 
Chapter 9.20 - FINES, PENALTIES AND BAIL

(Ord. No. 4603, § K, 4-25-2011; Ord. No. 4807, § A, 12-2-2013; Ord. No. 4864, § 1, 6-16-2014; Ord. No. 5222, § B, 12-3-2018) 
9.20.102 - Penalties for violation. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this Title for which another penalty is not provided and required shall be fined not less than fifty dollars nor more than one thousand dollars for each offense. 
(Ord. 2731 § C, 1991: Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
9.20.103 - Bail for traffic offenses defined by ordinance. 
(a)  Any person arrested for a violation of any provisions of this Title shall be released upon proper bail being furnished in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
(b)  Persons seventeen years of age or older arrested for a violation of any provisions of this Title who are unable to post the proper bail may be released by giving an individual bond (in the amount otherwise required). 
(c)  Persons under seventeen years of age who are unable to post the proper bail may be released on an individual bond (in the amount otherwise required) if the police department cannot, within a reasonable time, locate a parent or legal guardian to post the required bail. 
(Ord. 1982 § B (part), 1983) 
(Ord. No. 4603, § L, 4-25-2011) 
9.20.104 - Immobilization of vehicles for traffic violation judgments. 
(a)  A motor vehicle parked upon a public street, public parking lot or private parking lot regulated pursuant to contract at any time may, by or under the direction of an officer or member of the Wheeling police department be immobilized in such a manner as to prevent its operation, if there is outstanding one or more judgments issued in favor of the village of Wheeling against the owner of such motor vehicle. 
(b)  Upon immobilization of such motor vehicle, the officer or employee shall cause to be placed on such vehicle in a conspicuous manner, notice sufficient to warn any individual that such vehicle has been immobilized and that any attempt to move such vehicle might result in damage to such vehicle. As soon as practicable, the officer or employee shall inform the owner of the immobilized vehicle of the nature and circumstances of the prior outstanding traffic violation judgment for which such vehicle was immobilized. 
(c)  The owner of such immobilized vehicle, or other authorized person, shall be permitted to secure release of the vehicle upon payment of the amount of the fine or penalty for each violation for which there is an outstanding judgment plus statutory interest and the payment of the fees required by subsection (f) of this section. 
(d)  The owner of the immobilized vehicle, or other authorized person, shall have the right to a post-immobilization hearing to determine the validity of such immobilization, towing and any towing or storage charges. Such hearing must be requested within seven days after the vehicle is immobilized. The post-immobilization hearing shall not be determinative of or adjudicate any judgment issued relative to any immobilized vehicle. 
(e)  The immobilizing device or mechanism shall remain in place for seventy-two hours unless the owner has complied with subsection (c) of this section. If compliance has not occurred within seventy-two hours, the vehicle shall be towed or impounded. The village's current towing and storage fees shall be paid, along with fees specified in subsection (f) of this section, before the owner of such vehicle, or authorized person, shall be permitted to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle. 
(f)  The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall pay a fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, for such immobilization. The owner of an immobilized vehicle which was subsequently impounded shall pay a fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, for immobilization, plus the towing and storage charges actually incurred in such case. 
(g)  It is unlawful for any unauthorized person or persons to attempt to remove or to remove the vehicle immobilizing device. 
(h)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to deprive any person of the constitutional right to a hearing or trial as to the violations charged or to an appeal from the judgment entered. 
(Ord. 4131 § N, 2006; Ord. 2999 § A, 1994) 
9.20.105 - Reporting excessive stopping, standing and parking violations. 
(a)  The village shall send a certified report to the Illinois Secretary of State against the registered owner of any vehicle that has accumulated ten or more unsatisfied "stopping, standing and parking" violations in this Chapter. A violation under this Chapter shall be considered unsatisfied if the village has previously and properly cited a penalty to the registered owner, (see Section 9.18.123 of this Chapter, "Prima facie evidence"), according to the applicable provisions of the village code and said penalty has remained unpaid or remains outstanding for more than thirty days. 
(b)  The certified report to the secretary of state shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, last known address and driver's license number of the person who failed to pay the fine or penalty and the registration number of any vehicle known to be registered to such person in Illinois; 
(2)  The name of the municipality making the report; 
(3)  A statement that the village has sent a notice of impending driver's license suspension to the address recorded with the Illinois Secretary of State; 
(4)  The date on which the notice was sent; and 
(5)  The address to which the notice was sent. 
(c)  Before sending notice to the secretary of state the village shall provide notice to the registered owner of the vehicle. The notice sent by the village to the vehicle's registered owner shall be sent by first class United States mail, postage prepaid, to the address of the vehicle's registered owner as recorded with the Illinois Secretary of State and shall set forth the following: 
(1)  A statement that the vehicle has ten or more unsatisfied parking or standing violations as set forth in this Chapter; 
(2)  A statement that failure to pay any fine or penalty within forty-five days of the notice shall result in the village sending certification to the Illinois Secretary of State as described in subsection (a) of this section; 
(3)  A statement that failure to pay any fine or penalty within forty-five days of the notice may result in a suspension of the registered owner's Illinois driver's license by the Illinois Secretary of State pursuant to Section 6-306.5 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, (625 ILCS 5/6-306.5); and 
(4)  A statement that the registered owner may challenge the accuracy of the certified report by requesting in writing, within ten days of receipt of notice, a hearing with the village manager or his designee. The only bases for such a challenge are: 
(i)  The person not having been the owner or lessee of the vehicle or vehicles receiving ten or more standing, parking or compliance violation notices on the date or date such notices were issued; and 
(ii)  The person having already paid the fine or penalty for the ten or more violations indicated in the certified report. 
(Ord. 3894 § 1, 2004)

Chapter 9.32 - PROHIBITED PARKING 

9.32.010 - Designated no parking on major road. 
(a)  It is unlawful to park any vehicle on or along the following roadways within the corporate limits of the village: Lake-Cook Road, Route 68 (Dundee Road), Hintz Road, Palatine Road, Milwaukee Avenue, Wolf Road, Wheeling Road, Old McHenry Road, Route 83 (Elmhurst Road), Schoenbeck Road, Buffalo Grove Road. 
(b)  The director of public works is directed to post the appropriate signage along such roads. 
(Ord. 2840 § C, 1992: Ord. 2680 §§ A, B, 1991) 
(Ord. No. 4593, § B, 3-21-2011) 
Chapter 9.36 - PROHIBITED LEFT TURNS 

9.36.010 - Illinois Route 83. 
    Left turns from southeastbound Illinois Route 83 (Old McHenry Road) shall be prohibited at Weiland Road, and such intersection shall be designated "no left turn." 
(Ord. 2735 § A, 1991) 
9.36.020 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4654, passed Dec. 5, 2011, deleted 9.36.020 in its entirety. Former 9.36.020 pertained to prohibited left turn from Wille Avenue west on Dundee Road, and derived from Ord. No. 4624, passed Aug. 15, 2011. 
Chapter 9.38 - COMMUTER TRAIN STATION PARKING 

9.38.010 - Parking fees. 
    The fee for parking on a daily basis shall be one dollar and seventy-five cents per vehicle per day. The monthly rate for a parking permit shall be thirty-five dollars per permit per month for each vehicle. 
(Ord. 3155 § A (part), 1996) 
(Ord. No. 4496, § A, 2-8-2010) 
9.38.020 - Payment of fee required. 
    No vehicle shall park in the designated areas in the Wheeling commuter parking lots without the payment of the daily fee in the manner prescribed or without the display of a Wheeling parking permit. 
(Ord. 3155 § A (part), 1996) 
9.38.030 - Rules and regulations. 
    The village manager or his designee shall prepare rules and regulations for the operation of the commuter station parking lots and the collection and enforcement of the parking fees. These regulations shall be reported to the village board from time to time. 
(Ord. 3155 § A (part), 1996) 
9.38.040 - Penalties for violations. 
    Failure to pay the daily fee or display the required permit shall be a violation of this chapter and be subject to the penalties contained in Section 9.20.101 of this Title. 
(Ord. 3155 § A (part), 1996) 
Chapter 9.40 - VEHICLE SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT 

9.40.010 - Use of motor vehicles for unlawful purposes. 
A.  Definitions. For purposes of this Chapter: 
1.  "Business day" means any day in which the office of the village clerk of the village of Wheeling is open to the public for a minimum of seven hours. 
2.  "Motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles and motor scooters. 
3.  "Owner of record" means the record title holder(s) of the vehicle. 
4.  "Hearing officer" a licensed attorney, who is not an officer or employee of the village, designated by the village manager. 
B.  Conduct Prohibited. A motor vehicle that is used in connection with any of the following violations may be subject to seizure and impoundment by the village, and the owner of record or lessee of said vehicle shall be liable to the village for an administrative penalty of five hundred dollars plus any applicable towing fees. 
1.  Driving under the influence, as provided in Section 5/11-501(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-501(a)). 
2.  Driving with suspended or revoked license, as provided in Section 5/6-303 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/6-303), except if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (moving or parking) or due to failure to comply with emission testing. 
3.  When a motor vehicle is operated by a person against whom a warrant has been issued by a Circuit Court in Illinois for failing to answer charges that the driver violated subsection (B)(1) or (B)(2) above or (B)(4) below. 
4.  Driving without a valid drivers license or with an expired drivers license, as provided in Section 5/6-101 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/6-101), if the period of expiration is greater than one year. 
5.  Fleeing or attempting to elude, in violation of 625 ILCS 5/11-204(c). 
[6.]  (Intentionally omitted.) 
7.  Firearm offenses: 
a.  720 ILCS 5/24-1, Unlawful use of weapons. 
b.  720 ILCS 5/24-1.1, Unlawful use or possession of weapons by felons or persons in the custody of the Department of Corrections facilities. 
c.  720 ILCS 5/24-1.2, Aggravated discharge of a firearm. 
d.  720 ILCS 5/24-1.2-5, Aggravated discharge of a machine gun or a firearm equipped with a device designed or used for silencing the report of a firearm. 
e.  720 ILCS 5/24-1.5, Reckless discharge of a firearm. 
f.  720 ILCS 5/24-1.6, Aggravated unlawful use of a weapon. 
g.  720 ILCS 5/25-3, Unlawful sale of firearms. 
8.  Drug offenses. Possession of cannabis more than thirty grams, 720 ILCS 550/4(d), (e), (f) and (g). 
9.  Drug offenses. Unauthorized possession of controlled substances, 720 ILCS 570/402. 
C.  Seizure and Impoundment. 
1.  Whenever a police officer has reason to believe that a vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this section, the police officer shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility approved by the chief of police. This section shall not apply if the vehicle used in the violation was stolen at that time and verified proof of the theft is provided to the Village. 
2.  The police officer shall notify any person identifying himself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, if there is such a person, of the fact of the seizure and of the vehicle owner or lessee's right to request an administrative hearing to be conducted under this section. 
D.  Administrative Hearing. Within ten business days after a vehicle is seized and impounded pursuant to this section, the village shall notify the owner of record or lessee and any lien holder by first class U.S. mail or personal service to the addresses registered with the Secretary of State, of the owner's, lessee's, and any lien holder's right to request a hearing to challenge whether a violation of this section has occurred. The owner of record, lessee or any lien holder seeking a hearing must file a written request for a hearing with the chief of police or his designee no later than ten business days after notice was mailed. If a request for a hearing is filed, the city shall notify by first class mail or personal service, the owner of record or lessee and any lien holder of the date, time and location of the administrative hearing. The hearing date must be no more than fifteen business days after a request for a hearing has been filed. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of evidence that the vehicle was used in violation of this section, then the hearing officer shall enter an order finding the owner of record or lessee of the vehicle civilly liable to the village for the administrative penalty of five hundred dollars. If, after a hearing, the hearing officer does not determine by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was used in such a violation, the hearing officer shall enter an order finding for the owner or lessee and for the return of the vehicle. If the owner of record or lessee requests a hearing but fails to appear at the hearing or fails to request a hearing in a timely manner, the owner of record or lessee shall be deemed to have waived his or her right to a hearing and the hearing officer shall enter a default order in favor of the village in the amount of the administrative penalty. However, if the owner of record or lessee pays such penalty and the vehicle is returned to the owner or lessee, no default order need be entered if the owner or lessee is informed of his or her right to a hearing and signs a written waiver, in which case an order of liability shall be deemed to have been made when the village receives the written waiver. All orders entered by the hearing officer shall be in writing. 
E.  Disposition of Impounded Vehicle. A penalty imposed pursuant to this section shall constitute a debt due and owing the village. A vehicle impounded pursuant to this section shall remain impounded until: 
1.  The penalty of five hundred dollars is paid to the village and all applicable towing fees are paid to the towing agent, in which case the person who paid the penalty shall be given possession of the vehicle, 
2.  A bond in the amount of five hundred dollars is posted with the police department and all applicable towing fees are paid to the towing agent, at which time the vehicle will be released to the person who posted the bond, or 
3.  The vehicle is deemed abandoned or unclaimed as provided in subsection G below, in which case the vehicle shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of abandoned vehicles. 
F.  Posting of Bond. If a bond in the amount of five hundred dollars is posted with the police department, the impounded vehicle shall be released to the owner or lessee of record or any lien holder; the owner or lessee of the vehicle shall still be liable to the towing agent for any applicable towing fees. If a five hundred dollar penalty is imposed for violation of this section, the five hundred dollar bond will be forfeited to the village; however if a violation of this section is not proven by a preponderance of the evidence, the five hundred dollar bond will be returned to the person posting the bond. All bond money posted pursuant to this section shall be held by the village until the hearing officer issues a decision, or, if there is a judicial review, until the court issues its decision. 
G.  Vehicle Possession. Any motor vehicle that is not reclaimed within thirty-five days after the expiration of the time during which the owner of record or lessee may seek judicial review of the village's action under this section, or the time at which a final judgment is rendered in favor of the village, or the time a final administrative decision is rendered against an owner of record or lessee who is in default, may be disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle as provided by law, provided, however, that where proceedings have been instituted under state or federal drug asset forfeiture laws, the subject vehicle may not be disposed of by the village except as consistent with those proceedings. 
H.  Any owner of record, lessee, lien holder or other person with a legal interest in the motor vehicle, shall have the right to appeal the decision of the hearing officer to the Circuit Court for the First Judicial Circuit, Cook County, Illinois, pursuant to the Administrative Review Act, 735 ILCS 5/3-101, et seq., as amended. Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any fine, penalty, or administrative fee imposed under this chapter which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of the deadline for seeking judicial review under the Administrative Review Act may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 4294 § 1, 2007: Ord. 4276 § 2, 2007) 
(Ord. No. 4707, § 2, 7-16-2012) 
9.40.020 - Tow rotation list. 
A.  Pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/4-203.5, the chief of police shall be authorized to establish a tow rotation list in the village. The chief of police shall create an application to be placed on the tow rotation list and include the requirements for all potential towing vendors which contain, at minimum, the requirements of 625 ILCS 5/4-203.5. The chief of police shall evaluate the applications on an annual basis and determine whether the applicants are qualified and whether any changes should be made to the tow rotation list. The chief of police may choose to have only one towing service on its tow rotation list. Complaints regarding the process for inclusion on a tow rotation list or the use of a tow rotation list may be referred in writing to the chief of police. The chief of police shall make the final determination as to which qualified towing services shall be included on a tow rotation list, 
B.  Use of Tow Rotation List. Whenever a Wheeling police officer initiates a tow of a vehicle, the officer shall contact the Wheeling Police Dispatch and indicate that a tow has been authorized. If more than one towing service is on the tow rotation list, the police department shall then select a towing service from tow rotation list corresponding to the geographical area where the tow was authorized, and shall contact that towing service directly by phone, computer, or similar means. Towing services shall be contacted in the order listed on the appropriate tow rotation list, at which point the towing service shall be placed at the end of that tow rotation list. In the event a listed towing service is not available, the next listed towing service on that tow rotation list shall be contacted. 
C.  Deviations. 
1.  The Wheeling Police Department may decide to deviate from the list if the next towing service is incapable or not properly qualified to handle a specific task or does not have the specific equipment or in the event of an emergency. A deviation from the tow rotation order for this reason shall not cause a loss of rotation turn by the towing service determined to be incapable or not properly equipped for handling the request. 
2.  In the event of an emergency, the Wheeling Police Department, taking into account the safety and location of the situation, may deviate from the order of the tow rotation list and obtain towing service from any source deemed appropriate. 
D.  In addition, if the owner or operator of a disabled vehicle is not under arrest and does not abandon his vehicle, and the vehicle is not impeding or obstructing traffic, illegally parked or poses a security or safety risk, as determined by the officer, the officer shall allow the owner to select a towing service. If the owner chooses not to specify a towing service, the law enforcement agency shall select a towing service for the vehicle as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
E.  If a tow operator is present or arrives where a tow is needed and has not been requested by the agency, it shall be instructed to leave by law enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4976, § B, 12-21-2015) 
Chapter 9.42 - ORDINANCE ENFORCEMENT THROUGH ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF VEHICULAR REGULATION AND AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM VIOLATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4571, passed Dec. 13, 2010, repealed Ch. 9.42 in its entirety and added a new Ch. 9.42 to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 9.42 derived from Ord. 4417, passed April 20, 2009. 

9.42.010 - Purpose. 
1.  The stated purpose of this section is to provide for the fair and efficient enforcement of municipal regulations through the administrative adjudication of automated traffic law violations and violations of village ordinances regulating the standing and parking of vehicles, the condition and use of vehicle equipment and the display of vehicle licenses or stickers within the village borders, and establishing a schedule of uniform fines and penalties, and authority and procedures for collection of unpaid fines and penalties. 
2.  For purposes of this section: 
(a)  "Vehicle compliance violation" means the violation of any regulation governing the condition or use of equipment on a vehicle or governing the display of village licenses or stickers. 
(b)  "Automated traffic law enforcement system" means either a device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a red light signal in violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar provision of this Chapter, or a device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with the visual signals on a school bus, as specified in Sections 12-803 and 12-805 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, to produce recorded images of motor vehicles that fail to stop before meeting or overtaking, from either direction, any school bus stopped at any location for the purpose of receiving or discharge pupils in violation of Section 11-1414 of the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar provision of this Chapter. 
(c)  "Automated traffic law violation" means a motor vehicle entering an intersection against a red signal indication in violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-306), or similar Village Code provision, as described in Section 11-208.6 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-208.6), or a motor vehicle failing to stop before meeting or overtaking a school bus stopped at any location for the purpose of receiving or discharge pupils in violation of Section 11-1414 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-1414, or similar Village Code provision, as described in Section 11-208.9 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-208.9). However, no automated traffic law violation shall exist where a motor vehicle comes to a complete stop and does not enter the intersection, as defined by Section 1-132 of the Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-132), during the cycle of the red signal indication unless one or more pedestrians or bicyclists are present, even if the motor vehicle stops at a point past a stop line or crosswalk where a driver is required to stop, as specified in subsection (c) of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(d)  "Certified report" means a report concerning five or more unpaid fines or penalties for automated traffic law violations made by the village to the secretary in accordance with Section 6-306.5 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(e)  "Determination notice" means a notice of final determination of an automated traffic law violation liability issued pursuant to Section 11-208.3, 11-208.6, or 11-208.9 of the Vehicle Code and pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter.
