    Notice: Upon determination by the director of public works, that a tree is infected, infested or otherwise a public nuisance as prohibited under this Chapter, the director of public works shall give written notice to the owner of the property of the existence of such infected, infested or otherwise diseased tree described in this Chapter and to require the removal and lawful disposal of such nuisance tree within thirty days following such notice. Notice shall be served on the owner of the property via personal service on the owner or by U.S. Mail, first class delivery and certified mail. Unless otherwise known, the owner of the property shall be presumed to be the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities. This notice shall identify the property, a description of the infected or infested tree or trees, a brief summary of the requirements of this Chapter, and a request that such tree or trees be removed. In addition, this notice shall explain that the village shall be entitled to enter on the property and remove the affected tree or trees in the event the property owner fails to do so within thirty days of such notice and that any such removal costs will be charged to the owner and constitute a lien on the property. 
(Ord. No. 4629, § A, 9-6-2011) 
12.12.050 - Owner's responsibility to remove and legally dispose of diseased and infested trees. 
    The owner of the parcel of land on which such infected, infested, diseased, dead and/or dying tree exists shall remove such nuisance and shall cause the same to be disposed of legally, according to the regulations set by Illinois Department of Agriculture within thirty days of notification to such property owner. 
(Ord. No. 4629, § A, 9-6-2011) 
12.12.060 - Summary abatement authorized. 
    Abatement: If any person served with a notice as provided in this Chapter refuses or neglects to remove the nuisance tree or abate the condition in violation of this Chapter within thirty days of the date that such notice is served, then the director of public works and any person(s) directed to remove said nuisance on behalf of the village may enter in or upon the property where the nuisance is located and remove same. The cost and expense of such removal shall be charged to and paid by the owner of the property within thirty days after an invoice containing the information below. This notice may be personally served on the property owner or sent via U.S. Mail, first class delivery and certified mail. 
1.  Identify the property, by common description; 
2.  A description of the requirements of this Chapter, including the prohibition on nuisance trees; 
3.  A description of the removal activity rendered; 
4.  The amount of the cost and expense incurred or payable for the removal activity; 
5.  The date or dates when such cost or expense was incurred by the Village; and 
6.  Payment to be made within thirty days of the notice or a lien may be recorded against the property. 
(Ord. No. 4629, § A, 9-6-2011) 
12.12.065 - Liens. 
    If a nuisance described in this Chapter is removed by the village, or person(s) directed to remove said nuisance on behalf of the village, and the invoice remains unpaid after the thirty-day period, a notice of lien containing the cost and expense of removal incurred by the village may be recorded in the following manner: the village shall file a notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds in the county in which said real estate is located or in the office of the registrar of titles of such county, if applicable. The lien notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
1.  A description of the property; 
2.  The amount of the removal cost; and 
3.  The date or dates when such cost or expense was incurred by the village. 
(Ord. No. 4629, § A, 9-6-2011) 
12.12.070 - Release of lien. 
    Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner or persons interested in the affected property, after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release may be filed of record in the same manner provided for the filing of a notice of lien. 
(Ord. No. 4629, § A, 9-6-2011) 
12.12.080 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall be fined an amount not less than two hundred fifty dollars and not more than one thousand dollars for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each day during or on which a diseased or infested tree is permitted to remain on the property after thirty days from service of notice. 
(Ord. No. 4629, § A, 9-6-2011) 
Chapter 12.16 - BARBERRY BUSHES 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Planting prohibited. 
    It shall be a nuisance and unlawful to plant or permit the growth of the bush of the species of tall, common or European barberry, further known as Barberis Vulgaris, or its horticultural varieties within the village. (1956 Code § 421) 
12.16.020 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04 of this code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 799 § A (part); March 1, 1965) 
Chapter 12.17 - BUCKTHORN TREE AND BUSHES 
Sections: 

12.17.010 - Planting prohibited. 
    It shall be a nuisance and unlawful to plant or permit the growth of the tree or bush of the species of common or glossy Buckthorn, further known as Rhamnus cathartica or Rhamnus frangula, or any of their horticultural varieties within the village. 
(Ord. 3802 § 3, 2003) 
12.17.020 - Right of entry. 
    The officers, agents, servants, and employees of the village are hereby authorized and directed to enter on and upon private property, upon first giving notice to the owner or occupants, for the purpose of inspecting the property and detecting the presence of Buckthorn trees. 
(Ord. 3802 § 4, 2003) 
12.17.030 - Notice to remove or control tree-Required action. 
    The village manager, or representative, shall give to the owner of the premises where any public nuisance described in this section shall be found, a written notice of the existence of such nuisance, which notice shall require the owner to take action to cause the removal and disposal or other necessary horticultural control of the same within thirty days following such notice, such removal and disposal to be under the direction, approval and general supervision of the village manager. The notice shall also notify the owner that unless such nuisance is removed and disposed of or otherwise controlled in compliance with the terms thereof within such thirty day period, the owner may become subject to a fine for failure to compliance, and, further, that the village may proceed with the removal and disposal of such nuisance, and assess the owner a sum equal to the cost of such removal and disposal to the village. 
(Ord. 3802 § 5, 2003) 
12.17.040 - Owner's responsibility to remove and legally dispose of tree. 
    The owner, occupant, or agent of the parcel of land on which such Buckthorn tree exists shall forthwith remove such tree and shall cause the same to be disposed of legally or otherwise controlled within thirty days of notification to such owner, occupant, or agent. 
(Ord. 3802 § 6, 2003) 
12.17.050 - Procedure upon failure to abate. 
    In all cases where the owner, occupant, or agent of the parcel of land on which such Buckthorn tree is located cannot be found, or if found and notified neglects or refuses to abate such nuisance, it shall be lawful for the village to abate the same by the removal or other control of such tree, and in that event the owner, occupant, or agent or any of them shall be charged with those expenses which may be incurred by the village in the removal or abatement and legal disposal of the tree as aforesaid, which expense shall be collected by the village by suit or otherwise in addition to the fine or penalty provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3802 § 7, 2003) 
12.17.060 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04 of this Code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 3802 § 8, 2003) 
Chapter 12.20 - ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE WEEDS, GRASS, BUSHES, TREES AND OTHER VEGETATION* 
Sections: 

12.20.000 - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall govern the maintenance of grass, weeds, trees, bushes and other vegetation located in the village. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.010 - Definitions. 
    "Director" means the director of community development or his or her designee. 
    "Noxious weed" means any plant which is determined by the Dean of the College of Agriculture of the University of Illinois and the Director of the Agricultural Experiment Station at the University of Illinois, to be injurious to the public health, crops, livestock, land or other property pursuant to the Illinois Noxious Weed Law, 505 ILCS 100/1 et seq. and identified in Title 8, Part 220, Section 220.60 of the Illinois Administrative Code. As of the effective date of the amendment to this chapter, the following plants have been designated and declared noxious weeds pursuant to the Illinois Noxious Weed Law: Marihuana (Cannabis sativa L.); Giant ragweed (Ambrosia trifida L.); Common ragweed (Ambrosia artemisiifolia L.); Canada Thistle (Cirsium arvense); Perennial Sowthistle (Sonchus arvensis); Musk thistle (Carduus nutans); Perennial members of the sorghum genus, including johnsongrass (Sorghum halepense), sorghum almum, and other johnsongrass X sorghum crosses with rhizomes; and Kudzu (Pueraria labata). 
    "Nuisance weed" shall include any plant declared by the director to be a nuisance weed, and shall include the following: Barnyard grass (Echinochloa crusgalli); Black medic (Medicago lupulina); Black mustard (Brassica nigra); Bull thistle (Cirsium vulgare); Canada blue grass (Poa compressa); Charlock, wild mustard (Brassica kaber); Chicory (Cichorium intybus); Cocklebur (Xanthium strumarium); Common burdock (Arcticum minus); Common dandelion (Taraxacum officinale); Common teasel, Fuller's teasel (Dipsacus sylvestris Huds.); Common wood sorrel (Oxalis stricta); Corn speedwell (Veronica arvensis); Creeping amaranth (Amaranthus graecizanus); Crowfoot grass, yard grass (Eleusine indica); Curly dock (Rurnex crispus); Cut-leaved teasel (Dipsacus laciniatus); Dead nettle, henbit (Lamium amplexicaule); Eyebane, Nodding spurge (Euphorbia maculata); Field nut sedge (Cyperus esculentus); Field sorrel (Rumex acetosella); Garlic mustard (Alliaria petiolata); Giant foxtail (Setaria faberi); Hairy crab grass (Digitaria sanguinalis); Lamb's quarters (Chenopodium album); Leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula); Meadow fescue (Festuca pratensis); Nimbleweed (Muhlenbergia schreberi); Nodding chickweed (Cerastium nutans); Orchard grass (Dactylis glomerata); Ox-eye daisy (Chrysanthemum leaucanthemum); Poison hemlock (Conium maculatum); Poison Ivy (Rhus radicans); Prickly lettuce (Lactuca serriola); Purslane speedwell (Veronica peregrina); Quack grass (Agropyron repens); Reed canary grass (Phalaris arundinacea); Redtop (Agrostis alba, L.); Rough amaranth (Amaranthus retroflexus); Shepard's purse (Capsella bursa-pastoris); Smooth crab grass (Digitaria ischaemum); Spiny sow thistle (Sonchus asper); Spotted creeping spurge (Euphorbia supina); Store-front sow thistle (Sonchus oleraceus); Tall nettle (Urtica procera); Velvetleaf, Butterpint (Abutilon thoephrasti); Western ragweed (Ambrosia psilostachya); Wild carrot, Queen Anne's lace (Daucus carota); Yarrow, Milfoil (Achillea millefolium); Yellow foxtail (Setaria glauca). 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.020 - Public nuisance-Noxious weeds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of real estate in the village to permit the growth of any noxious weeds on such property. Any such noxious weed growth on real estate in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance as endangering the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.025 - Public nuisance-Improperly maintained vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of real estate in the village to permit dead, overgrown and improperly maintained vegetation to remain on such property. Any vegetation, including, but not limited to, trees, bushes, grass, flowers and other plants that are found to be improperly maintained, overgrown or dead is hereby declared to be a nuisance as endangering the health, safety and welfare of the public as well as a threat to diminish the value of surrounding property. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.030 - Maximum height of grass and other plants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of real estate in the village to permit any grass or plants, including nuisance weeds, other than trees, bushes, flowers, agricultural or other ornamental plants, to grow to a height exceeding eight inches on such property. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.035 - Bushes and trees and other overgrown vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of real estate in the village to permit the overgrowth of vegetation on any such property in such a manner as to cause a detriment to neighboring properties or property values, or to cause a hazardous condition to pedestrian and/or vehicular traffic, or likely to harbor mosquitoes, rodents or other vermin or in such a manner as to constitute a public nuisance as endangering the health, safety and welfare of the public. Nothing in this section shall cause any vegetation to be maintained and/or trimmed in a manner to the detriment of the species natural habit. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.036 - Dead vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of real estate in the village to permit to remain on such property any dead trees, dead bushes, dead weeds, or other dead vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.037 - Landscape vegetation. 
    Every owner of real estate is required to maintain his or her landscape vegetation on such property in a manner consistent with the property maintenance requirements of the village code. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.040 - Procedure for filing lien for abatement costs. 
    If any weeds, grass, bushes, trees or other vegetation prohibited by this chapter or other relevant provisions of the village code are cut and removed by the village or by someone directed to cut and remove them on behalf of the village, a notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred by the village shall be recorded in the following manner. The village or the person performing the service by authority of the village, in its or his own name, may file notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds in the county in which said real estate is located or in the office of the registrar of titles of such county if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens System. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and 
(3)  The date or dates when said cost and expense was incurred by the village, and shall be filed within sixty days the cost and expense is incurred. 
    Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and a release shall be filed and recorded in the same manner as filing notice of the said lien. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.050 - Notice to abate. 
    In the event of any violation of this chapter, the director of community development, or his or her designee, shall notify, in writing, such owner to cut, destroy, or remove such growth, objects or conditions prohibited by this chapter or other relevant provision of the village code. Notice shall be given to the owner of the property on which the prohibited nuisance weeds, grass, bushes, trees or other vegetation exist. For purposes of this section, the person to whom the last general tax bill on the property was sent shall be presumed to be the owner. Notice to abate a violation of this chapter shall be given in writing to the property owner and shall state a specified period of time for abatement by the property owner. Where a property owner cannot be found, or otherwise served by notice or by mail, then alternatively, notice to abate a violation of this chapter may be given by posting a sign in a conspicuous manner on the front entrance of the property. If there is no structure on the property, a sign may be posted anywhere on the premises. The notice shall state that unless such nuisance is abated or removed by a specific date, the village will cause it to be abated or removed, the cost thereof will be charged to the owner, and that such cost shall be a lien upon the real estate where the nuisance was abated or removed. Such notice shall also state that the failure of such owner to abate the nuisance as required by such notice shall be deemed an implied consent for the village to abate or remove such nuisance. If such owner fails to abate any nuisance within the time limit specified in such notice, the village may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the expense of the abatement as to each particular lot or tract, and such expense shall be charged and paid by such owner. The text of the notice shall contain a reference to the provision of this code violated and may contain such other information respecting the nature of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
12.20.060 - Abatement notice and proceeding. 
    The director of community development or his or her designee shall notify, by First Class U.S. Mail, any property owner who violates any provision of this chapter to abate such violation or violations existing on the property. If the property owner fails to abate said violation on his or her property within seven calendar days from such notice or other time period as determined by the director of community development necessary to abate the violation, the director of community development may order the abatement of the violation. Any cost incurred by the village in abating such violation shall be charged against the real estate upon which the violation is located and there shall be a lien upon such real estate. 
(Ord. No. 4453, § A, 9-14-2009) 
Title 13 - WATER AND SEWERS 
Chapter 13.01 - DEFINITIONS 

13.01.010 - Administrator. 
    "Administrator" means the Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.020 - Approving authority. 
    "Approving authority" means the director of the community development department. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.030 - Basic user charge. 
    "Basic user charge" means the basic assessment for water, sewer, and storm sewer service. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 5179, § A, 5-21-2018) 
13.01.040 - Biochemical oxygen demand. 
    "Biochemical oxygen demand" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at twenty degrees Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.050 - Building drain. 
    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning five feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.060 - Building sewer. 
    "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.070 - Capital improvement charge. 
    "Capital improvement charge" means the charge levied on users to improve, extend or reconstruct the sewage treatment works. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.080 - Combined sewer. 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, storm, surface and groundwater drainage. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.090 - Commercial user. 
    "Commercial user" includes transit lodging, retail and wholesale establishments or places engaged in selling merchandise, or rendering service. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.100 - Control manhole. 
    "Control manhole" means a structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to provide access for the village representative to sample and/or measure discharges. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.110 - Debt service charge. 
    "Debt service charge" shall be the amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal and coverage of (loan, bond, etc.) outstanding. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.120 - Director. 
    "Director" means the Director of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.130 - Dwelling unit. 
    "Dwelling unit" means a structure or portion thereof designed and built as a complete, self-sufficient living facility for one family, including permanent provisions for sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. Units in a hotel or motel are not to be counted as dwelling units. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.140 - Easement. 
    "Easement" means an acquired legal right for the specific use of the land owned by others. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.150 - Effluent criteria. 
    "Effluent criteria" shall be defined in any applicable NPDES Permit. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.160 - Federal Act. 
    "Federal Act" means the Federal Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 455 et seq.) as amended, (Pub. L. 95-217). 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.170 - Federal grant. 
    "Federal grant" means the U.S. government participation in the financing of the construction of treatment work as provided for by Title II-Grants for Construction of Treatment Works of the Act and implementing regulations. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.180 - Floatable oil. 
    "Floatable oil" means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.190 - Garbage. 
    "Garbage" means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of food. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.200 - Industrial users. 
    "Industrial users" includes establishments engaged in manufacturing activities involving the mechanical or chemical transformation of materials of substance into products. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.210 - Industrial waste. 
    "Industrial waste" means any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.220 - Institutional/governmental user. 
    "Institutional/governmental user" includes schools, churches, penal institutions, and users associated with federal, state, and local governments. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.230 - Local capital cost charge. 
    "Local capital cost charge" means charges for costs other than the operation, maintenance and replacement costs, i.e. debt service and capital improvement costs. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.240 - Major contributing industry. 
    "Major contributing industry" means an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: 
(a)  Has a flow of fifty thousand gallons or more per average work day; or 
(b)  Has a flow greater than ten percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste; or 
(c)  Has in its waste, a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under Section 307 (a) of the Federal Act; or 
(d)  Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.250 - Milligrams per liter. 
    "Milligrams per liter" means a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001 g of the constituent in 1,000 ml of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analyses. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.255 - Minimum. 
    "Minimum" means the basic assessment for water, sewer, and storm sewer service that is imposed on a "user", as defined herein, for each building or similar structure that is connected to the water main, sewer, or storm sewer. 
(Ord. No. 5179, § B, 5-21-2018) 
13.01.260 - Natural outlet. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.270 - NPDES permit. 
    "NPDES permit" means any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the administrator, or, where appropriated by the Director, after enactment of the Federal Clean Water Act to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to Section 402 of the Federal Act. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.280 - Ordinance. 
    "Ordinance" means this Title 13 of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.290 - Person. 
    "Person" means any and all persons, natural or artificial including any individual, firm, company, municipal, or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.300 - pH. 
    "pH" means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.310 - Plumbing. 
    "Plumbing" means the actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension of a plumbing system. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes from the source of a private water supply on the premises from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to and within any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work or assemble. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a building drain and a sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewerage disposal system five feet beyond the foundation walls. Plumbing does not mean or include the trade of sprinkler fittings for fire protection, the trade of drain-laying, the trade of drilling water wells, which constitutes the sources of private water supplies, and of making connections between such wells and pumping units in the water supply systems of buildings served by such private water supplies, or the business of installing water softening equipment and of maintaining and servicing the same, or the business of manufacturing or selling plumbing fixtures, appliances, equipment or hardware, or to the installation and servicing of electrical equipment sold by a not-for-profit corporation providing electrification on a cooperative basis, that either on or before January l, 1971, is or has been financed in whole or in part under the Federal Rural Electrification Act of 1936 and the Acts amendatory thereof and supplementary thereto, to its members for use on farms owned by individuals or operated by individual, nor does it mean or include minor repairs which do not require changes in the piping to or from plumbing fixtures or involve the removal, replacement, installation or reinstallation of any pipe or plumbing fixtures. Plumbing also includes the installation, repair and maintenance of interceptors installed in a plumbing system on the outside of a building to a point five feet beyond the outlet of the interceptor. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.320 - Population equivalent. 
    "Population equivalent" shall be a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.330 - Properly shredded garbage. 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.340 - ppm. 
    "ppm" means parts per million by weight. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.350 - Pretreatment. 
    "Pretreatment" means the treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into the wastewater treatment works. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.360 - Public sewer. 
    "Public sewer" means a sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the village. It also includes sewers within or outside the village boundaries that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the village sanitary (or combined sewer system), even though those sewers may not have been constructed with village funds. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.370 - Residential user. 
    "Residential user" means all the dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes, apartments, permanent multifamily dwellings. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.380 - Replacement. 
    "Replacement" means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.390 - Sanitary sewer. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which storm, surface, and groundwaters or polluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.400 - Sewer. 
    "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids, including stormwater, surfacewater and groundwater drainage. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.410 - Sewerage. 
    "Sewerage" means the spent water of the community and is used interchangeably with wastewater. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.420 - Sewer fund. 
    "Sewer fund" means the principal accounting designation for all revenues received in the operation of the sewerage system. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.430 - Slug. 
    "Slug" means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen minutes more than five times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.440 - State Act. 
    "State Act" means the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.450 - State grant. 
    "State grant" means the state of Illinois participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act and for making such grants as filed with the Secretary of State of Illinois. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.460 - Storm sewer. 
    "Storm sewer" means a sewer that carries storm, surface and groundwater drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.470 - Stormwater runoff. 
    "Stormwater runoff" means that portion of the precipitation that is drained into the sewers. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.480 - Surcharge. 
    "Surcharge" means the assessment in addition to the basic user charge and debt service charge which is levied on those persons whose wastes are greater in strength than the concentration values established in Chapter 00, Article III. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.490 - Suspended solids. 
    "Suspended solids" (SS) means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.500 - Unpolluted water. 
    "Unpolluted water" means water quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.510 - Useful life. 
    "Useful life" means the estimated period during which the collection system and/or treatment works will be operated. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.520 - User charge. 
    "User charge" means a charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.530 - User. 
    "User" means and includes all types of users including "residential user," "institutional/governmental user," "commercial user," or "industrial users," as defined herein, and each building or similar structure that is connected to the water main, sewer, or storm sewer. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 5179, § C, 5-21-2018) 
13.01.540 - Village. 
    "Village" means the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.550 - Wastewater. 
    "Wastewater" means the spent water of a community. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.560 - Wastewater facilities. 
    "Wastewater facilities" means the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.570 - Wastewater service charge. 
    "Wastewater service charge" shall be the charge per quarter or month levied on all users of the wastewater facilities. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in Section 13.08.080 and shall consist of the total of the basic user charge, the local capital cost and a surcharge, if applicable. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.580 - Wastewater treatment works. 
    "Wastewater treatment works" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "pollution control plant." 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.590 - Watercourse. 
    "Watercourse" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
13.01.600 - Water quality standards. 
    "Water quality standards" are defined in the Water Pollution Regulations of Illinois. 
(Ord. 2275 § A (part), 1986) 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER CONNECTIONS AND USE* 

13.04.010 - Persons authorized to turn on. 
    No water from the municipal water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person but the director of finance, or some other person authorized by him to perform this service. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.020 - Application for turn on. 
    Application to have water turned on shall be made in writing to the director of finance and shall contain an agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this Chapter as conditions governing the use of the municipal water supply by the applicant. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.030 - Deposit for service. 
(a)  Whenever a person, firm or corporation enters into a lease under the terms of which the lessee is responsible to pay for water used on the premises, the lessee shall, at the time of application, make a deposit with the village as herein provided. Such deposit shall be retained by the municipality to ensure the payment of all bills for water service. When service to the applicant is discontinued permanently, this deposit, less any amount still owed the village, shall be refunded, without interest. 
(b)  The deposit for residential and commercial users shall be one hundred dollars. A credit application shall be completed by residential users and the application shall include the applicant's social security number, employer information and driver's license number. 
(c)  The deposit for industrial users shall be two hundred dollars. 
(d)  The director of finance shall retain the right to increase the amount of the deposit required for any water user to an amount equal to the average bill for three months of water service during the prior twelve-month period. A factor that the director of finance may consider in requiring an increased deposit is the number of delinquent payments made by the water user during the prior twelve-month period. 
(Ord. 3750 § 1, 2003: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.035 - Final billing. 
(a)  Every owner of a property being serviced from the village water supply shall give thirty days prior written notice to the village of their intent to transfer ownership of such property. 
(b)  Every applicant who is a tenant of a property being serviced from the village water supply shall give thirty days prior written notice to the village of an intent to discontinue service from the village. 
(c)  In the event that a final reading cannot be obtained, usage will be prorated based on the date of the transfer of ownership. 
(Ord. 2780 § A, 1992: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.040 - Plumbing compliance. 
    No water shall be turned on for service to premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the ordinances of the village; provided, that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.050 - Connection required. 
(a)  Every building, structure or dwelling unit henceforth erected for human habitation, occupancy or use shall be provided with plumbing facilities complying with all applicable requirements of this code. 
(b)  When a water main is laid in any street or any easement, all buildings on property which abuts such street or easement shall connect with the water main. This subsection shall not apply to any property forcibly annexed to the village after December 1, 2003. 
(c)  All vaults or cisterns used on such premises shall be discontinued and shall be filled with sand or limestone screening within thirty days of connection to the respective service. 
(d)  Any existing private well on the property shall be abandoned and sealed by a licensed well driller within thirty days after connecting into the village water main in accordance with the Illinois State Department of Natural Resources Rules and Regulations. On property forcibly annexed to the village after December 1, 2003, existing private wells may, however, be maintained for purposes of outside irrigation only. There shall be no interconnection or cross-connection at any point on the property between the private well and the village water service to the property. All property owners desiring to maintain an existing well after connection to the village water main must supply to the village within thirty days after connecting into the village water main, certification from a licensed plumber that no such interconnection or cross-connection exists as well as as-built plans for the disconnection of the private well from the interior of the building and the connection to the village water main. 
(e)  No new wells will be allowed on property serviced by a connection to the system. 
(Ord. 3965 § 1, 2005: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.060 - Permit and notice for connections. 
    No connections to a water main shall be made without a permit issued by the director of community development. Twenty-four hours notice shall be given to the director of community development prior to any connection. Such notice shall be made by applicant, approved by the director of community development. All such connections shall be made under the supervision of the director, and no connections shall be covered until the work has been inspected by him or his designee. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.070 - Water connection charge. 
    There is established a water connection charge which shall be based on the size and the number of the water meters serving each building or other type of structure in the village for all industrial, commercial, institutional or governmental and residential users with the exception of multiple-family dwellings. The water connection charge shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. This water connection charge shall be paid by the owner of the property. 
    Multiple-family dwellings shall pay a water connection charge per dwelling unit as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. 
    The director of community development shall make the final decision on the size or the number of water meters required in accordance with accepted engineering practices. 
(Ord. 4131 § P, 2006: Ord. 3876 § C, 2004: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 1, 6-2-2014) 
13.04.080 - Permits issued to licensed plumbers. 
    No permit to connect with any of the mains or service pipes, or to install or alter any plumbing fixtures, shall be issued to any person unless such person is a duly licensed and bonded plumber, who shall have filed a bond as otherwise provided by ordinance before making any connection with the village water supply system. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.090 - Resale of water. 
    No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the municipal supply to any premises other than that which application has been made for and the meter installed, except in cases of emergency. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.100 - Tampering with system-Inspection. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person not authorized by the village to tamper with, alter or damage any part of the municipal waterworks or system, or any meter. Whenever any meter installed in any premises has been damaged, altered or tampered with, the cost of replacement and/or repairing such meter shall be charged to the person and the premises responsible for the payment of water recorded by said meter, and such sums shall become a part of the bill for water service. Nonpayment thereof shall be subject to the provisions of Sections 13.04.230, 13.04.240 and 13.04.250. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person not authorized by the director of community development to attach any form of pump directly to any water line, water main or water service pipe for the purpose of increasing the water pressure or to maintain an interconnection or cross-connection between the village water main and any private well on the property. The director of community development is authorized at any reasonable hour to inspect any water line, water service pipe, or water main on the premises or within the residence of any person for the purposes of determining compliance with this Chapter. 
(c)  If any person allows damage to occur either intentionally, through negligence, or in any other fashion to any water meter or portion of village's water supply system, it shall be said person's and the property owner's responsibility to contact the village for an inspection. Pursuant to said inspection, the village may recommend that the respective water meters, remote reader or any other portion of the municipal waterworks or system be replaced or repaired and such repair or replacement shall be at the property owner's or person's causing the damage expense. For purposes of this section, a meter with a broken seal or a frozen meter shall be deemed to be a damaged meter. 
(Ord. 3965 § 2, 2005; Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 2, 6-2-2014) 
13.04.110 - Fire hydrants. 
    No person shall tamper with any fire hydrant nor shall any person take water from any fire plug, hydrant, valve, faucet or pipe, or any other opening connected with the water system of the village, except where such person has made application for the use of water for such purpose and has received permission from the director of community development or the fire chief. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.120 - Installation supervision. 
    All water service pipes from the buffalo box to the premises to be served shall be installed by the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. The installation shall be the responsibility of, and paid for by, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. Such installation shall be under the supervision of the director of community development. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 3, 6-2-2014) 
13.04.130 - Water service specifications. 
    No water service shall be installed unless it conforms to the specifications of the village. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.140 - Responsibility/authority to repair. 
(a)  All water service pipes and plumbing systems of buildings are the property of the owner of the premises served and all repairs thereto shall be the responsibility of the owner. The village shall own and be responsible for the maintenance of the buffalo box and water meter except as provided in Section 13.04.100 and Section 13.04.180. 
(b)  The village may, in case of emergency, repair any water service pipe and, if this is done the cost of such repair work shall be paid to the village by the owner of the premises served. 
(c)  No claims shall be made against the village by reason of breaking of any of the water service pipes or apparatus, or from any other damage that may result from shutting off water for repairing, or for any other purpose or for any variation in pressure. No reduction will be made from the regular rates as billed on account of leaking pipes or fixtures. Leaks in the water service pipe between the buffalo box and the water meter shall be repaired by the property owner at his expense, and if not repaired within three days after receiving notice from the village, the water shall be shut off until the repair is made. if, in the opinion of the village, the leak is of sufficient size, the village may forthwith shut off the service until the repair is made. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 4, 6-2-2014) 
13.04.150 - Permit required for excavations. 
(a)  Excavations for installing water services or repairing the same shall be made in compliance with the ordinance provisions relating to making excavations in streets; provided, that it is unlawful to place any water service in the same excavation with, or directly over, any drain or sewer pipe. 
(b)  No person shall uncover or excavate under or around any water main, water meter or service line of the village for any purpose whatever without a written permit as provided in this Chapter, and no person shall under any circumstances cut into or break any pavement, in and about the laying or repairing of water pipes without a permit therefor granted by the village. The right is reserved by the village to deny such permit, and to require, instead, that such pavement be tunneled, under the supervision of the village. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.160 - Service cocks and shut-off boxes. 
(a)  All service cocks or ferrules must be inserted at or near the top of the street main, and in any case not nearer the bell of the pipe than six inches. The size of such cocks to be inserted shall be that specified in the permit. 
(b)  Shut-off boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every service pipe, and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located that they are easily accessible and shall be protected from frost. 
(c)  All service lines two inches or less in diameter leading from the water main shall be Type K copper tubing; larger sizes shall be ductile iron, unless otherwise specially permitted. Shut-off boxes shall be of a standard type approved by the village engineer. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.170 - Meter required-Installation charges. 
    All premises using water from the municipal water supply must be equipped with a remote reading meter installed by the village; provided, that such water service may be supplied by the village at a flat rate charge until such meter is installed therein as provided in this section on application made for such water service, or no water shall be furnished such premises. The charge to the applicant for the water meter and remote reading devices to be installed shall be retail cost of the meter plus thirty percent. Compound water meters may be required at the option of the village engineer and shall be based on the cost of the meter plus thirty percent. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 5, 6-2-2014) 
13.04.180 - Meter location and inspection. 
(a)  Meters shall be installed in a location that will be easily accessible and protected from frost, and other dangers and damage and the owner or person in charge shall at all times permit any duly authorized village employee free entry for the purpose of examining, testing, reading or repairing such meter and appurtenant installations. Failure to permit a duly authorized village employee entry to the premises for the purpose of installing, examining, testing, reading or repairing such meter and appurtenant installations shall result in disconnection and a notice of disconnection will be sent and shall follow the procedures for nonpayment set forth in Section 13.04.230, including a right to a hearing set forth in Section 13.04.240. Meters heretofore installed in inaccessible locations shall be moved at the expense of the owner of the premises. All owners and occupants shall, at their own expense, keep all water meters in good repair and properly protected from frost and other dangers and shall be responsible for the cost of replacing or repairing water meters that are damaged due to the failure of the owner and occupant to keep said meter in good repair or to protect said meter. 
(b)  Each building or other structure owned, rented or occupied independently of other buildings located on the same lot or subdivided area shall be served by a separate service line and shall be equipped with an individual water meter; except that private garages used for normal storage purposes and served from the water supply of one of the major buildings on the property need not be equipped with such meter. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 6, 6-2-2014; Ord. No. 4947, § B, 8-3-2015) 
13.04.190 - Reading meters. 
    The director of finance shall cause every water meter used in the village to be read at such times as are necessary so that bills may be sent out at the proper time. In the event that a reading cannot be obtained, an estimate shall be made of the usage, and a billing may be made based on said estimated reading. 
(Ord. 2780 § B, 1992: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.200 - Schedule of fees for water consumed. 
(a)  For all water billed by the Village of Wheeling during January 2019, and thereafter, the consumer shall pay six dollars and twenty-four cents per one thousand gallons. 
(b)  Each and every user, consumer, or property that is connected to the village's water service shall pay a minimum bi-monthly basic user charge of eighteen dollars and seventy-two cents for water billed in January 2019, and thereafter. 
(c)  Bulk water users may purchase water from the public works hydrant at a minimum charge of twenty-four dollars and ninety-six cents, or to be billed in accordance with subsection (a) of this section if the amount of water purchased exceeds twenty-four dollars and ninety-six cents. 
(Ord. 4292 § A, 2007: Ord. 4166 § A, 2006: Ord. 4031 § A, 2005: Ord. 3876 § A, 2004: Ord. 3750 § 3, 2003; Ord. 3639 § A, 2002: Ord. 3452 § A, 2000: Ord. 3288 § A, 1998: Ord. 3202 § A, 1997: Ord. 3120 § A, 1996: Ord. 2961 § A, 1994: Ord. 2780 § C, 1992: Ord. 2683 § A, 1991: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4393, § A, 12-22-2008; Ord. No. 4490, § A, 12-21-2009; Ord. No. 4570, § A, 12-13-2010; Ord. No. 4664, § A, 12-19-2011; Ord. No. 4747, § A, 12-17-2012; Ord. No. 4819, § A, 12-16-2013; Ord. No. 4918, § A, 12-15-2014; Ord. No. 4977, § A, 12-21-2015; Ord. No. 5055, § A, 12-19-2016; Ord. No. 5141, § A, 12-18-2017; Ord. No. 5179, § D, 5-21-2018; Ord. No. 5237, § A, 12-17-2018) 
13.04.210 - Water service during construction. 
(a)  During the construction of any building and before any water is installed as is provided for in this Chapter, the contractor so constructing such building may be permitted to use the municipal water supply by making application therefor and paying fees for the following types of construction as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code. 
(1)  Residential; 
(2)  Industrial/commercial. 
(b)  The contractor shall be required to supply a water truck or other means of transportation for purposes of securing water pursuant to this section at a site so designated by the director of community development. It is unlawful to secure such water from a fire hydrant without first receiving permission from the director of public works. 
(Ord. 4131 § Q, 2006: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4593, § C, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.220 - Sending out bills. 
    Bills for water and sewer service charges shall be dated and sent out at such times as may be directed by the director of finance, but in any case not less than twenty days prior to the due date. Failure to receive a bill shall not relieve the user of the responsibility for payment of the charges due. 
(Ord. 2780 § D, 1992: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.225 - Responsibility for water and sewer billing. 
    The owner, tenant and occupant of a premises, and the user of any water and/or sewer service at said premises shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the water and/or sewer service to such premises. Water and/or sewer service is furnished to a premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, tenant or occupant thereof, and the user of the services at said premises are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. 
(Ord. No. 4887, § 1, 9-2-2014) 
13.04.230 - Nonpayment. 
(a)  In the event that such bill for water and sewer service (including past incurred penalties) is not paid on or before the due date of said bill, a penalty of ten percent of the total amount due shall be added, the account shall be termed delinquent, and the following procedure used to collect: 
(b)  A delinquent notice shall be mailed. The notice shall be given by depositing the same in the U.S. mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the occupants of the premises and to the owner of the premises, to those addresses as are shown in the most current records of the village. Receipt of notice shall be conclusively presumed from proof of mailing the notice. The notice shall include the gross amount due, a service turnoff date for continued nonpayment, and information advising the consumer of the procedures for contesting a water bill as set forth in Section 13.04.240 of this Chapter. If payment is not received by the turnoff date indicated on the delinquent notice and there is no bona fide dispute as to the consumer's liability or as to the correctness of the water bill as determined by the director of finance after a hearing as set forth in Section 13.04.240 of this Chapter, water service shall be forthwith discontinued. The entire delinquent account, including all penalty and service charges, shall be paid in full before service is reestablished. The reestablishment of service shall be made between 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, upon the authorization of the finance department. If service is reestablished between 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, a service charge, as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, shall be added to the delinquent account. If service is reestablished anytime other than Monday through Friday between 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., a service charge, as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, shall be added to the delinquent account. 
    Schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, will be added to the unpaid balance. 
(c)  In the event that payment of a delinquent account is received in the office of the director of finance without inclusion of the ten percent delinquent penalty incurred, a notice shall be mailed to the debtor, stating the amount of penalty incurred and stating that the penalty shall be added to the debtor's account and included in the next regular billing. 
(d)  For the purposes of determining prompt payment, payment shall be deemed to be on time if received by the office of the director of finance no later than the start of business on the day following the due date. 
(e)  Upon request of the account holder and a record of prompt payment for the prior two years, the director of finance may waive the late payment penalty. Such waiver may not be granted more than once in any two-year period and shall not be mandatory in any case. 
(f)  In the event that a payment is returned due to insufficient funds, the village will not accept payment from the same bank account and a new payment shall be made by cash, cashier's check, or money order, and a twenty-five dollar processing fee will be added to the unpaid balance. 
(Ord. 4131 § R, 2006; Ord. 3750 §§ 4-6, 2003; Ord. 3627 § A, 2002; Ord. 2780 § E, 1992: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.240 - Contesting water bill-Hearing procedure. 
(a)  Any person desiring to contest a water bill may file a written request for a hearing with the director of finance within ten days of the date payment for such bill is due. Failure to file a request within the specified time shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. 
(b)  The hearing shall be held as soon as practicable after filing the request and at least forty-eight hours advance notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be given. 
(c)  The person contesting such bill shall have the burden of establishing that the charges set forth therein are in error. 
(d)  The decision of the director of finance made after the hearing regarding the validity of a water bill and whether to discontinue water service shall be final. 
(Ord. 3750 § 7, 2003; Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.245 - Meter testing. 
(a)  Any person contesting the amount of water used may request that the water meter servicing the premises be tested for accuracy. Such request shall be made in writing to the director of finance. Upon receipt of such request the village shall remove the water meter and have it tested by a reputable testing firm. In no event shall any person, not authorized by the village, remove any water meter. 
(b)  In the event the water meter is determined to be accurate, the person requesting the test shall be responsible for paying the costs of removal, testing and reinstallation of the meter. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.250 - Lien procedure for collection. 
(a)  Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid thirty days after it has been rendered, the village clerk shall file, with the recorder of deeds of the county in which the property is located, a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises serviced, and the amount of the unpaid bill, including all administrative costs, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for water served subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(b)  If the consumer whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises, and the director of finance has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known to the director of finance, whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of sixty days after it has been rendered. 
(c)  The failure of the director of finance to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner of the premises to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water bills as mentioned in this section. 
(d)  The village attorney is authorized and directed to institute foreclosure proceedings, in the name of the village of Wheeling, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which the water bill remains unpaid thirty days after it has been rendered. 
(e)  If a lien is filed by the village, a hearing is held according to any provision of this Chapter or foreclosure proceedings are instituted, filing fees, attorney's fees, and administrative costs shall be added to the delinquent amount due and owing. Water service shall not be resumed until reimbursement in full for all village expenses. 
(Ord. 3750 § 8, 2003; Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.260 - Sprinkling declared nonessential. 
    The use of water from the village water system for purposes of sprinkling or watering lawns is nonessential to the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the village of Wheeling. For the purpose of this section "lawn" shall be that portion of any land under cultivation with grass, trees, shrubs, brushes or types of vegetation not occupied by the principal building or accessory building. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.270 - Other uses declared nonessential. 
    Certain other uses of water from the village water service are nonessential to the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the village, and include, but are not limited to the filling of swimming pools and the noncommercial washing of cars. The village manager is empowered to determine if other uses not specified in this section are nonessential. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.280 - Nonessential uses restricted. 
(a)  The nonessential use of water from the village water system is prohibited every day from May 15th to September 15th between the hours of 12:00 noon and 6:00 p.m. and lawn sprinkling shall not occur on consecutive days. 
(b)  The village manager or his designee is authorized and empowered to permit the watering of newly laid sod or seed at any time and on any day upon issuance of an appropriate permit and for a time period not to exceed two consecutive weeks. 
(c)  The village manager is authorized and empowered to restrict nonessential use of water from the village water system for such additional period of time and in such manner as he may deem necessary in order to conserve the supply of water in the village of Wheeling. The village manager shall announce the additional restrictions, and the restrictions are effective upon the announcement. 
(d)  In the event additional restrictions become necessary, every effort shall be made to allow the sprinkling of newly laid sod or newly seeded lawns for a reasonable length of time after the sod or seed has been placed. The sprinkling, however, shall be allowed only with the permission of the village manager. 
(Ord. 2880 § A, 1993: Ord. 2516 § A, 1989: Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4946, § A, 8-3-2015) 
13.04.290 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
13.04.300 - Reevaluation of water fees. 
    The director of finance shall annually from the adoption of the ordinance codified in this Chapter evaluate the water charges contained in this Chapter and shall recommend to the board of trustees any adjustment of said fees necessary. 
(Ord. 2275 § B (part), 1986) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § N, 3-21-2011) 
13.04.310 - Cross-connection devices and survey. 
(a)  Every installed backflow prevention device shall be tested annually by a state certified cross connection device inspector (CCCDI), at the property owner's expense, to ensure proper function. The property owner is responsible for the proper completion of the annual testing and is responsible for submitting a copy of the inspection report to the village by the anniversary date of the testing, which is anniversary of the installation date. If the village has not received the report by the anniversary date for such testing, the village shall send a notice to the current water user and property owner via U.S. first class mail, which shall include notice that the possible penalty is disconnection. If the village does not receive the test report within thirty calendar days after sending the first notice, the village shall send the second notice via U.S. certified mail, which shall include notice that the possible penalty is disconnection. Failure to provide the village with a properly completed test report within thirty calendar days after sending out the second notice shall result in such property owner being served with a disconnection notice and the village shall follow the procedures for nonpayment set forth in Section 13.04.230, including a right to a hearing set forth in Section 13.04.240. 
(b)  All property owners shall comply with all recommendations made by the CCCDI, including, but not limited to, the correction of deficiencies, replacement of failed device(s), or the removal of cross-connection device(s), or the installation of backflow prevention devices. The property owner is responsible for the proper completion of the corrections recommended by the CCCDI. In case of a disagreement between the property owner and the CCCDI regarding the CCCDI's recommendations, the property owner shall report the disagreement in writing to the water supervisor or his or her designee together with the report by the CCCDI. The water supervisor or his or her designee shall order an independent CCCDI to conduct an independent inspection, at the owner's expense. After a review of all reports, the water supervisor or his or her designee shall make a decision based on the report by the independent inspector. Failure to comply with the recommendations of the CCCDI or the decision by the water supervisor or his or her designee shall constitute a violation of this Chapter and shall result in a notice of disconnection being sent and the village shall follow the procedures for nonpayment set forth in Section 13.04.230, including a right to a hearing set forth in Section 13.04.240. 
(c)  A property owner must complete and submit the cross-connection survey required by the federal and state government, as provided by the village within thirty calendar days from the date of the U.S. postmark. The property owner is responsible for the proper completion of the survey. If the village has not received the completed survey within thirty calendar days from the date of the U.S. postmark, the village shall send a notice to the current water user and property owner via U.S. first class mail, which shall include notice that the possible penalty is disconnection. If the village does not receive the completed survey within thirty calendar days after sending the first notice, the village shall send the second notice via U.S. certified mail, which shall include notice that the possible penalty is disconnection. Failure to provide the village with the completed survey within thirty calendar days after sending out the second notice shall result in such property owner being served with a disconnection notice, which shall follow the procedures for nonpayment set forth in Section 13.04.230, including a right to a hearing set forth in Section 13.04.240. 
(Ord. No. 4947, § A, 8-3-2015) 
Chapter 13.08 - SEWER USE AND CONNECTIONS* 

13.08.010 - Permit for connection required. 
    No person shall make any connections to the sewer mains of the village of Wheeling except on written application made to the director of community development and by the issuance of a permit authorizing the connection to be made and specifying the size thereof. 
(Ord. 2275 § C (part), 1986) 
13.08.020 - Connection required. 
(a)  Every building or structure henceforth erected for human habitation, occupancy or use shall be provided with plumbing facilities complying with all applicable requirements of this code. 
(b)  When a sewer main is laid in any street or any easements, all buildings located on property which abuts such street or easement shall connect with the sewer. This subsection shall not apply to any property forcibly annexed to the village after December 1, 2003. 
(c)  All septic tanks used on such premises shall be discontinued and the contents shall be hauled away. Discontinued receptacles shall be filled with sand or limestone screenings or removed within thirty days of connection to the respective service. 
(d)  No new septic tanks will be allowed on property serviced by a connection to the system. 
(Ord. 3965 § 3, 2005; Ord. 2275 § C (part), 1986) 
13.08.030 - Sewer connection charge. 
    There is established a sewer connection charge for residential users, based on the demand placed on the sewer system, for each sewer connection made to each residence, building or other type structure in the village as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this Code. Nonresidential users shall pay sewer connection fees based on the size as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this Code. 
(Ord. 4259 § B, 2007) 
13.08.040 - Payment prior to connection. 
    The applicant shall pay said fees upon making application for a permit and shall not be permitted to install any sewer pipes connecting with the sewer system until such fees have been paid and a permit has been granted. The applicant shall pay for all costs of labor and material for installing the sewer service from the respective mains to the premises to be served. 
(Ord. 2275 § C (part), 1986) 
13.08.050 - Right of entry to inspect. 
(a)  The director of community development of the village of Wheeling and every person authorized by him, including officials of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, shall have ready access to the premises, place or building to be served by the sewer, and it is unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent or obstruct the director of community development or such other person under his direction from making such inspections. 
(b)  While performing the necessary inspections on private properties, authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises and the occupant shall be held harmless for injury or death to the village employees and the village shall indemnify the occupant against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the occupant and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the occupant to maintain conditions as required by village ordinances and the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago. 
(Ord. 2275 § C (part), 1986) 
13.08.060 - Building permit issuance contingent on sewer connection. 
    No permit to construct or erect any building or structure on premises contiguous to any street or alley in the village of Wheeling in which there are located sewer mains shall be granted unless such structure or building connects its sewer with the public sewers of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 2275 § C (part), 1986) 
13.08.070 - Size and materials for connecting pipes. 
    The sewer connecting pipes from the buildings erected hereafter in the village of Wheeling on property contiguous to a street or alley in which there is located a public sewer system shall be in conformance with Title 16. 
(Ord. 2275 § C (part), 1986) 
13.08.080 - Service fee schedule-Basis for sewer service charges. 
(a)  The sewer service charge for the use and for service supplied by the sewer system of the village shall consist of a basic user charge for operation and maintenance plus replacement, and a local capital cost charge comprised of a debt service charge and a capital improvement charge. 
(1)  The debt service charge shall be computed by apportioning the annual debt service on a cost per one thousand gallon basis. 
(2)  The capital improvement charge shall be levied on all users to provide for capital improvements, extensions or reconstruction of the sewer system. The capital improvement charge is computed by apportioning the annual amount to be accrued as a cost per one thousand gallons. 
(3)  Except as otherwise provided herein the basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by water meters. It shall consist of operations and maintenance costs and shall be computed as follows: 
(A)  Estimate wastewater volume to be transported; 
(B)  Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the sewer system facilities including a replacement fund for the year; 
(C)  Proportion the estimated operation, maintenance and replacement costs to each user by volume; 
(D)  Compute costs per one thousand gallons. The adequacy of the sewer service charge shall be reviewed, not less than annually, by a certified public accountant for the village in their annual audit report. The sewer system service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in capital costs or a change in operation, maintenance and replacement costs. The users will be notified annually, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate and that portion of the user charges which are attributable to the operation, maintenance and replacement. 
(b)  Measurement of Flow. Except as otherwise provided herein the volume of flow used for computing basic user charges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of one thousand gallons. 
(1)  If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures any part, or all, of his water from sources other than the village waterworks system, all or a part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person shall install, at his expense, a water meter of a type approved by the village for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these other sources or a sewer meter. 
(2)  Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required by the village if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records and such devices shall be used to determine volumes to compute service charges. 
(3)  Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be installed, at his expense, by the person discharging such waste. Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is cancelled, without the consent of the village. 
(c)  Local Capital Cost Charge. 
(1)  A debt service charge of zero cents per one thousand gallons, to each user of the sewer system of the village is established. 
(2)  A capital improvement charge will be levied on all users as a charge of zero cents per one thousand gallons, to provide funds for extension, improvement and reconstruction of the sewer system. 
(d)  Basic User Charge. There shall be and there is established a basic user charge for the connection to, use of, and for service supplied by the sewer system of the village. A basic user charge is established as follows: For bills during January 2019, and thereafter, one dollar and fifty-four cents per one thousand gallons of billed water usage; 
    A minimum charge, as follows: 
    For water billed during January 2019, and thereafter, four dollars and sixty-two cents per bi-monthly billing period shall be applied to all users whose water consumption does not exceed three thousand gallons per bi-monthly billing period. All non-metered residential users of the waste water system shall pay a minimum flat rate of twenty-four dollars and sixty-four cents. The flat rate will allow a maximum of sixteen thousand gallons per bi-monthly billing period. 
    In the event use of the sewer system is determined by the village to be in excess of sixteen thousand gallons per bi-monthly billing period, the village may require such flat rate user to install metering devices on the water supply or sewer system service line to measure the amount of service supplied. 
(e)  The wastewater service charge shall be computed by the following formula: 
CW = CC + CD + CM + (VU - X) CU Where: CW = Amount of waste service charge per quarter CD = Debt service charge CC = Capital improvement charge CM = Minimum charge for operation, maintenance, and repair VU = Wastewater volume for billing period X = Allowable consumption in gallons for the minimum charge CU = Basic user rate for operation, maintenance and repair  
(f)  All books, documents, papers and records of the village which are applicable to this system of user charges shall be available to state and federal agencies for the purpose of making audit, examinations, excerpts, and transcriptions thereof. 
(g)  The method of computation of rates and service charges established shall be made available to a user within fourteen days of receipt of a written request for such.
