Chapter 15.10 - REAL ESTATE TRANSFER 

15.10.010 - Required upon real estate transfer. 
A.  No real estate in the village of Wheeling shall be sold, quit claimed, traded or otherwise transferred unless it has been determined that the village's water, sewer and garbage disposal assessments related to the parcel, as of the most recent billing, have been paid in full, and that the owner of the real estate is otherwise not in debt to the village, as evidenced by a transfer certificate issued by the director of finance. 
B.  The requirement of obtaining a transfer certificate shall be mandatory on all transfers of ownership of or beneficial interest in real estate located within the village. The requirement shall further be reflected on all real estate title insurance reports conducted precedent to the transfer of ownership to give public notice of the mandatory requirement of the transfer certificate. A certified copy of the ordinance codified in this Chapter shall be recorded with the county recorder of deeds, and copies shall be sent to all title insurance companies with notice that a transfer certificate is required on any transfer of ownership of real estate in the village. 
C.  An application for a transfer certificate can be secured from the office of the director of finance by any person owning real estate located within the village or his agent or nominee. The application for a transfer certificate must be submitted to the director of finance during regular business hours not less than seven business days prior to any proposed sale, assignment or other transfer for any legal or beneficial interest of such real estate or as soon as is practical to allow sufficient time for the finance director or his designee to determine if the applicant has met the requirements for a transfer certificate. 
1.  If the finance director or his designee determines that the applicant has paid in full all water, sewer and garbage disposal assessments as of the most recent billing, and that the owner is not otherwise in debt to the village, the finance director shall issue a transfer certificate which must be submitted with the original deed or document of transfer in order to transfer property within the village. The transfer certificate shall indicate that as of the date of the most recent billing, all water, sewer and garbage disposal assessments have been paid in full and that the owner is not otherwise in debt to the village. Any unbilled assessments as of the date of closing shall remain the responsibility of the owner of the real estate. The transfer certificate shall be valid for a period of thirty days from the date of issuance. The finance department shall keep a record of all transfer certificates on file in the office of the finance department, and copies shall be furnished, upon request, to any person having a tenancy interest in the property. 
2.  If the finance director or his designee determines that the applicant has not paid in full all water, sewer and/or garbage disposal assessments, or that the owner is otherwise in debt to the village, no transfer certificate shall be issued. The applicant will be given a report in a form adopted by the finance department which indicates any water, sewer, garbage assessments, and/or debts owed by the owner to the village. When, and if, the applicant has paid the debt noted on the report, he shall reapply for a transfer certificate. 
(Ord. No. 4739, § B, 12-10-2012) 
15.10.020 - Appeal of refusal to issue. 
A.  Any person whose application for a transfer certificate has been denied may appeal to the board of trustees and contest the findings contained on the report or request that the requirements of this Chapter be waived in his or her particular circumstances. 
B.  An appeal to the board of trustees must be perfected by filing a notice of appeal with the village clerk. Such notice of appeal must be filed within ten days from the date of issuance of the report denying the transfer certificate. The board of trustees may grant a variance from the requirements of the code only when the applicant can prove by a preponderance of the evidence that: 
1.  Compliance with the requirements of the code will place an extreme hardship on the applicant; or 
2.  Physical conditions make compliance impossible. 
C.  The board of trustees shall hold a hearing on the appeal within seven days of the filing of the notice of appeal. It shall render a written decision at the close of the hearing or within seven days of the close of the evidence, at the latest. 
(Ord. No. 4739, § B, 12-10-2012) 
Chapter 15.11 - PENALTIES 

15.11.010 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine as set forth in Chapter 1.24, Administrative Citations, of this code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4965, § L, 11-23-2015) 
Title 16 - PLUMBING CODE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 16.1 - PLUMBING CODE 
Sections: 

16.1-1 - Adoption of Illinois Plumbing Code. 
    That certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk, being marked and designated as "The Illinois Plumbing Code," as published and periodically updated by the Illinois Department of Public Health, is hereby adopted as the Plumbing Code of the village of Wheeling in the state of Illinois. The control of plumbing as herein provided, and each and all of the regulations of the current Illinois Plumbing Code are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in the ordinance codified in this section, with the additions, insertions and changes, as described in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 4131 § AO, 2006; Ord. 3961 § B, 2005; Ord. No. 4947, § C, 8-3-2015) 
Editor's note- Section C of Ord. No. 4947, adopted Aug. 3, 2015, changed the title of § 16.1-1 from "Adoption of Illinois Plumbing Code, 2014" to read as herein set out. 
16.1-2 - WaterSense products. 
    Pursuant to 17 Ill. Admin. Code 3730.307(c)(4) and subject to the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 890) and the Lawn Irrigation Contractor and Lawn Sprinkler System Registration Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 892), all new plumbing fixtures and irrigation controllers installed after the effective date of this section shall bear the WaterSense label (as designated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency WaterSense Program), when such labeled fixtures are available. 
(Ord. No. 4946, § B, 8-3-2015) 
Chapter 16.2 - CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL 
Sections: 

16.2.010 - Backflow prevention device. 
    If, in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code or in the judgment of the water supervisor or his designee an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the water supervisor will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, have a licensed plumbing contractor install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and all applicable local regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices upon installation and as required by the Illinois Plumbing Code, Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and local regulations. The installed device must be approved and inspected by village staff or a designee of the village. Said inspection shall be at the expense of the property owner. 
(Ord. 3293 § A (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 4851, § 1, 4-7-2014) 
16.2.020 - Prohibited connections to the public water supply. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the village of Wheeling may enter the supply or distribution system of said municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the water supervisor and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
(Ord. 3293 § A (part), 1998) 
16.2.030 - Public water supply inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the water supervisor to cause surveys and investigations to be made of commercial, industrial and other properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two years, or as often as the water supervisor shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least five years. 
(Ord. 3293 § A (part), 1998) 
16.2.040 - Cross-connection inspection. 
    The water supervisor shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time, in accordance with applicable law, any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the village of Wheeling for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross-connections, and that the water supervisor or his authorized agent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time, in accordance with applicable law, any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the village of Wheeling for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross-connection control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property shall furnish to the water supervisor any information which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such information shall be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3293 § A (part), 1998) 
16.2.050 - Discontinuance of service due to contamination. 
(a)  The water supervisor is authorized and directed to discontinue, after written notice to the owner or occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this Chapter is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution mains. 
(b)  The water supervisor may immediately disconnect the water connection to any party in order to prevent actual or imminent danger of harmful contamination or pollution of the public water supply. When, in the opinion of the water supervisor or the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, immediate disconnection is required to prevent actual or potential contamination or pollution of the public water supply, such action shall be followed by written notification to the owner or occupant of the cause of disconnection. 
(c)  Water service to any property disconnected under the provisions of this Chapter shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions of this Chapter, and until a reconnection fee of one hundred dollars is paid. 
(Ord. 3293 § A (part), 1998) 
16.2.060 - Responsibility for backflow contamination. 
    Any person responsible for backsiphoned or back pressured material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross-connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, shall bear the cost of clean-up of the potable water supply system. 
(Ord. 3293 § A (part), 1998)

(Ord. No. 4965, § M, 11-23-2015)

Title 17 - PLANNING, SUBDIVISIONS AND DEVELOPMENTS* 
Chapter 17.08 - OFFICIAL MAP* 

17.08.010 - Map adopted. 
    The map which is made a part of this Chapter, showing the existing and proposed streets, highways, and public ways and those areas existing or proposed as parks, playgrounds, school sites and other public grounds within the corporate limits of the village and in a contiguous territory not more than one and one-half miles from the village limits and not included in any municipality, is hereby adopted as the official map of the village of Wheeling, as a portion of the comprehensive plan to be adopted by the village. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.08.020 - Use of map. 
    This official map shall be made a part of and be construed with the proposed subdivision ordinance as it may be hereafter adopted and from time to time amended, which ordinance shall specifically state and refer to the standard requirements of the village relating to size of public ways, and other public grounds and public service facilities pursuant to the statute in such cases made and provided. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.08.030 - Changing map. 
    The plan commission may from time to time recommend to the corporate authorities such changes in the official map as may be deemed necessary by the plan commission. Such changes shall become part of the official map after their approval and adoption by the corporate authorities as amendments to this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.08.040 - Compliance with map required. 
    No map or plat of any subdivision presented for record, affecting land within the corporate limits of the village, or in contiguous territory not more than one and one-half miles from such limits and not included in any municipality shall be entitled to recording or shall be valid unless the subdivision thereon shown conforms with the requirements of the official map. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.08.050 - Enforcement duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of community development to enforce the requirements of the official map. The director of community development may call upon any other departments or official of the village to furnish him with such information or assistance as he may deem necessary for the observance or enforcement of the official map. It shall be the duty of such other department or officials to furnish such information or assistance whenever requested. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.08.060 - Filing map. 
    This official map shall be placed in file with the village clerk and shall be available at all times during the regular business hours of the village for public inspection. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.08.070 - Copies of map. 
    Copies of this official map shall be made available to all interested parties upon payment of an established fee. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.08.080 - Filing map with county. 
    The village clerk is directed to file the notice of the adoption of the comprehensive plan and the official map or amendments thereto with the county recorder of deeds of Cook County. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.12 - DEFINITIONS 

17.12.010 - Generally. 
    For the purpose of this Title, certain terms and words are defined in this Chapter. Words used in the present tense include the future. Words in the singular number include the plural, and words in the plural number include the singular. The phrase "used for" includes the phrases "arranged for," "designed for," "intended for," "maintained for" and "occupied for." The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is permissive. The requirements, terms and conditions contained within this Title shall apply to all developments, regardless of size, including but not limited to industrial, commercial, multi-family and single-family residential properties and lots. No development work shall be exempt from these requirements. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.020 - Alley. 
    "Alley" means a public right-of-way of public easement which affords only secondary means for vehicular access to the back (rear) or the side of property otherwise abutting on a street, but does not include a driveway. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.030 - Approval, final. 
    "Final approval" means the approval given the preliminary or final plat by the plan commission and village board of trustees. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.035 - Base flood. 
    "Base flood" means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.040 - Block. 
    "Block" means a tract of land bounded by the streets or by a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, shorelines of waterways, or boundary lines of the village of Wheeling, Illinois. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.050 - Consolidations. 
    "Consolidations" means combining two or more lots of record into a lesser number of lots. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.060 - Crosswalk. 
    "Crosswalk" means that portion of the sidewalk which lies between the curb and the sidewalk along a street. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.070 - Cul-de-sac. 
    "Cul-de-sac" means a minor street with only one outlet and turnaround. Cul-de-sacs shall meet all the requirements for a minor street and, in addition, shall provide a turnaround as required in Section 17.28.110 of this Title, and as described in the official Wheeling minimum design standards, which are made a part of this section by reference. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.080 - Developer. 
    "Developer" means the person, firm, or corporation having such contractual or proprietary interest in a parcel of land sought to be improved as a planned development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.085 - Development. 
    "Development" means any improvement to be made to a property (or lot) which requires village approval and a permit to construct. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.090 - Director of community development. 
    "Director of community development" means an administrative official designated by the village manager. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.095 - Drives, private streets, private thoroughfares, or private cul-de-sacs. 
    "Drives, private streets, private thoroughfares, or private cul-de-sacs" mean a paved way for the passage of motor vehicles open to the public within a planned development which is not dedicated to the village, but is maintained by the owners of the development and which is used for ingress and egress only. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.100 - Easement. 
    "Easement" means a grant by a property owner of the use of land for a specific purpose. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.110 - Extra-territorial plat approval jurisdiction. 
    "Extra-territorial plat approval jurisdiction" means the unincorporated area within one and one-half miles of the corporate limits of the village and not included in any other municipality or as otherwise set forth in the applicable state statutes. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.120 - Floodplain. 
    "Floodplain" means the land area which would be inundated by the waters of the base flood. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.130 - Floodplain regulations. 
    "Floodplain regulations" means those regulations adopted by the village of Wheeling as a part of the zoning ordinances, which regulate construction within the floodplain areas of Wheeling as the same may be amended and adopted from time to time. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.135 - Floor area ratio. 
    "Floor area ratio" is the area of the building divided by the area of the lot on which it is being constructed, or in the case of planned developments, the floor area of the buildings divided by the net site area. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.140 - Frontage. 
    "Frontage" means the length of the front property line of the lot, lots, or tract of land abutting a public or existing private street or right-of-way. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.150 - Grade. 
    "Grade" means the slope of any portion of the earth's surface or any improvements placed thereon, specified in percent, and shown on the street profile plans as required in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.160 - Improvements. 
    "Improvements" means any alteration, change or development of any facility, property or lot which requires approval by the village and a permit to proceed and complete its construction. "Public improvements" mean any infrastructure or facility for which the village or other governmental/municipal body may ultimately assume the ownership and subsequent responsibility of maintenance and operation, or which is constructed for the benefit and general use of the public. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.170 - Lot. 
    "Lot" means a parcel or tract of land, the plat of which has been or will be recorded either in the office of the county recorder of deeds, or with the registrar of titles; or a parcel of land, the deed of which was recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds or with the registrar of titles. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.175 - Lot and block. 
    "Lot and block" mean that if the boundaries of the tract coincide exactly with the lot which is a part of a subdivision or addition for which there is recorded an official map, the tract may be legally described by giving the lot and block numbers and the name and date of filing of the official map, as illustrated by the following: 
    "Lot 15 in Block 5 as said lots and block are delineated and so designated upon that certain map entitled "Map of the Village of Wheeling, Cook County, Illinois," filed August 23, 1909, in Liber 25 of Maps, page 2, in the Office of the County Recorder of the said County of Cook." 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.180 - Lot, corner. 
    "Corner lot" means a lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.190 - Lot, double frontage. 
    "Double frontage lot" means a lot having a pair of opposite lot lines along two substantially parallel streets. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.200 - Major street plan. 
    "Major street plan" means the major street plan of the official plan of the village of Wheeling as the same may be adopted and amended from time to time. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.202 - Metes and bounds. 
    "Metes and bounds" mean that if the boundaries of a given tract within a subdivision for which there is a recorded map do not conform exactly to boundaries shown on the official map, the tract is described by metes and bounds, with the point of beginning referred to a corner shown on the official map. Also, the numbers of the lots of which the tract is composed are given. Following is an example of a description of this kind: 
    "Beginning at the intersection of the Northern line of Escondido Avenue, with the Eastern boundary line of Lot 16, hereinafter referred to; running thence Northerly along said Eastern boundary line of Lot 16, and the Eastern boundary line of Lot 17, eighty-nine (89) feet; thence at right angles Westerly, fifty-one (51) feet; thence South 12 degrees 06 minutes East, seventy-five (75) feet to the Northern line of Escondido Avenue; thence Easterly along said line of Escondido Avenue, fifty-three and 13/100 (53.13) feet, more or less, to the point of beginning. 
    "Being a portion of Lots 16 and 17, in Block 5, as said lots and block are delineated and so designated upon that certain map entitled "Map of the Village of Wheeling, Cook County, Illinois," filed August 23, 1909, in Liber 25 of Maps, page 2, in the Office of the County Recorder of the said County of Cook." 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.205 - Net site area. 
    "Net site area" means the area of the tract of land in question, less the area of all dedicated public lands or those lands required to be dedicated under the Wheeling subdivision ordinance. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.210 - Official map. 
    "Official map" means that map adopted by the corporate authorities as specified in Chapter 17.08 of this Title, pursuant to the statutes of the state of Illinois, known as the official map of the village of Wheeling, with all changes and amendments thereto which may be adopted from time to time, and which is hereby made a part of and is to be construed with the comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.220 - Official plan. 
    "Official plan" means the comprehensive plan adopted by the board of trustees, known as the official plan of the village of Wheeling, together with all changes and amendments thereto which are adopted from time to time. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.230 - Official Wheeling standards. 
    "Official Wheeling standards" means those standards of installation, construction and design which are set forth as a part of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.235 - Outlots. 
    "Outlots" means private common grounds or areas, as set out in this code. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.240 - Owner. 
    "Owner" means the person, partnership, corporation, trustee, trust, or any other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest of record in the land sought to be subdivided to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the same under the statutes of the state of Illinois and under the ordinances of the village of Wheeling, Illinois. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.250 - Plan commission. 
    "Plan commission" means the plan commission of the village of Wheeling, established pursuant to the statutes of the state of Illinois. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.252 - Plan review committee. 
    The "plan review committee" shall be appointed by the village manager and shall consist of village employees. It shall review proposed plans for developments in the village of Wheeling. It shall be the purpose of this group to review the plans to ascertain conformance with this code and to make recommendations on alternatives available to the village for an individual development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.255 - Planned development. 
    "Planned development" means a unified tract of land containing not less than five acres, comprehensively planned as an entity via a unitary site plan which permits flexibility in building, usable open spaces, and the preservation of significant natural features, and which will contain, when developed, two or more buildings, and which is developed under the control of a single entity for sale or lease by separate parcels or units, as determined by the zoning classification of the property. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.260 - Plat, final. 
    "Final plat" means the plan of record of a subdivision, together with any accompanying material, as described in Chapter 17.24 of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.270 - Plat, preliminary. 
    "Preliminary plat" means the plan of layout of a proposed subdivision as described in Chapter 17.24 of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.275 - Private common grounds or areas. 
    "Private common grounds or areas" means any land area within the planned development which is under the ownership, control and responsibility of the owners or residents of such development, either as tenants in common or under a private association, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.280 - Public lands. 
    "Public lands" mean any land area within the planned development or subdivision which has been dedicated or reserved for use as streets, alleys, public ways, parks, playgrounds, schools, community buildings, ways for public service facilities, sidewalks, stormwater or floodwater run-off channels, public stormwater management or other public uses. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.285 - Public utilities. 
    "Public utilities" include, but are not limited to street lighting, stormwater drainage facilities, sanitary sewers or water mains. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.290 - Right-of-way. 
    "Right-of-way" means a strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a road, walkway, crosswalk, railroad, electric transmission line, or other special use. Every right-of-way established under this Title and shown on a final plat is separate and distinct from the lots and parcels adjoining such right-of-way and not included within the dimensions or areas of such lots or parcels. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.300 - Roadway. 
    "Roadway" means that portion of the street which has been or is to be improved and is or will be available for vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.310 - Sidewalk. 
    "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street, walkway, or crosswalk which is paved and intended for pedestrian use only. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.315 - Stormwater runoff. 
    For a definition of "Stormwater runoff," see Chapter 13.14 of this code. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.320 - Street. 
    "Street" means the entire paved width between back of curbs, or edge of pavement of every pavement open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.330 - Street, dead-end. 
    "Dead-end street" means a street with only one outlet, with no turnaround, which must be extended on future development of the adjacent land. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.340 - Street, major, secondary, and collector. 
    "Major, secondary, and collector street" means those streets as shown and designated in the major street plan and sector plans, as amended. All other streets shall be considered minor streets. For additional provisions, see Sections 17.28.030 and 17.32.070 of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.350 - Street, marginal access. 
    "Marginal access street" means a minor street parallel and adjacent to a major thoroughfare, which provides access to abutting properties while providing protection to local traffic from fast, through traffic on the major thoroughfare. For additional provisions, see Sections 17.28.030(e) and 17.32.070 of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.360 - Street width. 
    "Street width" means the shortest distance as measured perpendicular to the centerline between the limits delineating a street as defined in Section 17.12.320 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.370 - Subdivider. 
    "Subdivider" or "developer" means any person, partnership, corporation, trustee, trust or any other legal entity commencing proceedings under this Title to effect a subdivision or development of land hereunder. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.380 - Subdivision. 
    "Subdivision" means the division of a parcel of land into two or more lots or parcels of record for the purpose of transfer of ownership or development for any future use, either residential, commercial, or industrial. The term includes resubdivision of lots or parcels of record and, when appropriate to context, relates to the process of subdivision or to the land subdivided. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.381 - Subdivision, administrative. 
    "Administrative subdivision" refers to splitting an existing lot or parcel with the creation of a lot line or a lot line adjustment between two adjoining lots or the consolidation of two or more adjoining lots. The properties must be held by a common owner. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.385 - Unit. 
    "Unit" means either a multiple-family unit or an attached single-family dwelling unit, both of which may be subject to the Illinois Condominium Act. If recorded under the Condominium Act, the units shall be numbered consecutively within a planned development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.390 - Village engineer. 
    "Village engineer" means that person so appointed by the village manager. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.400 - Walkway. 
    "Walkway" means a right-of-way within a block, ten feet or more in width, dedicated for public use, intended primarily for pedestrians, but which may include utilities where necessary, and from which motor and engine propelled vehicles are excluded. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.405 - Water detention. 
    "Water detention" consists of stormwater detained on site as part of the overall stormwater management facility plan. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.12.410 - Zoning ordinance. 
    "Zoning ordinance" means the Wheeling zoning ordinance as amended and as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.16 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

17.16.010 - Short title. 
    This Title shall be known, cited and referred to as the "Wheeling Planning, Subdivisions and Developments Ordinance." 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.020 - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Title, the definitions contained in Chapter 17.12 of this Title shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly requires otherwise. Nothing contained in this Title shall be deemed to be a consent, license or permit to use any property or to locate, construct, or maintain any building, structure or facility or to carry on any trade, industry, occupation or activity. The provisions of this Title are cumulative and additional limitations, upon all other laws and ordinances, heretofore passed or which may be passed hereafter, governing any subject matter in this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.030 - Approval required for contract of sale. 
    No person, firm, or corporation proposing to make or having made a subdivision within the village and the area within the extra-territorial plat approval jurisdiction of the village shall enter into any contract for the sale of or shall offer to sell such subdivision or any part thereof until the final subdivision plat of the proposed subdivision has been properly recorded. This section shall not restrict the subdivider from being the contract purchaser of the property. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.040 - Approval required for construction on land. 
    No person, firm, or corporation proposing to make or having made a subdivision within the village and the area within the extra-territorial plat approval jurisdiction of the village shall proceed with any construction work on the proposed subdivision, including grading, until the final plat of the proposed subdivision has been properly recorded. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.050 - Approval required for recording. 
    No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to be recorded in the appropriate county recorder's office or have any validity until it has been approved in the manner prescribed by law. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.055 - Permit approval required for construction. 
    No development shall be entitled to issuance of a permit until satisfactorily meeting the requirements, terms and conditions of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.060 - Enforcement responsibility. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of community development, or his duly appointed representative, to enforce the provisions of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.070 - Compliance required for subdividing. 
    No land within the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling, or within the contiguous territory within one and one-half miles of the corporate limits of the village and not included in any municipality, shall be subdivided or entitled to be recorded, nor any street laid out, nor any improvements be made to the land until the provisions of this Title are met and the plats and plan or plans of the subdivision or planned development have been approved and certified by the plan commission and the president and board of trustees. All changes in the plats or plans of the subdivisions or planned developments referred to in this section must be approved and certified by the plan commission and the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.080 - Compliance required for building permit. 
    No building permit shall be issued by the village authorizing the building on or improvements of any subdivided land or planned development not of record as of the date of the ordinance codified in this Chapter unless the provisions and requirements of this Title and Title 19 have been met. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.090 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this Title is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.04 of this code. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.100 - Severability. 
    Should any chapter, section, clause or provision of this Title be declared invalid, it shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.16.110 - Saving clause. 
    The repeal of the ordinances or parts thereof by this Title shall not affect suits pending or rights existing on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Title, nor shall this Title impair, void or affect any right acquired or cause of action now existing under any such repealed ordinance or amendment thereto, nor shall this Title affect or impair the validity of any bond or other obligation issued prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.20 - PROCEDURE 

17.20.010 - Compliance with design principles required. 
    The subdivider or his agent shall comply with the general principles of design and minimum requirements for the layout of subdivisions set forth in Chapter 17.28 and with the provisions of Chapter 17.32 of this Title establishing minimum design standards and procedures for the installation of subdivision improvements, and in every case shall pursue the following procedure, hereinafter outlined. 
    Variation may be made to the requirements of this Title insofar as internal developments and improvements in a planned development are concerned. The provisions of this Chapter shall also be applicable to planned developments. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.011 - Administrative subdivisions. 
    Administrative subdivisions, by the determination of the engineering department and community development department, do not require review by the plan commission; however, do require approval of the village board. 
    Administrative subdivisions will only be permitted if the lots created meet all applicable standards for lot size and access. Parkway trees, sidewalk installations and water/sewer connections will not be required if the engineering department and community development department jointly determine that these items are not necessary in the subdivision. All other applicable requirements for subdivisions under Title 17 must be met. 
(Ord. 4016 § 1, 2005: Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.015 - Preliminary inquiry. 
    Inquiries from any person regarding making application for a planned development pursuant to this Title shall be directed to the director of community development. After a general review of the project, the director of community development, or his authorized representative, shall apprise the applicant of the procedures hereinafter set forth and give a general indication of the feasibility of the project. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.020 - Preliminary plat submission. 
(a)  Preapplication Conference. Any owner or representative of the owner of land located within the corporate limits or within one and one-half miles of such corporate limits, desiring to subdivide or resubdivide, shall first submit to the director of community development of the village of Wheeling such information as may be required by the plan commission (Chapter 17.24) to describe or outline the existing conditions of the site and the proposed development thereof. The applicant shall be supplied with pertinent information on plan commission requirements not herein contained, or as these regulations may be applied to the subject property. Prior to filing a planned development application, the applicant shall file with the director of community development five copies of a plat of survey, an aerial photograph of the subject site, preliminary plans and sketches and other such basic site information and in such quantity as may be deemed necessary by the director of community development. The director of community development shall schedule an initial conference with the applicant and the plan review committee for the purpose of reviewing the applicant's proposal and to advise the applicant of the required procedures for planned development approval. 
(b)  Contacting Director of Finance. The subdivider shall be directed to contact the director of finance when such documentation as is required for submission is prepared and is, in his opinion, ready for application and for the payment of required fees. 
(c)  Submitting Documentation. The subdivider shall submit the documentation to the director of community development for his submission to the plan commission and the director of community development shall inform the subdivider of the date of presentation to the plan commission. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § P, 3-21-2011) 
17.20.030 - Preliminary plat approval. 
(a)  Preparation and Filing. Before submitting a final plat for approval, the subdivider shall prepare a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision which shall conform with the provisions set forth in Chapters 17.24 and 17.28 of this Title, and shall provide sufficient number of copies as required to the director of community development. Within a maximum of thirty days following the final review of the preliminary plat by the plan review committee, the village planner may submit a written report of the committee's findings and recommendations to the plan commission. 
(b)  Conference Review. The preliminary plat will be reviewed by the plan commission, director of community development, village planner and village engineer as to conformity with the official plan and map and the principles, standards and requirements set forth in this Title. If the plat submitted is for a planned development, the conference review will be made upon receipt of the report of the plan review committee. 
(c)  Recommendation. After review of the preliminary plat and, if necessary, discussion with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable as to the extent of private and public improvements which will be required, the plan commission shall, within ninety days of submission of all required data, forward to the village board of trustees a report recommending either approval or disapproval of the preliminary plat, and a copy of such report shall be forwarded to the subdivider. 
(d)  Form of Notice of Approval of Preliminary Plat. Upon receipt of the report of the plan commission, the village board of trustees shall either accept or reject the preliminary plat. Such action shall be taken within thirty days after the first regular meeting of the village board of trustees following the plan commission's action. Upon acceptance of the preliminary plat, the following statement signed by the village president shall be stamped upon all record copies thereof: 
"NOTICE OF APPROVAL" 
  "Notice is hereby given that the preliminary plan of the subdivision shown in this plat has been approved by the Village Board of Trustees of the Village of Wheeling and that the Plan Commission of the Village of Wheeling is now ready to receive the final plat for consideration. 
The Village Board of Trustees of the Village of Wheeling, Illinois 
Date of Acceptance: _______ 
Date of Signature: _______ 
By: _______, President" 
(e)  Notification of Conditions. Plats requiring examination by a professional, other than the village planner, as determined by the director of community development, should be submitted to the village planner prior to final consideration by the plan commission, and his report should be submitted to the plan commission. The fees for services rendered by the planner shall be borne by the applicant. 
(f)  Length of Time Approval Effective. Approval of preliminary plat shall be effective for not more than twelve months following the date of approval by the corporate authorities. Extensions may be granted by the plan commission with concurrence by the president and board of trustees. 
(g)  Exceptions. Preliminary plats submitted by state and local governmental agencies and subdivisions containing three lots or less not involving new streets may be exempted from the applicable provisions of this section upon written application to the director of community development and with the approval of the majority vote of the members of the plan commission in attendance at the meeting at which the request was submitted; provided further, however, that the plan commission shall not approve both a preliminary plat and a final plat of subdivision, resubdivision or planned development of the same parcel of land at the same regularly scheduled meeting. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.040 - Final plat submission. 
(a)  Date of Submission. Within one year following acceptance of a preliminary plat by the corporate authorities, a final plat shall be submitted. The subdivider may elect to have final approval of a geographic part or parts of the plat which received preliminary approval, and the subdivider may delay submission for final approval of the remaining part or parts until a later date or dates beyond the one year period with the approval of the corporate authorities. 
(b)  To Whom Submitted. The final plat and accompanying documentation shall be submitted to the plan commission by the director of community development. 
(c)  Commission's Recommendation. The plan commission shall, within thirty days from the date of submission of all required documents, recommend acceptance or rejection to the village board of trustees. 
(d)  Time Limit for Decision. The village board of trustees will, within sixty days from the date of existing submission to the village board of trustees, indicate acceptance or rejection. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.050 - Final plat approval. 
(a)  Time Limit for Submission. The subdivider shall submit to the director of community development the original tracing and sufficient copies of the final plat as required by the director of community development within one year of the approval of the preliminary plat. The final plat shall include complete engineering construction plans for the proposed improvements. However, if approval of the preliminary plat must be obtained from another approving authority subsequent to approval by the board of trustees, the final plat shall be submitted within one year of such approval. The failure to submit a final plat for recording within the time above specified shall operate as a revocation of the approval of the preliminary plat, and the subsequent subdivision of the same property shall proceed only upon a new application to the director of community development. 
(b)  Certificates. The village planner shall then refer the final plat to the village engineer for review. If found satisfactory, the plat will be returned to the village planner together with a certificate showing that technical details of the plat itself have been checked and found satisfactory by the village engineer, or in lieu of approval, his recommendations therefor. If found satisfactory, the village planner shall then refer the final plat to the plan commission for final approval or rejection. 
(c)  Procedure for Approval, Rejection. The director of community development shall refer the final plat and all required supporting documents along with his recommendations to the village board of trustees within thirty days of its complete submission to the village planner. The village board of trustees shall approve or reject the final plat within sixty days of the submission of the last required document completing the final plat submission to the director of community development unless the time is extended by agreement with the subdivider. In the event that the village board of trustees rejects the final plat, the reasons for rejection shall be stated in the minutes of the board meeting, and a copy thereof or a written statement of the reason for the rejection shall be forwarded to the subdivider by the director of community development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.060 - Construction of public and private improvements. 
    Work shall not begin on the construction of the required surface and underground improvements until the following steps have been completed: 
(1)  The final plat must be approved by the corporate authorities; 
(2)  The necessary state, county or other appropriate permits have been issued; 
(3)  A performance guarantee assuring the payment of all labor and materials, and satisfactory completion of all underground and surface improvements, both public and private, within a reasonable time. The performance guarantee required in this Chapter shall be in the form of (a) an irrevocable, straight, commercial letter of credit with a financial institution approved by the village and in a form approved by the village attorney and village engineer; (b) a cash deposit in the total amount required; or (c) a performance bond approved by the village attorney and village engineer; 
(4)  The amount of cash or letter of credit to be deposited shall be equal to one hundred ten percent of the estimated cost of all underground and surface improvements as approved by the village engineer, including reasonable engineering and inspection fees necessary to ensure conformance with the established requirements for such improvements. A subsequent owner of the property shall deposit with the village a certified check in the amount of one thousand dollars or other acceptable surety to repair damaged curbs and gutters, parkways, manholes, street lights or other village-owned facilities located within the street right-of-way. If after the complete development of the property there is no damage to curbs, gutters, parkways, manholes, street lights or other village-owned facilities, the monies referred to in this subsection shall be returned to the owner; 
(5)  Upon approval of the letter of credit, bond or the acceptance of the cash by the village engineer or director of community development shall record or cause to be recorded the final plat of subdivision in the office of the county recorder of deeds, as may be required. The director of community development shall retain such final plat so approved and, upon payment by the subdivider to the village of Wheeling of the required fees for recording, he shall record the plat in the office of the county recorder of the appropriate county. The supporting documents transmitted with the final plat to the village board of trustees shall be filed with the director of community development. Such final plat, after recording, shall remain on file in the office of the director of community development. The print or copy of the final plat with copy of the approval thereof by the village board of trustees and one copy of all supporting documents shall be delivered to the subdivider. Reproducible copies (at the subdivider's or developer's expense) are acceptable for filing by the village in lieu of the original documents described in this subsection; 
(6)  The requirements set forth in this section apply to both an entire subdivision, or a resubdivision, or a unit of a subdivision or resubdivision as originally submitted for plat approval. Provisions of this section relative to performance guarantees shall not apply to those extra-territorial subdivisions or planned developments which are required to be approved by the corporate authorities of the village. However, the developer shall furnish copies of any bonds or performance guarantees he may be required to furnish to other corporate authorities. Once completed and upon tentative approval or acceptance of the surface or underground improvements by the corporate authorities, the person, firm or corporation developing the subdivision or lots therein shall provide the village with a maintenance guarantee in an amount equal to not less than ten percent of the estimated cost of such improvements to act as a guarantee running to the village for a period of twelve months following the tentative approval or acceptance of the facilities by the corporate authorities. Upon the completion of the final acceptance of the improvements by the corporate authorities at the end of the warranty period, the remaining funds shall be returned to the depositor, or the letter of credit or bond released, as the case may be; 
(7)  In the event the ownership of the subdivision or planned development changes before completion of the development, other than the gradual transfer of ownership from the developer to an association under the Condominium Act or the like, the new owner or entity shall provide such guarantees acceptable to the corporate authorities with the village as required in subsection (3) or (4) of this section, and all prior written commitments entered into by the previous owner shall be binding on its heirs, successors and assigns. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.070 - Building permits. 
    No building permits shall be issued until the final plat of subdivision has been recorded. This provision does not restrict the construction of one principal building per lot of record. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.20.080 - Permit approval. 
    No permit shall be issued until approval is granted by the village engineer assuring that all applicable sections and design requirements of this Title have been complied with and satisfactorily addressed. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.22 - AIRPORT HAZARD AREAS 

17.22.010 - Areas designated. 
    For purposes of this Title, the airport hazard areas shall be the territory so designated in Section 19.10.010(a)(1) and (2) of this code, both within and without the corporate boundaries of the village, but not including any such described territory lying more than one and one-half miles from the corporate boundaries of the village. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.22.020 - Subdivisions in airport hazard areas. 
    No subdivision shall be granted, either by preliminary or final plat approval, where the land sought to be subdivided lies in whole or in part within an airport hazard area, unless the legal owners of such portion as lies within the airport hazard area properly execute a covenant to run with such portion of the land that no construction or improvements on such land will be commenced above ground level until such construction or improvements are determined by the Federal Aviation Administration not to constitute a hazard to aerial navigation, such covenant to be granted to and be enforceable by the village. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.24 - PLAT PREPARATION AND SUPPORTING DATA 

17.24.010 - Preapplication conference data. 
    The following information shall be presented by the subdivider at the time of the preliminary consultation: 
(1)  Proof of ownership of the land to be subdivided, in the form of a deed, an option to purchase, or title policy. No further consideration will be given the proposed subdivision unless such proof of ownership is established at the time of the preapplication conference; 
(2)  Submit to the director of community development preliminary plat information as noted in Section 17.24.020 of this Chapter; 
(3)  The provisions of this Chapter shall also be applicable to planned developments; 
(4)  Where deemed necessary by the director of community development, the plan review committee shall review the plat and may require the following: 
(A)  Traffic impact study conducted by the village's independent consultant with the developer paying the cost of such study, 
(B)  Water adequacy report, i.e., number of fire hydrants necessary, adequate water pressure, looping of mains, etc., to be prepared by a village designated engineer, with the developer bearing the cost of such report, 
(C)  Report from appropriate school district relative to the impact of the development upon the school system, 
(D)  Report from the park district relative to the impact of the development upon the recreational needs of the community, 
(E)  Report from appropriate library district relative to the impact of the development upon the library district system, 
(F)  Economic impact and environmental impact evaluations prepared by the applicant. 
    The village planner shall submit a report of his findings to the plan commission for further consideration of the proposed plat. 
(5)  Deed or other evidence of title shall be required as part of documentation presented to the corporate authorities. If a metes and bounds subdivision has taken place in contravention of Section 17.16.070 of this Title, proof of when such subdivision took place should also be supplied to the corporate authorities; 
(6)  Application shall be filed with the Cook County soil and water conservation district if the property is two acres or larger. The report from the Cook County soil and water conservation district must accompany the preliminary plat; 
(7)  Subdivision processing fees shall be paid prior to formal plan commission review of the subdivision; 
(8)  All plats and supporting data shall be submitted to the director of community development at least two weeks prior to the plan commission meeting at which the project will be reviewed. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.020 - Information required on preliminary plat. 
    The preliminary plat shall be legibly drawn with waterproof, nonfading black ink, either manually or electronically on suitable tracing material of good quality at a scale not less than one hundred feet to one inch, and shall show correctly on its face or in supporting documents the following information: 
(a)  The proposed subdivision name, which shall not duplicate the name of any plat previously recorded in the village of Wheeling; 
(b)  Date, scale, and north arrow; 
(c)  The name and address of the owner, or trust number, including a list of the beneficiaries of the trust and their percentage of ownership, the subdivider and the registered surveyor, preparing the plat; 
(d)  Location of the subdivision by quarter section, section, township, range and county. A small scale drawing of the section or government subdivision of the section in which the subdivision lies, with quarter section and section lines and with the location of the subdivision indicated thereon and oriented in the same manner as the main drawing; 
(e)  The approximate length and bearing of the exterior boundaries of the subdivision, such boundary to be indicated by a solid, heavy line; 
(f)  Location and names of adjacent subdivisions and the owners of adjoining parcels of unsubdivided land; 
(g)  Present village or county zoning on the property to be subdivided or resubdivided adjacent to the subdivision; 
(h)  Location, widths and names of all existing and platted streets, alleys, or other public ways and easements, railroad and utility rights-of-way, parks, playgrounds, school sites, public grounds, cemeteries, watercourses, drainage ditches, permanent buildings, bridges and other pertinent data as determined by the village engineer within one hundred feet of the proposed subdivision or property owner or controlled by the subdivider; 
(i)  The water surface elevations of adjoining lakes or streams at the date of the survey and the approximate high, normal and low water elevations of such lakes or streams. All elevations shall be referred to North American Vertical Datum 1988 (NAVD 88); 
(j)  Boundary of any floodplain and floodway areas and corresponding base flood elevation data as determined in Title 22; 
(k)  Layout and improved width of all new streets and rights-of-way, such as alleys, drainage ways, highways, unusual easements for sewers, water mains, and other public utilities; 
(l)  Location of and distance to nearest water and sanitary sewer mains and storm sewers or other drainage facilities to which the subdivider proposes to connect, showing the size of existing facilities; 
(m)  Approximate dimensions of lots; 
(n)  Building setback lines shall be shown as a "--" dashed line in accordance with the applicable zoning district; 
(o)  Approximate radii of all curves and lengths of tangents; 
(p)  Approximate location and area of any property proposed to be dedicated for public use or to be reserved by deed covenant for use of all property owners in the subdivision with the conditions, if any, of such dedication or reservation; 
(q)  Contours of vertical intervals of not more than two feet, with reference to the North American Vertical Datum 1988 (NAVD 88), or in more frequent intervals, if required by the village engineer, for land of unusual topography; 
(r)  All corporate boundary lines on or adjacent to the proposed subdivision; 
(s)  A statement near the owner's name, to read: 
    "PRELIMINARY PLAT, NOT TO BE RECORDED"; 
(t)  A table of the following information: Total acreage of subdivision, acreage of streets, total number of lots, average area of lots, minimum lot acreage, and acreage of public lands to be dedicated other than streets. The developer shall estimate the approximate number of people who will reside in the proposed development; 
(u)  A complete listing of all existing covenants which apply to the land to be subdivided, and a complete listing of all covenants which are proposed by the subdivider to apply to the subdivided land, also a set of bylaws setting forth the establishment and operation of the planned development insofar as the maintenance of the internal improvements and common grounds are concerned; 
(v)  Where there is an existing subdivision and this submittal is a resubdivision, a certified copy of existing subdivision plat shall be submitted; 
(w)  A statement signed by each and all: the land planner, engineer, surveyor, or other person preparing preliminary plat documents, that the plat meets the requirements of this article to the best of his ability and knowledge; 
(x)  A list of arrangements made to relieve the impact of the development on the school districts, park district, library district and the village; 
(y)  Distances between all buildings be shown; 
(z)  Distances between perimeter buildings and lot lines be shown; 
(aa)  Utility easement locations be shown; 
(bb)  All public improvements, including but not limited to, sidewalks, street lights, water mains, sanitary and storm sewer mains, and stormwater management facilities, shall be shown. 
    When the submission of a preliminary plat has been waived pursuant to Section 17.20.030(g) of this Title, such information as may be requested by the plan commission relative to the preliminary plat shall be shown on a separate sheet which shall be submitted with the final plat and be considered as part of the required documentation. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.030 - Construction plans of surface and underground improvements. 
    As required under Section 17.20.040 and Chapter 17.32 of this Title, construction plans shall be furnished as a part of the final plat. However, if only a portion of the plat is to be improved and submitted for final approval, construction plans and specifications need be prepared for such portion only. However, the entire area of the proposed subdivision as well as any additional area necessary in order to assure a proper design of facilities shall be the basis for design and be so indicated, in enough detail to allow for proper engineering review. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.040 - Final plat preparation generally. 
    A final plat of subdivided land shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat and shall meet the requirements specified in the following sections. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.050 - Materials for plans. 
    All plats shall be legibly prepared either manually or electronically as follows: 
(a)  On tracing cloth, Mylar or other suitable reproducible medium; 
(b)  With waterproof, nonfading black ink on a scale not more than one hundred feet to an inch. The scale used shall be indicated on the plat graphically in letters. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.060 - Map and engineering information. 
    The final plat shall show correctly on its face: 
(a)  The name or names of the owners or trust numbers (listing the names of the beneficiaries and their percentage in the trust) of the property; 
(b)  The name and seal with required statements of the registered land surveyor who prepared the plat and the date thereof. The following statement shall also be shown: 
(1)  That the subdivision is within one and one-half miles of a municipality that has a comprehensive plan, 
(2)  Whether or not part of the property covered by this plat or subdivision is situated within the special flood hazard area, i.e., floodplain; 
(c)  The exact legal description of the property subdivided; 
(d)  All monuments erected, corners and other points established in the field in their proper places. The material of which the monuments, corners, or other points are made shall be noted at the representation thereof or by legend; 
(e)  The exact length and bearing of the exterior boundaries, the boundary line of all blocks, public grounds, streets and alleys, and all lot lines, except that when the lines in any tier or lots are parallel it shall be sufficient to mark the bearings of the outer lines on one tier thereof; 
(f)  All lots consecutively numbered; 
(g)  The exact width and designated use for all easements, streets and alleys; 
(h)  Accurate boundaries and legal descriptions of any areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use, with the purposes indicated thereon, and of any area to be reserved by deed covenant for the common use of all property owners in the subdivision; 
(i)  A north arrow properly located thereon; 
(j)  Radius of curve and central angle shall be shown on all streets; 
(k)  A note by the surveyor stating whether arc or chord dimensions are shown on all curved lines; 
(l)  That the subdivision is in the corporate limits or within one and one-half miles of the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling; 
(m)  Building setback lines shall be shown as a "--" dashed line in accordance with the applicable zoning district. 
    When the submission of a preliminary plat has been waived pursuant to Section 17.20.030(g) of this Title, such information as may be requested by the plan commission relative to the preliminary plat shall be submitted with the final plat and be considered as part of the required documentation. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.070 - Name, location and position. 
    The name of the plat shall be printed thereon in prominent letters and shall not be a duplicate of the name of any plat previously recorded in the village of Wheeling, Illinois. The following information relating to the position and location of the subdivision shall be shown on the plat: 
(a)  The location of the subdivision by quarter section, section, township, range, and county noted immediately under the name given the subdivision; 
(b)  The exact location of the subdivision indicated by distances and bearings with reference to a corner or corners established in the United States public land survey; 
(c)  Where provisions are made for access from any subdivision to any lake or stream, the plat shall show the area over which access is provided to the lake or stream; 
(d)  The names of adjoining streets, state highways, and subdivisions shown in their proper location; 
(e)  Abutting street and state highway lines of adjoining plats shown in their proper location. The width of these streets and highways shall be given also; 
(f)  All public utility easements shall be specified on the plat. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.080 - Roads and public spaces. 
(a)  Names. The name of each road or street in the plat shall be printed thereon in prominent letters. 
(b)  Dedication. All lands dedicated to or reserved for a public use such as schools, parks, etc., shall be clearly marked "hereby dedicated or reserved for (specified) use." All right-of-ways dedicated to the village of Wheeling shall be so indicated. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.090 - Site conditions and topography. 
    The final plat shall also show all existing buildings and structures. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.24.100 - Documents to accompany final plat. 
(a)  Legibility. To entitle a final plat to be recorded, such certificates as are required by law shall be lettered or printed legibly with black durable ink or typed legibly with black ribbon. 
(b)  Covenants. All covenants shall be shown on the final plat, or in accompanying documents attached thereto; provided, however, that in all developments there must be covenants running with the land for all common areas or grounds. 
(c)  Surveyor's Certificate. Certification, with seal, by a registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him, that the monuments and markers thereon exist as located, and that all dimensions and details are correct. Surveyor's certificate must show certification by the surveyor that the subdivision is within the corporate limits of the village of Wheeling, and that the village has adopted an official plan. 
(d)  Street Dedication. Notarized certification, by the owner or owners, of the dedication of streets and other dedicated areas for a specific public use. 
(e)  Approvals. Approvals by county and state authorities as required, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Subsequent to approval of a final plat by the plan commission, but prior to approval of the final plat by the village board of trustees, the subdivider shall provide a copy of the receipted property tax bill for the most recent tax installment. This provision shall apply to plats of subdivision, plats of subdivision vacation, and plats of dedication; 
(2)  If the subdivision is situated within five hundred fifty feet of any surface drain or watercourse serving a tributary area of six hundred forty acres or more, prior to recording the final plat, the subdivider shall submit a copy of the approved plat to the Illinois Department of Natural Resources, Office of Water Resources for its flood hazard report; 
(f)  Improvements. The subdivider shall sign a statement setting forth improvements he will make in the subdivision and agreement that such improvements shall be at his own expense, including all costs of inspections by the village during construction. 
(g)  Engineering Specifications. Specifications and engineering construction drawings, including profiles, cross-sections and details as applicable, of all public improvements. Elevations shall be referred to the established North American Vertical Datum 1988 (NAVD 88). 
(h)  Engineer's Statement. A statement signed by the village engineer approving the specifications, drawings and estimates of cost. 
(i)  Bond. Surety bond or including: 
(1)  United States government obligations and obligations of which both the principal and interest are guaranteed unconditionally by the United States government; 
(2)  Bonds of federal land banks; 
(3)  Bond or debentures of national mortgage associations established by or under the National Housing Act; 
(4)  Notes or bonds secured by mortgage insured by the Federal Housing Administrator or debentures issued pursuant to the provisions of the National Housing Act; 
(5)  Mortgages or trust deeds running to the benefit of the village on real estate situated in the state of Illinois; or cash, as set forth in Chapter 17.20 of this Title. Surety must be supplied to the village engineer prior to submission of the final plat to the village board of trustees for approval; 
(j)  Management Organization Structure and Bylaws. Management organization structure and bylaws where planned development is being submitted wherein individual dwelling units may be sold to the occupants. 
(k)  Temporary Buildings. A temporary building for model apartments, condominiums, townhouses and/or office space in only a planned unit development may be permitted, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The location of the temporary building shall be approved by the plan commission at the time of the submission of the final plat. The final plat of the planned development shall be approved prior to issuance of any building permit for a temporary building; 
(2)  Temporary buildings may be located by the plan commission without regard to setback requirements; 
(3)  The temporary building shall be removed upon completion of the project, but not to exceed two years from the date of issuance of the building permit for such building. After two years, the building must be removed by the owner or developer, or they must petition the plan commission for additional time within which the building will remain. The plan commission shall have complete jurisdiction as to granting the additional time without a public hearing, after a written report from the director of community development as to the condition of the building has been submitted to the plan commission; 
(4)  Regular building permit fees shall be charged for the temporary building; 
(5)  Any temporary building shall not be used for residential occupancy, but only for temporary models and/or sales or construction offices in connection with such project; 
(6)  Sewer and water shall be connected to the temporary building; 
(7)  The temporary building must have approval from both the fire department and community development department prior to final approval by the plan commission; 
(8)  The cost of the subsequent removal of the temporary building shall be considered when computing the amount of requisite performance bond. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.26 - IMPACT FEES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section A of Ord. No 4526, passed May 17, 2010, amended Ch. 17.26 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 17.26 was titled Park, School and Library Donations, was comprised of §§ 17.26.010-17.26.130, and derived from Ord. No. 3569. 

17.26.010 - Impact fees required. 
    As a condition of approval of an annexation, a final plat of subdivision, or of a final plat of a planned unit development, each owner, subdivider or developer is required to provide a cash contribution in accordance with the criteria and formula set forth herein to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the development for the following purposes: park and recreational sites and/or improvements, school sites and/or improvements, and library services and/or improvements. In lieu of a cash contribution, the owner, subdivider, or developer may make an actual land dedication, or a combination cash and land, subject to the final determination of the village board, as described in this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.020 - General purpose 
    The expected delay in reassessing the property taxes to correspond with the development that occurs on a given property is one year. Therefore, the intent of the fees described in this chapter is to provide funding to each entity to offset the cost of providing services to the residents in the development for one year. The fees for each entity are therefore directly related to the projected population of the development, based on the number, size, and type of the housing units to be constructed. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.030 - Donation process 
    Whenever an owner, subdivider, or developer seeks to annex land into the village, seeks approval of a final plat of subdivision, or seeks approval of a planned unit development: 
(a)  The owner, subdivider, or developer shall make a written request to the village's community development department for an invoice of the amount of fees owed pursuant to Chapter 17.26. 
(b)  The village shall timely respond to the owner's, subdivider's or developer's request pursuant to Section 17.26.030(a), using the formulas described in Chapter 17.26, with an invoice setting forth the amount of the required impact fee. 
(c)  The owner, subdivider or developer shall timely pay in full the required cash contribution to the village's community development department. In no case shall full payment be made more than thirty days after the developer receives each invoice set forth in Section 17.26.030(b). 
(d)  The village shall not approve any annexation, final plat of subdivision, planned unit development, or building permit related thereto, prior to receipt of full and final payment of the invoice set forth in Section 17.26.030(c). 
(e)  In the event that an owner, subdivider or developer proceeds with an annexation or planned unit development project with multiple buildings, and a request for a building permit is made to the village, the owner, subdivider or developer shall be responsible for payment of a proportionate share of the total fee under the terms of Section 17.26.030 prior to the issuance of a building permit by the village. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010)
