(d)  Objections to Population Projections. In the event an owner, subdivider or developer files a written objection to the table of estimated ultimate population listed in this section, the owner, subdivider or developer shall submit his or her own demographic study showing the estimated additional population to be generated from the subdivision or planned unit development; and in that event final determination of the density formula to be used in such calculations shall be made by the village board at its sole discretion. 
(e)  Fair Market Value of Land. Several formulas described in this Chapter use the fair market value of land as a factor in determining required impact fees. The fair market value of an acre of land is interpreted to mean land that is improved as described in this chapter that would be suitable to be dedicated as a park/recreation and school sites. The fair market value of such improved land in and surrounding the village is one hundred five thousand dollars per acre and such figure shall be used in making any calculation herein. The village board may, at its sole discretion, adopt a revised fair market value. 
(f)  Minimum Threshold for Requiring Fee. The impact fees described within this Chapter shall be applied to any new construction, building modification, subdivision, or planned unit development that causes a net increase of two bedrooms on the subject property. 
(g)  Maximum Fee Per Unit Per Entity. The maximum impact fee due to any single taxing body shall be two thousand dollars per unit. Any per-unit fee that exceeds this amount as the base formulas are periodically updated may be reduced accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.050 - Library district fee. 
(a)  Requirement. The ultimate density of a proposed development shall bear a direct relationship upon the cash contribution required. 
(b)  Formula. The library district fee shall be determined by multiplying the total number of dwelling units in the proposed development by the product of the population per dwelling unit multiplied by the per capita cost of providing library services as determined by the library district. 
(c)  Per Capita Cost of Services. The current cost of services is two hundred forty-eight dollars per person. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.060 - School district fees. 
(a)  Requirement. The ultimate number of students to be generated by a subdivision or planned unit development shall bear directly upon the required impact fee. 
(b)  Formula. The school district fees shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of the estimated children to be served in each such school classification (see Section 17.26.040(c), Population Projections) over the maximum recommended number of students to be served in each such school classification as stated herein (see Table 17.26.060(c) below), and then applying such ratio to the minimum recommended number of acres for a school site of each such school classification as stated herein (see Table 17.26.060(c) below). The product thereof shall be the acres of land deemed needed to have sufficient land for school sites to serve the estimated increased children in each school classification. That acreage shall then be multiplied by the current fair market value of land as described in this Chapter (Section 17.26.040(e), Fair Market Value of Land). 
(c)  School Classifications and Size of School Site. School classifications and size of school sites within the village shall be determined in accordance with the following table: 
School Site Size and

(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.070 - Park district fee. 
(a)  Requirement. The ultimate density of a proposed development shall bear directly upon the required impact fee. 
(b)  Formula. The fee shall be based on a requirement of 7.45 acres of active recreation as described in Table 17.26.070(c), per one thousand of ultimate population (see Section 17.26.040(c), Population Projections). That acreage shall then be multiplied by the current fair market value of land as described in this Chapter (Section 17.26.040(e), Fair Market Value of Land).

(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.080 - Land dedications in lieu of impact fees. 
(a)  Procedure for Requesting a Land Dedication in Lieu of Impact Fees. In order for an owner, subdivider or developer to contribute land in lieu of required impact fees, the entity receiving the land donation must provide written authorization to the village prior to final plat or final planned unit development approval. Any such written authorization provided to the village shall be signed and notarized and include a detailed description of the land to be dedicated (location, dimensions, intended use, etc.) as well as language clearly approving the dedication as well as the portion of the required impact fee that is to be replaced by the land dedication. 
    Upon receipt of the request by the developer and authorization of the entity to receive a land contribution, the village board shall then consider the request and may, at their sole discretion, approve a resolution authorizing a land dedication in lieu of all, or some portion, of the required impact fees. 
(b)  Philosophy of Acceptance. The land or site for school, park, and recreation land dedication must be suitable for the purpose for which it is intended. Land set aside by developers for schools, parks, recreation and conservation purposes shall not include what has been left over after residential, commercial, industrial and other development has been taken for prime land. The following requirements shall apply: 
(1)  Topography and Grading. The slope, topography, geology, grading and ground cover of the dedicated site must be suitable for its intended purposes and conform to design standards established by the village engineer. Grading on sites shall not differ greatly from surrounding land. 
(2)  Improved Sites. All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of electrical, water, sewer and streets (including enclosed drainage and curb and gutter) as applicable to the location of the site, or acceptable provision made therefore. The sidewalk and parkway improvements will be installed before final acceptance of public improvements. 
(3)  Land Conveyance by Warranty Deed. The following requirements shall be provided prior to acceptance of any land to be dedicated or donated: 
a.  A current survey; 
b.  A title insurance commitment, acceptable to the village, in an amount no less than the fair market value of the land as determined by the village; 
c.  A warranty deed; 
d.  A written statement from the grantor or developer stating that they shall be responsible for paying the real estate taxes on the land until an exemption is obtained; 
e.  A phase I environmental study indicating that the land is free from environmental contamination. 
(c)  Required Land for School Sites. 
(1)  Location. The comprehensive school plan and/or the standards adopted by the affected school district shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. Variances in land uses could, however, change the locations and/or number of sites. All elementary, junior high and senior high schools shall be located to serve the greatest number of children possible within walking distance. Access shall be available on fully improved streets. Adjacent land use to the school site must be considered. School sites shall not serve as buffers between residential-commercial and residential-industrial use. 
(2)  The amount of land to be dedicated shall be as described in Table 17.26.060(c). The school district may, at its discretion, authorize an alternative amount of land dedication, provided that the dedication meets the requirements of this section. 
(3)  Whenever planning is done jointly with the park district for a school-park site, the school-owned portion shall comply with the specifications contained herein. 
(d)  Required Land for Park, Recreation, and Conservation Sites. 
(1)  Active areas shall be defined as those areas specifically adapted and planned for a wide range of physical activity such as group games, physical education, sports, and athletics. Facilities usually include, but are not limited to, playfields, game courts, rinks, ball diamonds, pools, tennis courts, community centers, and play apparatus. Passive areas shall be defined as settings designed for informal unscheduled activity based on individual, family, or group interests such as picnicking, nature lore, horticultural displays, hiking and biking, historical programs, and camping. Facilities may include, but not be limited to, landscape displays, rest pavilions, preschool tot lots, vest pocket parks for senior citizens, woodland trails, outdoor education centers, botanical gardens, hobby areas for model planes, and kite flying. 
(2)  Location. The comprehensive park and recreation plan and/or the "Standards by Types of Recreation and Park Areas," as adopted by the Wheeling or Prospect Heights park district, shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. A central location which will serve equally the entire development is most desirable and whenever feasible, the site shall be in close proximity to elementary school sites. In large developments these sites can be located throughout the development according to established standards for park area distances. 
(3)  Credit for Private Open Spaces and Recreation Areas. 
a.  When an owner, subdivider or developer provides their open space for recreation areas and facilities in their development, it has the effect of reducing the demand for local public recreational services. Depending on the size of the development, a portion of the park and recreation area in subdivisions or planned unit developments may, at the option of the village board, be provided in the form of private open space in lieu of dedicated public open space. The extent of same shall be determined by the village board, based upon the needs of the projected residents and in conformance to the total park and recreation land for the general area. 
b.  In general, a substitution of private open space for dedicated parks will imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of recreational facilities, including equipment by the developer as part of his obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of facilities to be installed, must be approved by the village board, and before any credit is given for private recreation areas, the owner, subdivider or developer must guarantee that these private recreation areas will be permanently maintained for such use by the execution of the appropriate legal documents. Private swimming clubs are included in this provision. When an adjustment for private recreation areas is warranted, it will be necessary to compute the total parkland dedication that would have been required from the subdivision or planned unit development and then subtract the credit to be given. 
(4)  The amount of land to be dedicated shall be as described in Table 17.26.070(c). The school district may, at its discretion, authorize an alternative amount of land dedication, provided that the dedication meets the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.090 - Reservation of additional land. 
    Where the comprehensive plan for the standards of the village calls for a larger amount of park and recreational land or school sites in a particular subdivision or planned unit development that the developer is required to dedicate, the land needed beyond the developer's contribution shall be reserved for subsequent purchase by the village or other public entity designated by the village; provided, that such acquisition is made within one year from the date of approval of the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.100 - Annexation. 
    The policy of cash contributions or land dedications in lieu thereof as set forth in this chapter shall also apply to annexations of any land to the village and provisions therefore shall be governing all lands within the village and shall be incorporated in any preannexation agreement governing such land. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
17.26.110 - Indemnification. 
    Prior to distribution of any funds by the village under Chapter 17.26, the affected park districts, library districts and school districts shall be required, as a condition of receiving the donations provided for in Chapter 17.26, to give to the village a written hold harmless and indemnification agreement, to the village's satisfaction. The hold harmless and indemnification agreement shall indemnify the village from any loss, claims, costs (including reasonable attorney fees), and causes of actions of every kind incurred by the village as a result, either directly or indirectly, of the enactment of this chapter, or the administration or enforcement thereof, including any loss, claims and causes of actions of every kind so incurred as a result of a lawsuit brought or threatened by any subdivider or developer including, but not limited to, claims or threatened claims related to the distribution or expenditure of such funds by the park districts, library districts and school districts. If the village is sued by any subdivider or developer as a result, directly or indirectly, of the enactment or operation of this chapter, the affected park district, library district or school district may, at its option, undertake the defense thereof, but all costs and expenses of such defense, including attorney fees, shall then be borne by the affected park district, library district or school district. 
(Ord. No. 4526, § A, 5-17-2010) 
Chapter 17.28 - MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS AND GENERAL DESIGN STANDARDS* 

17.28.010 - Conformance generally. 
    In laying out a subdivision, the subdivider shall conform to: 
(1)  The zoning ordinance and all other applicable ordinances of the village of Wheeling, including floodplain regulations; 
(2)  The official plan and map, including sector plans if any, as amended, of the village of Wheeling; 
(3)  Applicable laws, rules and regulations of the state of Illinois and Cook and/or Lake County, and duly constituted agencies thereof; 
(4)  In all instances where a requirement of this Title is similar to or in conflict with other provisions of the village ordinances, county ordinances, rules or regulations, the most restrictive shall apply and prevail. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.020 - Streets generally. 
(a)  Providing. Public streets shall be provided for convenient access to all property within the subdivision. No private street or thoroughfare shall be permitted except in case of drives in planned developments where maintenance is the responsibility of the association or management organization of such development. 
(b)  Conformity with Official Map. The street layout of the subdivision shall be in general conformity with the official map for the most advantageous development of adjoining areas in the entire neighborhood. The streets shall be designed and located in relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions and natural terrain features, such as streams and existing tree growth, to provide public convenience and safety and in their appropriate relation to the proposed use of the land to be served by such streets. 
(c)  State and County Regulations. All streets in a subdivision abutting a state or county highway shall meet all the requirements of the state or county regulations pertaining thereto as well as meeting the requirements of this Title. Where such requirements are in conflict, the more restrictive shall apply. 
(d)  Width and Location. Whenever a tract to be subdivided embraces any part of a public street so designated on the official map, such part of such street shall be platted by the subdivision at the location and width indicated on the plan. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.030 - Street classification. 
    Major, secondary, and collector streets as classified in this section shall be as shown and designated on the official map. 
(a)  Major Street. Those state, county and village designated routes which provide continuity of travel and freedom from hazards and congestion necessary for interregional and village traffic movement. 
(b)  Secondary Street. Those routes so designated by the village to be of importance in intravillage traffic movement and necessary to provide easy access to neighboring communities. 
(c)  Collector Street. Those primary streets within the neighborhood unit providing a reasonable alignment coupled with an attractive pavement which will act to collect traffic from minor streets for travel to secondary and major streets. 
(d)  Minor Street. Those streets whose prime function is to give access to abutting property. They are not intended to carry heavy through traffic and are designed to discourage such movement. 
(e)  Marginal Access Street. The minor streets which serve to control access to major thoroughfares and permit development of lands adjacent to high speed and high capacity highways. Their prime function is property access. 
(f)  Drives. Private roadways within a planned development providing internal access from bordering public streets to buildings and parking areas in the development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.040 - Street continuations. 
    Provision shall be made so that all proposed streets shall have a direct connection with or be continuous and in line with existing, planned, or platted streets with which they are to connect, except in case of planned development where internal drives are a part of overall development plan and where a smooth flow of traffic around the development is possible. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.050 - Extending streets to boundaries. 
    Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions, or unless, in the opinion of the plan commission, such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with the existing layout or the most advantageous future development of adjacent tracts. Cul-de-sacs not over four hundred feet in length will be approved when necessitated by topography or other conditions or factors. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.060 - Street grades. 
    The grade of major and secondary streets shall be as required in the official Wheeling standards which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.070 - Horizontal curves. 
    There shall be a minimum centerline radius of six hundred feet for major streets, three hundred feet for secondary streets and one hundred fifty feet for all other streets, except for drives. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.080 - Vertical curves. 
    Vertical curves shall be as required in the official Wheeling standards which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.085 - Compliance. 
    Subdivisions shall comply with the zoning ordinance and all other applicable ordinances of the village of Wheeling, including floodplain regulations and all stormwater management as required within the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.090 - Street tangents. 
    A tangent at least one hundred feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on major, secondary and collector streets. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.100 - Street names. 
    New street names shall not duplicate the names of existing streets, but streets that are continuations of others already in existence and named shall bear the name of the existing streets. All new streets shall be given a name acceptable to the plan commission and approved by fire and police departments. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.110 - Cul-de-sac streets. 
    Streets designed to have one end permanently closed shall not exceed four hundred feet in length and shall terminate in a turnaround. A turnaround shall have a right-of-way not less than one hundred twenty feet in diameter and a paved roadway turnaround of ninety feet in diameter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.120 - Dead-end streets. 
    Dead-end streets are prohibited, except where a street is to be projected into the adjacent property upon future development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.130 - Half-streets. 
    Half-streets shall not be permitted except where they may be necessary to comply with the major or secondary street plan as shown in the official map. When a subdivision is adjacent to a previously dedicated half-street, the other half of the street shall be dedicated by the subdivider. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.140 - Intersections. 
(a)  Jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five feet shall not be permitted. Where streets intersect major streets, their alignment shall be continuous; 
(b)  Angles. Streets shall intersect in a manner to insure safe traffic flow, preferably at right angles, but in no case shall the centerlines of two streets intersect with an acute angle of less than sixty degrees. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.150 - Alleys. 
(a)  Commercial and Industrial Districts. Alleys may be provided in commercial and industrial districts, where no other provision is made for service access. All loading and parking shall be off-street and shall be consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(b)  Residential Areas. Alleys shall not be approved in residential areas unless exceptional circumstances prevail. 
(c)  Width. Where alleys are provided, they shall conform to the official map, but in no case shall they have a right-of-way less than thirty feet wide. 
(d)  Dead-end Alleys. Dead-end alleys are prohibited. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.160 - Streets parallel to right-of-ways. 
    Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad or limited access highway right-of-way, the plan commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in residential districts, or for parking, commercial, or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grade and possible future grade separations. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.170 - Reserve strips. 
    Reserve strips controlling access to streets or underground utilities shall be prohibited except where their control is placed with the village under conditions approved by the plan commission, or where they are a part of planned development, and control is vested in the management of such development under rules and bylaws submitted with the planned development plans. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.180 - Public use facilities and areas. 
(a)  Stormwater Runoff. In addition to providing for streets, alleys and access ways and easements for public facilities and utilities, provision shall be made for the dedication or reservation of such stormwater or floodwater runoff channels and basins, park, playground, school ground and other public grounds as may be reasonably required by the plan commission to conform to the principles set forth in the official map which shall be a part of the comprehensive plan of the village, and this Title. Provision shall be made for maintenance in perpetuity for all public facilities, either through private or public ownership. 
(b)  Miscellaneous Public Land. In addition to subsection (a) of this section, any public grounds designated on the official map which lie within a proposed subdivision and which have not been otherwise provided for shall be reserved for the particular public use or uses so designated on the official map for a period of twelve months from the date of recording of the final plat or subdivision. 
(c)  Designation on Plat. Such dedicated or reserved area shall be designated in the plat of subdivision by the proper words of "to be dedicated" or "reservation," designating the public body and its use to which the land is dedicated or reserved. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.190 - Block and lot layout. 
(1)  Length and Width Generally. The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be such as are appropriate for the locality and the type of development contemplated, but block length in residential areas shall not exceed twelve hundred sixty feet nor be less than four hundred feet nor have less than sufficient width to provide for two tiers of lots of appropriate depth between street lines. 
(2)  Walkways. Pedestrian walkways not less than ten feet wide may be required by the plan commission through the center of blocks more than nine hundred feet long where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation and/or other community facilities. 
(3)  Lots in General. The following regulations apply: 
(A)  Lot dimensions shall conform to the requirements of the appropriate zoning classification of the Wheeling zoning ordinance, but in no case shall a lot have an average depth of less than one hundred feet; 
(B)  Residential lots which abut upon major streets shall also abut upon a minor street. Vehicular access to such lots shall be to the minor street only; 
(C)  The lot shall be of sufficient depth to provide for adequate space to meet the appropriate zoning ordinance requirements for yards, off-street parking and loading, but lot depths in residential areas shall not exceed three times their average width; 
(D)  These provisions are not applicable to planned developments when a harmonious grouping of buildings is the design criteria and when the bulk requirements of the applicable codes are met. 
(4)  Side Lot Line Angle. Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines. 
(5)  Boundary Lines. Lots shall not cross municipal or county boundary lines. 
(6)  Double Frontage Lots. Double frontage lots shall be prohibited except where necessary to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries as in subsection (3) of this section. Whenever lots back up to a major street, suitable screen planting shall be provided by the subdivider along the major streets. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.200 - Easements. 
    Easements where required shall be provided along a lot line and normally centered upon the lot line. Evidence shall be furnished the plan commission that easements, and any easement provisions to be incorporated on the plat or in deeds, have been reviewed by the individual utility companies or the organization responsible for furnishing the service involved. Where easements will be used for rear or side lot drainage, they shall be a minimum of twelve feet wide and normally centered. All easements shall also be considered and noted as both utility and drainage easements. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.210 - Drainage and floodplain provisions. 
(1)  Study. Every proposed subdivision shall make provision for adequate surface drainage to prevent flooding. The provisions shall be based upon a study prepared by the subdivider's engineer of the entire area tributary to streams, channels, or drainage ways in the subdivision. This study, upon which design of the storm sewer and drainage system will be based, shall consist of at least the following: 
(A)  Analysis of area tributaries affecting the subdivision, including area, topography, drainage, rainfall intensity and frequency, runoff and flooding; 
(B)  A topographic map of the subdivision, indicating any floodplain and floodway areas and the corresponding base flood elevation data as determined in Title 22; 
(C)  A report of the basis of the design of the proposed sewers, open channels, and controlled flow detention basins proposed for the subdivision. 
(2)  Streets as Channels. The proposed drainage system and outlet of the subdivision shall be designed so that it will not fail to function if a base flood should occur. Streets shall be designed where possible to act as open channels, with positive drainage toward the major watercourse or channel in the area. 
(3)  Right-of-Way Provision for Major Watercourse. Each major river, drainageway or stream as shown on the most current flood boundary and floodway map including but not limited to the Des Plaines River, McDonald Creek, Buffalo Creek, Wheeling Drainage Ditch, which borders or traverses the proposed subdivision shall be provided with a stormwater easement or right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of the watercourse and of such further width as will be adequate to accommodate observed, computed, or anticipated flood flows and heights and will provide access along the channel for operation of channel operation and maintenance equipment. In any case, the minimum width of such a stream right-of-way shall not be less than forty feet on each side of the centerline of such major river drainageway or stream. If a major watercourse traverses through a subdivision, the watercourse shall be improved by the subdivider in compliance with plans and specifications on file in the village engineer's office. The improvements shall be guaranteed by surety as provided in Section 17.20.060 of this Title. 
(4)  Right-of-Way for Minor Watercourse. Each minor drainageway, channel, or watercourse which borders or traverses the proposed subdivision shall be maintained as open channels with a stormwater easement or right-of-way of adequate width to accommodate observed, computed, or anticipated runoff and flood flows. In any case, the minimum width of these channel rights-of-way shall be not less than twenty feet on each side of the centerline of such minor drainageway channel or watercourse. Upon indication of adequacy of design, as evidenced by the studies provided for in subsection (1) of this section, the upper reaches of such drainageways may be enclosed as a part of the storm system. If a minor watercourse traverses through a subdivision, the watercourse shall be improved by the subdivider in compliance with the approved plans and specifications on file in the village engineer's office. The improvements shall be guaranteed by surety as provided in Section 17.20.060 of this Title. 
(5)  Side Lot Drainage Easements. Where the drainage plan for a proposed subdivision required rear or side lot drainage easements, such easements shall be centered on the lot lines and shall be a minimum of twelve feet in width. With the exception of utility poles, no structures, landscaping (except for grass), or landfill shall be placed in these drainage easements. 
(6)  Floodplain Regulations. All floodplain areas of a subdivision are subject to the regulations of the floodplain ordinance, Title 22. 
(7)  Retention Basins. When a subdivision drainage plan proposes use of retention basins or ponds, which are to be dedicated for public use, provision shall be made that a public access be possible through extension of a street stub to connect the facility to a public street. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.220 - Natural features. 
    In all subdivisions due regard shall be given to the preservation of natural features. Streets and easements shall be located where they will not interfere with large trees, watercourses or historical or other similar community assets which, if preserved, would add attractiveness and value to the subdivision and village. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.230 - Standard requirements relating to parks, playgrounds, school sites and other public grounds. 
    Whenever a final plat of subdivision or part thereof, is submitted for approval to the corporate authorities, it shall have designated thereon the reservation of either a school site, park site, playground site or other public ground site as indicated on the official map in conformance with the following standard requirements relating to the size of such parks, playgrounds, school sites and other public grounds: 
(1) Elementary school site 10 acres (2) Junior high school site 30 acres (3) High school site 40 acres (4) Park sites 1 acre per 100 persons utilizing the property (5) Playground sites 1 acre per 100 persons utilizing the property (6) Public grounds (for use by governmental agencies) 25 acres  
    The location of these various sites shall be as indicated on the official map. 
    The above requirements are minimum standard requirements and may be increased or decreased as the corporate authorities having jurisdiction of such use may determine. 
    The corporate authority having jurisdiction of such use, be it a school board, park board or other authority, may waive the reservation of the school, park, playground or public land site by depositing a written waiver with the Wheeling plan commission. 
    The sites on the final plat of subdivision, shall be marked "Reserved For School Purposes" or "Reserved For Park Purposes" or "Reserved For Playground Purposes" or "Reserved For Public Grounds," as the case may be. In the body of the plat for subdivision, a statement shall be made that the area "Reserved For -" is reserved pursuant to the statute but is not in any way dedicated, and that in the event no action is taken within the statutory one year period by the corporate authority reserving the site to acquire the site by purchase or condemnation, the reservation shall become void. 
    Whenever a final plat of subdivision or part thereof has been approved by the corporate authorities as complying with the official map and there is designated therein a school site, park site or other public land, the corporate authorities having jurisdiction of such use, be it a school board, park board or other authority, such authority shall acquire the land so designated by purchase or commence proceedings to acquire such land by condemnation within one year from the date of approval of such plat; and if it does not do so within such period of one year, the land so designated may then be used by the owners thereof in any other manner consistent with this Title, including the official map and the zoning ordinance of the municipality. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.240 - Single-story buildings. 
    A plat of subdivision or planned development which contains single-story buildings on multiple-zoned land shall not be approved by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.260 - Storage of maintenance equipment. 
    If any maintenance equipment is stored on any planned development in the village of Wheeling, then such planned development should provide adequate storage facilities for the maintenance equipment. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.280 - Animal walk. 
    If any planned development in the village of Wheeling allows the residents thereof to maintain pets on the premises, then an animal walk shall be provided for the pets. The location and dimensions of such animal walk shall be approved by the plan commission of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.28.300 - Fence requirements. 
    All planned developments are subject to the fence requirements as set out in Section 19.12.100 of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.32 - MINIMUM DESIGN STANDARDS- INSTALLATION PROCEDURE 

17.32.010 - Insurance. 
    The party initiating or installing any of the improvements in this Chapter shall, prior to the installation hereof, furnish the village a certificate of insurance to protect and save the village harmless from any and all claims, expenses, liability or judgments, in any manner resulting from, arising out of, of incident to the making of any of the aforesaid improvement or the granting of permission to so make. Such party, naming such party and the village as the insured, shall cause a policy of insurance to be issued, in accordance with the village of Wheeling's insurance requirements, providing minimum public liability coverage in the amount of one million dollars for injury or death to one person, one million dollars for injury or death to more than one person in any one accident, and property damage coverage in any amount of not less than five hundred thousand dollars. All such policies of insurance shall be approved by the village board with the advice of the village attorney prior to the installation of any of the aforesaid improvements. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.020 - Required specifications designated-Directions for preparation. 
    All plans shall be complete enough so as not to require major field changes or redesigning of the improvements as they are constructed. Should revisions to the approved plans become necessary, such revision request shall be submitted to the village engineer and receive his approval prior to their construction. 
    Simultaneous with the filing of the final plat, eight sets of construction plans and specifications, prepared by a professional engineer registered in Illinois and bearing his seal, shall be furnished to the village engineer in accordance with the provisions of this section for the following subdivision improvements: 
(a)  Street pavements, including cross-sections of the proposed streets and as applicable on the adjoining property; 
(b)  Sanitary sewerage system; 
(c)  Storm drainage including sewers, stormwater management, facilities including retention/detention basins, if any; 
(d)  Water supply and distribution, including all fittings and appurtenances; 
(e)  A street lighting plan submitted on a separate drawing; 
(f)  Sidewalks; 
(g)  Curb and gutter; 
(h)  Public utility locations; 
(i)  Street signs, guardrails, etc.; 
(j)  Street trees and landscaping; 
(k)  Grading and soil erosion and sedimentation control; 
(l)  Include a demolition plan, if necessary, and tree preservation plan; 
(m)  Whatever other plan sheets that may be necessary to the proposed project, as determined by the village engineer. 
    Construction drawings shall be made on standard twenty-four inches by thirty-six inches plan and/or plan and profile sheets to a minimum horizontal scale of one inch equals fifty feet and a maximum vertical scale of one inch equals five feet on which are shown existing conditions and proposed construction. Eight copies of the final plat must be submitted as part of this submittal. The village reserves the right to have any material tested by a testing laboratory of its choice. The testing may be done prior to construction or after the material is in place. The cost of any testing ordered by the village shall be borne by the developer or subdivider. The developer or subdivider shall be responsible for providing full-time professional inspection of the work by the design engineer. Inspection conducted by the village in no way relieves the developer or contractor of his responsibility for the quality of the completed work. 
    Immediately upon completion of all the improvements, three complete, full sets of plans showing the improvements as built, shall be supplied to the village engineer for review by the subdivider or developer. The subdivider's or developer's engineer shall be responsible for coordinating and supervising the correction of any work not meeting the approval of the village. The developer shall cooperate with the village on all matters concerning the improvements. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.025 - Permits. 
(a)  Prior to commencing any work covered by the plans as designated in this section, all necessary permits shall be obtained from the appropriate permitting agency; 
(b)  Furthermore, for all developments requiring a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit, the applicant shall submit a notice of intent (NOI) to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency (IEPA) and shall comply with the requirements of the NPDES permit. The applicant shall provide the village with a copy of the NOI submitted to the IEPA; 
(c)  As required by the village engineer, a preconstruction conference shall be conducted prior to commencing any site related construction activities. 
(Ord. 4149 § 1, 2006) 
17.32.030 - Construction and inspection. 
(a)  Authorization to Begin Work. Prior to starting any of the work covered by the plans approved as designated in Section 17.32.020 of this Chapter, written authorization to start the work shall be obtained from the village engineer, upon receipt of all necessary permits and in accordance with construction methods approved by the village engineer. 
(b)  Inspections and Reports. All improvements shall be subject to inspection by duly authorized village inspectors, both during the course of construction and after construction is completed. The contractor shall provide for reasonable test and proof of quality of materials as requested by the inspector. Upon due cause, the village inspector or engineer may require that work be suspended. Due cause includes weather conditions, failure of design engineer to provide full-time inspection, questionable materials of construction, methods of construction or nonadherence to specifications and drawings. Failure to stop work upon the order of the village inspector or engineer shall constitute a violation of this Title. The village inspector shall prepare and submit to the village engineer or director of public works reports stating progress of work and giving his findings as to quality of materials and workmanship. He shall call attention to any circumstances that entail departure from drawings and specification. When an improvement has been completed, he shall prepare a summary report. 
(c)  Responsibility of Subdivider. Approval by the inspector or absence of inspection shall in no way relieve the subdivider of full responsibility for adherence by this contractor to specifications. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.040 - As built plans. 
    Upon completion of all public improvements and prior to tentative acceptance of such improvements, the subdivider shall make or cause to be made complete and accurate drawings showing the actual location of all valves, manholes, stubs, sewer and water mains, and such other facilities as the village engineer shall require. These drawings shall bear the signature and seal of a licensed professional engineer registered in the state of Illinois. The presentation of this map shall be tentative approval of the improvements and release of the surety bond assuring their completion. Receipt of these drawings shall initiate the village's tentative acceptance inspection procedure. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.050 - Survey monuments. 
    All permanent and other monuments shall be required as described in Chapter 17.36 of this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.060 - Acceptance of public improvements. 
(a)  Tentative Acceptance. Prior to recommending tentative acceptance appropriate televising of underground utilities, i.e., sanitary sewer and storm sewer if necessary will be required. Granting approval by the president and board of trustees of tentative acceptance of the public improvements does not constitute final acceptance of the improvements. The date of approval of tentative acceptance establishes the beginning of the required one year guarantee period of the public improvements. Final acceptance will not be granted until one year after the date of tentative acceptance, provided all the improvements have been successfully maintained, operating properly and meet with the approval of the village. 
(b)  Final Acceptance. Prior to recommending final acceptance appropriate televising of underground utilities, i.e., sanitary sewer and storm sewer if necessary may be required as determined by the village engineer. Granting final acceptance of the public improvements constructed in accordance with this Title for ownership as well as operation and maintenance purposes shall be after successful completion of the guarantee period covered by the guarantee surety and by enactment of a formal resolution of the president and board of trustees. However, the normal operating costs of the pumping stations, street lights, etc., shall be assumed by the village when put in operation, upon being tentatively accepted subject to the guarantee. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.070 - Design standards-Streets. 
    It is recognized that traditional methods of suburban development and street layout have resulted in limited opportunities for pedestrian as well as bicycling traffic to move about freely within the community. Therefore, consideration shall be given to the incorporation within the design of necessary walkways and bicycle paths in order to provide a systematic cross-access for pedestrian and cyclist activities. Included within this requirement shall also be adequate provisions for parking and storage of bicycles, such as bike racks. 
    Pavement widths shall be measured back to back of curbs in subsections (a) through (f) of this section. 
(a)  Major Streets. Major streets shall have a right-of-way width as established by the official village plan, but in no case less than one hundred feet, a fifty-one foot pavement width, as described in Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. The plan commission may require a landscaped or grassed median of at least four feet in width, if it so desires in specific cases; 
(b)  Secondary Streets. Secondary streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less than eighty feet, a pavement width of fifty-one feet as described in Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter; 
(c)  Collector Streets. Collector streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less than sixty-six feet, a pavement width of thirty-nine feet, as described in Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter; 
(d)  Minor Streets. Minor streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less than sixty-six feet, a pavement width of thirty feet, as described in Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter; The right-of-way width of minor streets in planned developments may be reduced by village board approval; 
(e)  Marginal Access Streets. Marginal access streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less than forty feet, a pavement width of thirty feet, as described in Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter; 
(f)  Cul-de-sac. Cul-de-sacs shall meet all the requirements for a minor street and, in addition, shall provide a turnaround as required in Section 17.28.110 of this Title, and as described in Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.080 - Design standards-Alleys. 
    The installation, construction and design of all alley pavements shall be in accordance with the requirements of the village engineer. The width of such pavement shall be not less than twenty feet, with a right-of-way width of thirty feet. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.090 - Design standards-Curbs. 
    No street shall be paved hereafter unless provision is made for the concurrent installation of concrete curbing along each side edge of the pavement. The type of curbing shall be designated by the village engineer and shall consist of either concrete curbs or combination concrete curbs and gutters. The installation, construction and design of the curbing herein required shall be in accordance with Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.100 - Design standards-Sanitary sewage system. 
(a)  General Requirements. Sanitary sewers shall be installed and constructed in such a manner that every lot, parcel of land or building to be serviced thereby shall be serviced by means of a service connection within its own frontage. The installation, construction and design of the sanitary sewers herein required shall be in accordance with Chapter 4, Sanitary Sewage Facilities, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(b)  Service Area. Sanitary sewers shall be designed and constructed to serve the ultimate service area and in all cases shall be extended to the farthest adjacent property line, unless approved otherwise by the village engineer. 
(c)  Septic Tanks. A subdivision plat within the village shall in no case be approved which shall be dependent upon individual septic tanks. However, where there are lots of one acre or more outside the corporate limits, but within the official map area, individual septic tanks shall be permitted on lots of one acre or more. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.110 - Design standards-Storm drainage system. 
(a)  Required. A storm sewer system shall be constructed throughout the development or entire subdivision which shall be separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system and which shall provide an efficient outlet which will not fail to function when the receiving stream is in full flood. 
    All developments shall provide an adequate stormwater drainage system which will convey runoff to the system outfall. Provisions within the plans for controlling all erosion and sedimentation are to be shown. Where necessary, applicable and required, such as for stormwater discharges into open waterways (i.e., rivers, creeks, ditches, etc.) an approved debris collection/separation device shall be installed. Compliance with all permitting agencies shall be met, particularly those of the National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (N.P.D.E.S.), Phase II regulations. 
(b)  Standards. No street shall be constructed unless provisions are made for the concurrent installation and construction of storm sewers. The installation, construction and design of the storm sewers herein required shall be in accordance with Chapter 3, Stormwater Facilities, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.120 - Design standards-Water supply and distribution system. 
(a)  Mains. Water mains shall be installed in such a manner that every lot, parcel of land, or building to be serviced thereby shall be serviced by means of a separate service connection within its own frontage and shall be so connected to the existing water distribution system as to be circulating. All water mains shall be looped. Fire suppression and protection services where necessary shall be accommodated in a single combined service. This single water service shall be sized to simultaneously supply the domestic needs of the structure as well as the fire suppression system demand. The installation, construction and design of the mains herein required shall be in accordance with Chapter 5, Water Distribution System, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(b)  Hydrants. Fire hydrants and auxiliary valves in general shall be installed and located at intervals of approximately three hundred feet in a manner permitting connection of a ten foot to twenty foot, nonflexible streamer hose connection with a fire truck parked on the pavement. The installation, construction, and design of the hydrants herein required shall be in accordance with Chapter 5, Water Distribution System, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(c)  Appurtenances. Other necessary appurtenances, such as valves, valve vaults, fittings, etc., shall be installed where necessary. The installation, construction and design of these appurtenances shall be in accordance with Chapter 5, Water Distribution System, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
(Ord. No. 5094, § A, 6-19-2017) 
17.32.130 - Design standards-Services. 
    Services for sewers and water shall be constructed to connect with the utility mains constructed within any street, right-of-way or easement, to serve each adjoining lot, tract, building site, or building. Such service shall extend to the building being served. All such service for sewers and water connected with mains constructed within any street or easement shall be located at the approximate centerline of each lot, any deviation made from this requirement shall receive prior approval by the village engineer. All service trenches and installation shall be inspected by the village representative(s) before any trenches are backfilled. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.140 - Design standards-Street lighting. 
(a)  Residential. Residential street lighting facilities shall be provided. 
(b)  Commercial and Industrial. Commercial and industrial street lighting facilities shall be provided. 
(c)  Street lighting design shall be in accordance with Chapter 8, Lighting, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.150 - Design standards-Sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  Concrete sidewalks a minimum of five feet in width, located one foot off the property line and within the street right-of-way shall be installed on each side of every street in every zoning district; 
(2)  It shall be the sole responsibility of the subdivider and/or installer to dedicate or cause to be dedicated all required right-of-way on or fronting its property and to convey to the village for the benefit of the public all sidewalks required in subsection (1) of this section; 
(3)  Sidewalks shall be designed in accordance with Chapter 7, Sidewalks, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.155 - Wheeling sidewalk construction fund. 
    Sidewalks will be installed where appropriate and shall be required in all cases. However, if, in the opinion of the village engineer, it is impractical to install such a sidewalk or other extenuating circumstances exist, then a contribution for such sidewalk shall be made and deposited in the village of Wheeling sidewalk construction fund in accordance with the following: 
(a)  The Wheeling sidewalk construction fund shall be maintained by the director of finance; 
(b)  In lieu of the actual construction or installation of any sidewalk required by ordinance, the village may require that the cost of constructing or installing such sidewalk be deposited in the Wheeling sidewalk construction fund, where, the plan commission shall make a recommendation to the village board and where determined by the village engineer: 
(1)  Current and projected pedestrian traffic does not warrant the sidewalk, 
(2)  Construction or installation of the sidewalk at the time will result in an isolated sidewalk segment, 
(3)  The village board feels that it is in the best interest of the village to do so; 
(c)  Sidewalk cost, for the purpose of determining required deposits to the Wheeling sidewalk fund, shall be established by the president and board of trustees, by resolution, on an annual basis. Deposit in the Wheeling sidewalk fund of an amount approved by the village for any specific sidewalk or sidewalks shall relieve the subdivider or property owner, and all subsequent owners of that property, of the responsibility of constructing and installing such sidewalk or sidewalks; 
(d)  The village may utilize funds available from time to time within the Wheeling sidewalk fund for the construction or installation of any sidewalks within the village, as may be determined to be appropriate by the village, at its sole discretion. The village shall not be obligated to utilize funds within the Wheeling sidewalk fund for any particular project or sidewalk, regardless of whether a deposit to the fund has been made in lieu of construction of a particular sidewalk; 
(e)  All right-of-way for required sidewalks shall be dedicated to the village of Wheeling. The sidewalks themselves shall be conveyed to the village. The instrument(s) of dedication and conveyance shall be in a form acceptable to the village attorney. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
(Ord. No. 4592, § Q, 3-21-2011) 
17.32.160 - Design standards-Street signs, guardrails. 
(a)  Street Signs. All new public streets and rights-of-way shall be properly signed in accordance with the "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices," and as approved by the Wheeling police department. Plans for any proposed streets shall be submitted to the village engineer and the Wheeling police department for their review and approval. 
(1)  (A)  Street Identification Signs. Street name signs shall be installed at the northeast corner of each intersection on two and three-eighths' inch O.D. Schedule 40 pipe, SS-20 industrial pipe, or as approved by the village engineer, or attached to streetlight poles, wherever possible, with brackets at a mounting height of ten feet. Sign poles shall be buried a minimum of three feet below grade, and encased in ten-inch diameter concrete footings. Sign blanks shall be constructed of .080 mill-finish aluminum of the extruded type. Six-inch-high blanks shall be used for signing all minor and collector streets and nine-inch-high blanks used on major roads. All signs shall be fastened to the posts with vandal-proof nuts and bolts. 
(B)  Street name signs shall be attached to both faces of the sign blank on a diamond grade green background with four inch high diamond grade white letters on minor and collector streets and six inch high diamond grade letters on major streets. 
(2)  (A)  Regulatory Signs. All regulatory signs shall be located two feet behind the curb and having a minimum mounting height of five feet, as measured from the bottom of the sign to the curb. All signs shall be erected on steel one and three-fourths inch square posts of sufficient length to provide the proper sign mounting height, inserted into a two-inch diameter by three-foot-anchor post. All signs shall be fastened to the posts with a break away bolt and rivet system. 
(B)  All regulatory signs shall be constructed of aluminum blanks (ASTM 503-8 grade or equal) with standard rounded corners. Sign faces shall be of the diamond grade type, and in accordance with the following sizes: 
Type of Sign Size of Sign Stop signs 30? × 30? Yield signs 30? × 30? Speed limit 24? × 18? No parking this side 12? × 18? No parking any time 12? × 18? No parking 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 12? × 18?  
(b)  Guardrails. Guardrails shall be placed along the shoulder of any street and drive where required by the village engineer. 
(c)  Appraisal. The installation, construction and design of the above improvements shall be in accordance with the approval of the village engineer. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.170 - Design standards-Landscaping, street trees. 
    Trees and landscaping shall meet the requirements of Title 12, Trees and Vegetation of the village Municipal Code. 
(a)  Grading and Seeding. All street rights-of-way other than the area used by walks and pavements shall be graded and sodded; 
(b)  Spacing. Street trees shall be provided throughout the entire proposed subdivision. Such trees shall be planted within the street right-of-way not less than ten feet, unless approved otherwise, from the right-of-way line and on each side. They shall be spaced so that: 
(1)  Minimum spacing will be forty feet, 
(2)  Maximum spacing will be eighty feet, 
(3)  Each lot shall have at least one tree in the street right-of-way along its frontage except corner lots which shall have at least two trees, one on each side facing the street, to be planted at least twenty-five feet from the corner lot line. Placement of trees in a planned development shall be pursuant to the designation of the plan commission; 
(c)  Species. Trees shall be of any desirable species which meet the approval of the village board of trustees or such body or commission as may be designated by the village board of trustees for this purpose, and the subdivider shall furnish trees that are guaranteed for growth for a period of one year from planting and certified free from disease under the state of Illinois plant inspection department standards; 
(d)  Prohibiting Undesirable Trees. Trees undesirable for parkway shall be prohibited (such as trees that have inherent factors which might cause nuisance, destruction of sewers, pavements or curbs by the growth of roots, or the creation of hazards to safety). Examples of such trees are considered to be poplar, willow, cottonwood, elm, box elder, silver maple and similar soft wood trees; 
(e)  Screen Planting. Screen and decorative planting as approved shall be provided by the subdivider in all areas where buildings back up to streets. Live landscaping shall be provided in shopping centers and parking areas, as approved by the plan commission; 
(f)  Time and Method of Installing. The time and method of installation of landscaping and street trees shall be in accordance with the requirements of the department of public works; 
(g)  Diameter. The trees shall be of a diameter not less than three and one-half inches as measured by calipers at a distance of a minimum of six inches above the root. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.180 - Design standards-Oversize design. 
    Where required in the overall village utility planning, as evidenced by the official plan and master plans for water and sewer, subdivision improvements shall be constructed in accordance with the plans. When major or secondary streets are included within or are projected through a proposed subdivision by the official plan, the subdivider shall assume a cost equivalent to that of a major or a secondary street. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.190 - Design standards-Minimum requirements. 
    The requirements of this Title shall be considered minimum requirements and the board of trustees may increase the minimum requirements set forth herein in specific cases where the volume or type of traffic, the soil or topographic conditions, or the area of a proposed improvement may so warrant. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.200 - Final construction plans. 
    Final construction plans shall be prepared as specified in accordance with earlier sections. They shall be drawn on sheets measuring twenty-four inches by thirty-six inches and shall contain at least the following information in the following order: 
(a)  Detailed engineering plans and specifications covering all proposed public and private improvements; (b) Over-all lot grading plan; 
(c)  All related supplemental sheets including but not limited to: erosion control, street lighting and signing, pertinent notes and village standard details. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.32.210 - Material standards. 
    All construction of improvements covered by this Title shall be in accordance with, and construction materials used shall be in compliance with the practice, methods and materials required in the appropriate chapters and sections of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.33 - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 

17.33.010 - Detention/retention facilities. 
    Stormwater management facilities, including retention and detention areas, as well as associated piping and conveyance, shall be designed and constructed in accordance with Chapter 3, Stormwater Facilities, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. Stormwater management shall be required for all projects. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.33.020 - Additional regulations. 
    When detention is provided, the following regulations shall apply in addition to the regulations of the village and the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago: 
(a)  Bypass Channel. A natural or surface channel system shall be designated with adequate capacity to convey through the development of the stormwater runoff from all tributary upstream areas. Further, it shall meet the requirements of Section 3.09 of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. Stormwater management shall be required for all projects. 
(1)  These bypass channels shall be designed to carry the peak rate of runoff from a one-hundred-year storm, assuming all storm sewers are blocked and that the upstream areas are fully developed and have been saturated with antecedent rainfall. No habitable structures shall be constructed within this overland flow route; however, streets and parking or playground areas and utility easements may be considered compatible users. 
(2)  The design of this overland flow route system shall also take into consideration control of stormwater velocity to prevent erosion or other damage to a facility which will restrict its primary use. Depths of flow shall be kept to a minimum and the channel configurations shall be approved by the village engineer. 
(3)  If the development should contain an existing natural waterway or flow way, this area shall be preserved as part of the bypass drainage system. Construction of a low flow system of storm sewers to carry the minor storm runoff with a bottom of sufficient width which is adequate to facilitate maintenance and carry the runoff without eroding velocities shall be included in the plans for development. 
(b)  Dry Basins. All pervious dry bottom stormwater storage areas shall be designed to serve a secondary purpose for recreation, open space or other types of uses that will not be adversely affected by occasional or intermittent inundation. 
(1)  A method of carrying the low flow through these areas shall be provided in addition to a system of drains, and both shall be provided with a positive gravity outlet to a natural channel or storm sewer having adequate capacity. 
(2)  Flow through designs for detention basins are discouraged and generally not permitted. 
(3)  The combination of storage of the water from a one-hundred-year storm and the designed release rate shall not result in a storage duration in excess of seventy-two hours. Maximum depth of planned stormwater storage facility shall not exceed four feet unless the existing natural ground contours and other conditions lend to greater storage depth, and such as approved by the village engineer. Minimum grades for turf areas shall be two percent and maximum slopes shall be ten percent (ten units horizontally to one unit vertically). Storage area side slopes shall be kept as close to the natural land contours as practical and a ten percent slope or less shall be used wherever possible. If slopes greater than ten percent are necessary to meet storage requirements or area restrictions, the approval shall be obtained from the village engineer and suitable erosion control provided, in addition to the protection required to insure public health, safety and welfare. In no case will side slopes greater than 3:1 be permitted. 
(4)  Outlet control structures shall be designed as simply as possible and shall require little or no attention for proper operation. Each stormwater storage area shall be provided with a method of emergency overflow in the event that a storm in excess of the one-hundred-year frequency storm occurs. This emergency overflow facility shall be designed to function without attention and shall become part of the natural or surface channel system described in subsection (a) of this section. Hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to substantiate all design features. 
(5)  Both outlet control structures and emergency overflow facilities shall be designed and constructed to fully protect the public health, safety and welfare. Stormwater runoff velocities shall be kept as a minimum and turbulent conditions at an outfall control structure will not be permitted without complete protection for the public safety. The use of restrictive fences shall be kept to a minimum and used only when no other method is feasible. 
(c)  Wet Basins. Wet bottom stormwater storage areas shall be designed with all of the items required for dry bottom stormwater storage areas except that a low flow conduit and a system of drains with a positive gravity outlet may be eliminated. Each such area shall comply with the following conditions: 
(1)  Water surface area shall not exceed one-tenth of the tributary drainage area unless approved otherwise; 
(2)  Shoreline protection shall be provided to prevent erosion from wave action; 
(3)  Minimum normal water depth shall be four feet. If fish are to be used to keep the pond clean, a minimum of one-fourth of the pond area shall be a minimum of ten feet deep; 
(4)  Facilities shall be available, if possible, to allow the pond level to be lowered by gravity flow for cleaning purposes and shoreline maintenance; 
(5)  Control structures for stormwater release shall be designed to operate at full capacity with only a minor increase in the water surface level. Hydraulic calculations shall be submitted to substantiate all design features; 
(6)  In the event that the water surface of the pond is to be raised for purposes of storing water for irrigation or in anticipation of the evapo-transpiration demands of dry weather, the volume remaining for storage of excess stormwater runoff shall still be sufficient to contain the one-hundred-year storm runoff; 
(7)  Aeration facilities to prevent pond stagnation shall be provided. Design calculations to substantiate the effectiveness of these aeration facilities shall be submitted with the engineering plans. 
(d)  Roof and Parking Lot Storage. Paved surfaces that are to serve as stormwater storage areas shall have minimum grades of one percent. Rooftop storage will not be allowed. If a portion of an area within a stormwater storage area is to be paved for parking or recreational purposes, the paved surface shall be placed near the highest elevation within the storage area as possible. Parking lot grades shall not exceed normal design parameters. 
(e)  Flood Damage Prevention. The facilities for stormwater runoff control shall be constructed prior to any earth moving or drainage related construction on the project site. 
(f)  Erosion Control. During the construction phases, means, methods, and facilities shall be provided to prevent the erosion of the earth. Silting of downstream areas are to be prevented through the strategic use of silting basins, sodding of runoff channels or other such methods in accordance with the soil erosion and sedimentation plan for the project as well as limiting the period of time during which the earth is stripped of vegetation. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.33.030 - Watershed development ordinance adopted by reference. 
    The Lake County Watershed Development Ordinance, as most recently amended by the County of Lake on October 13, 2015, is hereby adopted by reference and is in full force and effect within the areas of the village of Wheeling, located in Lake County and is found in its own compilation. 
(Ord. 4067 § C, 2006) 
(Ord. No. 4725, § 1, 10-1-2012; Ord. No. 4789, § I, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 4972, § A, 12-7-2015) 
Chapter 17.36 - SURVEYING REQUIREMENTS 

17.36.010 - Surveys required. 
    Every subdivision of land under the terms of this Title shall require a survey meeting the requirements specified in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.36.020 - Monuments. 
    All lot corners, points of curvature, points of tangent, etc., shall be marked with iron pipes or concrete monuments. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.36.030 - Accuracy of survey. 
    The survey shall be performed by a surveyor registered in the state of Illinois. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.36.040 - Re-staking. 
    Upon completion of the construction of structures within the subdivision, the subdivider shall have the entire subdivision or any portion thereof he desires to have accepted, checked, verified and re-staked if necessary by a registered licensed Illinois land surveyor. Iron pipe monumentation shall be eighteen inches long and at least three-quarters inch in diameter. This work shall be performed and certified to by the surveyor. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.40 - CONSTRUCTION DESIGN AND INSTALLATION STANDARDS FOR IMPROVEMENTS 

17.40.010 - Generally. 
    In all cases the developer or subdivider shall be responsible for having his engineer coordinate, supervise, stake and inspect all work for satisfactory compliance covered in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.020 - Standards for underground improvements generally. 
(1)  Outside Pavement. The underground utilities shall be installed outside the pavement wherever possible. The use of public utility easements across the front of lots is encouraged. Special care shall be taken to insure that services clear other utilities installed in such easement. 
(2)  Screenings. Where underground utilities are installed in the roadway, under sidewalks or within three feet thereof, appropriate backfill material shall be used for back-filling the trenches. This shall also apply to work undertaken by the utility companies. 
(3)  Pipe Standards. The loading on pipes shall be determined from the appropriate design tables. 
(4)  Curved Alignment. Sewers may be installed on a curved alignment if approved by the village engineer. Minimum radius of curved sewers shall be no less than two hundred feet, as measured at the centerline of the sewer. 
(5)  Manholes. Manholes, shall be a minimum of four feet in diameter and designed in accordance with the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. The manholes shall be located at no more than four hundred feet intervals. Manholes shall be built at points where the sizes of the sewer changes, where the horizontal or vertical alignment changes at changes in pipe material and at the junction of two or more sewers. Sanitary sewer manholes shall be of precast concrete construction. 
    On curved sewers, ten inches in diameter or under, having a radius of less than six hundred feet, the maximum manhole spacing shall be two hundred fifty feet. 
(6)  Compliance with Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. All sewers shall be installed in accordance with whichever is more restrictive; The Manual of Practice of the Design of Public and Private Improvements and the Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance adopted by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. 
(7)  Elevation References. All elevations shall be referred to North American Vertical Datum 1988 (NAVD 88). 
(8)  Separate Sewers. Separate storm sewers and sanitary sewer systems are required. No combined sewer will be permitted. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.030 - Standards for storm sewers. 
    The design and materials shall be in accordance with Chapter 3, Stormwater Facilities, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(1)  Computing Method. The runoff and storm sewer design shall be determined by the rational method. The intensity used shall be a return frequency of not less than five years. The coefficient (c) shall be determined by the character of the area to be drained and shall conform to accepted standard engineering practices as found in Section 3.04C Runoff Coefficient in the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(2)  Flood Hazards. Where the downstream capacity of the sewer system is inadequate and the proposed sewers will not handle the runoff, or where the topography of the ground is such that flooding can be expected more often than the period for which the system is designed, the developer's engineer shall point this out in his drainage computations report. The possibility of flooding may then be reduced through the use of a modified grading plan and/or possible use of oversized detention basins. Prior to planning any detention basin, the location must be approved by the village engineer. 
(3)  Catch Basins. All catch basins shall be a minimum of four feet in diameter and shall have a sump of three and one-half feet. The catch basins shall be spaced to provide sufficient drainage of the tributary area without causing excessive ponding. 
    Where the quantity of water entering a catch basin may cause the overloading of an existing sewer, the outlet pipe from the catch basin may be restricted in its diameter. In no case, however, shall the size of the sewer or grate opening be underdesigned. 
(4)  Draining Rear Lots. Where it is necessary to install drainage structure to drain rear lot areas and other such areas, Type 8, grate may be permitted. 
(5)  Material. All storm sewers shall be reinforced concrete. RCP C-76 Class shall be as determined by the loading. The same shall apply to inlet and catch basin connection pipe. 
(6)  Minimum Size. The minimum size storm sewer shall be twelve inches in diameter unless approved otherwise. The minimum size connection pipe shall be eight inches. 
(7)  Inlets. Inlets may be used, but they shall discharge into catch basins and not directly into the storm sewer as outlined in Section 3.07, Design of Inlets and Catchbasins, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.040 - Standards for sanitary sewers. 
    Design and materials shall be in accordance with Chapter 4, Sanitary Sewer Facilities of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(1)  Quantity and Quality of Effluent. The quantity and quality of effluent shall be determined in accordance with the standards established by Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago (M.W.R.D.G.C.) as determined with their Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance and the Sewage and Waste Control Ordinance (latest editions). 
(2)  Rate of Infiltration/Exfiltration. The allowable rate of infiltration/exfiltration shall not exceed limits established by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago (M.W.R.D.G.C.). The village will not accept any sanitary sewer that fails to meet these requirements. 
(3)  Inspection. The village shall check and inspect the sanitary sewers before tentative acceptance for conformance to these standards. All sanitary sewers shall be televised at the developer's expense with the appropriate tapes and reports submitted to the village engineer prior to tentative acceptance of such sewers.
