Any and all noted defects and/or deficiencies shall be corrected by and at the developer's expense prior to such tentative acceptance. 
(4)  Footing Drains, Sump Pumps and Downspouts. Footing drains, sump pumps and downspouts shall not be connected to sanitary sewers and shall be in accordance with Section 3.06, Stormwater Facilities, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.050 - Standards for water mains. 
    Design and materials shall be in accordance with Chapter 6, Water Distribution System, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.060 - Standards for pavement design. 
    Design and materials shall be in accordance with Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(1)  Width of Pavement. The width of the pavement shall be in accordance with Section 17.32.070 of this Title. The crown shall vary from four inches to six inches, depending on the width of the pavement. 
(2)  Pavement Types. 
(a)  Flexible Design. 
(b)  Rigid Design. 
(3)  Minimum Pavement Grade. The minimum pavement grade shall be four-tenths of one percent. 
(4)  Maximum Grade. The maximum grade for major and secondary streets shall be three percent. The maximum grade for other streets shall be five percent. 
(5)  Vertical Curves. Vertical curves shall be used wherever the algebraic difference in grade exceeds one and one-half percent. Minimum length to be one hundred feet or as may be required by the village engineer. 
(6)  Curb Return Radius. A minimum curb return radius of thirty feet shall be used at the intersection of two major or secondary or one major or secondary and one other type street. The minimum radius for other streets shall be twenty feet. 
(7)  Subgrade. The subgrade for all pavements shall be in accordance with The Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction in the state of Illinois, published by the Illinois Department of Transportation, latest edition. 
(8)  Materials. Curb and gutter shall be portland cement concrete (six-bag mix). The village standard for curb and gutter shall be used. Curb design and materials shall be in accordance with Chapter 6, Pavement Design, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(9)  Whenever new curb and gutter is placed abutting existing curb, two five-eighths' inch dowel bars must be drilled and set into the existing curb and gutter section. 
(10)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be constructed of six-bag mix portland cement concrete and shall be five feet minimum in width and five inches in depth, with expansion joints at fifty-foot intervals and contraction joints at five-foot intervals. Sidewalk design and materials shall be in accordance with Chapter 7, Sidewalks, and Section 6.09 of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(11)  Driveway. Driveway design and materials shall be in accordance with Section 6.08 of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.070 - Construction and material standards. 
    Where not otherwise covered herein, all work and materials used shall be constructed as provided in The Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction specified earlier. 
(1)  The village engineer's office shall be notified at least forty-eight hours before any construction begins. 
(2)  All bituminous concrete and portland cement concrete shall be mixed and produced under the supervision and control of a competent testing laboratory with daily reports submitted to the village engineer, or the design engineer shall furnish the village engineer a report from the plant certifying that the material furnished was in accordance with specifications. 
(3)  Bituminous Aggregate Mixture Base Course. The minimum Marshall Stability = 1900 lbs. The material shall be mixed under the supervision and control of a competent testing laboratory with daily reports submitted to the village engineer, or the design engineer shall furnish the village engineer a report from the plant certifying that the bituminous material furnished was in accordance with the specifications: After one winter and spring season, the base course shall be cleaned and repaired or replaced, if necessary, to the satisfaction of the village engineer then primed at the rate of 0.15 gallons per square yard prior to the placement of the bituminous concrete wearing surface course. 
(4)  Portland cement concrete six-bag mix. Such material shall meet the following: 
(A)  The minimum compressive strength at twenty-eight days shall be four thousand pounds per square inch; 
(B)  The slump shall not exceed three inches; 
(C)  Air content of the mix shall be five, plus or minus one percent; 
(D)  The amount of water added at the job site shall be noted on the delivery truck ticket; 
(E)  The delivery truck ticket shall be available to the village engineer, or his duly authorized representatives; 
(F)  Curing compound shall be applied to the concrete for curing purposes; 
(G)  The village engineer may require the subdivider's engineer or contractor to take a number of test cylinders or beams to be cured and tested in compression by a materials laboratory which will be at no expense to the village. The number or samples to be taken and the breaking dates shall be as determined by the village engineer. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.080 - Construction scheduling. 
(a)  Concrete. Concrete may be placed only during the period from April 1st to November 15th. 
(b)  Concrete Cold Weather. Concrete placed during cold weather or outside of the time limits stated in subsection (a) of this section shall meet the requirements of the village of Wheeling "Cold Weather Construction - Concrete" policy. 
(c)  Bituminous Concrete. Bituminous concrete work may be constructed only during the period from April 1st to November 15th, weather permitting. 
(d)  Extension of Dates. The dates specified in the above subsections may be extended upon the written approval of the village engineer. 
(e)  Daylight Hours. All work must be performed during daylight hours and shall be governed by the previously referenced standards and applicable temperatures. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.40.090 - Inspection. 
    The developer's engineer shall provide full-time construction inspection. The village shall, at the expense of the developer, make inspections as it deems necessary throughout the construction period, including those improvements that are to be installed internally in a planned development which may be maintained by the management. Maximum cooperation shall be provided to all village inspectors. 
    In the case of a planned development, the developer's engineer and village will consider all sanitary sewer services and water services as to be privately maintained. However, due to the problem of infiltration and leakage, they shall be subject to the same inspection as if they were to be public. All storm sewers shall be inspected as though public. 
    Prior to priming the sub-base the village engineer shall be notified so that he may check for proper thickness, crown and curb edge exposure. 
    Upon completion of the underground improvements, sewers, watermains, drainage appurtenances, etc., shall be thoroughly inspected and defects noted on a punch list to be provided to the developer. Correction of the items noted on the punch list shall initiate the tentative acceptance of the work. The date of the resolution approved by the village board of trustees shall constitute the date of tentative acceptance of the public improvements. 
    Tentative acceptance shall not mean that the village accepts the responsibility for maintaining these improvements. 
    Maintenance from time of tentative acceptance until final acceptance of the improvements shall be the responsibility of the developer or subdivider. 
    It may occasionally be necessary to make emergency interim repairs to the underground or surface improvements. The village shall notify the developer or subdivider when it becomes necessary to make these repairs and it shall be the developer's or subdivider's responsibility to see that these repairs are made within twenty-four hours of notification. If these repairs are not accomplished during this period, the village may make the repairs and charge all costs to the developer or subdivider. 
    After the bituminous concrete binder course or bituminous aggregate mixture base course has been installed for a winter followed by a spring, it shall be thoroughly inspected by the village, the developer's engineer and the contractor. A punch list shall be made of all defects and as soon as these are corrected the bituminous concrete surface course will be installed. The underground improvements will also be reinspected at this time. 
    After the bituminous concrete surface course has been installed for twelve months, a final inspection shall be made by the village and the developer. This inspection will cover all improvements including but not limited to sidewalks, pavements, sewers, watermains, street lights, buffalo boxes, lot grading, etc. After all improvements meet with the approval of the village engineer, he will recommend final acceptance be made. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.42 - RECAPTURE 

17.42.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this Chapter, the following terms have the indicated meaning, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
(1)  "Recapture" means the reimbursement of the village or the reimbursement of an owner or developer of real property for a portion of the cost of certain public improvements from fees or amounts charged to owners of other or adjacent properties within the village, if and when the owners, developers or occupants of such other or adjacent properties tie into, or connect to, or use such public improvements; 
(2)  "Public improvements" mean water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, detention basins, retention basins, and any public improvement associated with any of the foregoing. Public improvements which are subject to recapture are limited to those which are or will be dedicated to the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.42.020 - Recapture authorized. 
(a)  Whenever an owner or developer of property within the village of Wheeling (1) proposes to install or construct any public improvement which will benefit adjacent or other properties within the village, or (2) is required by the village to install or construct any public improvement of a size or capacity, or in a location, or with an extension, which will benefit adjacent or other properties within the village, the president and board of trustees may, by ordinance, provide for the recapture of part of the cost of such public improvement in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter; 
(b)  The authorization of this section is permissive only. The adoption of an ordinance providing for the recapture of part of the cost of any public improvement is discretionary with the president and board of trustees of the village. Nothing within this Chapter or within the Wheeling Municipal Code shall obligate the president and board of trustees to provide for recapture or shall entitle any owner or developer of real property to recapture. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.42.030 - Application for recapture ordinance and agreement. 
    An owner or developer of real property located within the village of Wheeling may apply for a recapture agreement and ordinance at any time prior to the installation of the public improvements which are to be the subject of the agreement. The application shall be made to the director of community development and shall be accompanied by an application fee, as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, and shall include the following, in addition to any further requirements which are deemed necessary: 
(1)  Proof of ownership of the property on which the public improvements are to be constructed or installed, together with written authorization by all owners of such real estate, duly acknowledged by an officer authorized to administer oaths; 
(2)  A description of the public improvements, together with such plans and drawings as will enable the village to determine the nature, scope and capacity of such improvements; 
(3)  An estimate of the cost of construction and installation of the improvements, including materials, labor, design and financing, and where applicable, a separate identification of those costs and expenses attendant upon the village's request to alter or expand the public improvements to meet village needs or to service areas not owned by the developer or owners; 
(4)  A description of the adjacent or other areas within the village of Wheeling which will be, or which are capable of being, serviced or benefited by the proposed public improvements, together with a statement or engineering analysis in support of the asserted capability or benefit; 
(5)  A legal description of the parcels or areas claimed to be benefited or served by the proposed public improvements, together with the identification of the record owners as indicated in the tax record of the appropriate county office, of all such property. 
(Ord. 4131 § AP, 2006: Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.42.040 - Procedures for recapture-Public hearing. 
(a)  The president and board of trustees shall hold a public hearing on any proposed recapture ordinance initiated by the corporate authorities or on application by the owner or developer installing or constructing the public improvements. The village shall give written notice to the record owner, as indicated in the tax records of the appropriate county office, of any property expected to be benefited, at least fourteen days prior to the passage of any recapture ordinance. The village shall also publish notice of the proposed recapture in a secular newspaper of general circulation in the village at least fourteen days prior to the passage of any recapture ordinance. All testimonies shall be taken under oath and administered by the village clerk. After the public hearing has been conducted, the president and board of trustees shall make findings which shall be incorporated into any recapture ordinance to be passed. Such findings shall include: 
(1)  A description of the public improvements for which recapture is to be allowed; 
(2)  A specification of the identity of the owners or developer installing such public improvements in whose favor the recapture rights granted by the ordinance shall run; 
(3)  A description of the adjacent or other property found by the president and board of trustees to be benefited; 
(4)  A limit on the cost of the public improvements for which recapture is to be allowed, which shall not exceed the engineers estimate by more than ten percent; 
(5)  A formula or specific allocation based on ascertained benefit for distributing an identified portion of the cost of such public improvements to the adjacent or other properties benefited. 
(b)  In addition to the above-mentioned findings any recapture ordinance shall contain an express provision that the obligation of the village to reimburse the owner or developer installing or constructing the public improvement shall be a limited obligation payable only out of fees and amounts charged owners of other or adjacent properties found to be benefited, if and when the owners of such other or adjacent properties tie into or connect to or use such public improvements. 
(c)  The village manager and village staff are authorized to negotiate with the owners or developers installing or constructing the public improvements and with the owners of adjacent or other properties benefited, or asserted to be benefited, toward an agreement as to the total cost of the public utilities and as to the proportion of such cost incurred primarily for the benefit of adjacent or other properties. Any such agreement, if approved by the president and board of trustees of the village, shall be reflected in the recapture ordinance. 
(d)  After completion of the public improvements for which recapture is to be allowed, if the actual cost is less than the limit specified in the recapture ordinance, the ordinance shall be amended to reflect such lower amount, and the recapture agreement shall be limited to that lower amount. If the actual cost is higher than the amount specified in the recapture ordinance, no change shall be made in the ordinance, and the additional costs shall not be subject to recapture. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.42.050 - Recapture ordinance incorporated into agreement. 
(a)  After passage of a recapture ordinance, the ordinance shall be incorporated into an agreement between the village and the owner or developer installing the public improvements. The agreement may contain such other terms and provisions as deemed appropriate by the village. The owner of any adjacent or other property found to be benefited and with whom an agreement has been reached may also become a party to such agreement. 
(b)  The agreement incorporating the recapture ordinance, when executed, shall be recorded against the property of the owners or developer installing the public improvements and against each of the adjacent or other properties found to be benefited. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.44 - STREET LIGHTING 

17.44.010 - Generally. 
(a)  Plan Preparation. All plans shall be prepared by a licensed professional engineer registered in Illinois. The lighting plans shall be a part of the construction plans and shall be on a separate plan sheet. Street lighting design shall be in accordance with the requirements under Chapter 8, Street Lighting, of the Manual of Practice for Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(b)  Approval. All design and subsequent installation of street lighting must meet with the approval of the village engineer. 
(c)  As-Built Drawings. Upon completion of the lighting system improvements an accurate set of as-built lighting drawings shall be furnished. 
(d)  Special Conditions. In special cases, the village engineer may designate larger lamps, taller (or shorter) poles or vary the spacing as he deems necessary to meet special design requirements or conditions. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.020 - Location. 
    Street lighting is required within all subdivisions and shall be in accordance with Chapter 8, Street Lighting, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. In the case of planned development a lighting system may be proposed to best meet the design criteria of the development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.030 - Light distribution. 
    Pole spacing and light distribution shall meet the requirements found in Sections 8.05, Pole Spacing, and 8.06, Uniformity Ratio, of Chapter 8, Street Lighting, of the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. Other types of distribution and spacing shall be used where designated by the village engineer. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.040 - Individual control. 
    On individual control of lights, the photoelectric control shall be mounted integrally to the luminaire. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.050 - Group control. 
    The control of a group of units shall be limited to five and the photoelectric control shall be mounted on the top of the standard nearest the control cabinet or within the cabinet may be granted subject to review of the plans by the village engineer is required. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.060 - Ballast. 
    Ballasts shall be of the constant wattage type. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.070 - Power supply location. 
    Connection to the power supply shall be made as near to the secondary supply of the distribution transformer as practical. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.080 - Power supply connection. 
    Connections to the power supply will be reviewed by the village and shall be approved by the Commonwealth Edison Company. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.090 - Conduit. 
    All street crossovers shall have two-inch galvanized rigid steel conduit used as a raceway for underground cable with two-inch insulating fiber bushings. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.100 - Underground cable. 
    Underground cable shall be unit duct type, buried approximately twenty-four inches below finished grade. Lines shall be located two feet back of the curb or as approved by the village engineer. Underground cable shall be not less than No. 6 wire unless otherwise approved. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.110 - Splices. 
    All underground cable shall be continuous. Necessary splices shall be made as approved above ground level and shall have their location recorded on the "As-Built" plans. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.120 - Control cabinet. 
    Control cabinets shall be approved by the village engineer. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.130 - Materials generally. 
    All materials shall be approved by the village engineer. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.140 - Materials for luminaire. 
    Luminaires shall be in accordance with the style and type as shown on the village of Wheeling, street light standard detail. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.150 - Materials for standards and brackets. 
    Standards and brackets shall be in accordance with the style and type as shown on the village of Wheeling, street light standard detail. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.160 - Materials for lamps. 
    Lamps shall be two hundred fifty watt unless approved otherwise by the village engineer. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.170 - Materials for controls. 
    The photoelectric cell control for individual lights shall be contained on the luminaire with fuse protection. The photoelectric cell control of a group system shall be mounted on top of the pole nearest the control cabinet or within the cabinet and the manufacturer shall be approved by the village engineer. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.180 - Materials for control cabinet. 
    Control cabinet for a group system shall be in accordance with Section 17.44.120 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.190 - Wire-Power supply to pole base. 
    All cable shall be consistent with the underground street light cable. A three-wire system shall be used from the power supply to the control cabinet. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.44.200 - Wire-Pole and bracket. 
    All fixture wires shall be consistent with the underground street light system cable. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.46 - PLANNED DEVELOPMENT-CONDITIONS AND STANDARDS 

17.46.010 - Generally. 
    In general, all the foregoing conditions shall apply for planned developments unless otherwise stated in the specific section of Title 17. 
    Planned developments may not be used to avoid other ordinance requirements or as a means to make improvements at a lower standard than otherwise required. All planned developments shall provide for ownership and maintenance of common areas. Common areas may not be dedicated to the public. No increase in density or resubdivision of the planned development arrangement may be allowed without new approvals. 
    Public dedicated lands shall not be used when computing density requirements. 
    Parking areas shall be assigned to each dwelling unit and meet the requirements of Title 19. The number of parking areas cannot be reduced in the future. 
    A planned development, whether a new development or changed ownership of an existing building or project, is a subdivision of land and must comply with this ordinance and be approved. When planned development is applied to existing buildings or projects, requirements for a preliminary plat may be waived by the plan commission. All individually owned properties shall have access to a public street or to a common area which, in turn, has access to a public street. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.46.020 - Open space. 
    Open space shall be provided which shall not be less than twenty-five percent of the net site area. Open space shall be covered by grass or shrubbery suitably landscaped, or water areas as approved by the plan commission, and shall not be covered by buildings, parking areas or streets. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.46.030 - Traffic regulation and control. 
    The owner or entity owning any shopping center, apartment complex, or planned development, may enter into a contract with the corporate authorities pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code and the Illinois Motor Vehicle Act (S.H.A., Ch. 95-1/2, Sec. 11-209 et seq.) relative to the control and regulation of traffic within the shopping center, apartment complex or planned development. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.46.040 - Refuse disposal. 
    Areas for refuse must be provided by the developer in accordance with the following recommendations: 
(a)  Planned developments' or apartment type developments' garbage should either be containerized, i.e., trash receptacles or compacted; 
(b)  The developer shall submit in writing the type of service he expects to have, which shall be approved by the village health officer; 
(c)  The village health officer shall be consulted to determine size and number of containers required, also size and number of enclosures; 
(d)  Areas shall be large enough to facilitate easy opening and closing of lids and, also, large enough to accommodate household materials which cannot normally be placed in containers; 
(e)  Solid, wood or brick type enclosures having a minimum height of six feet shall be required and located conveniently for residents; 
(f)  Service for townhouse developments shall be treated the same as private dwellings, i.e., approved cans or plastic bags shall be used. Specific storage areas shall be included in plans. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.46.050 - Fire lanes. 
    A seventeen-foot fire lane shall be provided if so required by the fire chief at the side and rear of all structures, and no parking shall be allowed in that area. The developer shall furnish the fire department with a plat of the development indicating the street names and numbers prior to the approval of the development. The fire chief, or his duly authorized agent, shall submit written approval of the final plat prior to its presentation to the plan commission. In addition, street numbers shall be at least six inches in height so that they can easily be seen from the street whenever and wherever possible, and street numbers shall be in a sequence to be approved, in writing, by the engineering department. All preliminary plat plans for planned developments shall be submitted to the fire department, at which time the department shall determine the necessity for fire lanes. Fire lanes shall be required for buildings to which there is not sufficient normal access for fire-fighting equipment, or at such other location as the fire chief designates. Fire lanes shall be designed in accordance with Section 6.12, Fire Lanes, in Chapter 6, Pavement Design, in the Manual of Practice for the Design of Public and Private Improvements which are made a part of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.48 - FEES 

17.48.010 - Generally. 
    To defray the administrative costs of review and engineering and inspection costs incurred by the village, the developer is required to reimburse the village as provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.48.020 - Fees for processing plats. 
(a)  For processing of preliminary and final plat and documents (not including engineering improvement plans), fees, as provided in the schedule of fees and charges set forth in Chapter 1.26 of this code, shall be paid before consideration of the subdivision by the plan commission or village board: 
(1)  For any plat containing ten acres or less; 
(2)  For any plat containing more than ten acres or fraction thereof: 
    Once review of the preliminary plat of subdivision has begun, no portion of this fee is returnable; 
(3)  For any public hearings held in connection with a request for variations from this Title. 
    The costs associated with holding a public hearing are detailed in Title 19, zoning, of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
(b)  All fees are to be paid prior to the hearing. 
(Ord. 4131 § AQ, 2006: Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
(Ord. No. 4901, § A, 12-8-2014) 
17.48.030 - Processing plans for public or private improvements. 
    For review and processing by the village engineer, of the plans and specifications for the construction of public or private improvements, a fee shall be paid before review by the village engineer after filing of the plans and specifications with the village engineer. 
    The fee shall be as set forth in Section 17.48.060 of this Chapter. 
    Once review of the plans and specifications has begun, no portion of this fee is returnable. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
(Ord. No. 4901, § A, 12-8-2014) 
17.48.050 - Inspection of improvements generally. 
    In addition to the full-time inspection that the developer's engineer shall furnish, the village will perform a limited amount of inspection as previously stated. The amount of village inspection will be at the discretion of the village engineer or the supervisor of inspection services. 
    The village engineer, on behalf of the village, shall charge the developer for all inspection of surface and underground improvements to be made on Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays at the rate including, but not limited to, appropriate village personnel's hourly salary and benefit reimbursement plus administrative costs, fees, etc., as well as reimbursables with a three-hour minimum. 
    The developer will be billed as required for inspection services performed by the village. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.48.060 - Fees for plan review, resubmittals, plan changes and inspection services. 
    The fees to be charged for the review of plans, resubmittals, plan changes and inspection services is as follows: Review and inspection fee shall be three and one-half percent of the estimated cost of construction. Fees are for each development or unit thereof submitted for approval. 
    These fees shall be paid prior to approval by the village engineer. No portion of the fee is returnable. 
    The developer shall issue a check to the village of Wheeling for an amount equal to the required fee based upon the developer's engineer's estimated cost as approved by the village engineer. 
    The village engineer shall review the final plans, specifications, calculations, contract documents, etc., and request that all revisions or changes be made before a final submittal for his approval is to be made. The village engineer will then furnish the director of community development a copy of the approved permit drawings, etc. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.48.070 - Fee for outside consultants. 
    In the event that the village is required to utilize consulting or outside engineering services in connection with the review of any project, the developer shall be required to reimburse the village for the actual costs incurred by the village for those. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 17.52 - VARIATIONS 

17.52.010 - Conditions required for granting. 
    The village board of trustees may grant a variance from the provisions of this Title in specific cases: 
(1)  Where the reasonable future volume or type of traffic may so warrant; 
(2)  Where topographic or soil conditions may so warrant; 
(3)  Where, by reason of an exceptional situation, surrounding or condition, the strict application of any provision of this Title would result in peculiar and exceptional practical difficulties or particular hardship upon the owner of property abutting upon an existing or proposed street; 
(4)  Where the property in question cannot yield a reasonable return if permitted to be used only under the terms of this Title, and where the plight of the owner is due to unique circumstances, and where the variation, if granted, would not alter the essential character of the area; 
(5)  Where construction materials equivalent to those enumerated in this Title are not approved in writing by the village engineer. 
    In the event the village engineer does not approve any substitution of materials requested by the developer under subsection (5) of this section the developer or his authorized agent may apply to the corporate authorities for a variation from the applicable provisions of this Title. The corporate authorities shall then direct the plan commission to hold a public meeting as outlined hereafter. 
    Requests for a variance of this Title shall be submitted to the village clerk, who shall forward the application to the person designated by the village manager being the village planner or any other person so designated who shall transmit the application to the plan commission for a public hearing thereon, with a copy to the board of trustees. Notice of the time, place, and subject matter of such public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the village not more than thirty days nor less than fifteen days prior to the date of such hearing. After such hearing, the plan commission shall submit its recommendation in a report to the village board of trustees who may then grant or deny the variance requested. No variation shall be granted by the village board of trustees unless a public hearing on such variation has been held by the plan commission. 
    The plan commission shall recommend to the corporate authorities that any variations from the regulations of this Title be granted so long as the variations are legal and in harmony with the general purpose and intent and in accordance with the general or specific rules herein contained only in those areas where there are practical difficulties or particular hardship in conforming to the strict letter of any of the regulations contained in this Title. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.52.015 - Written notice. 
(a)  In addition to the notice requirements otherwise provided in this Chapter, an applicant for any public hearing required by this subdivision ordinance shall, not less than fifteen days and not more than thirty days prior to the date set for the public hearing, serve documented written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known taxpayers or property owner or owners of record reflected in the county records of all property within two hundred and fifty feet in each direction of the property lines of the subject property for which the public hearing is requested, provided the number of feet occupied by all public roads, streets, alleys, and other public ways shall be excluded in computing the two hundred fifty foot requirements. In the event of a planned development, two hundred fifty feet shall be measured from the outermost property line of the entire planned development. If any part of a condominium property is located within two hundred fifty feet of the property which is the subject of a hearing, written notification, as outlined above, shall be sent to each taxpayer of record within all condominium buildings that are located within or partially within the required distance from the property lines as well as the condominium association. If written notification is sent to a trust company or lending institution of record the notice requirement of this section shall be deemed satisfied. Copies of the notice and list of addresses shall be provided to the village planner; 
(b)  The notice herein required shall contain the address of the location for which the public hearing is requested, a brief statement of the nature of the request, the name and address of the legal and beneficial owner of the property, and time and date on which such hearing shall be held. If, after a bona fide effort to determine such by the applicant the owner cannot be found, the notice requirements of this section shall be deemed satisfied upon filing by the applicant of an affidavit evidencing the inability to serve such notice; 
(c)  The applicant shall furnish, at the time of hearing, an affidavit certifying that he/she has complied with therequirements of this subsection. Attached to the written statement shall be a list of all property owners notified in accordance with the above and the returned notice sent to each of the individuals therein specified. Forms of the affidavit shall be made available by the community development department. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
17.52.020 - Plan commission recommendations. 
    The plan commission may recommend variations from these requirements in specific cases which do not affect the general plan or the spirit of the Title. Such recommendations shall be communicated to the village board of trustees in writing with the reasons therefor before the final approval of the plat by the village board of trustees. No variation shall be made which conflicts with the provisions of the official map of the village of Wheeling. 
(Ord. 3954 (part), 2005) 
Title 19 - ZONING* 
Chapters: 
Chapter 19.01 - DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

19.01.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Chapter, certain terms and words are herewith defined as follows: words in the present tense include the future; words in the singular number include the plural, words in the plural number include the singular; the word "building" includes the word "structure" but does not include pole lines and fences; and the word "shall" is mandatory and not directory. 
    "Accessory building or structure" means a structure which: 
(a)  Is maintained on the same lot and under the same ownership as a principal building; 
(b)  Is smaller in floor area, building bulk and lot coverage than any principal building on the lot; 
(c)  In its use is subordinate to and serves a principal building; 
(d)  Is designed and built for the use to which it is put or to be put, and does not include structural or other features inconsistent with or incompatible with a principal building; 
(e)  Is permanently affixed to the ground (except for home equipment sheds with maximum floor area of one hundred twenty square feet); and 
(f)  Contributes to the comfort, convenience, or necessity of the owners, occupants, or users of the principal building served. 
    In no event shall an accessory building or structure be used for residential or dwelling purposes. 
Figure 1: Principal and Accessory Buildings or Structures 

    "Accessory use" means a use which: 
(a)  Is conducted on the same lot and by the same party as a principal use; 
(b)  Is subordinate in area, extent, and purpose to the principal use and is clearly incidental to the principal use; 
(c)  Contributes to the comfort, convenience, or necessity of the party conducting the principal use; and 
(d)  Will not alter the character of the area or be detrimental thereto. 
    Acreage, Gross. "Gross acreage" means: 
(a)  The total area in acres of a tract of land, including all nonresidential land uses (such as required detention basins, park sites, religious institutions, educational institutions, agricultural uses, governmental uses), and further including the rights-of-way of publicly dedicated streets and all other dedicated public lands required under the Wheeling Municipal Code; and 
(b)  Shall expressly exclude all ponds and water surfaces existing on the property prior to development (whether natural or man-made) but shall include detention basins, so long as such detention basins or areas are not presently under water. 
    Acreage, Net. "Net acreage" means the total acreage of a tract of land that is available for development. "Net acreage" shall exclude detention basins, retention basins, and any land dedicated to public use as a right-of-way or public access easement. 
    "Adult day service" means a facility that provides daytime meal services, transportation, health monitoring, medication supervision, personal care and recreational/therapeutic activities, for adults who want to remain in the community but who cannot be home alone during the day due to a physical, social and/or mental impairment. Does not include medical office, medical service facility, or nursing home. 
    Adult Entertainment Establishment. (See "Entertainment Establishment, Adult") means and includes "entertainment establishment, adult" and "retail establishment, adult." 
    Adult Retail Establishment. (See "Retail Establishment, Adult"). 
    "Airport" means the Chicago Executive Airport located partially in the village of Wheeling, Illinois and partially in the city of Prospect Heights, Illinois, Range 11, East of the Third Principal Meridian, Cook County, Illinois. 
    "Alley" means a way which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Alteration" (see also "Structural Alteration") means any construction which would result in a change in height or lateral dimensions of an existing structure. 
    "Ambulance service" means a privately owned facility for the dispatch, storage and maintenance of emergency medical care vehicles. 
    "Animal boarding facility" means an establishment in which more than three dogs or three cats, or any combination thereof, over the age of five months may be kept for boarding, breeding, safekeeping, convalescence, humane disposal, placement, sale or sporting purposes. 
    "Animal grooming or training facility" means an establishment providing bathing, trimming or training services for domestic animals on a commercial basis. This term includes the boarding of domestic animals for a maximum period of forty-eight hours incidental to the grooming or training services provided. 
    "Animal hospital/clinic" means an establishment providing medical and surgical treatment of domestic animals, including grooming and boarding for not more than thirty days if incidental to the medical care. This term also includes an animal crematorium. 
    "Annexed area" means any area of land that has been incorporated into the village of Wheeling resulting in a change of the boundaries of the village. 
    "Antenna" means equipment used for transmitting or receiving radio frequency signals which is attached to a tower, building or other structure, usually consisting of a series of directional panels, microwave or satellite dishes, or omnidirectional "whip" antennae. Does not include small cell antenna. 
    "Antenna, small cell" means a personal wireless telecommunications facility consisting of an antenna and related equipment either installed singly or as part of a network to provide coverage or enhance capacity in a limited defined area. Such facilities are regulated in Title 11, Rights-of-Way, Streets, and Sidewalks, of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
    "Antenna support structure" means any building, pole, telescoping mast, tower, tripod, or any other structure which supports an antenna. 
    "Applicant" shall mean, unless otherwise specified, an owner or other person with a legal property interest, including, a subdivider, developer, or other agent of the landowner, who has filed an application for subdivision or development. 
    "Appurtenance" as used in this Title with reference to mobile homes, anything added to the exterior of a mobile home (with the exception of metal awnings) is an appurtenance. 
    "Artist studio" means work space for one or more artists or artisans, including the accessory sale of art produced on the premises. 
    "Assembly hall" means an establishment providing meeting space for social gatherings, including but not limited to wedding receptions, graduation parties and business or retirement functions. This term includes, but is not limited to, a banquet hall, rental hall, nonalcoholic social club, nondenominational chapel or a meeting space for a club or membership organization. This term does not include a convention center. 
    "Bank or other financial institution" means an establishment providing retail banking, credit and mortgage services. This term does not include a currency exchange, a payday loan agency or a title loan agency (see definitions for currency exchange and short-term lending facility). 
    "Basement" means a story having part but not more than one-half its height below ground line. A basement is counted as a story for the purpose of height regulation if subdivided and used for business. 
    "Bed and breakfast" means an operator-occupied residence providing accommodations for a charge to the public with no more than five guest rooms for rent and in operation for more than ten nights in a twelve-month period. Breakfast may be provided to the guests only. Bed and breakfast establishments shall not include motels, hotels, boarding houses, or food service establishments. 
    "Bedroom" means any spaces or room designed for sleeping purposes, whether or not such room or space is open and accessible to other rooms or spaces. 
    "Board of appeals" means an officially constituted body whose principal duties are to hear appeals, and where appropriate, grant variance from the strict application of the zoning ordinance. This is the short form of the name, village of Wheeling board of zoning appeals. In the village of Wheeling, the plan commission acts as the board of appeals. 
    "Boardinghouse" means a building other than a hotel where, for compensation, meals, or lodging and meals are provided for more than two but not more than ten persons. 
    "Broadcasting or recording studio" means an establishment containing one or more broadcasting studios for over-the-air, cable or satellite delivery of radio or television programs, or studios for the audio or video recording or filming of musical performances, radio or television programs or motion pictures. This term does not include a transmission tower. 
    "Buffer" means open spaces, landscaped areas, fences, walls, berms, or any combination thereof, used to physically separate or screen one use or property from another use or property to visually shield or block noise, light, or other potential nuisances. 
Figure 2: Example of a Buffer Between Different Use Types 

    "Bufferyard" means the space in which required buffering is located. Bufferyard width, design and location are set forth in Section 19.11.020 of this Title. 
    "Building" means any covered structure built for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind, and which is permanently affixed to the land. 
    "Building bulk regulations" means restrictions controlling the size of buildings or other structures and the relationship of buildings, structures and uses to each other and to open areas and lot lines. Bulk regulations include restrictions controlling: 
(a)  Maximum height; 
(b)  Maximum lot coverage; 
(c)  Minimum size of yards. 
    "Building line" means an imaginary line drawn parallel to a straight lot line or tangent to a curved lot line, at the closest point of any principal building or structure on the site. 
    "Building maintenance service" means an establishment providing routine maintenance of buildings. This term includes, but is not limited to, a window washing, building cleaning, pest extermination or disinfecting service. 
    Building, Principal. "Principal building" means a nonaccessory building in which the principal use of the lot is conducted. 
    "Business" means any lawful commercial endeavor to engage in the manufacture, purchase, sale, lease, or exchange of goods and/or services. 
    "Business offices" means an office, in which only normal clerical functions, or professional services are performed, and specifically eliminating therein the sale, repair, or manufacture of articles for sale either on the premises, or elsewhere. 
    "Business service" means an establishment providing services to business establishments on a fee or contract basis, including, but not limited to, advertising services, business equipment and furniture sales or rental or protective services. This term includes, but is not limited to, an employment agency, photocopy center, commercial photography studio or mailing service. This term does not include maintenance, repair and office uses such as accounting, advertising, architectural design, city planning, environmental analysis, insurance, interior design, investment, landscape design, law, management consulting, title research and real estate. 
    "Cabana" means a room enclosure of traditional construction erected or constructed adjacent to a mobile home for residential use by the occupant of the mobile home. 
    "Caliper" refers to the diameter of a tree. In nursery-landscape practice, caliper is measured six inches above the ground level up to and including four-inch diameter size, and twelve inches above the ground level for larger sizes. 
    "Car sharing facility" means a public or private parking stall reserved for the storage of a car sharing vehicle. The configuration of car sharing facilities is subject to the restrictions of this Title (see Appendix A, Use Table, and Section 19.10.060(k)). 
    "Car sharing vehicle" means a passenger vehicle, up to eighteen feet in total length, that is owned or leased by a car sharing organization. Such vehicles shall be made available to the members of the car sharing organization, with membership available to the general public. 
    "Car wash" means an establishment providing washing, waxing or cleaning of light motor vehicles, including access and queuing lanes. 
    "Caregiver" shall mean the individual directly responsible for the care of the children in a child care service or day care home. 
    "Catering service" means an establishment providing the processing, assembly and packaging of food into servings for consumption off-premises without provision for on-site pickup or consumption. This term includes, but is not limited to, the preparation of meals by a catering business or by a nonprofit organization operating a meal program. 
    "Cellar" means a story having more than one-half of its height below grade. A cellar is not included in computing the number of stories for the purpose of height measurement. 
    Centerline, Street. "Street centerline" means an imaginary line that is equidistant from the boundaries of the street (alley, runway, etc.) or as otherwise established on the official map. 
    "Change of use" shall mean any use that substantially differs from the previous use of a building or land in terms of, for example, required parking, landscaping, drainage, and particularly in terms of the new use's overall effect on the surrounding neighborhood and zoning district purpose. 
    "Child care service" means a family home in which care is provided for three or less children for less than twenty-four hours per day. The maximum of three children includes the family's natural, foster, or adopted children and all other persons under the age of twelve. This term includes homes that receive only children from a single household. This term does not include a day care home. 
    "Clubs and lodges" means a nonprofit association of persons who are bona fide members paying annual dues which owns, hires or leases a building or portion thereof, the use of such premises being restricted to members and their guests. The affairs and management of such "private club or lodge" are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting. It shall be permissible to serve food and meals on such premises provided adequate dining room space and kitchen facilities are available. Where properly licensed under existing village ordinance, the consumption of intoxicating beverages by members of such club or lodge or their guests may be permitted. 
    Collector Street. (See "Street, Collector"). 
    "College" means an educational institution authorized by the state to award baccalaureate or higher degrees, or any campus of the state vocational, technical and adult education system. This term includes any classroom, laboratory, sporting facility or office associated with such institution. This term does not include a dormitory. 
    "Co-location" means the location of wireless telecommunications equipment from more than one provider on a common tower, building or structure. 
    "Community center" means a building or group of buildings operated by a public or nonprofit group or agency and used for recreational, social, educational or cultural activities. 
    "Comprehensive plan" means a comprehensive, long-range plan intended to guide the growth and development of the village of Wheeling. 
    "Compressed natural gas (CNG) fueling station" means a commercial facility dispensing compressed natural gas via means of quick-fill technology to a limited number of third party vehicles whose drivers have been trained and licensed to dispense CNG by the owner of the CNG fueling station pursuant to training and licensing standards approved by the village. Subject to the requirements of the Life Safety Code. 
    "Concrete/asphalt plant" means a facility for the mixing and crushing and the storage and transporting of raw or recycled aggregate, along with concrete, and liquid asphalt to make asphalt cement concrete (A.C.C.) or concrete for the purpose of sale. 
    "Condominium" means a building or group of buildings, in which the dwelling units, offices, or floor areas are owned individually, and the structure, common areas, and facilities are owned by all of the owners on a proportional, undivided basis. 
    "Condominium association" means the community association that administers and maintains the common property and common elements of a condominium. 
    "Conforming building or structure" means a building, or other structures, which is designed or intended for a conforming use and which complies with all the regulations of this Title, or of any amendment hereto, governing use, lot size, building bulk and off-street parking and loading for the zoning district in which such building or structure is located. 
    "Conforming use" means any lawful use of a building or lot which complies with the provisions of this Title. 
    "Construction" means the erection or alteration of any structure either of a permanent or temporary character. 
    "Contractor's shop" means an establishment used for the indoor repair, maintenance or storage of a contractor's vehicles, equipment or materials, and may include the contractor's business office. 
    "Contractor's yard" means an establishment used for the outdoor storage of a contractor's vehicles, equipment or materials. 
    "Convenience store" means any retail establishment offering for sale prepackaged food products, household items, sundry items, and other goods commonly associated with the same, and which may also sell gasoline; operated primarily for the convenience of the motoring public, walk-in shopper, or someone purchasing a few items. 
    "Convention and exposition center" means a commercial facility used for assemblies or meetings of the members or representatives of groups, including exhibition space. This term does not include banquet halls, clubs, lodges or other meeting facilities of private or nonprofit groups that are primarily used by group members. 
    Corner Lot. (See "Lot, Corner"). 
    "Cultural institution" means a nonprofit institution that displays or preserves objects of interest to the arts or sciences. This term includes, but is not limited to, a museum, art gallery, aquarium or planetarium. 
    "Curb line" means the line that is represented by the back of the curb. 
    "Currency exchange" means any entity, except a bank, trust company, savings bank, savings and loan association, credit union, or industrial loan and thrift company, engaged in the business of cashing checks, drafts, money orders, or travelers' checks for a fee. A person who provides these services incidental to the person's primary business is not included in the definition if the charge for cashing a check or draft does not exceed one dollar or one percent of the value of the check or draft, whichever is greater. 
    "Day care center" means an establishment in which the operator is provided with compensation in return for providing one or more individuals with care for less than twenty-four hours at a time. The term includes, but is not limited to, a day nursery, nursery school, or other supplemental care facility. This term does not include a family day care home or adult day care center (see "Adult day services"). 
    "Day care home" means a family home which receives more than three up to a maximum of eight children for less than twenty-four hours per day. The number counted includes the family's natural, foster, or adopted children and all other persons under the age of twelve. The term does not include facilities which receive only children from a single household. 
    "Deck" means an unenclosed exterior structure which is attached or adjacent to the exterior wall of a building, which has a floor but no roof. 
    "Density" means the numerical value obtained by dividing the total number of dwelling units in a development by the gross acreage of the actual tract of land upon which the dwelling units are to be located. 
    "Developable area" means the total area of a parcel or group of parcels, minus any undevelopable areas including wetlands, floodplains, steep slopes, or other natural resource areas. 
    "Developer's agreement" means an agreement by a developer with the village that clearly establishes the developer's responsibility regarding project phasing, the provision of public and private facilities, improvements and any other mutually agreed upon terms and requirements. 
    "Developmental disability" means a physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or more of a person's major life activities, impairs their ability to live independently, or a record of having such impairment, but such term does not include current use of, nor addiction to, a controlled substance. 
    "District" means a portion of the territory of the village of Wheeling within which certain uniform regulations and requirements, or various combinations thereof, apply under the provisions of this Title. 
    "Donation box" means a freestanding accessory structure, container, receptacle, or similar device that is used for soliciting and collecting donations of clothing or other salvageable personal property. This term excludes any unattended donation boxes located within a building. 
    Double Frontage Lot. (See "Lot, Double Frontage"). 
    "Drive-through facility" means a facility which is used for dispensing services or products to customers in motor vehicles. Such facility may require access lanes, signing, lighting and audio systems. This term does not include a drive-in theater. 
    "Driveway" means that portion of a lot paved with asphalt, concrete, or other surface approved by the village, used for the purpose of parking, ingress and egress to a carport, garage, parking area, or loading and unloading area for vehicles. 
    "Dry cleaning establishment" means an establishment which launders or dry cleans articles dropped-off on the premises directly by the customer or where articles are dropped-off, sorted and picked up but where laundering or cleaning is done elsewhere. 
    Dwelling, Duplex. (See "Dwelling, two-family"). 
    Dwelling, Multiple-Family. "Multiple-family dwelling" means a building containing three or more dwelling units whose residents live independently of one another. 
Figure 3: Examples of Multiple-Family Dwelling 
Figure 3a: Quadruplex 

Figure 3b: Townhouse 

Figure 3c: Coach House or Manor Home 

Figure 3d: Condominiums or Apartments 

    Dwelling, Single-Family. "Single-family dwelling" means a building containing one dwelling unit only. 
Figure 4: Example of Single-Family Dwelling 

    Dwelling, Two-Family. "Two-family dwelling" means a building designed for or occupied exclusively by two families living independently of one another. 
Figure 5: Example of Two-Family Dwelling 

    "Dwelling unit" means a structure or portion thereof designed and built as a complete, self-sufficient living facility for one family, including permanent provisions for sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. Units in a hotel or motel are not to be counted as dwelling units. 
    "Easement" means a grant by a property owner to allow use by the public, a corporation, or persons for specific purposes such as the construction, maintenance, and repair of utilities, drainageways and roadways. 
    "Egress" means an exit. 
    "Electric vehicle" means any vehicle that operates, either partially or exclusively, on electrical energy that is stored on the vehicle. 
    "Electric vehicle charging station" means a public or private parking space that is served by battery charging station equipment that has as its primary purpose the transfer of electric energy (by conductive or inductive means) to a battery or other energy storage device in an electric vehicle. Subject to the regulations described in Section 19.10.060(l). 
    "Elevation (distance)" means a vertical distance above or below a fixed reference level. 
    "Elevation (drawing)" means a fully dimensioned drawing of the front, rear, or side of a building or other structure showing features such as windows, doors, and the relationship of the grade to the floor level. 
    "Entertainment establishment" means an establishment that features the viewing of or participation in activities other than eating or drinking that become a primary function of the business more than ten times in a calendar [year]. Activities could include, but are not limited to, dancing, performances, or any event that draws a large number of people. Includes venues specifically designed for entertainment as well as establishments, such as restaurants or taverns, that serve a different function during most operating hours. 
    Entertainment Establishment, Adult. "Adult entertainment establishment" means an establishment providing nude dancing or other live or recorded performances that depict, describe or relate to specified sexual activities as defined herein. 
    Entertainment, Incidental. "Incidental entertainment" means the viewing of or participation in activities, other than eating or drinking, that is incidental to the primary function of the business. Incidental entertainment may include, but is not limited to, live or recorded background music. 
    "FAA" means the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States government. 
    "Facade" means the exterior wall of a building that is exposed to the public view or the wall viewed by persons not in the building. 
    "Family" means: 
(a)  An individual or two or more persons related by blood, marriage, domestic partnership, or adoption, and including not more than two boarders or lodgers, living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit, or 
(b)  A group of not more than four persons who need not be related by blood, marriage, or adoption, living together as a single housekeeping unit; plus, in either case; or 
(c)  A group of not more than eight persons with developmental disabilities who need not be related by blood, marriage, or adoption, living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit; plus in all cases, usual domestic servants or attendant support staff. In all cases, shall be located a minimum of one-eighth mile from any other similar housekeeping unit. 
    "Farmers' market" means a designated area where, on designated days and times, growers and producers may sell directly to the public, in accordance with the village regulations within Title 4, Taxes, Business Regulations, and Licenses, and Title 5, Health and Sanitation, of the Wheeling Municipal Code. 
    "Fence" means a structure which is a barrier and is used for purposes of privacy, protection and confinement. 
    "Flea market" means a building or open area in which stalls or sales areas are set aside, rented or otherwise provided and which are intended for use by various individuals to sell articles that are, but not necessarily limited to, homemade, homegrown, handcrafted, old, obsolete or antique and may include the selling of goods at retail by businesses or individuals who are generally engaged in retail trade. 
    "Floor area" for the purpose of determining the number of required off-street parking spaces and loading berths, means the sum of the gross horizontal areas of the several floors of the building, or portion thereof, which are: 
(a)  Devoted to the principal use of the premises, including accessory storage areas located within selling or working space such as counters, racks or closets; 
(b)  Any basement floor area devoted to retailing activities; and 
(c)  Floor area devoted to the production or processing of goods, or to business or professional offices. For this purpose, floor area shall not include: 
(1)  Floor area devoted primarily to storage purposes (except as otherwise noted herein), 
(2)  Floor area devoted to off-street parking or loading facilities, including aisles, ramps and maneuvering space, or 
(3)  Basement floor area other than area devoted to retailing activities, to the production or processing of goods, or to business or professional offices; 
(d)  Ground floor area, in the case of a single-family detached dwelling or a two-family dwelling, shall be measured from outside wall to outside wall and shall include utility areas, but should not include garage areas or utilities accessible only from the outside of the main dwelling area; 
(e)  Floor area shall be measured in multiple dwellings from inside wall to inside wall in all private living spaces, and shall not include public halls or utility areas other than closets and other similar storage spaces. 
    Front Lot Line. (See "Lot Line, Front"). 
    Front of Corner Lot. (See "Lot, Front of Corner"). 
    "Frontage" means all of the property abutting on a street measured along the street line. 
    "Funeral home" means an establishment providing services involving the care, preparation or disposition of human dead. This term includes mortuaries but not crematoriums. 
    "Furniture and appliance rental and leasing" means an establishment providing the rental or leasing of furniture, electronics, small appliances, major appliances or other household items. This term includes incidental storage and maintenance of such items. 
    Garage, Private. "Private garage" means an accessory building or a portion of the principal building used for vehicular storage only and subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  A private garage may house no more than one commercial vehicle; 
(b)  Space may be rented for not more than one vehicle other than those belonging to the owner(s) or occupant(s) of the principal building; 
(c)  The owner(s) or occupant(s) of the private garage may use it for personal vehicle service but may not use it as a place of employment for performing repairs on vehicles other than those belonging to the owner(s) or occupant(s) of the principal building. 
    Garage, Storage. "Storage garage" means a building or portion thereof, other than a private garage, used exclusively for parking or temporary storage of self-propelled vehicles. 
    "Garden supply or landscaping center" means an establishment providing the retail sale of plants and the sale or rental of garden and landscape materials and equipment. This term includes outdoor storage of plants, materials or equipment. 
    "Gas station" means an establishment providing retail sale of fuel for motor vehicles, but not motor vehicle maintenance or repair work on the premises. This term includes accessory retail sales, commonly referred to as a convenience store, but does not include a fast food restaurant. 
    General Office. (See "Office, General"). 
    General Retail Establishment. (See "Retail Establishment, General"). 
    Government Office. (See "Office, Government"). 
    Gross Acreage. (See "Acreage, Gross"). 
    "Ground transportation service" means an establishment providing the storage, maintenance or dispatching of: 
(a)  Public passenger vehicles; 
(b)  Vehicles licensed or otherwise regulated as human service vehicles by the state of Illinois and used for the transportation of elderly or handicapped persons; 
(c)  School buses; 
(d)  Tow trucks. 
    Ground Transportation Service, Dispatch Office. "Dispatch office of ground transportation service" means an establishment providing the dispatch office or administration office for a fleet of: 
(a)  Public passenger vehicles; 
(b)  Vehicles licensed or otherwise regulated as human service vehicles by the state of Illinois and used for the transportation of elderly or handicapped persons; 
(c)  School buses; 
(d)  Tow trucks. 
    This term does not include a small or large ground transportation service. 
    Ground Transportation Service, Large. "Large ground transportation service" means an establishment providing the storage, maintenance or dispatching of: 
(a)  Public passenger vehicles; 
(b)  Vehicles licensed or otherwise regulated as human service vehicles by the state of Illinois and used for the transportation of elderly or handicapped persons; 
(c)  School buses; 
(d)  Tow trucks. 
    Ground Transportation Service, Small. "Small ground transportation service" means an establishment providing the storage or dispatching of: 
(a)  Public passenger vehicles; 
(b)  Vehicles licensed or otherwise regulated as human service vehicles by the state of Illinois and used for the transportation of elderly or handicapped persons; 
(c)  School buses. 
    Vehicle storage is limited to operable and licensed vehicles only. This term applies to establishments with a maximum fleet size of six vehicles with a maximum length of twenty-four feet. 
    "Health clinic" means a group of associated offices for four or more physical or mental health care professionals who provide specialized diagnostic, testing, physical therapy or treatment services, including clerical and administrative services, to persons for periods of less than twenty-four hours. This term includes urgent care clinics and does not include a medical office or hospital. 
    "Health Club" means an establishment that allows members to use equipment and facilities for exercising and improving physical fitness. For facilities accommodating twelve or fewer persons, see "Recreational and Instructional Facility-Small." 
    Height, Building. "Building height" means the vertical distance measured from the average grade at the front wall of a building to: 
(a)  The highest point of the coping of a flat roof; 
(b)  The deck line of a mansard roof; 
(c)  The mean height level between eaves and ridge for gable, hip or gambrel roofs. 
    Home Day care. (See "Day care home"). 
    "Home improvement center" means an establishment providing the sale or rental of building supplies, construction equipment or home decorating fixtures and accessories. This term includes a lumber yard or a contractors' building supply business and may include outdoor storage or tool and equipment sales or rental. This term does not include an establishment devoted exclusively to retail sales of paint, wallpaper or hardware or activities classified under vehicle/equipment sales and services, including vehicle towing services. 
    "Home occupation" means any use of a dwelling unit or residence for the operation of any business or commercial, mercantile or industrial activity or enterprise. 
    "Hospital" means a state-licensed institution providing primary health services and medical, psychiatric, or surgical care to persons, primarily inpatients, suffering from illness, disease, injury, deformity and other physical or mental conditions, and, as an integral part of the institution, related accessory uses or facilities, including, but not limited to, laboratories, central service facilities for inpatient or outpatient treatment, as well as training, research and administrative services for patients and employees. Also included are health services and care, and services and functions which support health services and care, which are shared with other hospitals or other health care providers. 
    "Hotel" means an establishment in which at least five rooms or units or at least seventy percent of the accommodations whichever is greater, are regularly used or available for occupancy for periods of less than thirty days or are available for more than thirty days but are not the primary residences of the occupants. This classification includes, but is not limited to, a motor lodge, motel or extended-stay hotel. 
    "Household maintenance and repair service" means an establishment providing the repair or servicing of household goods, furniture, appliances or lawn and garden equipment. 
    "Impervious surface" means any hard surfaced man-made area that does not readily absorb or retain water including, but not limited to, building roofs, parking and driveway areas, graveled areas, sidewalks, bicycle paths, and any other paved or concrete surfaces. 
    "Indoor sales area," for the purpose of calculating outdoor display area, means and includes all areas that are open to the general public without a staff escort, for the display of merchandise and discussion of business matters related thereto. 
    "Junk" means used machinery, scrap, iron, steel, other ferrous and nonferrous metals, tools, implements or portions thereof, glass, plastic, building materials, furniture, or other waste that has been abandoned from its original use and may be used again in its present or in a new form. 
    "Landing area" means the area of the airport used for the landing, taking off or taxiing of aircraft. 
    "Landscaped island" means a landscaped area defined by a curb and surrounded by paving on all sides. 
    "Landscaped peninsula" means a landscaped area defined by a curb and surrounded by paving on at least two sides. 
    "Laundromat" means an establishment providing washing, drying or dry cleaning machines on the premises for rental use to the general public for laundering or dry cleaning purposes. 
    "Library" means a public, nonprofit facility in which literary, musical, artistic or reference materials such as, but not limited to, books, manuscripts, computers, recordings or films are kept for use by or loaning to patrons of the facility, but are not normally offered for sale except on an incidental basis. 
    Liquor Store, Packaged. "Packaged liquor store" means a retail store that sells alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption. Refers to multiple classes of liquor license, some of which are considered a principal use and some of which are considered an accessory use. 
    Loading, Off-Street. "Off-street loading" means an area or space that is accessible from a street, alley or way, whether in a building or on a lot, that is set aside for the exclusive use of trucks or other vehicles while loading or unloading merchandise or materials. 
    "Lodginghouse" means a building where lodging only is provided for compensation to more than two but not more than ten persons. 
    "Lot" means a parcel of land that is designated by its owner or developer at the time of applying for a zoning certificate (or, if no zoning certificate is required, at the time of applying for an occupancy certificate) as a tract, all of which is to be used, developed, or built upon as a unit under single ownership. So long as it satisfies the requirements of this Title, such lot may consist of: 
(a)  A single lot of record; or 
(b)  A combination of complete lots of record and portions of lots of record, or of portions of lots of record only. 
Figure 6: Types of Lots 

    "Lot area" means the area of a horizontal plane bounded by the front, side and rear lot lines, but not including any area occupied by the waters of a duly recorded lake, river or stream. 
    "Lot depth" means the mean horizontal distance between the front lot line and the rear lot line of a lot, measured within the lot boundary. 
Figure 7: Measuring Lot Depth 

    Lot, Corner. "Corner lot" means a lot abutting two or more streets at their intersection. The minimum rear yard requirement shall be applied to the yard opposite the front yard having the least width. 
    Lot, Double Frontage. "Double frontage lot" means a lot having frontage on two nonintersecting streets. 
    Lot, Front of Corner. "Front of corner lot" means the side of the lot having the least dimension. If both sides are the same dimensions, the owner shall, at the time he applies for a zoning permit under this Title, choose the street which the lot shall be deemed to front upon. 
    Lot Line, Front. "Front lot line" means the boundary of a lot which is along an existing or dedicated public street, or, where no public street exists, is along a public way. 
    Lot Line, Rear. "Real lot line" means the lot line opposite to and most distant from the front lot line. In the case of an irregular, triangular or gore-shaped lot, the rear lot line shall be an imaginary line, parallel to and farthest from the front lot line, not less than ten feet long and wholly within the lot. In cases where neither of these definitions are applicable, the zoning administrator shall designate the rear lot line. 
    Lot Line, Side. "Side lot line" means any boundary of a lot which is not a front lot line or a rear lot line. 
    "Lot of record" means a lot which is part of a subdivision, the plat of which has been recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds of Cook or Lake County, or a parcel of land, the deed to which was recorded in the office of such recorder prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Chapter. 
    "Lot size requirements" mean restrictions controlling the minimum area and minimum width of lots and the density of residential development in terms of dwelling units per acre. 
    Lot, Through. (See "Lot, Double Frontage"). 
    "Lot width" means the distance between side lot lines measured at the front building setback line along the chord. 
Figure 8: Lot Width along the Chord 

    Manufacturing, Heavy. "Heavy manufacturing" means an establishment engaged in manufacturing, assembly, fabrication, packaging or other industrial processing of products primarily from extracted or raw materials or the bulk storage and handling of such products and materials, where such activity involves the use or production of explosives, highly flammable liquids or gases, or toxic or hazardous materials or produces toxic, hazardous or noxious odors, fumes or dust. 
    Manufacturing, Light.
